ï»¿THE WATER OF [THE WONDROUS ISLES]1-the wondrous isles

THE FIRST PART : OF [THE HOUSE OF CAPTIVITY

CHAPTER]210-the house of captivity chapter I. CATCH AT [UTTERHAY

Whilom]2-utterhay whilom , as tells the tale , was [a walled cheaping - town hight Utterhay]211-a walled cheaping - town hight utterhay , which was builded in [a bight of [the land]213-the land]212-a bight of the land a little off [the great highway which went from over [the mountains]215-the mountains to [the sea]216-the sea]214-the great highway which went from over the mountains to the sea .

[The said town]217-the said town was hard on the borders of [a wood , which [men]219-men held to be mighty great , or maybe measureless]218-a wood , which men held to be mighty great , or maybe measureless [; though [few indeed]221-few indeed had entered [it]218-a wood , which men held to be mighty great , or maybe measureless , and [they]221-few indeed that had , brought back tales wild and confused thereof]220-; though few indeed had entered it , and they that had , brought back tales wild and confused thereof .

Therein was neither highway nor byway , nor wood - reeve nor way - warden ; never came chapman thence into [Utterhay]3-utterhay ; [no man of Utterhay]222-no man of utterhay was so poor or so bold that [he]222-no man of utterhay durst raise the hunt therein ; [no outlaw durst]223-no outlaw durst flee thereto ; [no man of God]224-no man of god had such trust in [the saints]225-the saints that [he]222-no man of utterhay durst build [him]222-no man of utterhay [a cell in [that wood]227-that wood]226-a cell in that wood .

For [all men]228-all men deemed it more than perilous ; and [some]229-some said that there walked the worst of the dead ; othersome that [the Goddesses of [the Gentiles]231-the gentiles]230-the goddesses of the gentiles haunted [there]232-there ; others again that it was [the faery rather]233-the faery rather , but [they]233-the faery rather full of malice and guile . But most commonly it was deemed that the devils swarmed amidst of [its]232-there thickets , and that wheresoever [a man]234-a man sought to , who was once environed by it , ever it was the Gate of Hell whereto [he]234-a man came . And [the said wood]235-the said wood was called [Evilshaw]97-evilshaw .

Nevertheless [the cheaping - town]236-the cheaping - town throve not ill ; for whatso evil things haunted [Evilshaw]97-evilshaw , never came [they]237-they into [Utterhay]3-utterhay in such guise that [men]219-men knew [them]237-they , neither wotted [they]219-men of any hurt that [they]219-men had of [the Devils of Evilshaw]97-evilshaw .

Now in [the said cheaping - town]239-the said cheaping - town , on a day , it was market and high noon , and in [the market - place]240-the market - place was much [people]241-people thronging ; and amidst of [them]241-people went [a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters by seeming , black - haired , hook - nosed and hawk - eyed , not so fair to look on as masterful and proud . [She]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters led a great grey ass betwixt two panniers , wherein [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters laded [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters marketings . But now [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters had done [[her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters chaffer]243-her chaffer , and was looking about [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters as if to note [the folk]244-the folk for [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters disport ; but when [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters came across [a child]245-a child , whether [it]245-a child were borne in arms or led by [[its]245-a child kinswomen]246-its kinswomen , or were going alone , as were [some]229-some , [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters seemed more heedful of [it]245-a child , and eyed [it]245-a child more closely than aught else .

So [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters strolled about till [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters was come to the outskirts of [the throng]248-the throng , and there [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters happened on [a babe of some two winters]249-a babe of some two winters , which was crawling about on [its]249-a babe of some two winters hands and knees , with scarce a rag upon its little body . [She]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters watched it , and looked whereto it was going , and saw [a woman]250-a woman sitting on a stone , with none anigh [her]250-a woman , [her]250-a woman face bowed over [her]250-a woman knees as if [she]250-a woman were weary or sorry . Unto [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters crept [the little one , murmuring and merry]251-the little one , murmuring and merry , and put [its]251-the little one , murmuring and merry arms about [the woman]252-the woman 's legs , and buried its face in the folds of [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters gown : [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters looked up therewith , and showed a face which had once been full fair , but was now grown bony and haggard , though [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters were scarce past five and twenty years . [She]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters took [the child]253-the child and strained it to [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters bosom , and kissed it , face and hands , and made it great cheer , but ever woefully . [The tall stranger]254-the tall stranger stood looking down on [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters , and noted how evilly [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters was clad , and how [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters seemed to have nought to do with [that throng of [thriving cheapeners]256-thriving cheapeners]255-that throng of thriving cheapeners , and [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters smiled somewhat sourly .

At last [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters spake , and [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters voice was not so harsh as might have been looked for from [her]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters face : [Dame]98-dame , [she]242-a woman , tall , and strong of aspect , of some thirty winters said , [thou]257-thee seemest to be less busy than [most folk]258-most folk [here]259-here ; might [I]0-i crave of [thee]257-thee to tell [an alien who has but some hour to dwell in [this good town where [she]260-an alien who has but some hour to dwell in this good town where she may find her a chamber wherein to rest and eat a morsel , and be untroubled of ribalds and ill company may find [her]260-an alien who has but some hour to dwell in this good town where she may find her a chamber wherein to rest and eat a morsel , and be untroubled of ribalds and ill company a chamber wherein to rest and eat a morsel , and be untroubled of ribalds and ill company]261-this good town where she may find her a chamber wherein to rest and eat a morsel , and be untroubled of ribalds and ill company]260-an alien who has but some hour to dwell in this good town where she may find her a chamber wherein to rest and eat a morsel , and be untroubled of ribalds and ill company ? Said [the poor - wife]262-the poor - wife : Short shall be [my]0-i tale ; [I]0-i am over poor to know of [hostelries]263-hostelries and [ale - houses]264-ale - houses that [I]0-i may tell [thee]257-thee aught thereof . Said [the other]265-the other : Maybe [some neighbour of thine]266-some neighbour of thine would take [me]0-i in for [thy]257-thee sake ? Said [the mother]267-the mother : What neighbours have [I]0-i since [[my]0-i man]268-my man died ; and [I]0-i dying of hunger , and in [this town]269-this town of thrift and abundance ?

[The leader of the ass]270-the leader of the ass was silent a while , then [she]270-the leader of the ass said : [Poor woman]271-poor woman ! [I]0-i begin to have pity on [thee]271-poor woman ; and [I]0-i tell [thee]271-poor woman that luck hath come to [thee]271-poor woman to - day .

Now [the poor - wife]262-the poor - wife had stood up with the babe in [her]262-the poor - wife arms and was turning to go [her]262-the poor - wife ways ; but [the alien]273-the alien put forth a hand to [her]262-the poor - wife , and said : Stand a while and hearken good tidings . And [she]270-the leader of the ass put [her]270-the leader of the ass hand to [her]270-the leader of the ass girdle - pouch , and drew thereout a good golden piece , [a noble]274-a noble , and said : When [I]0-i am sitting down in [thine house]275-thine house [thou]276-thou wilt have earned this , and when [I]0-i take [my]0-i soles out thereof there will be three more of like countenance , if [I]0-i be content with [thee]276-thou meanwhile .

[The woman]252-the woman looked on the gold , and tears came into [her]252-the woman eyes ; but [she]270-the leader of the ass laughed and said : [Houseroom]99-houseroom may [I]0-i give [thee]276-thou for an hour truly , and therewithal water of the well , and a mouse 's meal of bread . If [thou]276-thou deem that worth [three nobles]278-three nobles , how may [I]0-i say [thee]276-thou nay , when [they]278-three nobles may save the life of [[my]0-i little one]279-my little one . But what else wouldst [thou]276-thou of [me]0-i ? Little enough , said [the alien]273-the alien ; so lead [me]0-i straight to [thine house]275-thine house .

So went [they]282-they forth of [the market - place]240-the market - place , and [the woman]252-the woman led [them]282-they , [the alien]273-the alien and [the ass]286-the ass , out of [the street]287-the street through the west gate of [Utterhay]3-utterhay , that , to wit , which looked on [Evilshaw]97-evilshaw , and so into [a scattering street]288-a scattering street without the wall , the end of which neared a corner of the wood aforesaid : [the houses there]289-the houses there were nought so evil of fashion , but whereas [they]289-the houses there were so nigh unto [the Devil 's Park]290-the devil 's park , [rich men]291-rich men might no longer away with [them]289-the houses there , and [they]289-the houses there were become wares for [poor folk]292-poor folk .

Now [the townswoman]293-the townswoman laid [her]293-the townswoman hand on the latch of the door that was [hers]293-the townswoman , and threw the door open ; then [she]293-the townswoman put forth [her]293-the townswoman palm to the other , and said : Wilt [thou]294-thou give [me]0-i the first gold now , since rest is made sure for [thee]294-thou , as long as [thou]294-thou wilt ? [The ass - leader]295-the ass - leader put it into [her]295-the ass - leader hand , and [she]295-the ass - leader took it and laid it on [[her]295-the ass - leader baby]296-her baby 's cheek , and then kissed both gold and [child]297-child together ; then [she]293-the townswoman turned to [the alien]273-the alien and said : As for [thy]294-thou way - beast , [I]0-i have nought for [him]296-her baby , neither hay nor corn : [thou]294-thou [wert]299-wert best to leave [him]296-her baby in [the street]287-the street . [The stranger]301-the stranger nodded a yeasay , and [the three]302-the three went in together , [the mother]267-the mother , [the child]253-the child , and [the alien]273-the alien .

Not right small was [the chamber]306-the chamber ; but there was little therein ; one stool to wit , a yew - chair , a little table , and a coffer : there was no fire on the hearth , nought save white ashes of small wood ; but it was [June]100-june , so that was of no account .

[The guest]307-the guest sat down in the yew - chair , and [the poor - wife]262-the poor - wife laid [[her]262-the poor - wife child]309-her child down gently on the floor and came and stood before [the stranger]301-the stranger , as if abiding [her]262-the poor - wife bidding .

Spake [the alien]273-the alien : Nought so uncomely or strait is [[thy]262-the poor - wife chamber]312-thy chamber ; and [[thy]262-the poor - wife child]313-thy child , which [I]0-i see is [a woman]250-a woman , and therefore belike shall long abide with [thee]262-the poor - wife , is lovely of shape , and fair of flesh . Now also [thou]262-the poor - wife shalt have better days , as [I]0-i deem , and [I]0-i pray them on thine head .

[She]0-i spake in a kind wheedling voice , and [the poor - wife]262-the poor - wife 's face grew softer , and presently tears fell down on to the table from [her]0-i , but [she]0-i spake no word . [The guest]307-the guest now drew forth , [not three nobles]317-not three nobles , but four , and laid [them]317-not three nobles on the table , and said : Lo , [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend , the three nobles which [I]0-i behight [thee]318-my friend ! now are [they]317-not three nobles thine ; but this other [thou]262-the poor - wife shalt take and spend for [me]0-i . Go up into [the town]319-the town , and buy for [me]0-i white bread of the best ; and right good flesh , or poulaine if it may be , already cooked and dight ; and , withal , the best wine that [thou]262-the poor - wife mayst get , and sweetmeats for [[thy]262-the poor - wife baby]320-thy baby ; and when [thou]262-the poor - wife comest back , [we]321-we will sit together and dine here . And thereafter , when [we]321-we be full of meat and drink , [we]321-we shall devise something more for [thy]262-the poor - wife good speed .

[The woman]252-the woman knelt before [her]252-the woman weeping , but might speak no word because of the fullness of [her]252-the woman heart . [She]252-the woman kissed [the guest]307-the guest 's hands , and took the money , and then arose and caught up [[her]252-the woman child]309-her child , and kissed [her]252-the woman bare flesh eagerly many times , and then hastened out of [the house]325-the house and up [the street]287-the street and through the gate ; and [the guest]307-the guest sat hearkening to the sound of [her]252-the woman footsteps till it died out , and there was nought to be heard save the far - off murmur of [the market]328-the market , and the chirrup of [the little one on the floor]329-the little one on the floor .

Then arose [the guest]307-the guest and took up [the child]253-the child from the floor , who kicked and screamed , and craved [[her]253-the child mother]332-her mother as [her]253-the child broken speech might ; but [the alien]273-the alien spake softly to [her]332-her mother , and said : Hush , [dear one]334-dear one , and be good , and [we]335-we will go and find [her]332-her mother ; and [she]273-the alien gave [her]253-the child therewith a sugar - plum from out of [her]273-the alien scrip . Then [she]273-the alien came out of doors , and spake sweetly to [the little one]336-the little one : See now this pretty way - beast . [We]335-we will ride merrily on [him]336-the little one to find [[thy]336-the little one mother]337-thy mother .

Then [she]273-the alien laid [the child]253-the child in the pannier with a soft cushion under , and a silk cloth over [her]253-the child , so that [she]253-the child lay there happily . Then [she]273-the alien took [her]273-the alien ass 's rein and went [her]273-the alien ways over the waste toward [Evilshaw]4-evilshaw ; for , as [ye]339-ye may deem , where [the houses]340-the houses and [the street]287-the street ended , the beaten way ended also .

Quietly and speedily [she]273-the alien went , and met but [three men on the way]342-three men on the way ; and when these saw [her]273-the alien , and that [she]273-the alien was making for [Evilshaw]97-evilshaw , [they]342-three men on the way turned [their]342-three men on the way heads away , [each one]343-each one , and blessed [themselves]342-three men on the way , and went past swiftly . [Not one]344-not one sought to stay [her]273-the alien , or held any converse with [her]273-the alien , and no foot [she]273-the alien heard following after [her]273-the alien . So in scarce more than the saying of a low mass [she]273-the alien was in amongst the trees , with [her]273-the alien ass and [her]273-the alien wares and [her]273-the alien prey .

No stay [she]273-the alien made [there]232-there , but held forward at [her]273-the alien best before the night should fall upon [her]273-the alien . And whatsoever might be told concerning the creatures that [other folk]346-other folk had met in [Evilshaw]4-evilshaw , of [her]273-the alien it must needs be said that therein [she]273-the alien happened on nought worser than [herself]273-the alien .

CHAPTER II . NOW SHALL BE TOLD OF THE HOUSE BY [THE WATER - SIDE]5-the water - side

Four days [they]347-they wended [the wood]348-the wood , and nought befell to tell of . [The witch - wife]349-the witch - wife for even such was [she]349-the witch - wife fed [the stolen child]350-the stolen child well and duly , and whiles caressed [her]350-the stolen child and spake sweetly unto [her]350-the stolen child ; whiles also [she]349-the witch - wife would take [her]350-the stolen child out of the pannier , and set [her]350-the stolen child on the ass 's back and hold [her]350-the stolen child thereon heedfully ; or , otherwhiles , when [they]347-they came upon [grassy and flowery places]351-grassy and flowery places , [she]349-the witch - wife would set [her]350-the stolen child down on the ground and let [her]350-the stolen child roam about , and pluck the flowers and the strawberries . And whoso might be sorry , [the child]253-the child was glad , so many things new and fair as [she]253-the child came upon .

At last , when the fifth day was waning , and [they]347-they had been a long while wending a wood set thick with trees , it began to grow grey betwixt the distant boles , and then from grey to white , and it was as if a new world of light lay before [them]347-they . Thitherward went [they]347-they , and in a little , and before the sun was set , came [they]347-they to [the shore of [a great water]354-a great water]353-the shore of a great water , and thence was [no more land]355-no more land to be seen before [them]347-they than if it had been [the main sea]356-the main sea [itself]356-the main sea , though this was [a sweet water]357-a sweet water . Albeit , less than a half mile from [the shore]358-the shore lay two eyots , as [it]359-it might have been on [the salt sea]360-the salt sea ; but one of these sat low down on [the water]361-the water , and was green and well bushed , but the other , which lay east of [it]359-it , and was nigher to [the shore]358-the shore , was high , rocky , and barren .

Now the ending of [the wood]348-the wood left a fair green plain betwixt [it]348-the wood and [the water]361-the water , whiles more than a furlong across , whiles much less ; and whiles the trees came down close to [the water - side]365-the water - side . But [the place whereas [they]347-they came from out [the wood]348-the wood]366-the place whereas they came from out the wood was of the widest , and there [it]368-it was a broad bight of greensward of the fashion of the moon seven nights old , and a close hedge of thicket there was at the back of [it]368-it ; and [the lake]369-the lake lay south , and [the wood]348-the wood north . Some deal of [this greensward]371-this greensward was broken by closes of [acre - land]372-acre - land , and the tall green wheat stood blossoming therein ; but the most was [sweet meadow]373-sweet meadow , and there as now was a gallant flock of goats feeding down it ; five kine withal , and a tethered bull . Through the widest of [this meadow]374-this meadow ran a clear stream winding down to [the lake]369-the lake , and on [a little knoll beside a lap of [the said stream]377-the said stream]376-a little knoll beside a lap of the said stream , two bow - shots from [the water]361-the water , was [a knoll]379-a knoll , whereon stood , amidst of [a potherb garden]380-a potherb garden , [a little house strongly framed of timber]381-a little house strongly framed of timber . Before [it]368-it [the steep bank of the lake]382-the steep bank of the lake broke down into [a slowly - shelving beach , whose honey - coloured sand thrust up a tongue in amongst the grass of [the mead]384-the mead]383-a slowly - shelving beach , whose honey - coloured sand thrust up a tongue in amongst the grass of the mead .

Went [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife straight to the door of [the said house]386-the said house as if [she]349-the witch - wife were at [home]387-home , as was sooth indeed . [She]349-the witch - wife threw the door open , and unladed the ass of all [his]388-his wares , and [first of [the youngling]390-the youngling , whom [she]349-the witch - wife shook awake , and bore into [the house]325-the house , and laid safely on the floor of [the chamber]306-the chamber]389-first of the youngling , whom she shook awake , and bore into the house , and laid safely on the floor of the chamber ; nor did [she]349-the witch - wife wait on [her]349-the witch - wife wailing , but set about what was to be done to kindle fire , and milk a she - goat , and get meat upon the board . That did [she]349-the witch - wife , and fed both [herself]349-the witch - wife and [the child]253-the child plenteously : neither did [she]349-the witch - wife stint [her]349-the witch - wife of meat ever , from that time forward , however else [she]349-the witch - wife dealt with [her]349-the witch - wife .

CHAPTER III . OF SKIN - CHANGING

One thing must here be told : Whenas [the said dame]394-the said dame stood forth clad amidst of [the chamber]306-the chamber the next morning , [the child]253-the child ran up to [her]394-the said dame to greet [her]394-the said dame or what not , but straightway when [she]253-the child saw [her]394-the said dame close , drew aback , and stood gasping with affright ; for verily [she]253-the child deemed this was nowise [she]394-the said dame who had brought [her]394-the said dame last night into [the fair chamber]397-the fair chamber , and given bread and milk to [her]394-the said dame and put [her]394-the said dame to bed , but [someone else]398-someone else . For [this one]399-this one had not dark hair , and hooked nose , and eyen hawk- bright ; stark and tall was [she]399-this one indeed , as [that other one]400-that other one , and by seeming of the same - like age ; but there came to an end all [her]399-this one likeness to [last night 's housewife]401-last night 's housewife . [This one]399-this one had golden - red hair flowing down from [her]399-this one head ; eyes of hazel colour , long and not well- opened , but narrow and sly . High of cheekbones [she]399-this one was , long - chinned and thin - lipped ; [her]399-this one skin was fine and white , but without ruddiness ; flat - breasted [she]399-this one was , and narrow - hipped .

Now [she]399-this one laughed at [the babe]403-the babe 's terror , and said , but in [her]399-this one old voice at least : [Thou]403-the babe foolish little beast ! [I]0-i know what scares [thee]403-the babe , to wit , that [thou]403-the babe deemest [me]0-i changed : now [I]0-i tell [thee]403-the babe that [I]0-i am [the one who brought [thee]403-the babe here last night]404-the one who brought thee here last night , and fed [thee]403-the babe ; neither is [my]0-i changing a matter of thine , since at least [I]0-i am the one who shall keep [thee]403-the babe from hunger and weather henceforward ; that is enough for [thee]403-the babe to know as now . Now [thou]403-the babe hast to eat and sleep and play and cry out , that [thou]403-the babe mayest the sooner wax , and grow into the doing of [my]0-i will .

Therewith [she]399-this one led [her]403-the babe out into the sunshine , and tethered [her]403-the babe to an ash sapling which grew anigh the door , that [the child]253-the child might be safe the while [she]399-this one went about [her]399-this one work in acre and mead .

But as for that matter of changing of aspect , [the maiden]406-the maiden came to know thereafter that [the witch]407-the witch durst not go into [the wood]348-the wood in the same skin as that which [she]399-this one wore at [home]387-home , wherefore [she]399-this one had changed it for the journey to [Utterhay]3-utterhay , and changed back again in the night - tide before [she]399-this one arose .

CHAPTER IV . OF THE WAXING OF THE STOLEN CHILD

This little one , who is henceforth called [Birdalone]101-birdalone , though [the witch]407-the witch called [her]101-birdalone but seldom so , nor indeed by any name , dwelt there betwixt [the water]361-the water and [the wood]348-the wood , and saw none save [the said witch - wife , who , as aforesaid , fed [her]403-the babe well]413-the said witch - wife , who , as aforesaid , fed her well , but scarce meddled with [her]403-the babe else for a long while ; so [she]403-the babe wandered well - nigh as [she]403-the babe had will , and much in [the wood]348-the wood ; for [she]403-the babe had no fear thereof , nor indeed of aught else save of [the dame]415-the dame . [She]403-the babe learned of the ways and the wo nt of all the creatures round about [her]403-the babe , and the very grass and flowers were [friends]416-friends to [her]403-the babe , and [she]403-the babe made tales of them in [her]403-the babe mind ; and the wild things feared [her]403-the babe in no wise , and the fowl would come to [her]403-the babe hand , and play with [her]403-the babe and love [her]403-the babe . [A lovely child]417-a lovely child [she]403-the babe was , rosy and strong , and as merry as the birds on the bough ; and had [she]403-the babe trouble , for whiles [she]403-the babe came across some ugly mood of [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife , [she]403-the babe bore it all as lightly as they .

Wore the years thus , till now [she]403-the babe was grown tall and thin , and had seen twelve winters , and was far stronger and handier than at first sight [she]403-the babe looked to be . That found [[her]403-the babe mistress]419-her mistress , and would not forego the using of [her]403-the babe deftness . For indeed [the maiden]406-the maiden knew all matters of wood and field full well , and somewhat of [the water]361-the water also though [no boat]422-no boat had [she]403-the babe ever seen [there]232-there , for [she]403-the babe learned [herself]403-the babe swimming , as the ducks do belike .

But now [[her]403-the babe mistress]419-her mistress would learn [her]403-the babe swinking , and hard was the lesson , for with twiggen rods and switches was [she]403-the babe learned , and was somewhat stubborn with [this woman]425-this woman , who [she]403-the babe deemed loved [her]403-the babe not ; and , however it were , there began to grow in [her]403-the babe an inkling that all was not well with [the dame]415-the dame , and howsoever [she]415-the dame might fear [her]415-the dame , [she]415-the dame trusted [her]415-the dame not , nor worshipped [her]415-the dame ; otherwise [she]403-the babe had learned [her]403-the babe lesson speedily ; for [she]403-the babe was not slack nor a sluggard , and hated not the toil , even when it pained and wearied [her]403-the babe , but against the anger and malice [she]403-the babe hardened [her]403-the babe heart .

It is to be said , that though there [she]403-the babe dwelt alone with [the witch- wife]427-the witch- wife , [she]403-the babe had somehow got to know that [[they]428-they two]429-they two were not alone in [the world]430-the world , and [she]403-the babe knew of male and female , and young and old . [Thereof]102-thereof doubtless [the witch]407-the witch [herself]407-the witch had learned [her]403-the babe , would [she]407-the witch , would [she]407-the witch not ; for though [she]407-the witch were mostly few - spoken , yet whiles the tongue of [her]407-the witch would loosen , and [she]407-the witch would tell Birdalone tales of [men]219-men and [women]433-women , and [kings]434-kings and [warriors and thralls]435-warriors and thralls , and [the folk of [the world]430-the world beyond [them]428-they]436-the folk of the world beyond them , if it were but to scare [the child]253-the child . Yea , and when [she]403-the babe rated [Birdalone]101-birdalone , or girded at [her]101-birdalone , words would come forth which [the maiden]406-the maiden stored up , and by laying two and two together gat wisdom howso it were . Moreover , [she]101-birdalone was of the race of [Adam]103-adam , and [her]101-birdalone heart conceived of diverse matters from [[her]101-birdalone mother]332-her mother 's milk and [[her]101-birdalone father]441-her father 's blood , and [her]101-birdalone heart and [her]101-birdalone mind grew up along with [her]101-birdalone body . Herein also was [she]101-birdalone wise , to wit , how to give wrath the go - by , so that [she]101-birdalone oft found [the wood]348-the wood a better home than [the house]325-the house : for now [she]101-birdalone knew that [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife would enter [it]348-the wood never ; wherefore [she]101-birdalone loved it much , and haunted [it]348-the wood daily if [she]101-birdalone might .

Amidst all this [she]101-birdalone lived not unmerrily ; for [the earth]445-the earth was [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend , and solaced [her]101-birdalone when [she]101-birdalone had suffered aught : withal [she]101-birdalone was soon grown hardy as well as strong ; and evil [she]101-birdalone could thole , nor let it burden [her]101-birdalone with misery .

CHAPTER V. OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone , AND HOW [SHE]101-birdalone IS GROWN INTO MAIDENHOOD

Wear the years and the years amidst such days as these , and now is [Birdalone]101-birdalone grown [a dear maiden of seventeen summers]447-a dear maiden of seventeen summers ; and yet was [her]101-birdalone life not unhappy ; though the mirth of [her]101-birdalone childhood was somewhat chastened in [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone walked [the earth]445-the earth soberly and measurely , as though deep thoughts were ever in [her]101-birdalone head : though , forsooth , it is not all so sure that [her]101-birdalone serious face and solemn eyes were but a part of the beauty which was growing with the coming forth of childhood into youth and maidenhood . But this at least is sure , that about this time those forebodings which had shown [her]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone had no call to love and honour [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress took clearer shape , and became a burden on [her]101-birdalone , which [she]101-birdalone might never wholly shake off . For this [she]101-birdalone saw , that [she]101-birdalone was not [her]101-birdalone own , but [a chattel]450-a chattel and a tool of one who not only used [her]101-birdalone as [a thrall in the passing day]451-a thrall in the passing day , but had it in [her]101-birdalone mind to make of [her]101-birdalone a thing accursed like to [herself]101-birdalone , and to bait the trap with [her]101-birdalone for the taking of [the sons of Adam]452-the sons of adam . Forsooth [she]101-birdalone saw , though dimly , that [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress was indeed wicked , and that in the bonds of that wickedness was [she]101-birdalone bound .

One thing , moreover , had [she]101-birdalone noted now this long while , that once and again , it might be once every two moons , [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife would arise in the dead of night and go forth from [the house]325-the house , and be away for a day , or two or three , or whiles more , and come back again weary and fordone ; but never said [she]101-birdalone any word to [Birdalone]101-birdalone hereof . Yet oft when [she]101-birdalone arose to go this errand , before [she]101-birdalone left [the chamber]306-the chamber would [she]101-birdalone come to [[Birdalone]101-birdalone 's truckle - bed]457-birdalone 's truckle - bed , and stand over [her]101-birdalone to note if [she]101-birdalone were asleep or not ; and ever at such times did [Birdalone]101-birdalone feign slumber amidst of sickening dread . Forsooth in these latter days it whiles entered [the maiden]406-the maiden 's head that when [the dame]415-the dame was gone [she]406-the maiden would rise and follow [her]415-the dame and see whither [she]415-the dame went , and what [she]415-the dame did ; but terror constrained [her]415-the dame that [she]415-the dame went not .

Now from amidst all these imaginings arose a hope in [her]415-the dame that [she]415-the dame might one day escape from [[her]415-the dame thralldom]460-her thralldom : and whiles , when [she]415-the dame was lonely and safe in [the wood]348-the wood , to this hope [she]415-the dame yielded [herself]415-the dame ; but thereof came such tumult of [her]415-the dame soul for joy of the hope , that [she]415-the dame might not master [her]415-the dame passion ; [the earth]445-the earth would seem to rise beneath [her]415-the dame , and [the woods]463-the woods to whirl about before [her]415-the dame eyes , so that [she]415-the dame might not keep [her]415-the dame feet , but would sink adown to [earth]464-earth , and lie there weeping . Then most oft would come the cold fit after the hot , and the terror would take [her]415-the dame that some day [the witch]407-the witch would surprise the joy of that hope in [her]415-the dame eyes , and would know what it meant , or that some light word might bewray [her]415-the dame ; and therewith came imaginings of what would then befall [her]415-the dame , nor were that hard to picture , and it would come before [her]415-the dame over and over again till [she]415-the dame became weary and worn out therewith .

But though [they]466-they abode ever with [her]415-the dame , these troubling thoughts pricked not so oft at the keenest , but were as the dull ache of little import that comes after pain overcome : for in sooth busy and toilsome days did [she]415-the dame wear , which irked [her]415-the dame in nowise , since it eased [her]415-the dame of the torment of those hopes and fears aforesaid , and brought [her]415-the dame sound sleep and sweet awaking . The kine and the goats must [she]415-the dame milk , and plough and sow and reap [the acre - land]467-the acre - land according to the seasons , and lead the beasts to [the woodland pastures]468-the woodland pastures when [their]466-they own were flooded or burned ; [she]415-the dame must gather the fruits of [the orchard]469-the orchard , and the hazel nuts up [the woodlands]470-the woodlands , and beat the walnut - trees in September . [She]415-the dame must make the butter and the cheese , grind the wheat in the quern , make and bake the bread , and in all ways earn [her]415-the dame livelihood hard enough . Moreover , [the bowman]471-the bowman 's craft had [she]415-the dame learned , and at [the dame]415-the dame 's bidding must fare alone into [the wood]348-the wood now and again to slay big deer and little , and win venison : but neither did that irk [her]415-the dame at all , for rest and peace were in [the woods]463-the woods for [her]415-the dame .

True it is , that as [she]415-the dame wended thicket or glade or wood - lawn , [she]415-the dame would at whiles grow timorous , and tread light and heedfully , lest rustling leaves or crackling stick should arouse [some strange creature in human shape]475-some strange creature in human shape , devil , or god now damned , or [woman of the faery]476-woman of the faery . But if such were there , either [they]475-some strange creature in human shape were wise and would not be seen , or kind and had no will to scare [the simple maiden]477-the simple maiden ; or else maybe there were none such in those days . Anyhow , nought evil came to [her]415-the dame out of Evilshaw .

CHAPTER VI . HEREIN IS TOLD OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone 'S RAIMENT[101-birdalone]

Lank and long is [Birdalone]101-birdalone the sweet , with legs that come forth bare and browned from under [her]101-birdalone scant grey coat and scantier smock beneath , which was all [her]101-birdalone raiment save when the time was bitter , and then , forsooth , it was a cloak of goat - skin that eked [her]101-birdalone attire : for [the dame]415-the dame heeded little the clothing of [her]101-birdalone ; nor did [Birdalone]101-birdalone give so much heed thereto that [she]101-birdalone cared to risk the anger of [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress by asking [her]419-her mistress for aught .

But on a day of this same spring , when [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife was of sweeter temper than [her]349-the witch - wife wo nt was , and the day was very warm and kindly , though it was but one of the last of February days , [Birdalone]101-birdalone , blushing and shamefaced , craved timidly some more womanly attire . But [the dame]415-the dame turned gruffly on [her]101-birdalone and said : Tush , [child]297-child ! what needeth it ? here be [no men]483-no men to behold [thee]297-child . [I]0-i shall see to it , that when due time comes [thou]297-child shalt be whitened and sleeked to the very utmost . But look [thou]297-child ! [thou]297-child art [a handy wench]484-a handy wench ; take the deer - skin that hangs up yonder and make [thee]297-child brogues for [thy]297-child feet , if so [thou]297-child wilt .

Even so did [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and shaped the skin to [her]101-birdalone feet ; but as [she]101-birdalone was sewing them a fancy came into [her]101-birdalone head ; for [she]101-birdalone had just come across some threads of silk of divers colours ; so [she]101-birdalone took them and [her]101-birdalone shoon and [her]101-birdalone needle up into the wood , and there sat down happily under a great spreading oak which much [she]101-birdalone haunted , and fell to broidering the kindly deer - skin . And [she]101-birdalone got to be long about it , and came back to it the next day and the next , and many days , whenso [her]101-birdalone servitude would suffer it , and yet the shoon were scarce done .

So on a morning [the dame]415-the dame looked on [her]101-birdalone feet as [she]101-birdalone moved about [the chamber]306-the chamber , and cried out at [her]101-birdalone : What ! art [thou]297-child barefoot as an hen yet ? Hast [thou]297-child spoilt [the good deer - skin]487-the good deer - skin and art yet but shoeless ? Nay , [our lady]488-our lady , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , but the shoon are not altogether done . Show them to [me]0-i , said [the dame]415-the dame .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone went to [her]101-birdalone little coffer to fetch them , and brought them somewhat timorously , for [she]101-birdalone knew not how [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress would take [her]101-birdalone working on them so long , if perchance [she]419-her mistress would blame [her]101-birdalone , or it might be chastise [her]101-birdalone , for even in those days [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife 's hand was whiles raised against [her]101-birdalone . But now when [the dame]415-the dame took the shoes and looked on them , and saw how there were oak - leaves done into them , and flowers , and coneys , and squirrels , [she]415-the dame but smiled somewhat grimly on [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and said : Well , belike [thou]297-child art [a fool]493-a fool to waste [thy]297-child time and [mine]0-i in such toys ; and to give [thee]297-child [thy]297-child due would be to give [thee]297-child stripes . But [thou]297-child doest herein after the nature of [earthly women]494-earthly women , to adorn [thy]297-child body , whatsoever else is toward . And well is that , since [I]0-i would have [thee]297-child [a woman so soon as may be]495-a woman so soon as may be ; and [I]0-i will help [thy]297-child mind for finery , since [thou]297-child art so deft with [thy]297-child needle .

Therewith [she]415-the dame went to the big coffer and drew forth thence a piece of fine green cloth , and another of fine linen , and said to [Birdalone]101-birdalone : This mayest [thou]297-child take , and make [thee]297-child a gown thereof and a new smock , and make them if [thou]297-child wilt as gay as [thy]297-child new shoon are gotten to be ; and here is wherewithal . And therewith [she]415-the dame gave [her]415-the dame two handfuls of silken threads and gold , and said : Now [I]0-i suppose that [I]0-i must do the more part of [thy]297-child work , while [thou]297-child art making [thee]297-child these gaudy garments . But maybe [someone]496-someone may be coming this way ere long , who will deem the bird the finer for [her]415-the dame fine feathers . Now depart from [me]0-i ; for [I]0-i would both work for [thee]297-child and [me]0-i , and ponder weighty matters .

Who was glad now but [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; [she]101-birdalone grew red with new pleasure , and knelt down and kissed [the witch]407-the witch 's hand , and then went [her]101-birdalone ways to [the wood]348-the wood with [her]101-birdalone precious lading , and wrought there under [her]101-birdalone oak - tree day after day , and all days , either there , or in [the house]325-the house when the weather was foul . That was in the middle of March , when all birds were singing , and the young leaves showing on the hawthorns , so that there were pale green clouds , as it were , betwixt the great grey boles of oak and sweet - chestnut ; and by [the lake]369-the lake the meadow - saffron new - thrust - up was opening its blossom ; and [March]104-march wore and April , and still [she]101-birdalone was at work happily when now it was later May , and the hare - bells were in full bloom down the bent before [her]101-birdalone .

All this while [the witch]407-the witch had meddled little with [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and had bidden [her]101-birdalone to no work afield or in the stead which was anywise grievous , but had done all [herself]101-birdalone ; yet was [she]407-the witch few - spoken with [her]101-birdalone , and would oft behold [her]101-birdalone gloomily . And one evening when [Birdalone]101-birdalone came in from [the wood]348-the wood , [the witch]407-the witch came close up to [her]101-birdalone and stared [her]101-birdalone in the face , and said suddenly : Is it in thine heart to flee away from [me]0-i and leave [me]0-i ?

A sharp pang of fear shot through [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's heart at that word , and [she]101-birdalone turned very red , and then pale to the lips , but stammered out : No , [lady]504-lady , it is not in [mine]101-birdalone heart . [The dame]415-the dame looked grimly on [her]101-birdalone and said : If [thou]506-thou try it and fail , [thou]506-thou shalt rue it once only , to wit , lifelong ; and [thou]506-thou canst but fail . [She]415-the dame was silent a while , and then spake in a milder voice : Be content here a while with [me]0-i , and thereafter [thou]506-thou shalt be more content , and that before long .

[She]415-the dame said no more at that time ; but [her]415-the dame word clave to [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's heart , and for some time thereafter [she]415-the dame was sorely oppressed with a burden of fear , and knew not how to hold [herself]415-the dame before [the witch- wife]427-the witch- wife . But the days wore , and nought betid , and [the maiden]406-the maiden 's heart grew lighter , and still [she]415-the dame wrought on at [her]415-the dame gown and [her]415-the dame smock , and it was well - nigh done . [She]415-the dame had broidered the said gown with roses and lilies , and a tall tree springing up from amidmost the hem of the skirt , and a hart on either side thereof , face to face of each other . And the smock [she]415-the dame had sewn daintily at the hems and the bosom with fair knots and buds . It was now past the middle of June , hot and bright weather .

CHAPTER VII . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone HATH AN ADVENTURE IN [THE WOOD]6-the wood

On a day [she]101-birdalone went to [the wood]348-the wood , and sat down under [her]101-birdalone oak - tree , and it was far and far out of sight of anyone standing in [the meadow]510-the meadow by [the lake]369-the lake ; and in [the wood]348-the wood [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked to see nought at all save the rabbits and squirrels , who were , forsooth , familiar enough with [her]101-birdalone , and fearless , so that [they]513-they would come to [her]101-birdalone hand and sport with [her]101-birdalone when [she]101-birdalone hailed [them]513-they . Wherefore , as the day was exceeding hot , [she]101-birdalone put off from [her]101-birdalone [her]101-birdalone simple raiment , that [she]101-birdalone might feel all the pleasure of the cool shadow and what air was stirring , and the kindness of the greensward upon [her]101-birdalone very body . So [she]101-birdalone sat sewing , covered but by a lap of the green gown which [her]101-birdalone needle was painting .

But as [she]101-birdalone sat there intent on [her]101-birdalone work , and [her]101-birdalone head bent over it , and it was now at the point of high noon , [she]101-birdalone heard as if some creature were going anigh to [her]101-birdalone ; [she]101-birdalone heeded it not , deeming that it would be but [some wandering hind]514-some wandering hind . But even therewith [she]101-birdalone heard [one]515-one say [her]101-birdalone name in a soft voice , and [she]101-birdalone leapt up trembling , deeming at first that it would be [the witch]407-the witch come to fetch [her]101-birdalone : but yet more scared [she]101-birdalone was , when [she]101-birdalone saw standing before [her]101-birdalone the shape of [a young woman as naked as [herself]101-birdalone]517-a young woman as naked as herself , save that [she]101-birdalone had an oak wreath round about [her]101-birdalone loins .

[The new - comer]518-the new - comer , who was now close to [her]101-birdalone , smiled on [her]101-birdalone , and said in a kind and sweet voice : Fear nought , [Birdalone]101-birdalone , for [I]0-i deem [thou]519-thy wilt find [me]0-i [a friend]520-a friend , and it is not unlike that [thou]519-thy wilt need one ere long . And furthermore , [I]0-i will say it , said [she]0-i smiling , that since [I]0-i am not afraid of [thee]519-thy , [thou]519-thy needest not be afraid of [me]0-i . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]101-birdalone also smiling : True it is that [thou]519-thy art nought fearsome to look on . [The new - comer]518-the new - comer laughed outright , and said : Are [we]522-we not well met then in [the wildwood]523-the wildwood ? and [we]522-we both as [two children whom [the earth]445-the earth]524-two children whom the earth loveth . So play [we]522-we at a game . At what game ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . Spake [she]0-i [of the oak - wreath]526-of the oak - wreath : This ; [thou]519-thy shalt tell [me]0-i what [I]0-i am like in thine eyes first , because [thou]519-thy wert afraid of [me]0-i ; and then when [thou]519-thy art done , [I]0-i will tell [thee]519-thy what [thou]519-thy seemest to [me]0-i .

[Quoth Birdalone]101-birdalone : For [me]0-i that will be hard ; for [I]0-i have nought to liken [thee]519-thy to , whereas save this sight of [thee]519-thy [I]0-i have seen nought save [her]0-i that dwelleth in [the House by [the Water]7-the water]527-the house by the water , and whom [I]0-i serve . Nay , said the other , then will [I]0-i begin , and tell [thee]519-thy first whatlike [thou]519-thy art , so that [thou]519-thy wilt know the better how to frame [thy]519-thy word concerning [me]0-i . But tell [me]0-i , hast [thou]519-thy ever seen [thyself]528-thyself in a mirror ? What thing is that ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . It is a polished round of steel or some other white metal , said [the wood - maiden]529-the wood - maiden , which giveth back in all truth the image of whatso cometh before it . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone and reddened therewith : [We]530-we have at home a broad latten dish , which it is [my]0-i work , amongst other things , to brighten and keep bright ; yet may [I]0-i not make it so bright that [I]0-i may see much of [mine]0-i image therein ; and yet . What wouldst [thou]519-thy ? said [the wood - woman]531-the wood - woman . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : [I]0-i shall tell [thee]519-thy presently when [thy]519-thy part of the play is done .

Laughed [the new - comer]518-the new - comer , and said : It is well ; now am [I]0-i to be [thy]519-thy mirror . Thus it is with [thee]519-thy : [thou]519-thy standest before [me]0-i [a tall and slim maiden]533-a tall and slim maiden , somewhat thin , as befitteth [thy]519-thy seventeen summers ; where [thy]519-thy flesh is bare of wo nt , as [thy]519-thy throat and thine arms and [thy]519-thy legs from the middle down , it is tanned a beauteous colour , but otherwhere it is even as fair a white , wholesome and clean , and as if the golden sunlight , which fulfilleth the promise of [the earth]445-the earth , were playing therein . Fairer and rounder shall be thine arms and [thy]519-thy shoulders when [thou]519-thy hast seen five more summers , yet scarce more lovesome , so strong and fine as now they are . Low are [thy]519-thy breasts , as is meet for [so young a maiden]535-so young a maiden , yet is there no lack in them ; nor ever shall they be fairer than now they are . In goodly fashion sits thine head upon [thy]519-thy shoulders , upheld by a long and most well - wrought neck , that the sun hath tanned as aforesaid . The hair of [thee]519-thy is simple brown , yet somewhat more golden than dark ; and ah ! now [thou]519-thy lettest it loose it waveth softly past [thy]519-thy fair smooth forehead and on to [thy]519-thy shoulders , and is not stayed by [thy]519-thy girdlestead , but hideth nought of [thy]519-thy knees , and [thy]519-thy legs shapely thin , and [thy]519-thy strong and clean - wrought ankles and feet , which are with [thee]519-thy as full of thine heart and [thy]519-thy soul and as wise and deft as be [thy]519-thy wrists and thine hands , and [their]519-thy very fellows . Now as to [thy]519-thy face : under that smooth forehead is [thy]519-thy nose , which is of measure , neither small nor great , straight , and lovely carven at the nostrils : thine eyen are as grey as a hawk 's , but kind and serious , and nothing fierce nor shifting . Nay , now [thou]519-thy lettest thine eyelids fall , it is as fair with [thy]519-thy face as if they were open , so smooth and simple are [they]536-they and with [their]536-they long full lashes . But well are thine eyen set in thine head , wide apart , well opened , and so as none shall say [thou]519-thy mayst not look in the face of [them]536-they . [Thy]519-thy cheeks shall one day be a snare for the unwary , yet are they not fully rounded , as some would have them ; but not [I]0-i , for most pitiful kind are [they]536-they forsooth . Delicate and clear - made is the little trench that goeth from [thy]519-thy nose to [thy]519-thy lips , and sweet it is , and there is more might in it than in sweet words spoken . [Thy]519-thy lips , they are of the finest fashion , yet rather thin than full ; and [some]229-some would not have it so ; but [I]0-i would , whereas [I]0-i see therein a sign of [thy]519-thy valiancy and friendliness . Surely [[he]538-he who did [thy]519-thy carven chin]539-he who did thy carven chin had a mind to a master - work and did no less . Great was the deftness of [thine imaginer]540-thine imaginer , and [he]538-he would have all folk that see [thee]519-thy wonder at [thy]519-thy deep thinking and [thy]519-thy carefulness and [thy]519-thy kindness . [Ah maiden]541-ah maiden ! is it so that [thy]519-thy thoughts are ever deep and solemn ? Yet at least [I]0-i know it of [thee]519-thy that they be hale and true and sweet .

[[My]0-i friend]318-my friend , when [thou]519-thy hast a mirror , some of all this shalt [thou]519-thy see , but not all ; and when [thou]519-thy hast [a lover]543-a lover some deal wilt [thou]519-thy hear , but not all . But now [[thy]519-thy [she]544-thy she - friend - friend]544-thy she - friend may tell it [thee]519-thy all , if [she]544-thy she - friend have eyes to see it , as have [I]0-i ; whereas [no man]545-no man could say so much of [thee]519-thy before the mere love should overtake [him]545-no man , and turn [his]545-no man speech into the folly of love and the madness of desire . So now [I]0-i have played the play , and told [thee]519-thy of [thee]519-thy ; tell [me]0-i now of [me]0-i , and play [thy]519-thy play .

For a while stood [Birdalone]101-birdalone silent , blushing and confused , but whiles casting shy glances at [her]101-birdalone own body , what [she]101-birdalone might see of it . At last [she]101-birdalone spake : [Fair friend]546-fair friend , [I]0-i would do [thy]0-i will , but [I]0-i am not deft of speech ; for [I]0-i speak but little , save with the fowl and wild things , and [they]547-they may not learn [me]0-i the speech of [man]548-man . Yet [I]0-i will say that [I]0-i wonder to hear [thee]519-thy call [me]0-i fair and beauteous ; for [[my]0-i dame]549-my dame tells [me]0-i that never , nor sayeth aught of [my]0-i aspect save in [her]549-my dame anger , and then it is : Rag ! and bag - of - bones ! and when wilt [thou]519-thy be [a woman]250-a woman , [thou]519-thy lank elf [thou]519-thy ? [The new - comer]518-the new - comer laughed well - favouredly hereat , and put forth a hand , and stroked [[her]518-the new - comer friend]446-her friend 's cheek . [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked piteous kind on [her]101-birdalone and said : But now [I]0-i must needs believe [thy]519-thy words , [thou]519-thy who art so kind to [me]0-i , and withal [thyself]553-thyself so beauteous . And [I]0-i will tell [thee]519-thy that it fills [my]0-i heart with joy to know that [I]0-i am fair like to [thee]519-thy . For this moreover [I]0-i will tell [thee]519-thy , that [I]0-i have seen nought in [field or woodland]554-field or woodland that is as lovely to [me]0-i as [thou]519-thy art ; nay , not the fritillary nodding at [[our]555-our brook]556-our brook 's mouth , nor the willow - boughs waving on [Green Eyot]8-green eyot ; nor the wild - cat sporting on the little woodlawn , when [she]557-she saw [me]0-i not ; nor the white doe rising up from the grass to look to [her]557-she fawn ; nor aught that moves and grows . Yet there is another thing which [I]0-i must tell [thee]519-thy , to wit , that what [thou]519-thy hast said about the fashion of any part of [me]0-i , that same , setting aside [thy]519-thy lovely words , which make the tears come into the eyes of [me]0-i , would [I]0-i say of [thee]519-thy . Look [thou]519-thy ! [I]0-i take thine hair and lay the tress amongst [mine]0-i , and [thou]519-thy mayst not tell which is which ; and amidst the soft waves of it [thy]519-thy forehead is nestling smooth as [thou]519-thy saidst of [mine]0-i : hawk - grey and wide apart are thine eyen , and deep thought and all tenderness is in them , as of [me]0-i [thou]519-thy sayest : fine is [thy]519-thy nose and of due measure ; and [thy]519-thy cheeks a little hollow , and somewhat thin [thy]519-thy lovely lips ; and [thy]519-thy round chin so goodly carven , as it might not be better done . And of [thy]519-thy body else [I]0-i will say as [thou]519-thy sayst of [mine]0-i , though [I]0-i deem these hands have done more work than thine . But see [thou]519-thy ! [thy]519-thy leg and [mine]0-i as they stand together ; and thine arm , as if it were of [my]0-i body . Slim and slender [thou]519-thy art , or it may be lank ; and [I]0-i deem [[our]558-our dame]559-our dame would call [thee]519-thy also bag - of - bones . Now is this strange . Who art [thou]519-thy ? Art [thou]519-thy [[my]0-i very own sister]560-my very own sister ? [I]0-i would [thou]519-thy wert .

Spake then to [Birdalone]101-birdalone that image of [her]101-birdalone , and said , smiling kindly on [her]101-birdalone : As to [our]558-our likeness , [thou]519-thy hast it now ; so alike are [we]558-our , as if [we]558-our were cast in one mould . But [[thy]519-thy sister]561-thy sister of blood [I]0-i am not ; nay , [I]0-i will tell [thee]519-thy at once that [I]0-i am not of [the children of Adam]562-the children of adam . As to what [I]0-i am , that is a long story , and [I]0-i may not tell it as now ; but [thou]519-thy mayst call [me]0-i [Habundia]106-habundia , as [I]0-i call [thee]519-thy [Birdalone]101-birdalone . Now it is true that to [everyone]563-everyone [I]0-i show not [myself]0-i in this fair shape of [thee]519-thy ; but be not aghast thereat , or deem [me]0-i like unto [[thy]519-thy mistress]564-thy mistress herein , for as now [I]0-i am , so ever shall [I]0-i be unto [thee]519-thy .

Quoth [Birdalone]101-birdalone , looking on [her]519-thy anxiously : Yea , and [I]0-i shall see [thee]519-thy again , shall [I]0-i not ? else should [I]0-i grieve , and wish that [I]0-i had never seen [thee]519-thy at all . [Yea]565-yea , forsooth , said [Habundia]106-habundia , for [I]0-i [myself]0-i were most fain to see [thee]519-thy oft . But now must [thou]566-thou presently get [thee]519-thy back [home]387-home , for evil as now is the mood of [[thy]566-thou mistress]564-thy mistress , and [she]564-thy mistress is rueing the gift of the green gown , and hath in [her]564-thy mistress mind to seek occasion to chastise [thee]519-thy .

Now was [Birdalone]101-birdalone half weeping , as [she]101-birdalone did on [her]101-birdalone raiment while [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend looked on [her]101-birdalone kindly . [She]101-birdalone said presently : [Habundia]106-habundia , [thou]106-habundia seest [I]0-i am hard bestead ; give [me]0-i some good rede thereto .

That will [I]0-i , said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife . When [thou]106-habundia goest [home]387-home to [the house]325-the house , be glad of countenance , and joyous that [thy]106-habundia gown is nigh done ; and therewith be exceeding wary . For [I]0-i deem it most like that [she]570-the wood - wife will ask [thee]519-thy what [thou]106-habundia hast seen in [the wood]348-the wood , and then if [thou]106-habundia falter , or [thy]106-habundia face change , then [she]570-the wood - wife will have an inkling of what hath befallen , to wit , that [thou]106-habundia hast seen [someone]496-someone ; and then will [she]570-the wood - wife be minded to question [thy]106-habundia skin . But if [thou]106-habundia keep countenance valiantly , then presently will [her]570-the wood - wife doubt run off [her]570-the wood - wife , and [she]570-the wood - wife will cease grudging , and will grow mild with [thee]519-thy and meddle not . This is the first rede , and is for to - day ; and now for the second , which is for days yet unborn . [Thou]106-habundia hast in [thy]106-habundia mind to flee away from [her]570-the wood - wife ; and even so shalt [thou]106-habundia do one day , though it may be by way of [Weeping Cross]107-weeping cross ; for [she]570-the wood - wife is sly and wise and grim , though sooth it is that [she]570-the wood - wife hateth [thee]519-thy not utterly . Now [thou]106-habundia must note that nowise [she]570-the wood - wife hindereth [thee]519-thy from faring in [this wood]575-this wood , and that is because [she]570-the wood - wife wotteth , as [I]0-i do , that by this way there is no outgoing for [thee]519-thy . Wherefore look [thou]106-habundia to it that it is by the way of the water that [thou]106-habundia shalt fare to [the land of [men - folk]577-men - folk]576-the land of men - folk . Belike this may seem marvellous to [thee]519-thy ; but so it is ; and belike [I]0-i may tell [thee]519-thy more hereof when time serveth . Now cometh the last word of [my]0-i rede . Maybe if [thou]106-habundia come often to [the wood]348-the wood , [we]579-we shall whiles happen on each other ; but if [thou]106-habundia have occasion for [me]0-i , and wouldst see [me]0-i at once , come hither , and make fire , and burn a hair of [my]0-i head therein , and [I]0-i will be with [thee]519-thy : here is for [thee]519-thy a tress of [mine]0-i hair ; now [thou]106-habundia art clad , [thou]106-habundia mayst take a knife from [thy]106-habundia pouch and shear it from off [me]0-i .

Even so did [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and set the tress in [her]101-birdalone pouch ; and therewith [they]579-we kissed and embraced [each other]580-each other , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone went [her]101-birdalone ways [home]387-home to [the house]325-the house , but [Habundia]106-habundia went back into [the wood]348-the wood as [she]106-habundia had come .

CHAPTER VIII . OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone AND [THE WITCH - WIFE]349-the witch - wife

It went with [Birdalone]101-birdalone as [Habundia]106-habundia had foretold , for [she]106-habundia came [home]387-home to [the house]325-the house glad of semblance , flushed and light - foot , so that [she]106-habundia was lovely and graceful beyond [her]106-habundia wo nt . [The dame]415-the dame looked on [her]106-habundia doubtfully and grimly a while , and then [she]415-the dame said : What ails [thee]106-habundia , [[my]0-i servant]588-my servant , that [thou]106-habundia lookest so masterful ? Nought ails [me]0-i , [lady]504-lady , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , save that [I]0-i am gay because of the summer season , and chiefly because of [thy]106-habundia kindness and [thy]106-habundia gift , and that [I]0-i have well- nigh done [my]0-i work thereon , and that soon now [I]0-i shall feel these dainty things beating about [my]0-i ankles . And [she]106-habundia held up and spread abroad the skirt with [her]106-habundia two hands , and it was indeed goodly to look on .

[The witch - wife]349-the witch - wife snorted scornfully and scowled on [her]106-habundia , and said : Thine ankles forsooth ! Bag - o'-bones ! [thou]106-habundia wisp ! forsooth , [thou]106-habundia art in love with [thy]106-habundia looks , though [thou]106-habundia knowest not what like [a fair woman]591-a fair woman is . [Forsooth]101-birdalone , [I]0-i begin to think that [thou]106-habundia wilt never grow into [a woman]250-a woman at all , but will abide [a skinny elf]593-a skinny elf [thy]106-habundia life long . Belike [I]0-i did [myself]0-i wrong to suffer [thee]106-habundia to waste these three or four months of [thy]106-habundia thrall 's work , since for nought but thrall 's work shalt [thou]106-habundia ever be meet .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone hung [her]101-birdalone head adown , and blushed , but smiled a little , and swayed [her]101-birdalone body gently , as a willow - bough is swayed when a light air arises in the morning . But [the witch]407-the witch stood so scowling on [her]101-birdalone , and with so sour a look , that [Birdalone]101-birdalone , glancing at [her]407-the witch , found [her]101-birdalone heart sink so within [her]101-birdalone , that [she]101-birdalone scarce kept countenance ; yet [she]101-birdalone lost it not .

Then said [the witch]407-the witch sharply : Wert [thou]106-habundia in the wood to - day ? [Yea]596-yea , [lady]504-lady , said [the maiden]406-the maiden . Then said [the dame]415-the dame fiercely : And what sawest [thou]106-habundia ? Quoth [Birdalone]101-birdalone , looking up with an innocent face somewhat scared : [Lady]504-lady , [I]0-i saw a bear , one of the big ones , crossing a glade . And [thou]106-habundia without bow and arrow or wood - knife , [I]0-i warrant [me]0-i , said [the witch]407-the witch . [Thou]106-habundia shalt be whipped , to keep [thee]106-habundia in mind that [thy]106-habundia life is [mine]0-i and not thine . Nay , nay , [I]0-i pray [thee]106-habundia be not wroth ! said [the maid]602-the maid ; [he]603-he was a long way down [the glade]604-the glade , and would not have followed [me]0-i if [he]603-he had seen [me]0-i : there was no peril therein . Said [the witch- wife]427-the witch- wife : Didst [thou]106-habundia see [aught]606-aught else ? [Yea]607-yea , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and was weeping somewhat now ; which forsooth was not hard for [her]427-the witch- wife to do , over - wrought as [she]427-the witch- wife was betwixt hope and fear : yea , [I]0-i saw [my]0-i white doe and [her]608-her fawn , and [they]609-they passed close by [me]0-i ; and two herons flew over [my]0-i head toward the water ; and . . . But [the witch]407-the witch turned sharply and said : Thrall ! hast [thou]106-habundia seen [a woman]250-a woman to - day in [the wood]348-the wood ? [A woman]250-a woman ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and [what woman]614-what woman , [[my]0-i lady]615-my lady , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . Hath [any woman]616-any woman come to [the house]325-the house , and passed forth into [the wood]348-the wood ?

[The dame]415-the dame looked on [her]415-the dame carefully , and remembered how [she]415-the dame had faltered and changed countenance that other day , when [she]415-the dame had charged [her]415-the dame with being minded to flee ; and now [she]415-the dame saw [her]415-the dame with wondering face , and in no wise confused or afraid of guilt , as it seemed ; so [she]415-the dame believed [her]415-the dame tale , and being the more at ease thereby , [her]415-the dame wrath ran off [her]415-the dame , and [she]415-the dame spake altogether pleasantly to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and said : Now [I]0-i have had [my]0-i gird at [thee]415-the dame , [[my]0-i servant]588-my servant , [I]0-i must tell [thee]415-the dame that in sooth it is not all for nothing that [thou]415-the dame hast had these months of rest ; for verily [thou]415-the dame hast grown more of [a woman]250-a woman thereby , and hast sleekened and rounded much . Albeit , the haysel will wait no longer for [us]622-we , and the day after to - morrow [we]622-we must fall to on it . But when that is done , [thou]415-the dame shalt be free to do [thy]415-the dame green gown , or what [thou]415-the dame wilt , till wheat harvest is toward ; and thereafter [we]622-we shall see to it . Or what sayest [thou]415-the dame ?

[Birdalone]101-birdalone wondered somewhat at this so gracious word , but not much ; for in [her]101-birdalone heart now was some guile born to meet [the witch]407-the witch 's guile ; so [she]101-birdalone knelt down and took [the dame]415-the dame 's hands and kissed them , and said : [I]0-i say nought , [lady]504-lady , save that [I]0-i thank [thee]415-the dame over and over again that [thou]415-the dame art become so good to [me]0-i ; and that [I]0-i will full merrily work for [thee]415-the dame in [the hay - field]626-the hay - field , or at whatsoever else [thou]415-the dame wilt .

And indeed [she]101-birdalone was so light - hearted that [she]101-birdalone had so escaped from the hand of [the witch]407-the witch for that time , and above all , that [she]101-birdalone had gotten [a friend]520-a friend so kind and dear as [the wood - woman]531-the wood - woman , that [her]101-birdalone heart went out even toward [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress , so that [she]101-birdalone went nigh to loving [her]419-her mistress .

CHAPTER IX . OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone 'S SWIMMING[101-birdalone]

Full fair was the morrow morn , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose betimes before the sun was up , and [she]101-birdalone thought [she]101-birdalone would make of this a holiday before [the swink afield]631-the swink afield began again , since [the witch]407-the witch was grown good toward [her]101-birdalone . So [she]101-birdalone did on [her]101-birdalone fair shoes , and [her]101-birdalone new raiment , though the green gown was not fully done , and said to [herself]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone would consider what [she]101-birdalone would do with [her]101-birdalone holiday when [she]101-birdalone was amidst of [her]101-birdalone bathing .

So [she]101-birdalone went down to [the water]361-the water - side , and when [she]101-birdalone was standing knee- deep in [the little sandy bight aforesaid]634-the little sandy bight aforesaid , [she]101-birdalone looked over to [Green Eyot]8-green eyot , and was minded to swim over thither , as oft [she]101-birdalone did . And it was a windless dawn after a hot night , and a light mist lay upon the face of [the water]361-the water , and above it rose the greenery of the eyot .

[She]101-birdalone pushed off into the deep and swam strongly through the still water , and the sun rose while [she]101-birdalone was on the way , and by then [she]101-birdalone had laid a hand on the willow - twigs of the eyot , was sending a long beam across [the waters]636-the waters ; and [her]101-birdalone wet shoulders rose up into the path of it and were turned into ruddy gold . [She]101-birdalone hoisted [herself]101-birdalone up , and climbing the low bank , was standing amongst [the meadow]510-the meadow - sweet , and dripping on to its fragrance . Then [she]101-birdalone turned about to [the green plain]638-the green plain and [the house]325-the house and [the hedge of woodland beyond]640-the hedge of woodland beyond , and sighed , and said softly : A pity of it , to leave it ! If it were no better otherwhere , and not so fair ?

Then [she]101-birdalone turned inward to the eyot , which had done [her]101-birdalone nought but good , and which [she]101-birdalone loved ; and [she]101-birdalone unbound [her]101-birdalone hair , and let it fall till the ends of the tresses mingled with the heads of the meadow- sweet , and thereafter walked quietly up into [the grassy middle of [the isle]642-the isle]641-the grassy middle of the isle .

[She]101-birdalone was wo nt to go to [a knoll there where the grass was fine , and flowery at this time with white clover and dog violet , and lie down under the shade of a big thorn with a much - twisted bole]643-a knoll there where the grass was fine , and flowery at this time with white clover and dog violet , and lie down under the shade of a big thorn with a much - twisted bole : but to - day some thought came across [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone turned before [she]101-birdalone came to the thorn , and went straight over [the eyot]644-the eyot which was but a furlong over at [that place]645-that place and down to [the southward - looking shore thereof]646-the southward - looking shore thereof . There [she]101-birdalone let [herself]101-birdalone softly down into [the water]361-the water and thrust off without more ado , and swam on and on till [she]101-birdalone had gone a long way . Then [she]101-birdalone communed with [herself]101-birdalone , and found that [she]101-birdalone was thinking : If [I]0-i might only swim all [the water]361-the water and be free .

And still [she]101-birdalone swam on : and now a light wind had been drawn up from the west , and was driving a little ripple athwart [the lake]369-the lake , and [she]101-birdalone swam the swiftlier for it awhile , but then turned over on [her]101-birdalone back and floated southward still . Till on a sudden , as [she]101-birdalone lay looking up toward the far - away blue sky , and [she]101-birdalone so little and low on the face of the waters , and [the lake]369-the lake so deep beneath [her]101-birdalone , and the wind coming ever fresher from the west , and the ripple rising higher against [her]101-birdalone , a terror fell upon [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone longed for the green earth and its well - wrought little blossoms and leaves and grass ; then [she]101-birdalone turned over again and swam straight for [the eyot]644-the eyot , which now was but [a little green heap far away before [her]101-birdalone]652-a little green heap far away before her .

Long [she]101-birdalone was ere [she]101-birdalone made [land]653-land [there]232-there , and the sun was high in the heavens when [she]101-birdalone came , all spent and weary , to the shadow of the hawthorn - tree ; and [she]101-birdalone cast [herself]101-birdalone down there and fell asleep straightway . Forsooth [her]101-birdalone swim was about as much as [she]101-birdalone had might for .

When [she]101-birdalone awoke it lacked but an hour of noon - tide , and [she]101-birdalone felt the life in [her]101-birdalone and was happy , but had no will to rise up for a while ; for it was ajoy to [her]101-birdalone to turn [her]101-birdalone head this way and that to the dear and dainty flowers , that made [the wide , grey , empty lake]655-the wide , grey , empty lake seem so far away , and no more to be dealt with than the very sky itself .

At last [she]101-birdalone arose , and when [she]101-birdalone had plucked and eaten some handfuls of the strawberries which grew plenteously on [the sweet ground of the eyot]656-the sweet ground of the eyot , [she]101-birdalone went down to [the landward - looking shore]657-the landward - looking shore , and took [the water]361-the water , and swam slowly across [the warm ripple]659-the warm ripple till [she]101-birdalone came once more to [the strand]660-the strand and [her]101-birdalone raiment . [She]101-birdalone clad [herself]101-birdalone , and set [her]101-birdalone hand to [her]101-birdalone pouch and drew forth bread , and sat eating it on the bank above the smooth sand . Then [she]101-birdalone looked around , and stood up with [her]101-birdalone face toward [the house]325-the house , to see if [the dame]415-the dame would call to [her]101-birdalone . But [she]101-birdalone saw [the witch]407-the witch come out of [the porch]664-the porch and stand there looking under the sharp of [her]407-the witch hand toward [her]101-birdalone , and thereafter [she]101-birdalone went back again into [the house]325-the house without giving any sign . Wherefore [Birdalone]101-birdalone deemed that [she]101-birdalone had leave that day , and that [she]101-birdalone might take yet more holiday ; so [she]101-birdalone stepped lightly down from [her]101-birdalone place of vantage , turned [her]101-birdalone face toward the east , and went quietly along [the very lip of [the water]361-the water]666-the very lip of the water .

CHAPTER X. [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone COMES ON NEW TIDINGS

Soon [she]101-birdalone had covered up [the house]325-the house from [her]101-birdalone , for on that eastern end , both a tongue of [the woodland]669-the woodland shoved out west into [the meadow]510-the meadow , and , withal , the whole body of the wood there drew down to the water , and presently cut off all the greensward save a narrow strip along by [the lake]369-the lake , off the narrowest whereof lay [the rocky eyot aforesaid]672-the rocky eyot aforesaid , nigher unto the shore than lay [Green Eyot]8-green eyot .

Now never had [Birdalone]101-birdalone gone so far east as to be over against [Rock Eyot]9-rock eyot . In [her]101-birdalone childish days [the witch]407-the witch had let [her]101-birdalone know that [she]101-birdalone might go where [she]101-birdalone would , but therewith had told [her]101-birdalone a tale of a huge serpent which dwelt in [the dark wood]674-the dark wood over against [Rock Eyot]9-rock eyot , whose wo nt it was to lap [his]675-his folds round and round living things that went there , and devour them ; and many an evil dream had that evil serpent brought to [Birdalone]101-birdalone . In after days belike [she]101-birdalone scarce trowed in the tale , yet the terror of it abode with [her]101-birdalone . Moreover the wildwood toward that side , as it drew toward [the water]361-the water , was dark and dreary and forbidding , running into black thickets standing amidst quagmires , all unlike to [the sweet , clean upland ridges]677-the sweet , clean upland ridges , oak begrown and greenswarded , of the parts which lay toward [the north]678-the north , and which [she]101-birdalone mostly haunted .

But this summer day , which was so bright and hot , [Birdalone]101-birdalone deemed [she]101-birdalone might harden [her]101-birdalone heart to try the adventure ; and [she]101-birdalone had a mind to enter [the wood]348-the wood thereby , and win [her]101-birdalone way up into [the oakland]680-the oakland whereas [she]101-birdalone had met [Habundia]106-habundia , and perchance [she]101-birdalone might happen on [her]101-birdalone ; for [she]101-birdalone would not dare to summon [her]106-habundia so soon after [their]681-their first meeting . And if [she]101-birdalone met [her]106-habundia , there would be the holiday worthily brought to an end !

On went [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and was soon at the narrowest of [the greensward]682-the greensward , and had the wood black on [her]101-birdalone left hand , for the trees of [it]348-the wood were mostly alder . But when [she]101-birdalone was come just over against [Rock Eyot]9-rock eyot , [she]101-birdalone found [a straight creek or inlet of the water across [her]101-birdalone way]683-a straight creek or inlet of the water across her way ; and [the said creek]684-the said creek ran right up into [the alder thicket]685-the alder thicket ; and , indeed , was much overhung by huge ancient alders , gnarled , riven , mossy , and falling low over the water . But close on [the mouth of [the creek]687-the creek]686-the mouth of the creek , on [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's side thereof , lay a thing floating on the dull water , which [she]101-birdalone knew not how to call [a boat]688-a boat , for such had [she]101-birdalone never seen , nor heard of , but which was indeed [a boat]688-a boat , oarless and sailless .

[She]101-birdalone looked on it all about , and wondered ; yet [she]101-birdalone saw at once that it was for wending [the water]361-the water , and [she]101-birdalone thought , might [she]101-birdalone but have a long pole , [she]101-birdalone might push it about [the shallow parts of [the lake]369-the lake]691-the shallow parts of the lake , and belike take much fish . [She]101-birdalone tried to shove it somewhat toward [the lake]369-the lake , but with [her]101-birdalone little might could make nothing of the work ; for [the craft]694-the craft was heavy , like [a barge]695-a barge , if there were nothing else that withstood [her]101-birdalone .

About this new thing [she]101-birdalone hung a long while , wondering that [she]101-birdalone had never heard thereof , or been set to toil therewith . [She]101-birdalone noted that it was mostly pale grey of hue , as if it had been bleached by sun and water , but at the stem and stern were smears of darker colour , as though [someone]496-someone had been trying the tints of staining there .

Now so much did this new matter take up all [her]101-birdalone mind , that [she]101-birdalone thought no more of going up into the wood ; but though [she]101-birdalone had fain abided there long to see whatever might be seen , [she]101-birdalone deemed it would go ill with [her]101-birdalone did [the witch]407-the witch happen on [her]101-birdalone there ; wherefore [she]101-birdalone turned about , and went back the way [she]101-birdalone had come , going very slowly and pondering the tidings .
