And ever [she]101-birdalone called to mind what [Habundia]106-habundia had said to [her]101-birdalone , that it was by [water]698-water [she]101-birdalone must flee , and wondered if [she]106-habundia had sent [her]101-birdalone this thing that [she]101-birdalone might escape therein ; so different as [her]101-birdalone going would be thereby to swimming [the lake]369-the lake with [her]101-birdalone wet body . Then again [she]101-birdalone thought , that before [she]101-birdalone might let [herself]101-birdalone hope this , it were best , if [she]101-birdalone might , to find out from [the witch]407-the witch what was the thing , and if [she]101-birdalone knew thereof . Yet at last [she]101-birdalone called to mind how [little patient of questions]701-little patient of questions was [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress , and that if [she]101-birdalone were unheedful [she]101-birdalone might come to raise an evil storm about [her]101-birdalone . Wherefore [she]101-birdalone took this rede at the last , that [she]101-birdalone would keep all hidden in [her]101-birdalone own breast till [she]101-birdalone should see [Habundia]106-habundia again ; and meanwhile [she]101-birdalone might steal down thither from time to time to see if the thing still abode [there]232-there ; which [she]101-birdalone might the easier do by swimming if [she]101-birdalone chose [her]101-birdalone time heedfully , and go thither from [Rock Eyot]9-rock eyot , which now and again [she]101-birdalone visited .

CHAPTER XI . OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone 'S GUILT AND THE CHASTISEMENT THEREOF[101-birdalone]

By this [she]101-birdalone was come back to [the sandy bight]704-the sandy bight , and the sun was westering ; and [she]101-birdalone looked up toward [the house]325-the house and saw that it was the time of [their]706-their evening meal , for the blue smoke of the cooking fire was going up into the air . So [she]101-birdalone went thither speedily , and entered gay of seeming . [The witch]407-the witch looked on [her]101-birdalone doubtfully , but presently fell to speaking with [her]101-birdalone graciously as yesterday , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone was glad and easy of mind , and went about the serving of [her]101-birdalone ; for always [she]101-birdalone ate after [the dame]415-the dame ; and [the mistress]709-the mistress asked [her]101-birdalone of many matters concerning [the house]325-the house , and the gathering of stuff .

So came the talk on the fishing of [the brook]711-the brook that ran before [their]706-their door , and how the trouts therein were but little , and not seldom none at all ; and even therewith came these words into [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's mouth , [she]101-birdalone scarce knew how : [[My]0-i lady]615-my lady , why do [we]706-their not fish [the lake]369-the lake , whereas there be shoal places betwixt [us]706-their and the eyots where lie many and great fish , as [I]0-i have seen when [I]0-i have been swimming thereover ? And now in [that same creek]714-that same creek whereas the serpent used to lurk when [I]0-i was little , [we]706-their have a thing come , which is made to swim on [the water]361-the water ; and [I]0-i , could [I]0-i have a long pole to shove withal .

But no time [she]101-birdalone had to make an end , ere [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife sprang up and turned on [her]101-birdalone with a snarl as of an evil dog , and [her]101-birdalone face changed horribly : [her]101-birdalone teeth showed grinning , [her]101-birdalone eyes goggled in [her]101-birdalone head , [her]101-birdalone brow was all to - furrowed , and [her]101-birdalone hands clenched like iron springs .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone shuddered back from [her]349-the witch - wife and cringed in mere terror , but had no might to cry out . [The witch]407-the witch hauled [her]101-birdalone up by the hair , and dragged [her]101-birdalone head back so that [her]101-birdalone throat lay bare before [her]101-birdalone all along . Then drew [the witch]407-the witch a sharp knife from [her]407-the witch girdle , and raised [her]407-the witch hand over [her]101-birdalone , growling and snarling like a wolf . But suddenly [she]407-the witch dropped the knife , [her]407-the witch hand fell to [her]407-the witch side , and [she]407-the witch fell in a heap on the floor and lay there hushed .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone stood gazing on [her]101-birdalone , and trembling in every limb ; too confused was [she]101-birdalone to think or do aught , though some image off light through the open door passed before [her]101-birdalone : but [her]101-birdalone feet seemed of lead , and , as in an evil dream , [she]101-birdalone had no might to move [her]101-birdalone limbs , and the minutes went by as [she]101-birdalone stood there half dead with fear .

At last , and belike it was no long while [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife came to [herself]349-the witch - wife again , and sat up on the floor , and looked all about [the chamber]306-the chamber , and when [her]349-the witch - wife eyes fell upon [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]349-the witch - wife said in a weak voice , yet joyfully ; Hah ! [thou]721-thou art there still , [[my]0-i good servant]722-my good servant ! Then [she]349-the witch - wife said : A sickness fell upon [me]0-i suddenly , as whiles it is wo nt ; but now am [I]0-i [myself]0-i again ; and presently [I]0-i have a word for [thee]101-birdalone .

Therewith [she]349-the witch - wife rose up slowly , [Birdalone]101-birdalone helping [her]349-the witch - wife , and sat in [her]349-the witch - wife big chair silent awhile , and then [she]349-the witch - wife spake : [[My]0-i servant]588-my servant , [thou]721-thou hast for the more part served [me]0-i well : but this time [thou]721-thou hast done ill , whereas [thou]721-thou hast been spying on [my]0-i ways ; whereof may come heavy trouble but if [we]724-we look to it . Well is it for [thee]721-thou that [thou]721-thou hast none unto whom [thou]721-thou mightest babble ; for then must [I]0-i needs have slain [thee]721-thou here and now . But for this first time [I]0-i pardon [thee]721-thou , and [thou]721-thou hast escaped the wrath .

[Her]349-the witch - wife voice was soft and wheedling ; but for [Birdalone]101-birdalone the terror had entered into [her]349-the witch - wife soul , and yet abode with [her]349-the witch - wife .

[The witch - wife]349-the witch - wife sat a while , and then arose and went about [the chamber]306-the chamber , and came to a certain aumbry and opened it , and drew forth a little flasket of lead and a golden cup scored over with strange signs , and laid them on the board beside [her]349-the witch - wife chair , wherein [she]349-the witch - wife now sat down again , and spake once more , still in the same soft and wheedling voice : Yet , [[my]0-i servant]588-my servant , [thy]721-thou guilt would be required of [me]0-i , if [I]0-i let this pass as if to - day were the same as yesterday ; yea , and of [thee]721-thou also would it be required ; therefore it is a part of the pardon that [thou]721-thou be corrected : and the correction must be terrible to [thee]721-thou , that [thou]721-thou mayst remember never again to thrust [thyself]728-thyself into the jaws of death . And what may [I]0-i do to correct [thee]721-thou ? It shall be in a strange way , such as [thou]721-thou hast never dreamed of . Yet the anguish thereof shall go to thine heart 's root ; but this must [thou]721-thou needs bear , for [my]0-i good and thine , so that both [we]729-we may live and be merry hereafter . Go now , fill this cup with water from the spring and come back with it . [Birdalone]101-birdalone took the cup with a sinking heart , and filled it , and brought it back , and stood before [the witch more dead than alive]730-the witch more dead than alive .

Then [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife took up the flasket and pulled out the stopple and betook it to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and said : Drink of this now , a little sip , no more . And [the maiden]406-the maiden did so , and the liquor was no sooner down [her]406-the maiden gullet than [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife and [the chamber]306-the chamber , and all things about [her]406-the maiden , became somewhat dim to [her]406-the maiden ; but yet not so much so as that [she]406-the maiden could not see them . But when [she]406-the maiden stretched out [her]406-the maiden arm [she]406-the maiden could see it not at all , nor [her]406-the maiden limbs nor any other part of [her]406-the maiden which [her]406-the maiden eyes might fall upon . Then would [she]406-the maiden have uttered a lamentable wail , but the voice was sealed up in [her]406-the maiden and no sound came from [her]406-the maiden voice . Then [she]406-the maiden heard [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife how [she]349-the witch - wife said and yet [she]406-the maiden heard it as if [her]349-the witch - wife voice came from afar , Nay , [thou]736-thee canst not speak , and [thou]736-thee canst not see [thyself]737-thyself , nor may any other , save [me]0-i , and [I]0-i but dimly . But this is but part of what [I]0-i must lay upon [thee]736-thee ; for next [I]0-i must give [thee]736-thee a new shape , and that both [thyself]737-thyself and all other may see . But , before [I]0-i do that , [I]0-i must speak a word to [thee]736-thee , which [thy]736-thee new shape would not suffer the sense thereof to reach to thine heart . Hearken !

CHAPTER XII . THE WORDS OF [THE WITCH - WIFE]108-the witch - wife TO [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone

Said [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife : When [thou]736-thee comest to [thyself]737-thyself for it is not [my]0-i will that [thou]736-thee shouldest never have thine own shape again , doubtless the first thing which [thou]736-thee shalt do with [thy]736-thee new - gained voice and [thy]736-thee new - gained wit shall be to curse [me]0-i , and curse [me]0-i again . Do as [thou]736-thee wilt herein ; but [I]0-i charge [thee]736-thee , disobey [me]0-i not , for that shall bring [thee]736-thee to [thy]736-thee bane . For if [thou]736-thee do not [my]0-i bidding , and if [thou]736-thee pry into [my]0-i matters , and lay bare that which [I]0-i will have hidden , then will it be imputed unto [thee]736-thee for guilt , and will [I]0-i , will [I]0-i not , [I]0-i must be avenged on [thee]736-thee even to slaying : and then is undone all the toil and pain [I]0-i have had in rearing [thee]736-thee into [a deft and lovely maiden]739-a deft and lovely maiden . Deem [thou]736-thee , then , this present anguish kind to [thee]736-thee , to keep [thee]736-thee that [thou]736-thee come not to nought .

Now since [I]0-i have begun speaking , [I]0-i will go on ; for little heretofore have [I]0-i spoken to [thee]736-thee what was in [mine]0-i heart . Well [I]0-i wot that [thou]736-thee thinkest of [me]0-i but as of an evil dream , whereof none can aught but long to awake from it . Yet [I]0-i would have [thee]736-thee look to this at least ; that [I]0-i took [thee]736-thee from poverty and pinching , and have reared [thee]736-thee as faithfully as ever [mother]740-mother did to [child]297-child ; clemming [thee]736-thee never , smiting [thee]736-thee not so oft , and but seldom cruelly . Moreover , [I]0-i have suffered [thee]736-thee to go whereso [thou]736-thee wouldest , and have compelled [thee]736-thee to toil for nought but what was needful for [our]742-our two livelihoods . And [I]0-i have not stayed [thy]736-thee swimmings in [the lake]369-the lake , nor [thy]736-thee wanderings in [the wood]348-the wood , and [thou]736-thee hast learned bowshot there , till [thou]736-thee art now [a past - master in the craft]745-a past - master in the craft : and , moreover , [thou]736-thee art swift - foot as the best of the deer , and mayest over - run any one of [them]746-them whom [thou]736-thee wilt .

Soothly a merry life hast [thou]736-thee had as [a child]245-a child , and merry now would be [thy]736-thee life , save for thine hatred of [me]0-i . Into a lovely lily - lass hast [thou]736-thee grown . That [I]0-i tell [thee]736-thee now , though [my]0-i wo nt has been to gird at [thee]736-thee for the fashion of [thy]736-thee body ; that was but the word of [the mistress]709-the mistress to the thrall . And now what awaiteth [thee]736-thee ? For [thou]736-thee mayst say : [I]0-i am lonely here , and there is [no man]545-no man to look on [me]0-i . Of what avail , therefore , is [my]0-i goodliness and shapeliness ? [Child]109-child , [I]0-i answer [thee]736-thee that the time is coming when [thou]736-thee shalt see here [a many of the fairest of [men]219-men]750-a many of the fairest of men , and then shalt [thou]736-thee be rather rose than lily , and fully come to womanhood ; and all those shall love and worship [thee]736-thee , and [thou]736-thee mayst gladden whom [thou]736-thee wilt , and whom [thou]736-thee wilt mayst sadden ; and no lack soever shalt [thou]736-thee have of the sweetness of love , or the glory of dominion .

Think of it then ! All this is for [thee]736-thee if [thou]736-thee dwell here quietly with [me]0-i , doing [my]0-i will till [thy]736-thee womanhood hath blossomed . Wherefore [I]0-i beseech and pray [thee]736-thee put out of [thy]736-thee mind the thought of fleeing from [me]0-i . For if [thou]736-thee try it , one of two things shall be : either [I]0-i shall bring [thee]736-thee back and slay [thee]736-thee , or make [thee]736-thee live in misery of torment ; or else [thou]736-thee wilt escape , and then what will it be ? Dost [thou]736-thee know how it shall go with [thee]736-thee , coming poor and nameless , [an outcast]752-an outcast , into the world of [men]219-men ? Lust shalt [thou]736-thee draw unto [thee]736-thee , but scarce love . [I]0-i say [an outcast]752-an outcast shalt [thou]736-thee be , without worship or dominion ; [thy]736-thee body shall be a prey to ribalds , and when the fine flower thereof hath faded , [thou]736-thee shalt find that the words of [[thy]736-thee lovers]755-thy lovers were but mockery . That [no man]545-no man shall love [thee]736-thee , and [no woman]757-no woman aid [thee]736-thee . Then shall Eld come to [thee]736-thee and find [thee]736-thee at [home]387-home with Hell ; and Death shall come and mock [thee]736-thee for [thy]736-thee life cast away for nought , for nought . This is [my]0-i word to [thee]736-thee : and now [I]0-i have nought to do to [thee]736-thee save to change [thee]736-thee [thy]736-thee skin , and therein must [thou]736-thee do as [thou]736-thee canst , but it shall be no ugly or evil shape at least . But another time maybe [I]0-i shall not be so kind as to give [thee]736-thee a new shape , but shall let [thee]736-thee wander about seen by none but [me]0-i . Then [she]0-i took the cup and took water in the hollow of [her]0-i hand and cast it into [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's face , and muttered words withal ; and presently [she]0-i saw [herself]0-i indeed , that [she]0-i was become [a milk - white hind]759-a milk - white hind ; and [she]0-i heard and saw again , but not as [she]0-i , [the maiden]406-the maiden , was wo nt to hear and see ; for both [her]0-i hearing and seeing and [her]0-i thought was of a beast and [not of a maiden]761-not of a maiden .

Said [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife : It is done now , till [I]0-i give [thee]736-thee grace again ; and now be off into [the field]763-the field ; but if [thou]736-thee stray more than half a bowshot from [the brook]711-the brook , it shall be the worse for [thee]736-thee . And now the day was done and night was come .

CHAPTER XIII . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone MEETETH [THE WOOD - WOMAN]110-the wood - woman AGAIN

It was fifteen days thereafter that [Birdalone]101-birdalone awoke lying in [her]101-birdalone bed on a bright morning , as if all this had been but a dream . But [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife was standing over [her]101-birdalone and crying out : [Thou]736-thee art late , slug - a - bed , this fair - weather day , and the grass all spoiling for lack of the scythe . Off ! and down to [the meadow]510-the meadow with [thee]736-thee .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone waited not for more words , but sprang out of bed , and had [her]101-birdalone work - a - day raiment on in a twinkling , and stayed but to wash [her]101-birdalone in [a pool of [the brook]711-the brook]767-a pool of the brook , and then was amidst the tall grass with the swathe falling before [her]101-birdalone . As [she]101-birdalone worked [she]101-birdalone thought , and could scarce tell whether joy at [her]101-birdalone present deliverance , or terror of [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife , were the greatest . Sore was [her]101-birdalone longing to go see [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend in [the wood]348-the wood , but the haysel lasted more than a week , and when that was done , whether it were of set purpose or no , [the dame]415-the dame forgat [her]415-the dame other promise , to give [Birdalone]101-birdalone more holiday , and kept [her]101-birdalone close to [her]101-birdalone work about [meadow]773-meadow and [acre]774-acre . Otherwise [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress nowise mishandled or threatened [her]101-birdalone , though [she]101-birdalone had gone back to the surliness and railing which was [her]101-birdalone wo nt . At last , on a morning when [the dame]415-the dame had bidden [her]101-birdalone to nought of work , [Birdalone]101-birdalone took [her]101-birdalone bow in [her]101-birdalone hand and cast [her]101-birdalone quiver on [her]101-birdalone back , and went [her]101-birdalone ways into [the wood]348-the wood , and forgat not the tress of [Habundia]106-habundia 's hair ; but [she]101-birdalone had no need to use it , for when [she]101-birdalone was come to [the Oak of [Tryst]13-tryst]12-the oak of tryst , straightway came [Habundia]106-habundia forth from the thicket , and now so like to [Birdalone]101-birdalone that it was a wonder , for as [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend [she]101-birdalone bare bow and quiver , and green gown trussed up till [her]446-her friend knees were naked .

So [they]779-they kissed and embraced , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone wept upon [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend 's bosom , but was ashamed of the words which would have told [her]101-birdalone of [her]101-birdalone case . Then [Habundia]106-habundia set [her]446-her friend down upon the greensward , and sat down beside [her]446-her friend , and caressed [her]446-her friend and soothed [her]446-her friend ; then [she]106-habundia smiled on [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and said : [Thy]101-birdalone tale is partly told without words , and [I]0-i would weep for [thee]101-birdalone if [I]0-i might shed tears . But [thou]101-birdalone mayest tell [me]0-i wherefore [thou]101-birdalone didst suffer this ; though forsooth [I]0-i have an inkling thereof . Hast [thou]101-birdalone happened on [[the witch]407-the witch 's ferry]782-the witch 's ferry ?

Even so it was , [sister]783-sister , quoth [Birdalone]101-birdalone . And therewith [she]106-habundia plucked up heart , and told [her]446-her friend all the tale of the vanishing of [her]106-habundia body and the skin - changing . And [Habundia]106-habundia answered : Well then , there is this to be said , that sooner or later this must have happened , for thereby lieth [thy]101-birdalone road of escape ; wherefore it is better sooner than later . But tell [me]0-i again : was [she]106-habundia fierce and rough in words with [thee]101-birdalone ? for what [she]106-habundia said to [thee]101-birdalone [thou]101-birdalone hast not yet told [me]0-i . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : In [her]106-habundia first fury , when [she]106-habundia was like to have slain [me]0-i , [she]106-habundia had no words , nought but wolfish cries . But thereafter [she]106-habundia spake unto [me]0-i strangely , yet neither fiercely nor roughly ; nay , it seemed to [me]0-i as if almost [she]106-habundia loved [me]0-i . And more than almost [she]106-habundia besought [me]0-i rather than commanded [me]0-i not to flee from [her]106-habundia . And [wert]784-wert [thou]101-birdalone beguiled by [her]106-habundia soft speech ? said [Habundia]106-habundia . Nowise to cast aside [my]0-i hope of escape , nay , not even in that hour , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; but amidst all the confusion and terror somewhat was [I]0-i moved to compassion on [her]106-habundia .

Spake [Habundia]106-habundia , looking anxiously on [her]106-habundia : Dost [thou]101-birdalone deem that [thou]101-birdalone art somewhat cowed by what [she]106-habundia hath done to [thee]101-birdalone ? Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and flushed very red : Oh no , no ! Nought save death or bonds shall come betwixt [me]0-i and [my]0-i utmost striving for escape . That is better than well , said [Habundia]106-habundia ; but again , canst [thou]101-birdalone have patience a little , and be wary and wise the while ? So meseemeth , said [the maiden]406-the maiden . Said [Habundia]106-habundia : Again it is well . Now is the summer beginning to wane , and by [my]0-i rede [thou]101-birdalone shalt not try the flight until May is come again and well - nigh worn into June ; for [thou]101-birdalone wilt be bigger then , [little sister]786-little sister , and tidings are waxing that shall get matters ready for [thy]101-birdalone departure : moreover , [thou]101-birdalone must yet learn what [thou]101-birdalone hast to do meanwhile , and thereof shall [I]0-i tell [thee]101-birdalone somewhat as now . For [that boat]787-that boat , the thing which [thou]101-birdalone didst find , and for which [thou]101-birdalone didst suffer , is called the Sending Boat , and therein [[thy]101-birdalone mistress]564-thy mistress fareth time and again , [I]0-i deem to seek to some other of [her]564-thy mistress kind , but [I]0-i know not unto whom , or whereto . Hast [thou]101-birdalone noted of [her]564-thy mistress that whiles [she]564-thy mistress goeth away privily by night and cloud ? Yea , verily , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and this is one of the things which heretofore hath made [me]0-i most afraid . Said [Habundia]106-habundia : Well now , that [she]564-thy mistress wendeth somewhither in this ferry [I]0-i wot ; but as [I]0-i wot not whither , so also [I]0-i know not what [she]564-thy mistress doth with the Sending Boat to make it obey [her]564-thy mistress ; whereas , though [I]0-i know all things of [the wood]348-the wood , [I]0-i know but little of [the lake]369-the lake . Wherefore , though there be peril to [thee]101-birdalone therein , follow [her]564-thy mistress twice or thrice when [she]564-thy mistress riseth up for this faring , and note closely what is [her]564-thy mistress manner of dealing with the said Sending Boat , so that [thou]101-birdalone mayst do in like wise . Wilt [thou]101-birdalone risk the smart and the skin - changing , or even if it were the stroke of the knife , to gather this wisdom ? And thereafter [thou]101-birdalone shalt come hither and tell [me]0-i how [thou]101-birdalone hast sped . With a good heart will [I]0-i , [dear sister]791-dear sister , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone .

Then [Habundia]106-habundia kissed [her]791-dear sister and said : It is a joy to [me]0-i to see [thee]791-dear sister so valiant , but herein may [I]0-i help [thee]791-dear sister somewhat ; here is a gold finger- ring , see [thou]101-birdalone ! fashioned as a serpent holding [his]792-his tail in [his]792-his mouth ; whenso [thou]101-birdalone goest on this quest , set [thou]101-birdalone this same ring on the middle finger of [thy]101-birdalone left hand , and say [thou]101-birdalone above [thy]101-birdalone breath at least :

To left and right , Before , behind , Of [me]0-i be sight As of the wind !

And nought then shall be seen of [thee]101-birdalone even by [one who standeth close beside]793-one who standeth close beside . But wear not the ring openly save at such times , or let [the witch]407-the witch have sight thereof ever , or [she]407-the witch will know that [thou]101-birdalone hast met [me]0-i . Dost [thou]101-birdalone understand , and canst [thou]101-birdalone remember ?

Laughed [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and took the ring and set it on [her]101-birdalone finger , and spake aloud even as [Habundia]106-habundia had given [her]101-birdalone the words . Then quoth [Habundia]106-habundia , laughing : Now have [I]0-i lost [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend and [sister]783-sister , for [thou]101-birdalone art gone , [Birdalone]101-birdalone . Take off the ring , sweetling , and get [thee]101-birdalone to thine hunting , for if [thou]101-birdalone come [home]387-home empty - handed there will be flyting awaiting [thee]101-birdalone , or worse .

So [Birdalone]101-birdalone took off the ring and came back to sight again laughing ; then [the wood - woman]531-the wood - woman kissed [her]101-birdalone and turned [her]531-the wood - woman heels to [her]101-birdalone , and was gone ; but [Birdalone]101-birdalone strung [her]101-birdalone bow , and got to [her]101-birdalone woodcraft , and presently had a brace of hares , wherewith [she]101-birdalone went back [home]387-home to [the dame]415-the dame ; who indeed girded at [her]101-birdalone for [her]101-birdalone sloth , and [her]101-birdalone little catch in so long a while ; but there it ended .

CHAPTER XIV . OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone 'S FISHING[349-the witch - wife]

Now were the days wearing toward wheat - harvest , and nought befel to tell of , save that on a morn [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife called [Birdalone]101-birdalone to [her]349-the witch - wife , and said : Now is little to be done till the wheat is ready for the hook , and [thy]101-birdalone days are idle ; or what is that word that fell from [thee]101-birdalone that other day , that there be good swims for fish about the eyots ? Canst [thou]101-birdalone swim across bearing thine angle , and back again therewith , and [thy]101-birdalone catch withal ? Yea , certes , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone gaily ; with one hand [I]0-i may swim gallantly , or with [my]0-i legs alone , if [I]0-i stir [mine]0-i arms ever so little . [I]0-i will go straightway if [thou]101-birdalone wilt , [lady]504-lady ; but give [me]0-i a length of twine so that [I]0-i may tie [my]0-i catch about [my]0-i middle when [I]0-i swim back again .

Therewith [she]504-lady went forth lightly to fetch [her]504-lady angle , which was in [a shed without]803-a shed without ; but just as [she]504-lady took it in [her]504-lady hand , a sudden thought came to [her]504-lady , so wary as [she]504-lady was grown . [She]504-lady undid the bosom of [her]504-lady gown , and took forth [her]504-lady serpent - ring ; for [she]504-lady bore it next to [her]504-lady skin , made fast to the bosom of [her]504-lady smock ; but now [she]504-lady hid it carefully in the thickest of [her]504-lady brow - hair , which was very thick and soft . Withal the tress of [Habundia]106-habundia 's hair [she]504-lady bore ever mingled with [her]504-lady own .

No sooner had [she]504-lady done it , but [she]504-lady was glad ; for [she]504-lady heard [the dame]415-the dame calling [her]504-lady , who , when [she]504-lady came to [the house]325-the house - door , spake and said : Now shall [I]0-i fare with [thee]504-lady down to [the water]361-the water , and look to [thy]504-lady garments lest they be fouled by some straying beast . And therewith [she]504-lady looked curiously on [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and knit [her]504-lady brows when [she]504-lady saw that [the maiden]406-the maiden changed countenance in nowise .

Down to [the water]361-the water went [they]809-they , and [the witch]407-the witch sat down close to where [Birdalone]101-birdalone should take [the water]361-the water , and watched [her]406-the maiden do off [her]406-the maiden raiment , and eyed [her]406-the maiden keenly when [she]406-the maiden was bare , but said nought . [Birdalone]101-birdalone turned [her]101-birdalone head as [she]101-birdalone stood knee - deep , and said : How long shall [I]0-i abide , [lady]504-lady , if [I]0-i have luck ? As long as [thou]813-thou wilt , said [the dame]415-the dame : most like [I]0-i shall be gone by then [thou]813-thou comest back , even if [thou]813-thou be away no long while .

Fell [Birdalone]101-birdalone to swimming then , and when [she]101-birdalone was more than half over , [the witch , stirring no more than need was]815-the witch , stirring no more than need was , got hold of [her]101-birdalone raiment , which was but the old grey coat over a smock , and ransacked it , but found nought , as well [ye]816-ye may wot . And when [she]815-the witch , stirring no more than need was had done , [she]815-the witch , stirring no more than need was sat down again in heavy mood as it seemed , and watched [Birdalone]101-birdalone swimming , and when [she]815-the witch , stirring no more than need was beheld [her]101-birdalone body come forth out of the water , and pass out of sight amongst the flowers of [the eyot]644-the eyot , [she]815-the witch , stirring no more than need was arose and went [her]815-the witch , stirring no more than need was ways [home]387-home .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone looked through the willow - boughs , and saw [her]101-birdalone turn away ; then [she]101-birdalone fared to [her]101-birdalone fishing with a smile , and soon had plenteous catch from under the willow - boughs . Then , whereas the day was very calm and fair , and [the dame]415-the dame had given [her]101-birdalone holiday , [she]101-birdalone wandered about [the eyot]644-the eyot , and most in a little wood of berry - trees , as quicken and whitebeam and dog - wood , and sported with the birds , who feared [her]101-birdalone not , but came and sat on [her]101-birdalone shoulders , and crept about [her]101-birdalone feet . [She]101-birdalone went also and stood a while on [the southern shore]821-the southern shore , and looked on the wide water dim in the offing under the hot - weather haze , and longed to be gone beyond it . Then [she]101-birdalone turned away , and to [the other shore]822-the other shore , and gat [her]101-birdalone fish and strung them on the string , and made them fast to [her]101-birdalone middle , and so took the water back again to [the yellow strand]823-the yellow strand , where now was [no one]824-no one awaiting [her]101-birdalone . But before [she]101-birdalone did on [her]101-birdalone garments , [she]101-birdalone looked on them , and saw that they lay not as [she]101-birdalone had left them , whereby [she]101-birdalone knew well that [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife had handled them .

Amidst all this the day was wearing to an end , and again [she]101-birdalone saw the smoke of the cooking - fire going up into the air from the chimney of [the house]325-the house ; and [she]101-birdalone smiled ruefully , thinking that [the witch]407-the witch might yet find an occasion for ransacking [her]101-birdalone raiment . But [she]101-birdalone plucked up heart , and came [home]387-home with [her]101-birdalone catch , and [the dame]415-the dame met [her]101-birdalone with a glum face , and neither praised [her]101-birdalone nor blamed [her]101-birdalone , but took the fish silently . Such ending had that day .

CHAPTER XV . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone WEARETH [HER]101-birdalone SERPENT - RING

After this [she]101-birdalone went once and again fishing on to [Green Eyot]8-green eyot by the bidding of [the dame]415-the dame , who went not again to [the shore]358-the shore with [her]101-birdalone . These times [she]101-birdalone had half a mind to go see [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , but durst not , lest the thing itself might have life enough to tell of [her]101-birdalone .

And now was come the time of wheat - harvest , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone must wear [her]101-birdalone days swinking in [the acre - land]467-the acre - land , clad but in smock and shoes ; and the toil was hard , and browned [her]101-birdalone skin and hardened [her]101-birdalone hands , but it irked [her]101-birdalone not , for [the witch]407-the witch let [her]101-birdalone work all alone , and it was holiday unto [the maiden]406-the maiden if [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress were not anigh , despite those words which had somewhat touched [her]101-birdalone heart that other day .

But when wheat - getting was done , there was again rest for [her]101-birdalone body , and swimming withal and fishing from the eyot by [the witch]407-the witch 's leave . And again by [her]101-birdalone own leave [she]101-birdalone went to seek [Habundia]106-habundia in [the wood]348-the wood , and spent a happy hour with [her]106-habundia , and came back with a fawn which [she]101-birdalone had shot , and so but barely saved [her]101-birdalone skin from the twig - shower . Then yet again [she]101-birdalone went into [the wood]348-the wood on [the witch]407-the witch 's errand as well as [her]101-birdalone own , and was paid by [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend 's sweet converse , and by nought else save the grudging girding of [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress .

But on a night when September was well in , and the sky was moonless and overcast , somewhat before midnight [the dame]415-the dame came and hung over [Birdalone]101-birdalone as [she]101-birdalone lay abed , and watched to see if [she]101-birdalone waked ; forsooth [the witch]407-the witch 's coming had waked [her]101-birdalone ; but even so [she]101-birdalone was wary , and lay still , nor changed [her]101-birdalone breathing . So [the witch]407-the witch turned away , but even therewith [Birdalone]101-birdalone made a shift to get a glimpse of [her]407-the witch , and this [she]101-birdalone saw thereby , that the semblance of [her]407-the witch was changed , and that [she]407-the witch bore the self - same skin wherewith [she]407-the witch had come to [Utterhay]3-utterhay , and which [she]407-the witch had worn twice or thrice afterwards when [she]407-the witch had an errand thither .

[The witch]407-the witch now glided swiftly to the door , and out into the night . [Birdalone]101-birdalone lay still a little , lest [she]101-birdalone should fall into a trap , and then arose very quietly and did on [her]101-birdalone smock , which lay ever under [her]101-birdalone pillow with the ring sewn thereto again , and so went out adoors also , and deemed [she]101-birdalone saw [the witch]407-the witch some way on ahead ; but it was nothing for [her]101-birdalone light feet to overtake [her]101-birdalone . So [she]101-birdalone stayed to take the ring from [her]101-birdalone smock , and set it on [her]101-birdalone finger ; then in a low voice [she]101-birdalone said :

To left and right , Before , behind , Of [me]0-i be sight As of the wind !

Then boldly [she]101-birdalone sped on , and was soon close on the heels of [the witch]407-the witch , who made [her]407-the witch way to [the edge of [the lake]369-the lake]849-the edge of the lake , and then turned east , and went even as [Birdalone]101-birdalone had gone when [she]101-birdalone came across [the Sending Boat]16-the sending boat .

So fared [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife straight to [the creek - side]852-the creek - side , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone must needs stick close to [her]349-the witch - wife , or [she]349-the witch - wife had known nought , so black was the night amongst the alder - boughs . But [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife fumbled about a while when [she]349-the witch - wife was stayed by [the creek]687-the creek , and presently drew somewhat from under [her]349-the witch - wife cloak , and [the maiden]406-the maiden saw that [she]349-the witch - wife was about striking flint upon steel , and quaked somewhat , lest [her]349-the witch - wife charm had played [her]349-the witch - wife false . Presently the tinder quickened , and [the dame]415-the dame had lighted a lantern , which [she]415-the dame held up , peering all about ; and full [she]415-the dame looked on the place whereas was [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and made no show of seeing [her]415-the dame , though well - nigh [the maiden]406-the maiden looked for it to see [her]415-the dame drop the lantern and spring on [her]415-the dame .

Now [the witch , holding the lantern aloft]858-the witch , holding the lantern aloft , steps over the gunwale of [the boat]859-the boat , and sits down on the thwart ; and it was a near thing but that [Birdalone]101-birdalone followed [her]858-the witch , holding the lantern aloft into [the boat]859-the boat , but [she]101-birdalone feared the getting forth again , so [she]101-birdalone but hung over it as close as [she]101-birdalone might . Then [she]101-birdalone saw [the witch]407-the witch draw out of [her]407-the witch girdle that sharp little knife which [Birdalone]101-birdalone had seen raised against [her]101-birdalone own throat ; and then [the witch]407-the witch bared [her]407-the witch arm , and pricked it till the blood sprang from that barren white skin ; thereat [she]407-the witch stood up , and went to the bows of [the craft]694-the craft and hung over them , and drew [her]407-the witch arm to and fro over the stem to bloody it ; and went thereafter to the stern , and took blood into [her]407-the witch right hand and passed it over the place of the steerage for there was no rudder and came back and sat down on the thwart again ; and , so far as [Birdalone]101-birdalone might see , busied [herself]101-birdalone in staunching the little wound on [her]101-birdalone arm . Then deemed [Birdalone]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone knew what manner of paint was that which had made the rusty smears which [she]101-birdalone had seen on [the boat]859-the boat by daylight .

But now as [the witch]407-the witch sat there , a harsh voice began to stir in [her]407-the witch throat , and then words came out of [her]407-the witch , and [she]407-the witch sang in a crow 's croak :

The red raven - wine now Hast [thou]866-thou drunk , stern and bow ; Then wake and awake And the wonted way take ! The way of the Wender forth over the flood , For the will of [the Sender]867-the sender is blent with the blood .

Therewithal began [the boat]859-the boat to stir , and anon it glided forth out of [the creek]687-the creek into [the waters of [the lake]369-the lake]870-the waters of the lake , and the light of the lantern died , and it was but a minute ere [Birdalone]101-birdalone lost all sight of it . [She]101-birdalone abode a little longer , lest perchance boat and [witch]872-witch might come back on [her]101-birdalone hands , and then turned and went swiftly back again . [She]101-birdalone would have drawn off [her]101-birdalone ring straightway , but the thought came on [her]101-birdalone , that [she]101-birdalone had seen [the witch]407-the witch depart in [her]407-the witch second semblance ; how if [she]407-the witch were abiding [her]407-the witch at [home]387-home in [her]407-the witch wonted skin ? So [she]101-birdalone came to [the house]325-the house even as [she]101-birdalone was , and opened the door , and looked in , quaking ; but there was no image of [a child of Adam therein]876-a child of adam therein , and no living thing , save the cat drowsing before the fire ; wherefore [Birdalone]101-birdalone took the ring from [her]101-birdalone finger and went to the hearth , and stirred up the cat with [her]101-birdalone foot till [he]877-he arose and fell to rubbing [himself]877-he against [her]101-birdalone legs , and [she]101-birdalone was fain of [him]877-he .

Thereafter [she]101-birdalone made [her]101-birdalone ring fast to [her]101-birdalone smock again , and set the smock under [her]101-birdalone pillow as [her]101-birdalone wo nt was , and betook [herself]101-birdalone to bed , and fell asleep sweetly , leaving all troublous thoughts for the morrow ; and that the more as [she]101-birdalone was free of [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife for that night at least .

CHAPTER XVI . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone MEETETH [HABUNDIA]106-habundia AGAIN ; AND LEARNETH [HER]101-birdalone FIRST WISDOM OF [HER]101-birdalone

When morning was , [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose , and longed sore to go into [the wood]348-the wood to seek [Habundia]106-habundia again , but durst not , lest [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife should come to hand again earlier than might be looked for . So [she]101-birdalone abode quiet and did what was toward near about [the house]325-the house . All that day [the witch]407-the witch came not back , nor the next ; but the morrow thereafter , when [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose , [she]101-birdalone found the wonted aspect of [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress in [the wonted place]884-the wonted place , who , when [she]101-birdalone saw [the maiden]406-the maiden , greeted [her]101-birdalone , and was somewhat blithe with [her]101-birdalone ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone would have asked [her]101-birdalone leave to go to [the wood]348-the wood , but [she]101-birdalone trusted little in [her]101-birdalone unwonted soft mood ; which yet lasted so long that on the third day [she]101-birdalone [herself]101-birdalone bade [Birdalone]101-birdalone go take [her]101-birdalone pleasure in [the wood]348-the wood , and bear back with [her]101-birdalone what of venison [she]101-birdalone might .

Forthwith went [Birdalone]101-birdalone as glad as might be , and met [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend at [the Oak of Tryst]12-the oak of tryst , and told [her]446-her friend closely how [all]889-all had betid ; and [Habundia]106-habundia said : Here , then , [thou]890-thee hast learned how to sail [the lake]369-the lake . But hast [thou]890-thee learned enough to try the adventure and not to fail ? Even so [I]0-i deem , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; but this [I]0-i would say , that [meseemeth]892-meseemeth it better that [I]0-i follow [the witch]407-the witch down to [the boat]859-the boat one more time at least ; for this first time it was dark ; and moreover shall [I]0-i not be surer of the spell if [I]0-i hear it said oftener , lest it be not ever the same words ? What sayest [thou]890-thee ? [She]101-birdalone said : [Thou]890-thee art right herein , and , since the adventure may not be tried till next [June]100-june is at hand , there is time enough and to spare . And now for this hour that is [we]895-we need talk no more of it . Only , [my]0-i sweet , [I]0-i beseech [thee]890-thee be wary ; and above all suffer not [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife to set eye or hand on the ring . Truly [mine]0-i heart oft aches sorely for [thy]890-thee peril ; for therein the image of [thee]890-thee abideth rather as of [[my]0-i daughter]897-my daughter than [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend . Yea , now [thou]890-thee laughest , but kindly , so that the sound of [thy]890-thee laughter is as sweet music . But know that though [thou]890-thee art but [a young maiden]899-a young maiden , and [I]0-i in all wise like unto [thee]890-thee of aspect , yet have [I]0-i dwelt many and many a year upon [the earth]445-the earth , and much wisdom have learned . Trowest [thou]890-thee [me]0-i ?

[Yea]901-yea , [yea]901-yea , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , with all [my]0-i heart . Then [she]101-birdalone hung [her]101-birdalone head a while and kept silence , and thereafter looked up and spake : [I]0-i would ask [thee]890-thee a thing and crave somewhat of [thee]890-thee , as if [thou]890-thee wert verily [[my]0-i mother]902-my mother ; wilt [thou]890-thee grant it [me]0-i ? Yea , surely , [child]297-child , said [Habundia]106-habundia . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : This it is then , that [thou]890-thee wilt learn [me]0-i of [thy]890-thee wisdom . [Habundia]106-habundia smiled full kindly on [her]101-birdalone , and said : This of all things [I]0-i would have had [thee]890-thee ask ; and this day and now shall [we]904-we begin to open the book of [the earth]445-the earth before [thee]890-thee . For therein is [mine]0-i heritage and [my]0-i dominion . Sit by [me]0-i , [child]297-child , and hearken !

So [the maiden]406-the maiden sat down by [her]406-the maiden likeness under the oak , and began to learn [her]406-the maiden lesson . Forsooth forgotten is the wisdom , though the tale of its learning abideth , wherefore nought may [we]904-we tell thereof .

When it was done , [Birdalone]101-birdalone kissed [[her]101-birdalone wood - mother]908-her wood - mother and said : This is now the best day of [my]0-i life , this and the day when first [I]0-i saw [thee]890-thee . [I]0-i will come hither now many times before the day of [my]0-i departure . [Yea]909-yea , but , [sweet child]910-sweet child , said [Habundia]106-habundia , beware of [the witch]407-the witch and [her]407-the witch cruelty ; [I]0-i fear [me]0-i [she]407-the witch shall yet be grim toward [thee]890-thee . So will [I]0-i be wary , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , but [I]0-i will venture some little peril of pain but if [thou]912-thou forbid [me]0-i , [mother]740-mother . And [I]0-i pray [thee]890-thee by [thy]890-thee love to forbid [me]0-i not . And this [I]0-i pray [thee]890-thee the more , because after one of these grim times then mostly doth [she]407-the witch meddle the less with [me]0-i for a while , wherefore [I]0-i shall be the freer to come hither . [Habundia]106-habundia kissed [her]890-thee and embraced [her]890-thee , and said : Valiant art [thou]912-thou for [a young maiden]899-a young maiden , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , and [I]0-i would not refrain [thee]899-a young maiden more than [a father]916-a father would refrain [[his]916-a father young son]917-his young son from the strokes of [the tilt - yard]918-the tilt - yard . But [I]0-i pray [thee]899-a young maiden to forget not [my]0-i love , and [my]0-i sorrow for [thy]899-a young maiden grief .

Therewith [they]919-they sundered , and it was drawing toward evening . [Birdalone]101-birdalone sought catch , and brought [home]387-home venison to [the dame]415-the dame , who was yet blithe with [her]101-birdalone , and spake that evening as [she]101-birdalone eyed [her]101-birdalone : [I]0-i can not tell how it is , but [thou]899-a young maiden seemest changed unto [me]0-i , and lookest more towards [thy]899-a young maiden womanhood than even yesterday . [I]0-i mean the face of [thee]899-a young maiden , for [wert]922-wert [thou]899-a young maiden stripped , lean enough [I]0-i should see [thee]899-a young maiden , doubtless . But now look to it , [I]0-i beseech [thee]899-a young maiden , to be both deft and obedient , so that [I]0-i may be as kind to [thee]899-a young maiden as [I]0-i would be , and kinder than [I]0-i have been heretofore .

CHAPTER XVII . THE PASSING OF THE YEAR INTO WINTER

Wore the days now , till on a night of October , toward the end thereof , [the witch]407-the witch went a - night - tide to [the Sending Boat]16-the sending boat , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone followed [her]407-the witch as erst . This time the night was wild and windy , but the moon was high aloft and big , and all cloud save a few flecks was blown from off the heavens ; so that the night was as light as could be ; and even at [the tree - hung creek]924-the tree - hung creek it was easy to see all that was done . And so it was that [the witch]407-the witch did and spake in all wise as [she]407-the witch did before .

Another time , when November was well - nigh out , [the dame]415-the dame arose for [[her]415-the dame lake - faring]927-her lake - faring ; but this night the snow lay deep betwixt [house]928-house and [water]698-water , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone thought that it would scarce do to follow . Forsooth [she]101-birdalone knew not whether [her]101-birdalone feet would the less leave their print in the snow because they were not to be seen . When [she]101-birdalone asked [Habundia]106-habundia thereof , [she]101-birdalone laughed and said : Once more [thou]930-thou hast been wise , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , for though it had been no harder to put this might into [thy]930-thou ring , that whoso wore it should not touch the ground , yet it hath not been done .

It must be told , that in this while [Birdalone]101-birdalone went oft to [the Trysting Tree]17-the trysting tree , and called on [[her]101-birdalone mother]332-her mother as now [she]101-birdalone called [her]332-her mother to come to [her]101-birdalone , and ever more and more of wisdom [she]101-birdalone won thereby . Though [the witch]407-the witch was oft surly with [her]332-her mother , and spared not [her]332-her mother girding , yet , the needful work done , [she]332-her mother meddled little with [her]332-her mother . But on a day [she]332-her mother straightly banned [her]332-her mother the wood , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone went notwithstanding , and when [she]101-birdalone was there with [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother nought [she]101-birdalone told [her]101-birdalone thereof , but was blithe and merry beyond [her]101-birdalone wo nt . [She]407-the witch came back [home]387-home thereafter empty handed , and stepped into [the chamber]306-the chamber proudly and with bright eyes and flushed cheeks , though [she]407-the witch looked for nought save chastisement ; yea , it might be even the skin- changing . Forsooth [the witch]407-the witch was sitting crouched in [her]407-the witch chair with [her]407-the witch hands on the elbows and [her]407-the witch head thrust forward , like a wild beast at point to spring ; but when [her]407-the witch eye fell on [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]407-the witch faltered and drew back into [herself]407-the witch again , and muttered somewhat unheard ; but to [Birdalone]101-birdalone spake nought of good or bad .

Now was winter - tide upon [them]938-them , when there was nought to do in [field and acre]939-field and acre , and but a little in the byre . In years bygone , and even in the last one , [the witch]407-the witch had not spared [Birdalone]101-birdalone toil any the more , but had made errands for [her]101-birdalone amidst the snow and biting winds , or over [the lake]369-the lake when it was laid with ice . But now [she]407-the witch bade [her]101-birdalone to nought save what [she]407-the witch had a will to ; whereby [she]407-the witch lost but little , whereas [Birdalone]101-birdalone was well willing to strive against wind and weather and the roughness of [the winter earth]942-the winter earth , and overcome if [she]407-the witch might , so that all were well done that had to be done about the stead .

Still did [the witch]407-the witch give [her]407-the witch hard words and rail at [her]101-birdalone for the most part , but from the teeth outward only , and because [she]101-birdalone was wo nt thereto . Inwardly indeed [she]407-the witch began to fear [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and deemed that [she]407-the witch would one day have the mastery ; and this led [her]407-the witch into fierce and restless moods ; so that [she]407-the witch would sit staring at [the maiden]406-the maiden 's beauty handling [her]407-the witch knife withal , and scarce able to forbear [her]101-birdalone . And in such a mood [she]407-the witch once made occasion to chastise [her]101-birdalone as [her]407-the witch wo nt had been erst , and looked to see [Birdalone]101-birdalone rebel against [her]407-the witch ; but it fell out otherwise , for [Birdalone]101-birdalone submitted [herself]101-birdalone to [her]101-birdalone meekly and with a cheerful countenance . And this also was a terror to [the witch , who deemed , as indeed it was , that the purpose]945-the witch , who deemed , as indeed it was , that the purpose was growing in [her]407-the witch thrall . So from that time [she]407-the witch meddled with [her]101-birdalone no more . All this while , as may be thought , [Birdalone]101-birdalone went yet oftener to [the Oak of Tryst]12-the oak of tryst , despite frost and snow and wind , and gat much lore of [[her]101-birdalone wood - mother]908-her wood - mother , and learned wisdom abundantly . And [her]101-birdalone days were happy .

CHAPTER XVIII . OF [SPRING - TIDE]18-spring - tide AND THE MIND OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone

Now was the winter gone and the spring - tide come again , and with the blossoming of the earth blossomed [Birdalone]101-birdalone also . Nought sweeter of flesh might [she]101-birdalone be than erst , but there was now a new majesty grown into [her]101-birdalone beauty ; [her]101-birdalone limbs were rounded , [her]101-birdalone body fulfilled , [her]101-birdalone skin sleeked and whitened ; and if [[any mother]947-any mother 's son]948-any mother 's son had beheld [her]101-birdalone feet as [they]949-they trod [the meadow]510-the meadow besprinkled with saffron and daffodil , ill had it gone with [him]948-any mother 's son were [he]948-any mother 's son gainsaid the kisses of [them]949-they , though for the kissing had [he]948-any mother 's son fared the worse belike .

That spring - tide , amidst of [April]111-april , [she]101-birdalone followed [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife down to [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat for the third time ; and there went everything as erst , and [she]101-birdalone deemed now that the lesson was well learned , and that [she]101-birdalone was well - nigh as wise as [the witch]407-the witch [herself]101-birdalone therein .

But the day after [she]101-birdalone went about somewhat pensive , as though a troublous thought were on [her]101-birdalone ; and when , three days thereafter , [she]101-birdalone met [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother , [she]101-birdalone spake to [her]934-the wood - mother even as [they]955-they parted , and said : [Mother]740-mother , much wisdom hast [thou]957-thou learned [me]0-i , and now this at the last withal , that hitherto there has been shame in [my]0-i life ; and now fain were [I]0-i to be done with it . [Fair child]958-fair child , said [Habundia]106-habundia , little is the shame though [this woman]425-this woman hath had the upper hand of [thee]958-fair child and hath used [thee]958-fair child cruelly : how mightest [thou]958-fair child , [a child]245-a child , strive with [her]425-this woman ? But now [I]0-i see and know that there is an end of that ; that [she]425-this woman feareth [thee]958-fair child now , and will never again raise a hand against [thee]958-fair child save [thou]958-fair child fall wholly into [her]425-this woman power ; as [thou]958-fair child shalt not , [[my]0-i child]915-my child . Be comforted then for what is gone by ! Nay , [mother]740-mother , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , it is not that which troubleth [me]0-i ; for , as [thou]958-fair child sayest , what else might [I]0-i do ? But [thy]958-fair child wisdom which [thou]958-fair child hast set in [my]0-i heart hath learned [me]0-i that for these last months [I]0-i have been meeting guile with guile and lies with lies . And now will [I]0-i do so no more , lest [I]0-i become [a guileful woman]963-a guileful woman , with nought good in [me]0-i save the fairness of [my]0-i body . Wherefore hearken , [sweet mother]964-sweet mother ! What is done , is done ; but when it cometh to the day , which is speedily drawing nigh , that [I]0-i must part from [thee]740-mother , it may be for a long while , then will [I]0-i not fare to the Sending Boat by night and cloud and with hidden head , but will walk thither in broad day , and let that befall which must befall .

Changed then [Habundia]106-habundia 's face and became haggard and woeful , and [she]106-habundia cried out : O if [I]0-i could but weep , as [[ye]965-ye children of [Adam]103-adam]966-ye children of adam ! O [my]0-i grief and sorrow ! [Child]297-child , [child]297-child ! then will betide that falling into [her]106-habundia hands which [I]0-i spake of e'en now ; and then shall [this wretch]969-this wretch , [this servant of evil]970-this servant of evil , assuredly slay [thee]297-child there and then , or will keep [thee]969-this wretch to torment [thee]297-child till [thy]297-child life be but a slow death . Nay , nay , do as [I]0-i should do , and fare with hidden head , and [my]0-i ring on [thy]297-child finger . Or else , O [child]297-child , how wilt [thou]297-child hurt [me]0-i !

[Birdalone]101-birdalone wept ; but presently [she]101-birdalone fell to caressing [the mother]267-the mother 's hand , and said : This is [thy]297-child doing , wherein [thou]297-child hast made [me]0-i wise . Yet fear not : for [I]0-i deem that [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife will not slay [me]0-i , whereas [she]349-the witch - wife looketh to have some gain of [me]0-i ; moreover , in the evil of [her]349-the witch - wife heart is mingled some love toward [me]0-i , whereof , as erst [I]0-i told [thee]267-the mother , [I]0-i have a morsel of compassion . [Mother]740-mother , [she]349-the witch - wife will not slay [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i say that [she]349-the witch - wife shall not torment [me]0-i , for [I]0-i will compel [her]349-the witch - wife to slay [me]0-i else . It is [my]0-i mind that [she]349-the witch - wife will let [me]0-i go . Said [the mother]267-the mother : [Yea]976-yea , mayhappen , yet but as a bird with a string to its leg . If it be so , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , then let [my]0-i luck prevail over [her]349-the witch - wife guile ; as well it may be , since [I]0-i have known [thee]267-the mother , [O wise mother]977-o wise mother !

[The wood - wife]570-the wood - wife hung [her]570-the wood - wife head and spake nought for a while ; then [she]570-the wood - wife said : [I]0-i see that [thou]979-thou wilt have it so , and that there is something in thine heart which [we]980-we , who are [not children of [Adam]103-adam]981-not children of adam , may not understand ; yet once [wert]980-we [thou]979-thou more like unto [us]980-we . Now all [I]0-i may say is , that [thou]979-thou must rule in this matter , and that [I]0-i am sad .

Then [she]570-the wood - wife looked down again and presently raised a brighter face , and said : Belike all shall be better than [I]0-i thought . Then [she]570-the wood - wife kissed [Birdalone]101-birdalone and [they]982-they parted for that time .

CHAPTER XIX . [THEY]982-they BID FAREWELL , [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone AND [THE WOOD - MOTHER]934-the wood - mother

Now [April]111-april was gone , and [May]112-may was come with the thorn a - blossoming , and there was [Birdalone]101-birdalone waxing still in loveliness . And now [the witch]407-the witch had left all girding at [her]407-the witch even , and spake to [her]407-the witch but little , save when [she]407-the witch needs must . But to [Birdalone]101-birdalone it seemed that [she]101-birdalone watched [her]407-the witch exceeding closely .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone went oft to [the wood]348-the wood , and learned yet more of lore : but of the matter of the Departure , how it was to be gone about [they]982-they spake no more , and great was the love betwixt [them]982-they .

At last when [May]112-may was worn nigh to [June]100-june came [Birdalone]101-birdalone to [the Oak of Tryst]12-the oak of tryst , and found [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother there ; and when [they]982-they had talked a while , but ever from the teeth out , spake [Habundia]106-habundia : Though [thou]987-thou be now the wiser of [us]982-they two maybe , yet have [I]0-i wisdom to wot that this is the hour of [our]982-they sundering , and that to - morrow [thou]987-thou wilt try the adventure of [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat : is it not so ? [Yea]989-yea , [mother]740-mother , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; [I]0-i bid [thee]740-mother farewell now : woe is [me]0-i therefor ! Said [Habundia]106-habundia : And [thou]987-thou wilt deliver [thyself]991-thyself into the hands of [the witch]407-the witch , wilt [thou]987-thou , as [thou]987-thou saidst that other day ? Quoth [Birdalone]101-birdalone : Is it not wisdom , [dear mother]993-dear mother , if [I]0-i trust in [my]0-i goodhap ? Alas , said [the mother]267-the mother , it may be so when all is said . But O [my]0-i sad heart ! and how [I]0-i fear for [thee]740-mother !

[[My]0-i mother]902-my mother , [[my]0-i mother]902-my mother ! said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , that [I]0-i should make the days grievous unto [thee]740-mother ! and [thou]987-thou who hast made [my]0-i days so joyous ! But now canst [thou]987-thou not say of [thy]987-thou wisdom that [we]997-we shall meet again ?

[The wood - woman]531-the wood - woman sat down , and let [her]531-the wood - woman head fall over [her]531-the wood - woman knees , and was silent a long while ; then [she]531-the wood - woman rose up and stood before [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and said : Yea , [we]997-we shall meet again , howsoever it may be . Let [us]997-we depart with that sweet word in the air between [us]997-we . Yet first [thou]987-thou shalt give [me]0-i a tress of thine hair , as [I]0-i did to [thee]740-mother when first [we]997-we met ; for by means of it may [I]0-i know to - morrow how [thou]987-thou hast sped .

Even so did [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and this was the end of [their]997-we talk , save broken words of lamentation as [they]997-we said farewell . And therewith for that while [they]997-we sundered .

CHAPTER XX . OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone AND [THE SENDING BOAT

Birdalone]101-birdalone woke up in the morning , and arose and clad [herself]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone saw not [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife in [the chamber]306-the chamber , though [her]101-birdalone bed looked as if it had been slept in . [Birdalone]101-birdalone accounted little thereof , whereas [the dame]415-the dame would oft go on one errand or another much betimes in the morning . Yet was [she]101-birdalone somewhat glad , for [she]101-birdalone was nowise wishful for a wrangle with [her]415-the dame . [Withal]114-withal , despite [her]101-birdalone valiancy , as may well be thought , [she]101-birdalone was all a - flutter with hopes and fears , and must needs refrain [her]101-birdalone body from overmuch quaking and restlessness if [she]101-birdalone might .

Now [she]101-birdalone mingled the tress of [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother 's hair with [her]101-birdalone own hair , but deemed it nought perilous to leave the ring yet sewn to [her]101-birdalone smock : [she]101-birdalone set some deal of bread and flesh in [her]101-birdalone scrip , lest [her]101-birdalone voyage should be long , and then all simply stepped over the threshold of [the House of [[her]101-birdalone Captivity]1004-her captivity]1003-the house of her captivity .

[She]101-birdalone went straight to [the strand aforesaid]1005-the strand aforesaid , seeing nought of [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife by the way ; and when [she]101-birdalone came [there]232-there , was about to turn straightway to [her]101-birdalone left hand down to [the creek]687-the creek , when it came into [her]101-birdalone mind that [she]101-birdalone would first swim over to [Green Eyot]8-green eyot for this last of times . For the eyot indeed [she]101-birdalone loved , and deemed it [her]101-birdalone own , since never had [her]101-birdalone evil dream , [the witch]407-the witch , set foot thereon . Moreover , [she]101-birdalone said to [herself]101-birdalone that [the cool lake]1010-the cool lake would allay the fever of [her]101-birdalone blood , and make [her]101-birdalone flesh firmer and less timorous for the adventure . And again , that if [the witch]407-the witch should see [her]101-birdalone from afar , as [she]101-birdalone could scarce fail to do , [she]101-birdalone would deem [the maiden]406-the maiden was about [her]101-birdalone wonted morning swimming , and would be the less like to spy on [her]101-birdalone .

So now , when [she]101-birdalone had let [her]101-birdalone garments slip from off [her]101-birdalone on to the sand close to [the water]361-the water 's edge , [she]101-birdalone stood a while , with [her]101-birdalone feet scarce covered by the little ripple of [the bight]1014-the bight , to be a token of safety to [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress . To say sooth , now it was come so nigh to the deed , [she]101-birdalone shrank aback a little , and was fain to dally with the time , and , if it might be , thrust something of no import betwixt [her]101-birdalone and the terror of the last moment .

Now [she]101-birdalone took [the water]361-the water , and rowed strongly with [her]101-birdalone lovely limbs till [she]101-birdalone came to the eyot , and there [she]101-birdalone went aland , and visited [every place which had been kind to [her]101-birdalone]1017-every place which had been kind to her ; and kissed the trees and flowers that had solaced [her]101-birdalone , and once more drew the birds and rabbits to sport with [her]101-birdalone ; till suddenly it came into [her]101-birdalone head that the time was wearing overfast . Then [she]101-birdalone ran down to [the water]361-the water and plunged in , and swam over to [the strand]660-the strand as fast as [she]101-birdalone might , and came aland there , thinking of nothing less than what had befallen .

For lo ! when [she]101-birdalone looked around for [her]101-birdalone raiment and [her]101-birdalone scrip , it was nowhere to be seen ; straightway then it came into [her]101-birdalone mind , as in one flash , that this was [the witch]407-the witch 's work ; that [she]407-the witch had divined this deed of the flight , and had watched [her]101-birdalone , and taken the occasion of [her]101-birdalone nakedness and absence that [she]407-the witch might draw [her]101-birdalone back to [the House of Captivity]1021-the house of captivity . And this the more as the precious ring was sewn to [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's smock , and [the witch]407-the witch would have found it there when [she]407-the witch handled the raiment .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone wasted no time in seeking for the lost ; [she]101-birdalone looked down on to the smooth sand , and saw there footprints which were not [her]101-birdalone own , and all those went straight back [home]387-home to [the house]325-the house . Then [she]101-birdalone turned , and for one moment of time looked up toward [the house]325-the house , and saw plainly [the witch]407-the witch come out adoors , and the sun flashed from something bright in [her]101-birdalone hand .

Then indeed [she]101-birdalone made no stay , but set off running at [her]101-birdalone swiftest along the water - side toward [the creek]687-the creek and [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat . As is aforesaid [she]101-birdalone was as fleet - foot as a deer , so but in a little space of time [she]101-birdalone had come to [the creek]687-the creek , and leapt into [the boat]859-the boat , panting and breathless . [She]101-birdalone turned and looked hastily along the path [her]101-birdalone feet had just worn , and deemed [she]101-birdalone saw a fluttering and flashing coming along it , but some way off ; yet was not sure , for [her]101-birdalone eyes were dizzy with the swiftness of [her]101-birdalone flight and the hot sun and the hurry of [her]101-birdalone heart . Then [she]101-birdalone looked about a moment confusedly , for [she]101-birdalone called to mind that in [her]101-birdalone nakedness [she]101-birdalone had neither knife , nor scissors , nor bodkin to let [her]101-birdalone blood withal . But even therewith close to hand [she]101-birdalone saw hanging down a stem of half - dead briar - rose with big thorns upon it ; [she]101-birdalone hastily tore off a length thereof and scratched [her]101-birdalone left arm till the blood flowed , and stepped lightly first to stem and then to stern , and besmeared them therewith . Then [she]101-birdalone sat down on the thwart and cried aloud :

The red raven - wine now Hast [thou]1031-thou drunk , stern and bow ; Then wake and awake And the wonted way take ! The way of [the Wender]1032-the wender forth over [the flood]1033-the flood , For the will of [the Sender]867-the sender is blent with the blood .

[Scarce]115-scarce had [she]101-birdalone time to wonder if [the boat]859-the boat would obey [her]101-birdalone spell ere it began to stir beneath [her]101-birdalone , and then glided out into [the lake]369-the lake and took its way over [the summer ripple]1037-the summer ripple , going betwixt [Green Eyot]8-green eyot and [the mainland]1038-the mainland , as if to weather [the western ness of the eyot]1039-the western ness of the eyot : and it went not a stonecast from [the shore of [the said mainland]1041-the said mainland]1040-the shore of the said mainland .

Hither to meet it now cometh [the witch]407-the witch , running along [the bank]1043-the bank , [her]407-the witch skirts flying wild about [her]407-the witch , and a heavy short - sword gleaming in [her]407-the witch hand . [Her]407-the witch furious running [she]101-birdalone stayed over against [the boat]859-the boat , and cried out in a voice broken for lack of breath :

Back over the flood To [the house]325-the house by [the wood]348-the wood ! Back unto [thy]101-birdalone rest In [the alder nest]1047-the alder nest ! For the blood of [the Sender]867-the sender lies warm on [thy]101-birdalone bow , And the heart of [the Wender]1032-the wender is weary as now .

But [she]101-birdalone saw that [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat heeded [her]101-birdalone words nothing , whereas it was not [her]101-birdalone blood that had awakened it , but [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's . Then cried out [the witch]407-the witch : [O child]1052-o child , [child]297-child ! say the spell and come back to [me]0-i ! to [me]0-i , who have reared [thee]297-child and loved [thee]297-child and hoped in [thee]297-child ! O come back !

But how should [Birdalone]101-birdalone heed [her]101-birdalone prayer ? [She]101-birdalone saw the sax ; and withal had [her]101-birdalone heart forgotten , [her]101-birdalone flesh might well remember . [She]101-birdalone sat still , nor so much as turned [her]101-birdalone head toward [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife .

Then came wild yelling words from [the witch]407-the witch 's mouth , and [she]101-birdalone cried : Go then , naked and outcast ! Go then , [naked fool]1056-naked fool ! and come back hither after [thou]1057-thee hast been under the hands of the pitiless ! Ah , it had been better for [thee]1057-thee had [I]0-i slain [thee]1057-thee ! And therewith [she]101-birdalone whirled the sax over [her]101-birdalone head and cast it at [Birdalone]101-birdalone . But now had [the boat]859-the boat turned its head toward [the ness of [Green Eyot]8-green eyot]1059-the ness of green eyot and was swiftly departing , so that [Birdalone]101-birdalone but half heard the last words of [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife , and the sax fell flashing into the water far astern .

There [the witch]407-the witch stood tossing [her]407-the witch arms and screaming , wordless ; but no more of [her]407-the witch saw [Birdalone]101-birdalone , for [the boat]859-the boat came round about [the ness of [Green Eyot]8-green eyot]1059-the ness of green eyot , and there lay [the Great Water under the summer heavens all wide and landless before [her]101-birdalone]1064-the great water under the summer heavens all wide and landless before her . And it was now noon of day .

Here ends the First Part of [the Water of [the Wondrous Isles]1-the wondrous isles]1065-the water of the wondrous isles , which is called Of [the House of Captivity]1021-the house of captivity . And now begins the Second Part , which is called Of [the Wondrous Isles]1-the wondrous isles .

THE SECOND PART : OF [THE WONDROUS ISLES]1-the wondrous isles

CHAPTER I. [THE FIRST ISLE]19-the first isle

So glided Birdalone over [the lake]369-the lake and was come forth from [the House of Captivity]1021-the house of captivity ; it might well be that [she]101-birdalone was but swimming unto death ; naked as [she]101-birdalone was , fireless , foodless , and helpless , at the mercy of mere sorcery . Yet [she]101-birdalone called to mind the word of [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother that [they]1070-they should meet again , and took heart thereby ; and [she]101-birdalone was glad in that [she]101-birdalone had had [her]101-birdalone will , and shaken off the guile and thraldom of [the witch]407-the witch . Much [she]101-birdalone thought of [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother , and loved [her]934-the wood - mother , and wondered had [she]101-birdalone yet sought into and seen [her]934-the wood - mother welfare by the burning of a hair of that tress of [hers]934-the wood - mother ; and therewith [she]101-birdalone looked on that tress of [Habundia]106-habundia 's hair and kissed it .

All day the Sending Boat sped on , and [she]101-birdalone saw [no land]1073-no land and nought to tell of . It was but wave and sky and the familiar fowl of [the lake]369-the lake , as coot , and mallard , and heron , and now and then a swift wood - dove going [her]101-birdalone ways from [shore]1075-shore to [shore]1075-shore ; two gerfalcons [she]101-birdalone saw also , an osprey , and a great ern on [his]1077-his errand high up aloft .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone waked in [her]101-birdalone loneliness till the day was spent , and somewhat worn of the night ; then [she]101-birdalone fell asleep for weariness ; but so it was , that before dusk [she]101-birdalone had deemed that a blue cloud lay before [her]101-birdalone in the offing which moved not .

[She]101-birdalone slept the short night through , and was awakened by [the boat]859-the boat smiting against something , and when [her]101-birdalone eyes opened [she]101-birdalone saw that [she]101-birdalone was come aland and that the sun was just risen . [She]101-birdalone stood up , and for the first minute wondered where [she]101-birdalone was , and [she]101-birdalone beheld [her]101-birdalone nakedness and knew not what it meant ; then [she]101-birdalone loosened [her]101-birdalone hair , and shook its abundance all about [her]101-birdalone , and thereafter [she]101-birdalone turned [her]101-birdalone eyes on [this new land]1079-this new land and saw that it was fair and goodly . The flowery grass came down to [the very water]1080-the very water , and first was [a fair meadow - land besprinkled with big ancient trees]1081-a fair meadow - land besprinkled with big ancient trees ; thence arose [slopes of vineyard]1082-slopes of vineyard , and [orchard]1083-orchard and [garden]1084-garden ; and , looking down on all , was [a great White House]1085-a great white house , carven and glorious . A little air of wind had awakened with the sunrise , and bore [the garden]1086-the garden sweetness down to [her]101-birdalone ; and warm it was after the chill of [the wide water]1087-the wide water . [No other land]1088-no other land could [she]101-birdalone see when [she]101-birdalone looked [lakeward thence]1089-lakeward thence .

[She]101-birdalone stepped ashore , and stood ankle - deep in [the sweet grass]1090-the sweet grass , and looked about [her]101-birdalone for a while , and saw no shape of [man astir]1091-man astir . [She]101-birdalone was yet weary , and stiff with abiding so long amongst the hard ribs of [the boat]859-the boat , so [she]101-birdalone laid [herself]101-birdalone down on the grass , and its softness solaced [her]101-birdalone ; and presently [she]101-birdalone fell asleep again .

CHAPTER II . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone FALLETH IN WITH NEW FRIENDS

When [she]101-birdalone next awoke , the sun was not yet high , and the morning young , yet [she]101-birdalone stood upon [her]101-birdalone feet much refreshed by that short slumber . [She]101-birdalone turned toward [the hill]1093-the hill and [the gay house]1094-the gay house , and saw one coming over [the meadow]510-the meadow to [her]101-birdalone , [a woman to wit , in a shining golden gown]1096-a woman to wit , in a shining golden gown , and as [she]101-birdalone drew nigh [Birdalone]101-birdalone could see that [she]101-birdalone was young and fair , tall , white - skinned and hazel - eyed , with long red hair dancing all about [her]101-birdalone as [she]101-birdalone tripped lightly and merrily over [the greensward]682-the greensward .

Now [she]101-birdalone comes up to [Birdalone]101-birdalone with wonder in [her]101-birdalone eyes , and greets [her]101-birdalone kindly , and asked [her]101-birdalone of [her]101-birdalone name , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone told it all simply ; and [the new - comer]518-the new - comer said : What errand hast [thou]1099-thou hither , that [thou]1099-thou art come thus naked and alone in [this ill - omened ferry]1100-this ill - omened ferry ? [Birdalone]101-birdalone trembled at [her]101-birdalone words , though [she]101-birdalone spake kindly to [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone said : It is a long story , but fate drave [me]0-i thereto , and misery , and [I]0-i knew not whither [I]0-i was bound . But is there no welcome for [me]0-i in [this lovely land]1101-this lovely land ? [I]0-i lack not deftness wholly ; and [I]0-i will be [a servant of [servants]1103-servants]1102-a servant of servants , and ask no better if it must be so . Said [the new - comer]518-the new - comer : Unto that mayst [thou]1099-thou come , but sore will be [thy]1099-thou servitude . [I]0-i fear [me]0-i [thy]1099-thou welcome here may be but evil . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : Wilt [thou]1099-thou not tell [me]0-i how so ? Quoth [that lady]1105-that lady : [We]1106-we know [[thy]1099-thou ferry]1107-thy ferry here , that it is the craft wherein cometh hither now and again [the sister of [[our]1106-we lady the Queen , into whose realm [thou]1099-thou art now come , and who liveth up in [the white palace yonder]1110-the white palace yonder , and whom [we]1106-we serve]1109-our lady the queen , into whose realm thou art now come , and who liveth up in the white palace yonder , and whom we serve]1108-the sister of our lady the queen , into whose realm thou art now come , and who liveth up in the white palace yonder , and whom we serve . And meseems [thou]1099-thou wilt not have come hither by [her]1105-that lady leave , or [thou]1099-thou wouldst be in other guise than this ; so that belike [thou]1099-thou wilt be [the runaway of [[thy]1099-thou mistress]564-thy mistress]1111-the runaway of thy mistress . Wherefore [I]0-i fear that [thou]1099-thou wilt be sent back to [[thy]1099-thou said mistress]1113-thy said mistress after a while , and that that while will be grievous to [thee]1099-thou , body and soul .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone 's heart sank , and [she]101-birdalone was pale and trembling ; but [she]101-birdalone said : [O dear lady]1114-o dear lady , might [I]0-i then depart as [I]0-i have come hither , without the wotting of [this Queen]1115-this queen ! after [thou]1099-thou hast given [me]0-i a morsel of bread , for [I]0-i am hungry . Said [the gold - clad one]1116-the gold - clad one , looking on [her]101-birdalone pitifully : Nay , [maiden]1117-maiden , [I]0-i can not choose but bring [thee]101-birdalone before [[our]1118-our mistress]1119-our mistress , whereas most like [she]1119-our mistress hath already seen [thee]101-birdalone from above there . For [she]1119-our mistress is far - sighted beyond the wo nt of [folk who be more manlike]1120-folk who be more manlike . But as for the bread , see [thou]1099-thou ! [I]0-i have brought a manchet in [my]0-i pouch , and cheese withal , as [I]0-i came hurrying ; for [I]0-i thought , [she]1119-our mistress will be hungry . And [she]1119-our mistress reached the victual out to [her]101-birdalone .
