And [Birdalone]101-birdalone took it and kissed [the golden lady]1121-the golden lady 's hands , and [she]101-birdalone might not refrain [her]101-birdalone tears , but wept as [she]101-birdalone ate .

Meanwhile [the golden lady]1121-the golden lady spake unto [her]101-birdalone and said : Nevertheless , [[thou]1099-thou poor maiden]1123-thou poor maiden , somewhat may be done for thine helping , and [I]0-i will presently speak to [[my]0-i sisters]1124-my sisters thereon , who are , both of [them]1124-my sisters , wiser than [I.]0-i [Sisters by blood]1125-sisters by blood are [we]1126-we not , but by love and fellowship . And [I]0-i doubt not but that as [we]1126-we go up into [the house]325-the house [we]1126-we shall happen upon [them]1124-my sisters in [the garden]1086-the garden . But now [I]0-i look upon [thee]1124-my sisters , how fair [a woman]250-a woman art [thou]1124-my sisters !

[Thou]1124-my sisters art kind and friendly , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , smiling amidst of [her]101-birdalone tears , might [I]0-i know by what name to call [so dear a woman]1130-so dear a woman ? [Thou]1124-my sisters shalt call [me]0-i [Aurea]116-viridis , said [the other]265-the other ; and [[my]0-i next sister]1132-my next sister is [Viridis]116-viridis , and the third , [Atra]117-atra ; for that is according to the hues of [our]1126-we raiment , and other names [we]1126-we have not now . And lo ! here cometh [Viridis]116-viridis over [the meadow]510-the meadow .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone looked , and saw a woman coming toward [them]1134-them clad all in green , with a rose - wreath on [her]1135-her head . And [she]1135-her drew nigh , and greeted [Birdalone]101-birdalone kindly , and [she]1135-her also was [a very beauteous woman]1136-a very beauteous woman ; not great of body , whereas [Aurea]116-viridis was tall and big - made , though excellently shapen . Light brown and goodly waved of hair was Viridis , [her]1135-her eyes brown , and rather long than great ; [her]1135-her lips full and ruddy , [her]1135-her cheeks soft and sweet and smooth , and as rosy - tinted pearl ; [her]1135-her hands small and delicate of fashion ; [her]1135-her whole body soft- shapen as an egg ; a kind , wheedling look [her]1135-her face bore .

When [she]1135-her had looked a while on [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]1135-her kissed [her]101-birdalone , and said : [I]0-i would [thou]1137-thou [wert]1138-we happier , for [thou]1137-thou art beauteous , and all but the evil must love [thee]1137-thou . Therewith [she]1135-her drew a cate from [her]1135-her pouch , and said : Eat somewhat , for [thou]1137-thou wilt be hungry ; and let [us]1138-we go meet [[our]1138-we other sister]1139-our other sister , who is wiser than [we]1138-we .

So [they]1138-we went , [all three of [them]1138-we]1140-all three of them , and came from off [the meadow]510-the meadow on to [the garden - slopes]1142-the garden - slopes , and at the entry thereof was come [Atra]117-atra to meet [them]1138-we ; [she]117-atra was clad all in black , [a tall , slim woman , with the grace of the willow - bough in the wind]1143-a tall , slim woman , with the grace of the willow - bough in the wind , with dark plenteous hair and grey hawk - eyes ; [her]117-atra skin privet - white , with but little red in [her]117-atra cheeks . [She]117-atra also greeted [Birdalone]101-birdalone kindly , but sadly withal . [She]117-atra gave [her]117-atra strawberries to eat laid on a big kale - blade ; and [she]117-atra said : [Sisters]1144-sisters , here are [we]1138-we hidden by the trees , and can not be seen from [the house]325-the house ; therefore [we]1138-we may sit [here]259-here for a minute or two , while [we]1138-we talk together as to what may perchance be done for the helping of [this unhappy maiden , who is so fair and lovely]1147-this unhappy maiden , who is so fair and lovely , and hath strayed into so ugly a trap . Then [she]117-atra said to [Birdalone]101-birdalone : [Thou]1148-thou must know , [poor wanderer]1149-poor wanderer , that [this Queen]1115-this queen , [[our]1138-we mistress]1119-our mistress , who is [sister to [the Witch Under the Wood]1153-the witch under the wood]1152-sister to the witch under the wood , is big and strong , well - made , and white - skinned , so that [she]117-atra deems [herself]117-atra [a Queen of all beauty]1154-a queen of all beauty : keen - eyed is [she]117-atra to see a fly where others would see nought smaller than a coney ; fine - eared withal ; wise in wizardry ; not altogether dull - witted , though [she]117-atra be proud , and crueller than the cruellest . But herein [she]117-atra faileth , that [her]117-atra memory is of the shortest for matters of the passing hour , albeit [she]117-atra remembers [her]117-atra spells and witch - songs over well . But other matters will scarce abide in [her]117-atra head for four and twenty hours . Wherefore , [sisters]1144-sisters , if [we]1138-we may keep [this maiden]1156-this maiden out of [her]117-atra sight after [she]117-atra hath seen [her]117-atra and given doom upon [her]117-atra till the dead of to - morrow night , [we]1138-we may perchance do some good for [her]117-atra ; and it is in [my]0-i mind that then [she]117-atra may do good for [us]1138-we also .

Now [they]1138-we rejoiced in this word of [Atra]117-atra the wise ; and [Atra]117-atra prayed [Birdalone]101-birdalone to tell [them]1138-we somewhat more of [her]117-atra story ; and [she]117-atra told [them]1138-we much ; but , whyso it were , [she]117-atra said nought concerning the wood - wife , whose outward semblance was the same as [hers]117-atra . Then [they]1138-we pitied [her]117-atra , and caressed [her]117-atra ; but [Atra]117-atra said : [We]1138-we must tarry here no more , but go straight up to [the lady]1157-the lady , or maybe [we]1138-we shall lose all .

So [they]1138-we went [their]1138-we ways and came into the pleasance , and trod the sweet greensward betwixt the garland flowers and the beauteous trees ; which now indeed , though [Birdalone]101-birdalone saw them all clear and over - clear , were become nought to [her]117-atra . [Those three]1158-those three also spake gently to [her]117-atra , and now and then asked [her]117-atra somewhat , as if to show [her]117-atra that [she]117-atra was one of [themselves]1158-those three ; but [she]117-atra spake not , or answered at random , and to say sooth scarce heard [their]1158-those three words : forsooth [she]117-atra was now become heart- sick , and was half dead for fear ; and [her]117-atra nakedness , which would have troubled [her]117-atra little across [the water]361-the water , was now grown a shame and a terror unto [her]117-atra , and every deal of [her]117-atra body quivered with the anguish thereof .

CHAPTER III . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone IS BROUGHT BEFORE [THE WITCH - WIFE]349-the witch - wife 'S [SISTER]118-sister[349-the witch - wife]

So came [they]1138-we at last to [the very house]1161-the very house , and whereas [it]1161-the very house stood high on the bent , a great stair or perron of stone went up to [it]1161-the very house , and was of much majesty . [They]1138-we went through [the porch]664-the porch , which was pillared and lovely , and into [a great hall most nobly builded]1163-a great hall most nobly builded , and at the other end thereof , on a golden throne raised upon a dais , sat [a big woman clad in red scarlet]1164-a big woman clad in red scarlet . [The three damsels]1165-the three damsels led [Birdalone]101-birdalone to some four paces of [the great lady]1166-the great lady , and then stood away from [her]101-birdalone , and left [her]101-birdalone standing there alone , [the scarlet - clad woman before [her]101-birdalone]1167-the scarlet - clad woman before her ; on the right and the left the tall pillars going up gleaming toward the roof , and about [her]101-birdalone feet the dark polished pavement , with the wallowing of strange beasts and great serpents and dragons all done on the coal- blue ground .

When [she]101-birdalone was so left alone , at first [she]101-birdalone tottered , and went nigh to falling ; but then came back some little heart to [her]101-birdalone , as [she]101-birdalone said to [herself]101-birdalone that now [she]101-birdalone should verily die once for all , and that no long while would be the passing from life into death . [She]101-birdalone looked up and beheld [the lady - witch]1168-the lady - witch , that [she]1168-the lady - witch was somewhat like to [[her]1168-the lady - witch sister]1169-her sister , white - skinned and of plenteous golden - hair as was [she]1168-the lady - witch , but younger of aspect , and nowise so ill - looked as that other had now become ; for somewhat well - shapen of body [she]101-birdalone was ; but [her]101-birdalone face forbidding ; [her]101-birdalone lower lip thrust out , [her]101-birdalone cheeks flaggy and drooping , [her]101-birdalone eyes little more than half open ; to be short , a face both proud , foolish , and cruel ; terrible indeed , sitting in judgment in that place on a shrinking naked creature .

Now [she]1168-the lady - witch spake ; and if there were no majesty or solemnity in the voice , there was ugly glee and malice therein ; but [she]1168-the lady - witch said to [those damsels]1170-those damsels : Is this the woman that [my]0-i keen eyes beheld come aland from [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister 's Sending Boat e'en now ? [Aurea]116-viridis knelt on one knee , and said : [Yea]1172-yea , so please [you]1168-the lady - witch , [[my]0-i lady]615-my lady .

Then said [the witch]407-the witch : Ho [thou]1175-thou ! Wilt [thou]1175-thou plead some errand hither from [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister ? Dost [thou]1175-thou deem [me]0-i so witless as not to know that if [she]1171-my sister had sent [thee]1175-thou hither [thou]1175-thou wouldst not have come in this plight ? Nay , [I]0-i know ; [thou]1175-thou hast stolen [thyself]1177-thyself from [her]1171-my sister : [thou]1175-thou art [a thief]1178-a thief , and as [a thief]1178-a thief shalt [thou]1175-thou be dealt with .

Spake [Birdalone]101-birdalone in a clear voice : No errand do [I]0-i feign from [[thy]1175-thou sister]561-thy sister , [lady]504-lady : when [I]0-i could bear [my]0-i life there no longer , [I]0-i took occasion to flee from [her]1171-my sister : this is all the tale . Yet once and again it hath been in [my]0-i mind that it was [[thy]1175-thou sister]561-thy sister who stole [me]0-i from [them]1183-them that loved [me]0-i .

Hah , thrall ! said [the lady]1157-the lady , [thou]1175-thou art bold ; [thou]1175-thou art over - bold , [thou]1175-thou naked wretch , to bandy words with [me]0-i . What heed [I]0-i [thy]1175-thou tale now [thou]1175-thou art under [my]0-i hand ? [Her]1157-the lady voice was cold rather than fierce , yet was there the poison of malice therein . But [Birdalone]101-birdalone spake : If [I]0-i be bold , [lady]504-lady , it is because [I]0-i see that [I]0-i have come into [the House of Death]1186-the house of death . [The dying]1187-the dying may well be bold .

[The House of Death]1186-the house of death ! cried [the stupid lady]1189-the stupid lady ; and wilt [thou]1175-thou call [[my]0-i noble house [the House of Death]1186-the house of death]1190-my noble house the house of death ? Now art [thou]1175-thou no longer bold , stripped thrall , but impudent .

Scorn rose into [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's heart at this word , but [she]101-birdalone refrained [her]101-birdalone , and spake : [I]0-i meant that [I]0-i have stirred the wrath in [thee]1175-thou , and that [thou]1175-thou wilt slay [me]0-i therefor ; and that it availeth not to crave mercy of [thee]1175-thou .

Laughed [the lady]1157-the lady : [Thou]1175-thou art [a fool]493-a fool , thrall , said [she]1157-the lady ; if a sparrow fled hither from [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister , [I]0-i should not wring its neck , but keep it for [her]1171-my sister . So shall [I]0-i do with [thee]1175-thou . [I]0-i shall not slay [thee]1175-thou , and so destroy [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister 's chattel ; nor shall [I]0-i spoil [thee]1175-thou , and spoil [her]1171-my sister possession . [I]0-i shall send [thee]1175-thou back unto [her]1171-my sister , the stolen thrall in [the stolen boat]1196-the stolen boat , when [I]0-i have learned [thee]1175-thou a lesson here . Forsooth it was for that cause [meseemeth]1197-meseemeth that [she]1171-my sister let [thee]1175-thou slip through [her]1171-my sister fingers , for [she]1171-my sister is wise enough to have stayed [thee]1175-thou from this holiday had [she]1171-my sister willed it . But [she]1171-my sister is tender - hearted , and kind , and soft , and might well deem that if [thy]1175-thou chastisement were done to [her]1171-my sister hand here , it were better done than by [her]1171-my sister mercy . Now , thrall , [I]0-i have spoken enough to [thee]1175-thou , or more than enough : get [thee]1175-thou back out of earshot !

CHAPTER IV . OF [THE WITCH]407-the witch 'S PRISON IN [THE WAILING - TOWER]7071-the wailing - tower[407-the witch]

[Birdalone]101-birdalone did as [she]101-birdalone was bidden , and [the witch]407-the witch called unto [her]101-birdalone Atra , who came and stood humbly on the footpace beside [her]101-birdalone , and held converse with [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress a while . Then [she]407-the witch went backward from [her]407-the witch a little , and then came to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and in a somewhat harsh voice bade [her]101-birdalone come with [her]101-birdalone . [Birdalone]101-birdalone followed [her]101-birdalone , quaking , and [they]1201-we came out of [the hall]1202-the hall and into [a long passage]1203-a long passage , which led to [a wide stair winding round a newel]1204-a wide stair winding round a newel ; and all was builded exceeding fair , had [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's heart suffered [her]101-birdalone eyes to see it ; but [her]101-birdalone flesh was weak , and quaked before the torment to come , so that [her]101-birdalone knees well- nigh failed [her]101-birdalone .

But now [Atra]117-atra lays a hand kindly on [her]101-birdalone shoulder and stays [her]101-birdalone , and says : Now meseems the walls of [the Wailing - Tower]20-the wailing - tower , for so it hight , have no ears to hear , and [we]1201-we may talk together . Wottest [thou]1205-thou why [I]0-i have brought [thee]1205-thou hither ? Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone in a faint voice : Hast [thou]1205-thou been bidden to whip [me]0-i ? And if [I]0-i had been so bidden , [dear maiden]1206-dear maiden , said [Atra]117-atra laughing , nowise would [I]0-i do it . Hold up [thine]1207-thine heart ! For all hath gone well so far , and now meseems betwixt [us]1201-we three [we]1201-we shall save [thee]1205-thou .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone 's spirit came back to [her]101-birdalone at that word , and [she]101-birdalone put [her]101-birdalone hands to [her]101-birdalone face and fell a - weeping . But [Atra]117-atra was kind to [her]101-birdalone and made much of [her]101-birdalone ; and [she]117-atra kissed [her]101-birdalone and wiped [her]101-birdalone tears , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone smiled again amidst [her]101-birdalone sobs , and [she]101-birdalone thanked [Atra]117-atra ; who said to [her]101-birdalone : First of all [I]0-i must tell [thee]101-birdalone that [I]0-i am taking [thee]101-birdalone to prison by [the witch]407-the witch 's bidding . Yea , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and what is [prison]1209-prison ? Said [Atra]117-atra : [A prison]1210-a prison is [a grim place where [poor folk who have done that which pleaseth [not rich folk]1213-not rich folk]1212-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk are shut up , that [they]1212-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk may be grieved and tormented by not being able to fare abroad , or go where [they]1212-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk would ; and by suffering whatsoever [[their]1212-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk masters]1214-their masters]1211-a grim place where poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk are shut up , that they may be grieved and tormented by not being able to fare abroad , or go where they would ; and by suffering whatsoever their masters may lay upon [them]1212-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk , as darkness , and cold , and hunger , and stripes . Somewhat so , or worse , [[our]1215-we lady]488-our lady would have it for [thee]101-birdalone ; but so would not [we]1215-we . Therefore for [thee]101-birdalone shall [this prison]1217-this prison be [a place where [thou]101-birdalone shalt be safe till [we]1215-we may bring [thee]101-birdalone forth when the night hath worn towards [its]1217-this prison ending]1218-a place where thou shalt be safe till we may bring thee forth when the night hath worn towards its ending . For [she]488-our lady will have forgotten [thee]101-birdalone by to - morrow ; and this [she]488-our lady knoweth ; wherefore just now , when [thou]101-birdalone stoodest out of earshot , [she]488-our lady was bidding [me]0-i , amongst other matters , to bring [thee]101-birdalone before [her]488-our lady to - morrow morning , and tell [her]488-our lady the tale of [thee]101-birdalone , that [she]488-our lady might call it to mind then what [she]488-our lady had will to this morning .

Yea , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , but will [she]488-our lady not remember that [she]488-our lady hath given [thee]101-birdalone a charge concerning [me]0-i ? But little thereof , said [Atra]117-atra , and with a few words [I]0-i may easily confuse [her]488-our lady memory so that speech thereon will fail [her]488-our lady . Keep up thine heart , sweetling ; but let [us]1219-us up this stair now forthwith , for [I]0-i were fain to have [thee]101-birdalone hid away in [this prison]1217-this prison , and then will [I]0-i down to [her]488-our lady and tell [her]488-our lady that [thou]101-birdalone art lying therein in all misery and terror , lest it come into [her]488-our lady head to send for [thee]101-birdalone ere [her]488-our lady memory is grown dim .

Again did [Birdalone]101-birdalone take heart , and [they]1219-us hastened a long way up the stair , till [Atra]117-atra stayed at last at a door all done with iron , endlong and over - thwart . Then [she]117-atra took a leash of keys from [her]117-atra girdle , one big and two little , and set the big one in the lock and turned it , and shoved the heavy door and entered thereby [a chamber four - square and vaulted]1221-a chamber four - square and vaulted ; and the vault was upheld by a pillar of red marble , wherein , somewhat higher than [a man]234-a man 's head , were set stanchions of latten , that could be clasped and unclasped . [This chamber]1223-this chamber was in a way goodly , but yet grim to look on ; for the walls were all of black ashlar stone close - jointed , and the floor black also , but of marble polished so wholly that it was as dark water , and gave back the image of [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's dear feet and legs as [she]117-atra went thereon . The windows were not small , and [the chamber]306-the chamber was light in every corner because of [them]1225-them , but [they]1225-them were so high up under the vaulting that [none]1226-none might see thereout aught save the heavens . There was nought in [the chamber]306-the chamber save a narrow bench of oak and three stools of the same , a great and stately carven chair dight with cushions of purple and gold , and in one corner a big oaken coffer .

Now spake [Atra]117-atra : This is [[[our]1219-us lady]488-our lady 's prison]1229-our lady 's prison , and [I]0-i fear [me]0-i [we]1219-us can not make it soft for [thee]117-atra , [dear stranger]1230-dear stranger . [Yea]1231-yea , [I]0-i must tell [thee]117-atra and [she]117-atra reddened therewith that it is part of [my]0-i charge to set [thee]117-atra in irons . [Birdalone]101-birdalone smiled on [her]117-atra , and was over weary to ask what that meant , though [she]101-birdalone knew not . But [Atra]117-atra went to the big coffer and opened it and thrust in [her]117-atra hands , and there was a jangling therewith , and when [she]117-atra turned about to [Birdalone]101-birdalone again [she]117-atra had iron chains in [her]117-atra hands , and [she]117-atra said : This shameth [me]0-i , [dear friend]1232-dear friend ; yet if [thou]1233-thou wouldst wear them it might be well , for [she]117-atra may have a mind to go visit [[her]117-atra prison]1234-her prison , and if [she]117-atra find [thee]1233-thou there unshackled [she]117-atra shall be wroth , and oftenest [her]117-atra wrath hath a whip in its hand . And these are the lightest that [I]0-i might find .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone smiled again , and spake not , for [she]101-birdalone was very weary , and [Atra]117-atra did the irons on [her]117-atra wrists and [her]117-atra ankles ; and said thereafter : Yet bear in mind that it is [a friend that hath the key of these things]1235-a friend that hath the key of these things . And now [I]0-i will go away for a little , but [I]0-i shall be on thine errands ; for first [I]0-i shall tell [the mistress]709-the mistress that [thou]1233-thou art lying here shackled and in all wanhope ; and next , by the will and command of [her]709-the mistress , [I]0-i am to see that [thou]1233-thou be well fed and nourished to - day that [thou]1233-thou mayst be the stronger for to - morrow . Now if [I]0-i may give [thee]1233-thou rede , it is that [thou]1233-thou forbear to open the coffer yonder ; for ugly things shalt [thou]1233-thou find there , and that may dishearten [thee]1233-thou again .

Therewith [she]0-i kissed [her]0-i kindly on the cheek and went [her]0-i ways , and the great key turned in the lock behind [her]0-i .

There then was [Birdalone]101-birdalone left to [herself]101-birdalone ; and [she]101-birdalone was over weary even to weep ; true it is that [she]101-birdalone made a step or two towards the coffer , but reframed [her]101-birdalone , and took two of the pillows from the great chair and turned aside into the other corner , [her]101-birdalone chains jingling as [she]101-birdalone went . There [she]101-birdalone laid [herself]101-birdalone down , and nestled into the very wall- nook , and presently fell asleep , and slumbered dreamlessly and sweetly a long while .

CHAPTER V. [THEY]1237-they FEAST IN [THE WITCH 'S PRISON]7072-the witch 's prison[1237-they]

[Birdalone]101-birdalone was awakened by the sound of the key in the lock , and the door opened , and there was [Atra]117-atra bearing dishes and platters , and behind [her]117-atra [Viridis]116-viridis with the like gear , and beakers and a flagon to boot , and both [they]1237-they were smiling and merry .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone 's heart leapt up to meet [them]1237-they , and in especial was [she]101-birdalone gladdened by the coming of [Viridis]116-viridis , who had seemed to be the kindest of [them]1237-they all .

[Viridis]116-viridis spake : Now is come the meat for [the dear sister]1238-the dear sister , and it is time , for surely [thou]1239-thee art famished , and it is now long past high noon . Do off [her]117-atra irons , [Atra]117-atra . Said [Atra]117-atra : Maybe it were well to let the fetters abide on [her]117-atra ankles , lest [the mistress]709-the mistress should come ; but for the wrists , reach out thine hands , [wayfarer]1241-wayfarer . So did [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and [Atra]117-atra laid [her]117-atra things on the ground , and unlocked the hand- shackles , and did them off : and meanwhile [Viridis]116-viridis spread forth the banquet , partly on the floor , and partly on that ill - omened coffer . Then [she]117-atra went up to [Birdalone]101-birdalone and kissed [her]101-birdalone , and said : Now shalt [thou]1239-thee sit in [[our]1242-us lady]488-our lady 's throne , and [we]1242-us shall serve [thee]1239-thee , and [thou]1239-thee shalt deem [thee]1239-thee [a great one]1244-a great one .

Nought else would [they]1242-us have , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone laid [her]101-birdalone nakedness on the purple cushions , and then [they]1242-us fell [all three]1245-all three to the feast . The victual was both plenteous and dainty , of venison and fowl , and cream and fruits and sweetmeats , and good wine [they]1242-us had withal : never had [Birdalone]101-birdalone feasted in like manner , and the heart came back unto [her]101-birdalone , and [her]101-birdalone cheeks grew rosy and [her]101-birdalone eyes glittered . But [she]101-birdalone said : How if [[your]1239-thee lady]1246-your lady were to come upon [us]1242-us here , and [we]1242-us so merry ? Said [Atra]117-atra : Out of the chair must [thou]1239-thee when [thou]1239-thee hearest the key in the lock , and then is all well , and [she]1246-your lady would have nought against [us]1242-us ; for [she]1246-your lady [herself]1246-your lady bade [us]1242-us , and [me]0-i in special , to keep [thee]1239-thee company here , and talk with [thee]1239-thee ; and [Aurea]116-viridis also would have been here , but that [she]116-viridis is serving [the lady]1157-the lady as now . Hath [she]1246-your lady then some pity on [me]0-i , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , that [she]1246-your lady hath bidden [thee]1239-thee do by [me]0-i what is most to [my]0-i pleasure ?

Laughed Viridis thereat , and [Atra]117-atra said : [She]1246-your lady hath no pity , nor ever shall have ; but so hard of heart is [she]1246-your lady , that [she]1246-your lady may not deem that [we]1242-us could love [thee]1239-thee , [a stranger]1248-a stranger , and unhappy , who can serve [us]1242-us in nowise ; so [she]1246-your lady feareth not the abatement of [thy]1239-thee grief from any compassion of [us]1242-us . Rather [she]1246-your lady hath sent [us]1242-us , and [me]0-i in especial , not to comfort [thee]1239-thee , but to grieve [thee]1239-thee by words ; for [she]1246-your lady biddeth [me]0-i tell [thee]1239-thee fair tales , forsooth , of what to - morrow shall be to [thee]1239-thee , and the day after ; and of how [she]1246-your lady shall begin on [thee]1239-thee , and what shall follow the beginning , and what [thou]1239-thee mayst look for after that . For by all this [she]1246-your lady deemeth to lower [thy]1239-thee pride and abate [thy]1239-thee valour , and to make every moment of to - day a terror to [thy]1239-thee flesh and [thy]1239-thee soul , so that thereby [thou]1239-thee mayest thole the bitterness twice over . Such is [her]1246-your lady pity for [thee]1239-thee ! And yet belike this cruelty hath saved [thee]1239-thee , for but for that [she]1246-your lady had not refrained [her]1246-your lady from [thee]1239-thee to - day , and to- morrow [thou]1239-thee shalt be far away from [her]1246-your lady .

Meanwhile , said [Viridis]116-viridis , in [her]116-viridis soft sweet voice , none of all these things will [we]1249-we talk over with [thee]1239-thee , but things comfortable and kind ; and [we]1249-we will tell each to each of [our]1249-we story . Will [we]1249-we not , [Atra]117-atra ? [Yea]1250-yea , verily , said [she]1246-your lady .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone looked upon [them]1251-them and said : Wondrous is [your]1239-thee compassion and loving - kindness unto [me]0-i , and scarce do [I]0-i know how to bear the burden thereof . But tell [me]0-i one thing truly ; will [ye]1239-thee not suffer in [my]0-i place when [this witch]1252-this witch cometh to know that [ye]1239-thee have stolen [me]0-i away from [her]1252-this witch ?

Nay , said [Atra]117-atra , [I]0-i have told [thee]1239-thee that by to - morrow [she]1252-this witch will have altogether , or at least almost , forgotten [thee]1239-thee and [thy]1239-thee coming hither . Moreover , [she]1252-this witch is foreseeing , and hath come to know that if [she]1252-this witch raise a hand against any of [us]1253-us three , it will lead [her]1252-this witch to [her]1252-this witch bane , save it be for heavy guilt clearly proven against [us]1253-us . Forsooth , in the earlier days of [our]1253-us captivity such a guilt [we]1253-us fell into , and did not wholly escape , as [Viridis]116-viridis can bear [me]0-i witness . But [we]1253-us are now grown wiser , and know [[our]1253-us mistress]1119-our mistress better , and will give [her]1119-our mistress no such joy .

[Viridis]116-viridis cast [her]116-viridis eyes down at those words and [Atra]117-atra 's smile , and turned red and then pale , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked on [her]117-atra wondering what ailed [her]117-atra ; then [she]101-birdalone said : Do [[ye]1255-ye [sisters]1144-sisters]1256-ye sisters work in [the field]763-the field and [the garden]1086-the garden ? [I]0-i mean at milking the kine and the goats , and digging the earth , and sowing and reaping , and the like . Nay , said [Atra]117-atra ; either [[our]1253-us mistress]1119-our mistress or [someone else who is of marvellous might , hath so ordained]1261-someone else who is of marvellous might , hath so ordained , that here everything waxeth of itself without tillage , or sowing or reaping , or any kind of tending ; and whatso [we]1253-us need of other matters [the mistress]709-the mistress taketh it for [us]1253-us from out of [her]709-the mistress Wonder- coffer , or suffereth [us]1253-us to take it for [ourselves]1253-us . For [thou]1263-thou must know that [this land]1264-this land is one of [the Isles of [the Lake]21-the lake]1265-the isles of the lake , and is called [the Isle of Increase Unsought]22-the isle of increase unsought .

[Meseemeth]119-meseemeth then , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , were [the mistress of [you]1267-ye]1266-the mistress of you to gainsay [you]1267-ye the gifts of the Wonder - coffer , [ye]1267-ye were undone . [Yea]1268-yea , verily , said [Atra]117-atra ; then would be but the fruits of [the earth]445-the earth and the wild creatures for [our]1253-us avail , and these , [we]1253-us have not learned how to turn them into dinner and supper . And [they]1270-they all laughed thereat ; but [Birdalone]101-birdalone said : See [ye]1267-ye then how [I]0-i was right to offer [myself]0-i unto [you]1267-ye as [a servant]1271-a servant , for in all matters of [the house]325-the house and the byre and [the field]763-the field have [I]0-i skill . But since [ye]1267-ye would not or could not have [me]0-i , [I]0-i wonder not that [ye]1267-ye be ill at ease here , and long to be gone , for as plenteous and lovely as [the isle]642-the isle is , and though [ye]1267-ye live [here]259-here without present mishandling or pining . For , sooth to say , [ye]1267-ye have over [you]1267-ye [a tyrant]1276-a tyrant and [a fool]493-a fool .

[Viridis]116-viridis answered : Yet is there something else , [dear friend]1232-dear friend , that whets [our]1279-us longing to depart . Tell [her]116-viridis thereof , [Atra]117-atra .

[Atra]117-atra smiled and said : Simple it is : there are [they]1280-they who long for [us]1279-us and for whom [we]1279-us long , and [we]1279-us would be together . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : Be these kinsfolk of [yours]1281-yours , as [fathers]1282-fathers , [mothers]1283-mothers , [sisters]1144-sisters , [brothers]1285-brothers , or [the like]1286-the like ?

Reddened [Viridis]116-viridis again ; but [Atra]117-atra spake , and [she]117-atra also blushed somewhat , though [she]117-atra smiled : [Those whom [we]1279-us love]1287-those whom we love , and who love [us]1279-us , be not queans , but carles ; neither be [they]1287-those whom we love of [our]1279-us blood , but aliens , till love overcometh [them]1287-those whom we love and causeth [them]1287-those whom we love to long to be of one flesh with [us]1279-us ; and [their]1287-those whom we love longing is beyond measure , and [they]1287-those whom we love desire [our]1279-us bodies , which [they]1287-those whom we love deem far fairer than belike [they]1287-those whom we love be . And [they]1287-those whom we love would bed [us]1279-us , and beget [children]1288-children on [us]1279-us . And all this [we]1279-us let [them]1287-those whom we love do with a good will , because [we]1279-us love [them]1287-those whom we love for [their]1287-those whom we love might , and [their]1287-those whom we love truth , and the hotness of [their]1287-those whom we love love toward [us]1279-us .

Looked up [Viridis]116-viridis thereat , and [her]116-viridis eyes gleamed amidst the flushing of [her]116-viridis cheeks , and [she]116-viridis said : [Sister]783-sister , [sister]783-sister ! even in such wise , and no other , as [they]1287-those whom we love desire [us]1279-us do [we]1279-us desire [them]1287-those whom we love ; it is no mere good will toward [them]1287-those whom we love from [us]1279-us , but longing and hot love .

Now must [Atra]117-atra blush no less than [Viridis]116-viridis ; yet [she]116-viridis but said : [I]0-i have told [thee]1291-thee hereof , [Birdalone]101-birdalone , because [I]0-i deem that [thou]1292-thou hast lived simply and without the sight of [men]219-men ; but it is what all know in the world of [the sons of Adam]452-the sons of adam . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : [Thou]1292-thou sayest sooth concerning [me]0-i . Yet about this love have [I]0-i learned somewhat even ere to - day , and now , as [ye]1295-ye speak and [I]0-i , meseems the lore of it comes pouring in on [me]0-i and fills [my]0-i heart with its sweetness . And O , to have such love from any , and with such love to be loved withal !

[Dear sister]791-dear sister , said [little Viridis]116-viridis , fear not ; such as [thou]1292-thou shall not fail of the love of [some man whom [thou]1292-thou must needs love]1297-some man whom thou must needs love . Is it not so , [sister Atra]117-atra ? Said [Atra]117-atra : [Yea]1298-yea ; such love shall come unto [her]117-atra as surely as death .

[They]1299-they were silent now a little , and it was as if some sweet incense had been burned within [the chamber]306-the chamber . For [Birdalone]101-birdalone the colour came and went in [her]101-birdalone cheeks , [her]101-birdalone flesh quaked , [her]101-birdalone heart beat quick , and [she]101-birdalone was oppressed by the sweetness of longing . More daintily [she]101-birdalone moved [her]101-birdalone limbs , and laid foot to foot and felt the sleekness of [her]101-birdalone sides ; and tender [she]101-birdalone was of [her]101-birdalone body as of that which should one day be so sorely loved .

Now [she]101-birdalone spake timidly to [the others]1301-the others , and said : Each one of [you]1301-the others then has [a man who loves [her]101-birdalone , and longs for [her]101-birdalone and for none else]1302-a man who loves her , and longs for her and for none else ? So it is , said [Viridis]116-viridis . How sweet that shall be ! said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; and now all the more [I]0-i wonder that [ye]1301-the others could trouble [yourselves]1301-the others over [me]0-i , or think of [me]0-i once ; and the kinder [I]0-i think it of [you]1301-the others .

Said [Atra]117-atra smiling on [her]101-birdalone : Nay , now must the cat be out of the bag , and [I]0-i must tell [thee]1301-the others that [thou]1301-the others art to think of [us]1303-us as chapmen who with [our]1303-us kindness would buy something of [thee]1301-the others , to wit , that [thou]1301-the others wouldst do an errand for [us]1303-us to [those three lovers of ours]1304-those three lovers of ours . Surely , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , it were a little payment to set against [your]1301-the others saving of [my]0-i life and [my]0-i soul ; and had [I]0-i to go barefoot over red gleeds [I]0-i would do it . And yet , if [I]0-i may go hence to [[your]1301-the others lovers]1305-your lovers , why not all three of [you]1301-the others along with [me]0-i ?

Said [Atra]117-atra : For this reason ; [[thy]1301-the others ferry]1107-thy ferry , the Sending Boat , wherein [ye]1301-the others came hither , is even somewhat akin to [[thy]1301-the others mistress]564-thy mistress and [ours]1303-us ; and [the mistress]709-the mistress here hath banned it against bearing [us]1303-us ; and now , were [we]1303-us so much as to touch it , such sore turmoil would arise , and such hideous noise as if earth and heaven were falling together ; and [the lady]1157-the lady would be on [us]1303-us straightway , and [we]1303-us should be undone ; and , as [thou]1310-thou shalt hear presently , this hath been proved . But [thou]1310-thou , [thou]1310-thou art free of [the said ferry]1311-the said ferry . Forsooth [I]0-i wot not why [[thy]1301-the others mistress]564-thy mistress banned it not against [thee]1301-the others ; maybe because [she]709-the mistress deemed not that [thou]1310-thou wouldst dare to use it or even go anigh it .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone considered , and thought that even so it was ; that [the witch]407-the witch deemed that [she]407-the witch would not dare use the Sending Boat , nor know how to , even if [she]407-the witch came upon it , and that if [she]407-the witch did so find it , [she]407-the witch would sicken [her]407-the witch of the road thereto . So now [she]407-the witch told [[her]407-the witch friends]1314-her friends the whole tale thereof more closely than [she]407-the witch had afore , save again what pertained to [Habundia]106-habundia ; withal [she]407-the witch told every word of what [[her]407-the witch mistress]419-her mistress had said to [her]407-the witch at that time when [she]419-her mistress changed [her]407-the witch into a hind . And [Viridis]116-viridis heard and wondered , and pitied [her]407-the witch . But [Atra]117-atra sat somewhat downcast a while . Then [she]117-atra said : However this may be , [we]1316-we will send [thee]1317-ye forth to - morrow in the dawn , and take the risk of what may befall thereafter ; and [thou]1317-ye shalt bear a token for each of [those three that love [us]1316-we]1318-those three that love us . For [we]1316-we deem that [they]1318-those three that love us have not forgotten aught , but are still seeking [us]1316-we .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone said : Whatsoever [ye]1317-ye bid [me]0-i ; that will [I]0-i do , and deem [me]0-i [[your]1317-ye debtor]1319-your debtor still . But now [I]0-i pray [you]1317-ye , pleasure [a poor captive]1320-a poor captive somewhat more . Wherein ? said [they]1318-those three that love us both ; [we]1316-we be all ready thereto . Said [the maiden]406-the maiden : Would [ye]1317-ye do so much as to tell [me]0-i the tale of how [ye]1317-ye came hither , and then how it hath been with [you]1317-ye from [your]1317-ye first coming until now ? With a good will , said [Atra]117-atra ; hearken !

CHAPTER VI . [ATRA]117-atra TELLS OF HOW [THEY]1318-those three that love us THREE CAME UNTO [THE ISLE OF]26-the isle [INCREASE]25-increase UNSOUGHT

[We]1316-we were born and bred in [the land that lies south - west along this Great Water]1322-the land that lies south - west along this great water , and [we]1316-we waxed happily , and became [fellows]1323-fellows when [we]1316-we were yet but [children]1288-children , and thus grew up [dear friends]1325-dear friends into maidenhood and womanhood . [We]1316-we were wooed by [many men]1326-many men , but [our]1316-we hearts turned to none of [them]1326-many men save unto [three , who were goodly , kind , and valiant]1327-three , who were goodly , kind , and valiant ; and [thou]1328-thou mayst call [them]1327-three , who were goodly , kind , and valiant [the Golden Knight]1329-the golden knight , who is [[Aurea]116-viridis 's man]1330-aurea 's man ; [the Green Knight]1331-the green knight , who is [man of Viridis]1332-man of viridis ; and [[my]0-i man]268-my man , [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire . But in this was unhap , that because of certain feuds which had endured from old time , this love was perilous unto [them]1327-three , who were goodly , kind , and valiant and [us]1316-we ; so that [we]1316-we lived in doubt and unrest .

Came a day , now three years ago , when [the king of [the whole land]1336-the whole land]1335-the king of the whole land brought [[his]1335-the king of the whole land folk]1337-his folk into [[our]1316-we lakeside country]1338-our lakeside country , and there held a court and a mote in [a fair great meadow anigh to [the water]361-the water]1339-a fair great meadow anigh to the water . But even as the mote was hallowed , and the Peace of [God]120-god proclaimed at the blast of the war - horn , came [[we]1316-we three woeful ladies clad in black and knelt before [the lord king]1342-the lord king]1341-we three woeful ladies clad in black and knelt before the lord king , and prayed [him]1342-the lord king hearken [us]1316-we . And [he]1342-the lord king deemed that [we]1316-we were fair , so [he]1342-the lord king had compassion on [us]1316-we , and raised [us]1316-we up , and bade [us]1316-we speak .

So [we]1316-we told [our]1316-we tale , how that strife and wounds and death stood betwixt [us]1316-we and love ; and [we]1316-we wept , and bewailed it , that [our]1316-we love must be slain because [men]219-men were wroth with [each other]580-each other and not with [us]1316-we .

[The king]1345-the king looked on [us]1316-we kindly , and said : Who be [the swains for whom these lovely damsels]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels make such a piece of work ? So [we]1316-we named [them]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels , and said that [they]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels were there in [the mote]1347-the mote ; and [the king]1345-the king knew [them]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels for [valiant men who had done [him]1345-the king good service]1349-valiant men who had done him good service ; and [he]1345-the king cried out [their]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels names , and bade [them]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels stand forth out of the throng . So forth [they]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels stood , [the Golden Knight]1329-the golden knight , [the Green Knight]1331-the green knight , and [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire and [he]1345-the king also was now [a knight]1353-a knight ; but now were [they]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels [all three clad in black]1354-all three clad in black , and [they]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels were unarmed , save for [their]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels swords girt to [their]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels sides , without which [no man amongst [us]1356-us]1355-no man amongst us may come to [the mote]1347-the mote , be [he]1355-no man amongst us [baron]1358-baron or [earl]1359-earl or [duke]1360-duke , or [the very lord king]1361-the very lord king [himself]1361-the very lord king .

So [the king]1345-the king looked upon [us]1356-us and [them]1346-the swains for whom these lovely damsels , and laughed and said : [Fair ladies]1363-fair ladies , [ye]1363-fair ladies have got [me]0-i by the nose , so needs must [my]0-i body follow . Do [[ye]1363-fair ladies three knights , whom [I]0-i know for [valiant men]1365-valiant men and true]1364-ye three knights , whom i know for valiant men and true , take each [his]1361-the very lord king love by the hand , and let the weddings be to - morrow . Who then were joyful but [us]1356-us ? But even at the word [the king]1345-the king spake arose great turmoil in [the mote]1347-the mote , for [they]1364-ye three knights , whom i know for valiant men and true smote the feud and contention awake , and [men]219-men thronged forward against [each other]580-each other , and swords were drawn and brandished . But [the king]1345-the king arose in [his]1345-the king place and spake long and deftly , and waxed exceeding wroth , while [none]1226-none heeded [him]1345-the king nor hearkened . And there stood [[our]1356-us three men]1372-our three men , who laid no hand to hilt , but abode heart - whole by seeming amid the tumult . And lovely [they]1372-our three men were to look on . At last [the wise men]1373-the wise men and [old barons]1374-old barons went between , and by fair words appeased the trouble , and [the mote]1347-the mote grew hushed . Then spake [the king]1345-the king : What is this , [[my]0-i thanes]1377-my thanes ? [I]0-i had deemed that [[my]0-i foemen]1378-my foemen were far away , and that [ye]1379-ye that here are were all friends unto [me]0-i and unto [each other]580-each other . But now must [we]1356-us try another rede . Therewith [he]1345-the king turned unto [[our]1356-us men]1381-our men and said : [[Ye]1379-ye champions]1382-ye champions , are [ye]1379-ye so much in love with Love that [ye]1379-ye will fight for [him]1345-the king ? [They]1381-our men all yeasaid that , and then [the king]1345-the king said : Then do [I]0-i declare that [these three]1384-these three will hold [the field]763-the field against [all comers]1386-all comers from matins till high noon , and that [he]1345-the king who vanquisheth [any one of [them]1384-these three]1387-any one of them shall have [[his]1345-the king lady]1388-his lady and [we]1356-us d [her]1388-his lady if [he]1345-the king will , and , if [he]1345-the king will , shall ransom [her]1388-his lady . And [this field]1389-this field shall be foughten after two months ' frist in [these fair meadows]7073-these fair meadows , when [I]1345-the king return from [the outermost marches of [the south]7075-the south]7074-the outermost marches of the south , whereto [I]1345-the king am now wending . But when the battle is done , then let [all men]228-all men bow to the judgment of [God]120-god , whether [he]120-god be well content or not , and this on peril of life and limb . And now let there be deep peace between [all men]228-all men meanwhile ; and if any break the peace , be [he]120-god high or low , [rich or unrich , churl or earl]7078-rich or unrich , churl or earl , [I]1345-the king swear it by the souls of [[my]1345-the king fathers]7079-my fathers that [he]120-god shall lose nought save [his]120-god life therefor .[1345-the king]

At these words was there a rumour of yeasay , and [all men]228-all men were content , save [[we]1391-us three poor maidens]1392-we three poor maidens , [into whose hearts had now entered fear of loss and death]1393-into whose hearts had now entered fear of loss and death .

But [[our]1391-us kindreds]1394-our kindreds on both sides were glad and proud , and [they]1394-our kindreds were not so bitter against [us]1391-us as [they]1394-our kindreds had been ; [they]1394-our kindreds put hand to pouch , and let rear for [us]1391-us a fair pavilion of painted timber , all hung with silk and pictured cloths and Saracen tapestry , by the very lake - side ; and gay boats gaily bedight lay off [the said pavilion]1395-the said pavilion for [our]1391-us pleasure ; and when all was done , it yet lacked a half month of the day of battle , and thither were [we]1391-us brought in triumph by [the kindreds]1396-the kindreds on a fair day of May , and there was not a sword or a spear amongst [the whole company]1397-the whole company , and peaceful and merry was all by seeming . But [we]1391-us were not suffered to meet [[our]1391-us lovers]1398-our lovers all this while , from the time when the mote was .

Now on a day came [a messenger on the spur]1399-a messenger on the spur , and did [us]1391-us to wit that [the king]1345-the king would be with [us]1391-us on the morrow , and that the day after , [the fateful field]1401-the fateful field should be foughten . Then , though the coming of this day had been so longed for by [us]1391-us , yet now it was at hand it cast [us]1391-us into all unrest and trouble , so that [we]1391-us scarce knew whether to go , or stand , or sit , or what to do with [our]1391-us bodies . [[Our]1391-us folk]1402-our folk , and [all other men withal]1403-all other men withal , were so busy making ready for the morrow of to- morrow , that [they]1402-our folk left [us]1391-us alone to wear through the day as [we]1391-us might .

Now it was afternoon , and the day hot and hazy , and [we]1391-us stood on [the very lip of [the land]213-the land]1404-the very lip of the land wearied with hope and fear , and striving to keep good countenance to [each other]580-each other ; and there came [a boat]688-a boat unto [the shore]358-the shore gaily painted and gilded , and bedight with silken cloths and cushions ; and [the steerer]1409-the steerer thereof was [a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters]1410-a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters ; red - haired [she]1410-a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters was , thin - lipped and narrow - eyed , flat - breasted and strait - hipped ; [an ungoodly woman]1411-an ungoodly woman , though [her]1410-a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters skin was white and smooth as for [her]1410-a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters age . Hast [thou]1412-thou ever seen [such an one]1413-such an one , [guest]1414-guest ? Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , smiling : Forsooth that have [I]0-i ; for such an one is [[my]0-i mistress]1415-my mistress to behold .

Well , said [Atra]117-atra , [this dame]1416-this dame stretched out [her]1416-this dame hands to [us]1417-we , and said : Will not [the pretty ladies]1418-the pretty ladies , [the dear ladies , who have nought on hand this afternoon]1419-the dear ladies , who have nought on hand this afternoon , come into [[my]0-i boat]1420-my boat and look on the face of the water , so calm and fair as it is , and let [their]1418-the pretty ladies lovely hands go over the gunwale and play with the ripple , and so beguile this heavy time for a two hours ; and then give a little gift of a piece or two of silver to [a poor carline]1421-a poor carline , who loveth [all fair ladies]1422-all fair ladies and [bright warriors]1423-bright warriors , and who needeth a little livelihood ?

Now [the woman]252-the woman seemed nought lovely unto [us]1417-we , and to [me]0-i forsooth [she]252-the woman seemed hateful ; but [we]1417-we looked on [each other]580-each other , and [we]1417-we found that [we]1417-we were utterly weary of going up and down on [the meadow]510-the meadow , and lying about in [the pavilion]1427-the pavilion , and it seemed as if this would give [us]1417-we a little rest ; withal [we]1417-we saw not that [the woman]252-the woman could do [us]1417-we any hurt , whereas [we]1417-we were three , and strong enough as [women]433-women go ; nor were [we]1417-we mariners so evil but that [we]1417-we might sail or steer [a boat]688-a boat at a pinch . So [we]1417-we stepped into [the boat]859-the boat straightway , and [the woman]252-the woman sat aft and paddled deftly with the steering oar , and [we]1417-we glided away from [the land]213-the land .

Soon [we]1417-we were come so far that [we]1417-we could but just see [[our]1417-we pavilion]1434-our pavilion through the haze , which had somewhat thickened , and [we]1417-we said to [the woman]252-the woman that [she]252-the woman should go about and make for [the shore]358-the shore , and that then [we]1417-we would go to and fro a while along by [our]1417-we stead . [She]252-the woman nodded yeasay , and began by seeming to dight [the craft]694-the craft for return . But therewith the haze was grown suddenly into a low cloud , which came down upon [us]1417-we from [the south - west]1438-the south - west in the arms of a cold breeze , that grew stronger every minute , so no wonder it was though [the steerer]1409-the steerer might not keep head to wind ; and then who was afraid and ashamed save [ourselves]1417-we ?

But [the woman]252-the woman said , and there seemed to be a mock in [her]252-the woman voice : Ill luck , [pretty ladies]1441-pretty ladies ! Now is there nought for it but to drive , if [we]1417-we would not drown . But belike this duskiness will clear presently , and then at least [we]1417-we shall know whither [we]1417-we be going ; and [we]1417-we may either turn back , or seek some other shelter , for [I]0-i know [the lake]369-the lake well ; [I]0-i know , [I]0-i know .

[We]1417-we were too terror - stricken to speak , for [we]1417-we felt that still the wind grew stronger , and [the lake]369-the lake began to rise into waves , and [the craft]694-the craft to wallow ; but well - nigh therewith was the dusk and the mist gone ; the sky was bright blue overhead , and the westering sun shone cloudless ; but on [no land]1073-no land [it]1446-it shone , or on aught save the blue waters and the white wave - crests .

Then wept [Aurea]116-viridis , and [this Viridis]1447-this viridis here , but as to [me]0-i , [I]0-i grew wroth and cried out to [the steerer]1409-the steerer : Accursed carline ! [thou]1449-thou hast betrayed [us]1417-we ; never now may [we]1417-we get back to [[our]1417-we pavilion]1434-our pavilion till the fight is foughten , and [[our]1417-we lovers]1398-our lovers will deem that [we]1417-we have forsaken [them]1398-our lovers , and [we]1417-we are shamed for ever . Well , well , said [the carline]1452-the carline , what remedy save patience for the winds and waves ? And [she]1452-the carline laughed mockingly . Quoth [I]0-i : There is this remedy , that [we]1417-we three arise and lay hands on [thee]1452-the carline , and cast [thee]1452-the carline outboard , save [thou]1452-the carline straightway turn [the boat]859-the boat 's head and back to the main . Forsooth [I]0-i doubt not but that as [thou]1449-thou hast raised this foul wind against [us]1417-we , [thou]1449-thou canst raise a fair wind for [us]1417-we .

Hearken to [the lovely lady]1454-the lovely lady ! quoth [the carline]1452-the carline , how [she]1454-the lovely lady deemeth [me]0-i to be none other than [the great God]1456-the great god [himself]1456-the great god , to hold the winds in the hollow of [my]0-i hand , and still the waves with a word ! What ! am [I]0-i wrought somewhat after [his]1456-the great god image , [kind ladies]1457-kind ladies ? And [she]1454-the lovely lady grinned horribly therewith . Then [she]1454-the lovely lady said again : As to [thy]1454-the lovely lady remedy , sweetling , meseemeth it nought . For how shall [ye]1454-the lovely lady sail this stormy water when [[your]1454-the lovely lady captain]1458-your captain is gone , and [ye]1454-the lovely lady but [holiday sailors]1459-holiday sailors belike ?

As [she]1454-the lovely lady spake , a great wave came up from the windward , and brake over [us]1417-we , and half filled [the craft]694-the craft , and lifted [her]1454-the lovely lady bows up towering , and then down [we]1417-we went into the trough ; and [I]0-i sat cowed and quaking , and spake never another word .

Now began the sun to sink , and the wind abated , and [the sea]216-the sea went down , but [the boat]859-the boat sped on as swift as ever over [the landless waters]1463-the landless waters .

Now the sun was down , and dusk was at hand , and [the carline]1452-the carline spake , and drew a bright - gleaming sax from under [her]1452-the carline raiment : [Damsels]121-damsels , [I]0-i warn [you]121-damsels that now it were best that [ye]121-damsels obey [me]0-i in all things ; for though [ye]121-damsels be three and [I]0-i one , yet whereas [I]0-i have [here]259-here [an edge - friend]1466-an edge - friend , [I]0-i may take the life of [any one of [you]121-damsels]1467-any one of you , or of all three , as simply as [I]0-i could cut a lamb 's throat . Moreover it will serve [you]121-damsels better in [the house whereto [ye]121-damsels are wending]1468-the house whereto ye are wending , that [I]0-i make a good tale of [you]121-damsels rather than a bad . For [the mistress of [that house]1470-that house]1469-the mistress of that house is of all might ; and [I]0-i must say it of [her]1469-the mistress of that house , though [she]1469-the mistress of that house is [[my]0-i very sister]1471-my very sister , yet [she]1469-the mistress of that house is not so sweet - tempered and kind of heart as [I]0-i am , but somewhat rough and unyielding of mood , so that it is best to please [her]1469-the mistress of that house . Wherefore , [maidens]1472-maidens , [I]0-i rede [you]121-damsels be sage .

[Our]1473-we unhappy hearts were now so sunken in wan - hope , that [we]1473-we had no word wherewith to answer [her]0-i , and [she]0-i spake : Now obey [ye]121-damsels [my]0-i bidding and eat and drink , that [ye]121-damsels may come hale and sound to [your]121-damsels journey 's end , for [I]0-i would not give starvelings to [[my]0-i dear sister]1474-my dear sister . Therewith [she]0-i brought forth victual for [us]1473-we , and that nought evil , of flesh and bread , and cheese and cakes , and good wine withal ; and [we]1473-we were hunger - weary as well as sorrow - weary ; and hunger did at that moment overcome sorrow , so [we]1473-we ate and drank , and , would [we]1473-we , would [we]1473-we not , something of heart came back to [us]1473-we thereby . Then again spake [the carline]1452-the carline : Now [my]0-i will is that [ye]121-damsels sleep ; and [ye]121-damsels have cushions and cloths enough to dight [you]121-damsels a fair bed ; and this bidding is easy for [you]121-damsels to obey . Forsooth , so weary were [we]1473-we with sorrow , and [our]1473-we hunger was now quenched , that [we]1473-we laid [us]1473-we down and slept at once , and forgat [our]1473-we troubles .

When [we]1473-we awoke it was after the first dawn , and [we]1473-we were come aland even where [thou]1476-thou didst this morning , [guest]1414-guest . And [thou]1476-thou mayst deem it wondrous , but so it was , that close to where [[our]1473-we boat]1478-our boat took [land]653-land lay the ferry which brought [thee]1476-thou hither .

Now [the carline]1452-the carline bade [us]1473-we get ashore , and [we]1473-we did so , and found [the land wondrous]1481-the land wondrous fair , little as that solaced [us]1473-we then . But [she]1452-the carline said unto [us]1473-we : Hearken ! now are [ye]1473-we come [home]387-home ; and long shall [ye]1473-we dwell here , for never shall [ye]1473-we depart hence save by the will of [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister and [me]0-i , wherefore , once more , [I]0-i rede [you]1473-we be good , for it will be better for [you]1473-we . Go forth now unto [yonder house]1484-yonder house , and on the way [ye]1473-we shall meet [the Queen of [this land]1264-this land]1485-the queen of this land , and [ye]1473-we have nought to do but to say to [her]1485-the queen of this land that [ye]1473-we are the Gift ; and then shall [she]1485-the queen of this land see to [your]1473-we matter .

Therewith [she]1485-the queen of this land gat into [[her]1485-the queen of this land own craft]1487-her own craft , [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , and therein did the deed and spake the words [ye]1473-we wot of , and was gone north - away ; and when [we]1489-we turned to seek for [[our]1489-we boat]1478-our boat wherein [we]1489-we had come hither , it was gone .

[We]1489-we stood miserably for a while on [the lip of [the land]213-the land]1491-the lip of the land , and then [I]0-i said that [we]1489-we might as well go meet [our]1489-we fate as die there of grief and hunger . So [we]1489-we went , and came into [those fair gardens]1493-those fair gardens , and as [we]1489-we went slowly up toward [the house]325-the house came on [us]1489-we [a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight . [A big woman]1496-a big woman [she]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight was , and like to [her]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight that beguiled [us]1489-we , but far younger and fairer of favour , foolish and proud of visage . [She]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight stared on [us]1489-we , and seemed half afeard of [us]1489-we at first , but asked [us]1489-we what [we]1489-we were , and [I]0-i answered that [we]1489-we were the Gift . The Gift ? said [she]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight , what meaneth that ? Will [ye]1497-ye obey [me]0-i in all things ? If [ye]1497-ye gainsay it , [ye]1497-ye will perish , unless [ye]1497-ye can eat grass ; for on [this isle]1498-this isle everything cometh from [my]0-i hand .

What might [we]1489-we do ? [We]1489-we all knelt down before [her]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight , and swore to do [her]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight will . Then [she]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight said , after [she]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight had stared on [us]1489-we a while : Now [I]0-i know : [ye]1497-ye are [they]1499-they of whom [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister spake , that [she]1171-my sister would fetch [me]0-i a gift of a leash of damsels for [my]0-i service . Now [I]0-i take the Gift and thank [her]1171-my sister good heart . But if [ye]1497-ye would do [my]0-i will , then . . . But [she]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight broke off here and stared at [us]1489-we a long while , and then [she]1495-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight said : Now [I]0-i know ; [she]1171-my sister bade [me]0-i treat [you]1497-ye well , and hold [my]0-i hand from [you]1497-ye , or evil would come of it , belike at last [my]0-i bane . So go [ye]1497-ye home to [the house]325-the house , and [I]0-i will give [you]1497-ye meat and drink , and show [you]1497-ye [[my]0-i stores]1502-my stores and the Wonder - coffer , and [ye]1497-ye shall serve [me]0-i in honour .

Even so did [we]1489-we ; and [we]1489-we ate and drank and rested , and nought [we]1489-we lacked , save leave to depart [home]387-home to [[our]1489-we lovers]1398-our lovers , and [some mistress better than this stupid and proud lump of flesh]1505-some mistress better than this stupid and proud lump of flesh . But the next morning when [we]1489-we came before [the lady]1157-the lady , [she]1157-the lady knew nought of what [we]1489-we were ; and again [we]1489-we had to tell [her]1157-the lady that [we]1489-we were the Gift , and again [she]1157-the lady glared at [us]1489-we balefully , and again [she]1157-the lady called to mind [[her]1157-the lady sister]1169-her sister and [her]1157-the lady rede concerning [us]1489-we . And this went on for many days , till at last [she]1157-the lady got to know what [we]1489-we were ; and [she]1157-the lady followed [[her]1157-the lady sister]1169-her sister 's rede in that [she]1157-the lady never mishandled [us]1489-we , though [we]1489-we could see that it irked [her]1157-the lady to forbear , nor did [she]1157-the lady speak to [us]1489-we more roughly than [[her]1157-the lady fool]1509-her fool 's wo nt was ; and [we]1489-we had in [our]1489-we hands all that was needed for [our]1489-we sustenance , and lived easily enough .

Now [our]1489-we coming hither betid three years ago , and a month thereafter comes [[thy]1510-thy witch]1511-thy witch hither in [[her]1511-thy witch ferry]1512-her ferry , and [she]1511-thy witch greeted [us]1489-we when [we]1489-we met , and asked [us]1489-we , grinning , had [she]1511-thy witch not been kind to win [us]1489-we such good days ? [Yea]1513-ye , and over kind , said [she]1511-thy witch , [ye]1513-ye would deem [me]0-i , knew [ye]1513-ye what would have betid [you]1513-ye save for [my]0-i good word . Forsooth [we]1489-we deemed it no kind deed to steal [us]1489-we from [[our]1489-we lovers]1398-our lovers ; but [we]1489-we kept good tongues in [our]1489-we heads , for thralls must needs kiss the rod .

[She]1511-thy witch went away in two days , but came again many times thereafter , till [we]1489-we won the secret of the Sending Boat , and [her]1511-thy witch spell therewith ; but [we]1489-we knew not that was banned against [us]1489-we . Wherefore on a day in the grey of the morning , when [we]1489-we had been on [this isle]1498-this isle somewhat less than a year , [we]1489-we went down to [it]1498-this isle and stepped in , and reddened stem and stern and said the spell - words . But straightway arose an hideous braying and clatter , and thunder came therewith , and trembling of [the earth]445-the earth , and the waters of [the lake]369-the lake arose in huge waves ; nor might [we]1489-we move from [our]1489-we seats in [the boat]859-the boat till [the two witches]1519-the two witches came running down to [us]1489-we , and haled [us]1489-we out ashore , and had [us]1489-we up into [the house]325-the house , and into [this very prison - chamber]1521-this very prison - chamber , wherein [we]1489-we are now sitting so merry . And here [we]1489-we bore what was laid upon [us]1489-we , whereof , [dear guest]1522-dear guest , [we]1489-we shall tell [thee]1522-dear guest nought . But this came of it , that never thereafter durst [we]1489-we try the adventure of the Sending Boat , but have lived on in lazy sorrow and shameful ease , till [thou]1523-thou , [dear guest]1522-dear guest and [sister]783-sister , [wert]1489-we sent hither by heaven for [our]1489-we helping .

Now what became of [[the king]1345-the king 's court]1527-the king 's court , and the hazelled field of [[our]1489-we champions]1528-our champions , [we]1489-we wot not , or whether [they]1528-our champions be yet alive [we]1489-we can not tell [thee]1522-dear guest ; but if [they]1528-our champions be alive , it is to [them]1528-our champions that [we]1489-we would have [thee]1522-dear guest do [our]1489-we errand , and thereof will [we]1489-we tell [thee]1522-dear guest closely to - morrow . And so , sweetling , an end of [my]0-i tale .

CHAPTER VII . THE THREE DAMSELS TAKE [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone OUT OF THE WITCH 'S [PRISON[117-atra]

Birdalone]101-birdalone thanked [Atra]117-atra much for [her]117-atra tale , and strange it was to [her]117-atra to hear of such new things and the deeds of [folk]1529-folk ; but the dealing of [the witches with those three]1530-the witches with those three was familiar to [her]117-atra and was of [[her]117-atra world]1531-her world .

Now [they]1530-the witches with those three talked merrily , till there came a footstep to the door and one without knocked . [Viridis]116-viridis paled thereat , and a pang of fear smote [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone swiftly got from out the chair and sat down on a stool ; but when [Atra]117-atra opened , it was but [Aurea]116-viridis come from [her]116-viridis service to bid [Atra]117-atra take [her]116-viridis place . So [she]101-birdalone went , and again was there pleasant converse betwixt [Aurea]116-viridis and [the other twain]1532-the other twain ; and certain matters did [Aurea]116-viridis tell [Birdalone]101-birdalone which had been left untold by [Atra]117-atra . And chiefly , when [Birdalone]101-birdalone asked if [any other folk]1533-any other folk had come into [the isle]642-the isle while [they]1533-any other folk dwelt [there]232-there , [she]101-birdalone said yea ; once had come [a knight]1353-a knight with [a lady]1537-a lady , [his]1353-a knight love , fleeing from war and mishap , and these had [the witch overcome by wizardry]1538-the witch overcome by wizardry , and destroyed [them]1538-the witch overcome by wizardry miserably : and that again another had strayed thither , and [him]1353-a knight also [the witch]407-the witch undid , because [he]1353-a knight would not do [her]407-the witch will and lie in [her]407-the witch bed . [Withal]114-withal had come drifting there [a young damsel]1540-a young damsel , [a castaway of the winds and waves]1541-a castaway of the winds and waves ; [her]1540-a young damsel [the witch]407-the witch kept as a thrall , and after a while took to mishandling [her]1540-a young damsel so sorely , that at last , what for shame and what for weariness of life , [she]1540-a young damsel cast [herself]1540-a young damsel into [the water]361-the water and was drowned . [None of [these folk]1545-these folk]1544-none of these folk might [the damsels]1546-the damsels help so as to do [them]1546-the damsels any good , though [they]1546-the damsels tried it , and went nigh to suffer therefor [themselves]1546-the damsels .

Now the day wore , and in a while [Atra]117-atra came back , and [Viridis]116-viridis must serve . At last the dusk and the dark was come . Then said [Atra]117-atra : Now must [we]1547-we twain begone to wait upon [[our]1547-we lady]488-our lady , as the wo nt is : and that is now for [our]1547-we good hap , for if [we]1547-we be with [her]488-our lady all three , and especially , to say sooth , if [I]0-i be with [her]488-our lady , [we]1547-we may well keep [her]488-our lady from visiting [thee]1549-thou here ; since belike [she]488-our lady shall yet dimly remember that [thou]1549-thou art in [[her]488-our lady prison]1234-her prison . Therefore [thou]1549-thou must forgive it if [I]0-i shackle [thy]1549-thou wrists again . And now if [thou]1549-thou wilt follow [my]0-i rede , [thou]1549-thou shalt try to sleep some deal , and it were well if [thou]1549-thou might'st sleep till [we]1547-we come for [thee]1549-thou in the grey dawn .

Therewith [they]1547-we left [her]488-our lady [there]232-there , and [she]488-our lady nestled in the corner once more , and there did verily fall asleep , and slept till the key in the lock and the opening door awakened [her]488-our lady , and [Atra]117-atra came stealing soft- footed into [the prison]1552-the prison . Eager [she]117-atra was and panting , and [she]117-atra kneeled before [Birdalone]101-birdalone and unlocked [her]117-atra leg - shackles , and then stood up and did the like by the irons on [her]117-atra wrists . Then [she]117-atra said : Look up , [dear friend]1232-dear friend , to [thy]117-atra prison windows , and behold the dawn beginning to break on the day of [thy]117-atra deliverance , and [ours]1547-we maybe . But come now at once : and again , wilt [thou]1549-thou pardon [me]0-i , that [we]1547-we clothe [thee]1549-thou not here for [thy]1549-thou journey ? For from [our]1547-we own bodies must [we]1547-we clothe [thee]1549-thou , and if by any hap [[our]1547-we lady]488-our lady were to see any one of [us]1547-we more or less unclad , it might draw [her]488-our lady on to see what was toward , and [we]1547-we might yet be found out , for [our]1547-we undoing .

Therewith [she]117-atra took [her]117-atra hand , and led [her]117-atra forth of [the prison]1552-the prison , and locked the door behind [her]117-atra ; and then [downstairs]1556-downstairs [they]1547-we went , and out - a- doors by a little wicket at the stair - end . The dawn drew on apace now , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone saw at once the other twain lurking in the wall- nook hard by . No word was spoken between [them]1547-we , and with noiseless feet [they]1547-we went forth into [the orchard]469-the orchard , where the blackbirds and thrushes were beginning [their]1547-we first morning song , and ere [they]1547-we came out on to [the meadow]510-the meadow the full choir of [them]1547-we was a - singing .

CHAPTER VIII . IN WHAT [WISE BIRDALONE]101-birdalone WAS CLAD , AND HOW [SHE]101-birdalone WENT [HER]101-birdalone WAYS FROM [THE ISLE]26-the isle OF INCREASE UNSOUGHT

When [they]1547-we were all clear of [the orchard trees]1559-the orchard trees [the three damsels]1165-the three damsels kept [Birdalone]101-birdalone between [them]1165-the three damsels closely , so that [her]101-birdalone white body should not be seen if [the lady]1157-the lady were awake and looking forth . Thus [they]1165-the three damsels brought [her]101-birdalone to where a few thorn - bushes made a cover for [them]1547-we close to [the water]361-the water 's edge , some twenty yards from [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat . There [they]1547-we stood together , and [Atra]117-atra said :

Now , [dear guest]1522-dear guest , and [dearest messenger]1565-dearest messenger , it is [our]1547-we matter to clothe [thee]101-birdalone from [our]1547-we very bodies ; and do [thou]1566-thou , [Viridis]116-viridis , begin .

[Viridis]116-viridis came forward blushing , as [her]116-viridis wo nt was , and took off [her]116-viridis green gown and laid it on the grass ; then [she]116-viridis set [her]116-viridis hand to [her]116-viridis smock , and did it off , and stood naked , knee set to knee , and swaying like the willow branch ; and then was seen all the dainty fashion of [her]116-viridis body , and how lovely of hue and sweet of flesh [she]116-viridis was .

But [she]116-viridis said : Dear sister [Birdalone]101-birdalone , here is [my]0-i smock , which [I]0-i lend [thee]101-birdalone , but as to [my]0-i love , [I]0-i give it [thee]101-birdalone therewith ; therefore grudge it not , though [thou]1566-thou give [me]0-i back the linen , for happy will be the day to [me]0-i when [I]0-i have it again ; for now none may do it on [me]0-i save [the Green Knight]1331-the green knight , [my]0-i own love . Therewith [she]116-viridis gave [her]101-birdalone the smock , and kissed [her]101-birdalone , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone did it on , and felt the valianter and mightier when [she]101-birdalone had a garment upon [her]101-birdalone .

Then [Aurea]116-viridis did off [her]116-viridis golden gown , and stood in smock alone , so that [her]116-viridis naked arms shone more precious than the golden sleeves that had covered them . And [she]116-viridis spake : [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [dear messenger]1568-dear messenger , take now [my]0-i golden gown , and send it back to [me]0-i when [thou]1569-thou hast found [the man unto whom it is due]1570-the man unto whom it is due ; and think meanwhile that , when [thou]1569-thou wearest it , [thou]1569-thou wearest [my]0-i love , and that when [thou]1569-thou pullest it off , [thou]1569-thou art clad with [my]0-i love instead of it .

So [Birdalone]101-birdalone did on the gown , and became to look on as [the daintiest of [the queens of [the earth]445-the earth]1572-the queens of the earth]1571-the daintiest of the queens of the earth ; and [she]101-birdalone turned [her]101-birdalone head about to look on [her]101-birdalone gold - clad flanks , and wondered .

Thereafter [Atra]117-atra knit up [her]117-atra skirts into [her]117-atra girdle , and then did off [her]117-atra shoon , so that [her]117-atra slim feet shone like pearls on the green grass ; and [she]117-atra said :

[Birdalone]101-birdalone , [sweet friend]1574-sweet friend ! wilt [thou]1569-thou be [[my]0-i messenger]1575-my messenger to bear these shoon to [[my]0-i Black Squire]1576-my black squire , and meanwhile put [my]0-i love for [thee]1569-thou under [thy]1569-thou feet , to speed [thee]1569-thou and to bear [thee]1569-thou up ? Wherefore be good to [me]0-i .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone then shod [herself]101-birdalone , and though pity it were to hide [her]101-birdalone feet from the eyes of [Earth]464-earth , yet felt [she]101-birdalone the stouter - hearted thereby , and [her]101-birdalone cheeks flushed and [her]101-birdalone eyes brightened .

Thereafter [Aurea]116-viridis gave [her]101-birdalone withal a golden collar for the neck , and Viridis a girdle of silver well - wrought , and Atra a gold finger - ring set with a sapphire stone ; and all these [she]116-viridis did on [her]116-viridis ; but yet [she]116-viridis knew that they were tokens to be delivered to [the three lovers]1578-the three lovers according as was due .

Then spake [Atra]117-atra : Lo , [sister]783-sister , [we]1580-we pray [thee]1569-thou to bear these lendings on [thy]1569-thou body in such wise that when [thou]1569-thou comest to [the mainland]1038-the mainland [they]1582-they may be seen by [knights seeking adventures]1583-knights seeking adventures , and that [thou]1569-thou mayst answer to any who may challenge [thee]1569-thou thereof and say that [thou]1569-thou bearest this raiment and these jewels from [Aurea and Viridis]116-viridis and [Atra]117-atra to [Baudoin the Golden Knight]123-baudoin , and to [Hugh the Green Knight]124-hugh , and to [Arthur the Black Squire]125-arthur . And if [thou]1569-thou deem that [thou]1569-thou hast found these , then shall [they]1578-the three lovers tell [thee]1569-thou a token , such as [we]1580-we shall tell [thee]1569-thou , that they be truly these and none other ; and thereafter , when [thou]1569-thou art made sure , [they]1578-the three lovers shall take of [thee]1569-thou the raiment , the gems , and the Sending Boat , and come hither if [they]1578-the three lovers may . And [God]120-god look to the rest ! But as for the token to be told aforesaid , [we]1580-we have determined that each of [us]1580-we shall tell [thee]1569-thou privily what question [thou]1569-thou shalt ask for [her]1569-thou , and what answer [thou]1569-thou must look for .

When [she]1569-thou had done speaking , [each]1584-each came up to [Birdalone]101-birdalone and spake something into [her]101-birdalone ear amidst blushes enough forsooth . And what [they]1578-the three lovers said will be seen hereafter . Then again said [Atra]117-atra : Now by this errand shall [we]1580-we be well paid for the care [we]1580-we have had of [thee]1569-thou . It may be , forsooth , that [thou]1569-thou shalt not find [[our]1580-we speech - friends]1585-our speech - friends ; for [they]1585-our speech - friends may be dead , or [they]1585-our speech - friends may deem [us]1580-we untrue , and may have forsaken [us]1580-we and [[their]1585-our speech - friends land]1586-their land ; and in any such case [thou]1569-thou art free of [our]1580-we errand ; but whatsoever may betide [us]1580-we , [God]120-god speed [thee]1569-thou !

Then [Viridis]116-viridis drew forth a basket from under a bush , and said : [We]1580-we know not how long [thy]116-viridis voyage may be , but some little provision for the way [we]1580-we may at least give [thee]116-viridis : now wilt [thou]1569-thou bear this aboard [thyself]1587-thyself ; for [we]1580-we dare not touch [[thy]116-viridis craft]1588-thy craft , nay , nor come nigh it , [no one of [us]1580-we]1589-no one of us . And [she]116-viridis set down the basket and cast [her]116-viridis arms about [her]116-viridis , and kissed [her]116-viridis and wept over [her]116-viridis ; and the other twain , [they]1590-they also kissed [her]116-viridis lovingly . [Birdalone]101-birdalone wept even as [Viridis]116-viridis , and said : May [ye]1590-they do well , who have been so kind to [me]0-i ; but now am [I]0-i both so glad and so sorry , that the voice of [me]0-i will not make due words for [me]0-i . O farewell !

Therewith [she]101-birdalone took up [her]101-birdalone basket , and turned and went speedily to [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat ; and [they]1590-they beheld [her]101-birdalone how [she]101-birdalone stepped aboard and bared [her]101-birdalone arm , and drew blood from it with the pin of [her]101-birdalone girdle - buckle , and therewith reddened stem and stern ; and a pang of fear smote into [their]1590-they hearts lest [[their]1590-they lady]1592-their lady had banned it for [Birdalone]101-birdalone as for [them]1590-they . But [Birdalone]101-birdalone sat down on the thwart , and turned [her]101-birdalone face south , and spake :

The red raven - wine now Hast [thou]1593-thou drunk , stern and bow ; Awake then , awake ! And the southward way take : The way of the Wender forth over the flood , For the will of [the Sender]867-the sender is blent with the blood .
