No cloud barred the gateway of the sun as [she]101-birdalone spoke ; no wave rose upon the bosom of [the lake]369-the lake ; no clatter nor tumult was there ; but [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat stirred , and then shot out swiftly into [the wide water]1087-the wide water ; and the sun arose as [they]1590-they looked , and [his]1598-his path of light flashed on [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's golden gown for a moment , and then it grew grey again , and presently [she]101-birdalone was gone from before [their]1590-they eyes .

So [they]1590-they turned up into [the orchard]469-the orchard : and now was [Viridis of good cheer]1600-viridis of good cheer , and [Aurea]116-viridis no less ; but [Atra]117-atra lagged behind , and as [she]117-atra went , some passion took [her]117-atra , [she]117-atra knew not wherefore ; [her]117-atra bosom swelled , [her]117-atra shoulders heaved therewith , and [she]117-atra wept .

CHAPTER IX . HOW [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone CAME TO [THE ISLE]26-the isle OF [THE YOUNG]126-the young AND THE OLD

All went well with [Birdalone]101-birdalone when [she]101-birdalone had left [the Isle of Increase]1601-the isle of increase Unsought , much as it had on [her]101-birdalone first voyage , save that now [she]101-birdalone was both clad and victualled , and [her]101-birdalone heart , if yet it harboured fear , was also full of new and strange hope ; and oft , even as [she]101-birdalone sat there amidst [the waste of waters]1602-the waste of waters , [she]101-birdalone wondered what new longing this was which wrought so sweet a pain in [her]101-birdalone , that it made [her]101-birdalone cheeks burn , and [her]101-birdalone eyes dim , and [her]101-birdalone hands and [her]101-birdalone limbs restless . And then would [she]101-birdalone set [her]101-birdalone mind to [[her]101-birdalone friends]1314-her friends and [their]1314-her friends errand , and would hope and pray for [them]1314-her friends ; but again would [she]101-birdalone fall to picture to [herself]101-birdalone what manner of [men]219-men [they]1314-her friends were who were so sore longed for by [those three beauteous women]1605-those three beauteous women ; and [she]101-birdalone deemed that since [they]1314-her friends were thus desired , [they]1314-her friends must be fairer even than [[her]101-birdalone friends of [the isle]642-the isle]1606-her friends of the isle ; and again the nameless longing overtook [her]101-birdalone , and held [her]101-birdalone till it wearied [her]101-birdalone into sleep .

When [she]101-birdalone awoke again [the boat]859-the boat had stayed , and [she]101-birdalone was come aland ; but the dawn was not yet come , and the night was moonless , yet was there light enough to see , from the water and the stars , that the bows of [the boat]859-the boat were lying safe on [a little sandy beach]1610-a little sandy beach . So [she]101-birdalone stepped out and looked around , and deemed [she]101-birdalone could see great trees before [her]101-birdalone , and imagined also dark masses of [she]101-birdalone knew not what . So [she]101-birdalone walked warily up [the said strand]1611-the said strand till [she]101-birdalone came on to soft grass , and smelled the scent of the clover as [her]101-birdalone foot - soles crushed it . There [she]101-birdalone sat down , and presently lay along and went to sleep .

After a while [she]101-birdalone awoke , and felt happy and well at ease , and had no will to move : the sun was shining brightly , but had not been up long : the song of birds was all about [her]101-birdalone , but amidst it [she]101-birdalone deemed [she]101-birdalone heard some speech of [man]548-man , though it were not like to what [she]101-birdalone had heard in [her]101-birdalone life before . So [she]101-birdalone raised [herself]101-birdalone on [her]101-birdalone elbow , and looked up and saw a new thing , and sat up now , and beheld and wondered .

For there stood before [her]101-birdalone , gazing wide - eyed on [her]101-birdalone , [two little children , some three winters of age]1613-two little children , some three winters of age , [a man]234-a man and [a woman as it seemed]1615-a woman as it seemed . [The man - child with light and fine white - golden hair , falling straight down and square over [his]1616-the man - child with light and fine white - golden hair , falling straight down and square over his brow brow]1616-the man - child with light and fine white - golden hair , falling straight down and square over his brow , and blue - grey eyes which were both kind and merry , and shyly seeking as it were . Plump and rosy [he]1616-the man - child with light and fine white - golden hair , falling straight down and square over his brow was , sturdy and stout - limbed . No less fair was [the woman]252-the woman ; [her]252-the woman hair golden - brown , as oft it is with [children who grow up dark - haired]1618-children who grow up dark - haired , and curling in fair little rings all over [her]252-the woman head ; [her]252-the woman eyes were big and dark grey ; [she]252-the woman was thinner than [the lad]1619-the lad , and somewhat taller .

[These two babes]1620-these two babes had between [them]1620-these two babes a milk - white she - goat , and had been playing with [her]101-birdalone , and now [she]101-birdalone turned [her]101-birdalone head to this and that one of [them]1620-these two babes , bleating , as if to crave more of the game ; but [they]1620-these two babes had no eyes for [her]101-birdalone , but stood staring with might and main on [the new - comer]518-the new - comer and [her]101-birdalone shining golden gown .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone laughed with joy when [she]101-birdalone saw [the little ones]1622-the little ones , and a dim memory of the days of [Utterhay]3-utterhay passed before [her]101-birdalone : [she]101-birdalone stretched out a hand to [them]1622-the little ones , and spake softly and caressingly , and [the little lad]1623-the little lad came forward smiling , and took [her]101-birdalone hand , and made as if [he]1623-the little lad would help [her]101-birdalone up for courtesy 's sake . [She]101-birdalone laughed on [him]1623-the little lad , and arose ; and when [she]101-birdalone stood up , tall and golden , [he]1623-the little lad seemed somewhat afeard of so big a creature , but stood [his]1623-the little lad ground valiantly . Then [she]101-birdalone stooped down to [him]1623-the little lad and kissed [him]1623-the little lad , and [he]1623-the little lad naysaid [her]101-birdalone not , but seemed rather glad when it was over ; but when [Birdalone]101-birdalone went to [the little maid]1624-the little maid , and kissed [her]1624-the little maid , [the child]253-the child clung to [her]1624-the little maid as if [she]1624-the little maid were [[her]253-the child mother]332-her mother , and babbled to [her]1624-the little maid .

Then comes [the lad]1619-the lad to [her]101-birdalone , and takes [her]101-birdalone hand , and would draw [her]101-birdalone away , and speaks to [her]101-birdalone in [his]1619-the lad prattle , and [she]101-birdalone understood [him]1619-the lad to mean that [she]101-birdalone should come with [him]1619-the lad to see [the father]1628-the father . So [she]101-birdalone went , wondering what should next betide ; and [the little maiden]1629-the little maiden went on the other side of [her]101-birdalone , holding by a fold of [her]1629-the little maiden skirt . Forsooth the goat followed bleating , not well pleased to be forgotten .

Now had [Birdalone]101-birdalone time to look about [her]101-birdalone , though [the two babes]1630-the two babes fell to prattling with [her]101-birdalone in [their]1630-the two babes way , and [she]101-birdalone thought it sweet to look down on the two little faces that looked up to [her]101-birdalone so pleased and merry .

[She]101-birdalone was in [a grassy plain]1631-a grassy plain , somewhat over rough and broken to be called [a meadow]1632-a meadow , and not enough be - timbered to be called [a wood]1633-a wood ; it rose up a little and slowly as [they]1630-the two babes left [the water]361-the water , but scarce so much as one might call [it]1635-it [a hill]1636-a hill . Straight before [her]101-birdalone on the way that [they]1630-the two babes were going went up into the air great masses of grey stone builded by [man]548-man 's hand , but looking , even from this way off , ragged and ruinous . It may well be thought that [Birdalone]101-birdalone wondered what things might lie betwixt the trees and [the towers]1638-the towers .

Now as [they]1630-the two babes went [they]1630-the two babes came on other goats , who seemed tame , and these joined [them]1630-the two babes to [their]1630-the two babes fellow , and suffered [the younglings]1639-the younglings to play with [them]1630-the two babes . Moreover there were [rabbits great plenty scuttling in and out of the brakes]1640-rabbits great plenty scuttling in and out of the brakes and the rough ground upon the way , and [the younglings]1639-the younglings beheld [them]1640-rabbits great plenty scuttling in and out of the brakes , and [the little lad]1623-the little lad said , after [his]1623-the little lad fashion : Why do the rabbits run away from [us]1630-the two babes , and the goats follow [us]1630-the two babes ? Now , sooth to say , [Birdalone]101-birdalone scarce knew why , and had no word ready for [the child]253-the child ; but [she]101-birdalone said at last : Mayhappen [they]1640-rabbits great plenty scuttling in and out of the brakes will come to [me]0-i ; so it was once when [I]0-i dwelt away from here . Shall [I]0-i go fetch [thee]253-the child one ? [The little ones]1622-the little ones yeasaid that , though somewhat shyly and doubtfully . Then said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : Do [ye]253-the child , [sweetlings]1645-sweetlings , abide [me]0-i here , and go not away . [They]1622-the little ones nodded [their]1622-the little ones heads thereat , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone kilted [her]101-birdalone skirts and went [her]101-birdalone ways to some broken bushed ground , where was a many rabbits playing about ; but [she]101-birdalone went not out of eye - shot of [the babes]1646-the babes . Before [she]101-birdalone was well - nigh to the little beasts , [she]101-birdalone fell to talking to [them]1622-the little ones in a low sweet voice , as had been [her]101-birdalone wo nt when [she]101-birdalone was little ; and when [they]1622-the little ones heard it , [those who had not scuttled away at first glance of [her]101-birdalone]1647-those who had not scuttled away at first glance of her , fell to creeping little short creeps one to the other , as [their]1622-the little ones manner is when [they]1622-the little ones be alone together and merry ; and [they]1622-the little ones suffered [her]101-birdalone to come quite amongst [them]1622-the little ones , and crept about [her]101-birdalone feet while [she]101-birdalone stood , still talking unto [them]1622-the little ones . Then [she]101-birdalone stooped down and took up one in [her]101-birdalone arms and caressed it , and then laid [him]1648-him down and took up another , and so with three or four of [them]1622-the little ones ; and [she]101-birdalone fell to pushing [them]1622-the little ones , and rolling them over with [her]101-birdalone foot ; then [she]101-birdalone turned a little away from [them]1622-the little ones toward [the children]1649-the children , and then a little more , and the rabbits fell to following [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone turned and took up one in [her]101-birdalone arms , and went straight on toward [the children]1649-the children , but turning and talking to [the rabbits]1651-the rabbits now and again .

As to [the babes]1646-the babes , [she]101-birdalone saw [the goats , of whom were now a dozen , or thereabouts , standing together in a kind of ring]1653-the goats , of whom were now a dozen , or thereabouts , standing together in a kind of ring , and [the little ones]1622-the little ones going from one to the other playing with [them]1622-the little ones happily . But presently [the lad]1619-the lad turned and saw [her]101-birdalone coming with [her]101-birdalone tail of little beasts , and [he]1619-the lad cried out a great Oh and ran toward [her]101-birdalone straightway , and [the maiden]406-the maiden after [him]1619-the lad ; and [he]1619-the lad held out [his]1619-the lad arms to have the rabbit [she]101-birdalone bore , and [she]101-birdalone gave it to [him]1619-the lad smiling , and said : [Lo]128-lo now ! here be [pretty playmates]1657-pretty playmates ; but look to it that [ye]1619-the lad be soft and kind with [them]1657-pretty playmates , for [they]1657-pretty playmates are but [feeble people]1658-feeble people . So [the younglings]1639-the younglings fell to sporting with [[their]1639-the younglings new friends]1660-their new friends , and for a little forgat both goats and [golden lady]1661-golden lady ; but the goats drew nigh , and stood about [them]1639-the younglings bleating , nor durst [they]1639-the younglings run at the rabbits to butt [them]1639-the younglings , because of [Birdalone]101-birdalone and [the little ones]1622-the little ones .

There then stood [the slim maiden]1663-the slim maiden , tall and gleaming above [her]1663-the slim maiden little flock ; and [her]1663-the slim maiden heart was full of mirth and rest , and the fear was all forgotten . But as [she]1663-the slim maiden looked up toward the grey walls , lo , new tidings to hand ! For [she]1663-the slim maiden saw [an old man with a long white beard]1664-an old man with a long white beard slowly coming toward [them]1639-the younglings : [she]1663-the slim maiden started not , but abode [his]1664-an old man with a long white beard coming quietly , and as [he]1664-an old man with a long white beard drew nigh [she]1663-the slim maiden could see of [him]1664-an old man with a long white beard that [he]1664-an old man with a long white beard was big and stark , and , old as [he]1664-an old man with a long white beard was , not yet bowed with [his]1664-an old man with a long white beard many years . [He]1664-an old man with a long white beard stood looking on [this Queen]1115-this queen and [[her]1115-this queen court]1666-her court silently a while , and then [he]1664-an old man with a long white beard spake : Such a sight [I]0-i looked not to see on this Isle of [the Young]126-the young and [the Old]1667-the old . [She]1663-the slim maiden said : But meseemeth it is full meet that [these younglings]1668-these younglings should sport with the creatures . [He]1664-an old man with a long white beard smiled and said : Such a voice [I]0-i looked not to hear on [the Isle of [the Young]1670-the young]1669-the isle of the young and [the Old]1667-the old .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone became somewhat troubled , and said : Am [I]0-i welcome here ? for if [I]0-i be not , [I]0-i will pray [thy]1663-the slim maiden leave to depart . [He]1664-an old man with a long white beard said : [Thou]1663-the slim maiden art as welcome as the very spring , [[my]0-i child]915-my child ; and if [thou]1663-the slim maiden have a mind to abide here , who shall naysay [thee]1663-the slim maiden ? For surely [thou]1663-the slim maiden art young ; nay , in regard to [me]0-i [thou]1663-the slim maiden art scarce older than [babes]1673-babes . All blessings be with [thee]1663-the slim maiden . But though [thou]1663-the slim maiden art true and kind , as is clear to be seen by [thy]1663-the slim maiden playing with [these children]1674-these children and the landward beasts in peace and love , yet it may be so that [thou]1663-the slim maiden hast brought hither somewhat less than peace . And [he]1664-an old man with a long white beard smiled upon [her]915-my child strangely .

[She]915-my child looked somewhat scared at [his]1664-an old man with a long white beard last words , and said : But how so ? If [I]0-i might [I]0-i would bear nought but peace and happiness to any place . [The old carle]1675-the old carle laughed outright now , and said : How so , [dear child]1676-dear child ? because [ladies]1677-ladies so sweet and lovesome as [thou]1663-the slim maiden be sent by love , and love rendeth apart that which was joined together .

[She]915-my child wondered at [his]1664-an old man with a long white beard word , and was bewildered by it , but [she]915-my child held [her]915-my child peace ; and [he]1664-an old man with a long white beard said : Now [we]1678-we may talk hereof later on ; but the matter to hand now is the quenching of thine hunger ; for [I]0-i will not ask [thee]915-my child whereby [thou]915-my child camest , since by water [thou]915-my child needs must have come . Wherefore now [I]0-i bid [thee]915-my child to [[our]1678-we house]1679-our house , and [these little ones]1680-these little ones shall go with [us]1678-we , and [the three of [these horned folk whom [we]1678-we are wo nt to tether amidst the wrack and ruin of what once was fair]1682-these horned folk whom we are wo nt to tether amidst the wrack and ruin of what once was fair]1681-the three of these horned folk whom we are wo nt to tether amidst the wrack and ruin of what once was fair ; [the rest]1683-the rest have [our]1678-we leave to depart , and [these nibblers]1684-these nibblers also ; for [we]1678-we have a potherb garden by [[our]1678-we house]1679-our house , and are fain to keep the increase of the same for [ourselves]1678-we . [Birdalone]101-birdalone laughed , and shook [her]101-birdalone skirts at [the coneys]1686-the coneys , and [they]1686-the coneys all scuttled away after the manner of [their]1686-the coneys kind . Thereat [the little lad]1623-the little lad looked downcast and well - nigh tearful , but [the maid]602-the maid stamped [her]602-the maid foot , and roared well - favouredly .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone did [her]101-birdalone best to solace [her]101-birdalone , and plucked a bough from a hawthorn bush far above [the little ones]1622-the little ones ' reach whereon was yet some belated blossom , and gave it to [her]101-birdalone and stilled [her]101-birdalone . But [the old man]7080-the old man picked out [his]7080-the old man milch - goats from the flock whereof was the white , and drave [them]1622-the little ones before [him]7080-the old man , while [the two babes]1630-the two babes went on still beside [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [the little carle]7082-the little carle holding [her]7082-the little carle hand and playing with the fingers thereof ; [the maiden]406-the maiden sometimes hanging on to [her]406-the maiden gown , sometimes going loose and sporting about beside [her]406-the maiden .[101-birdalone]

So came [they]1622-the little ones to where [the ground]1690-the ground became smoother , and there was a fair piece of greensward in [a nook made by those great walls and towers]1691-a nook made by those great walls and towers , which sheltered [it]1692-it from the north . [The said walls]1693-the said walls seemed to be the remnant of what had once been [a great house]1694-a great house and castle ; and up aloft , where was now no stair to come at [them]1693-the said walls , were chimneys and hearths here and there , and windows with fair seats in [them]1693-the said walls , and arched doors and carven pillars , and many things beautiful , but now was all ruined and broken , and [the house]325-the house was roofless and floorless : [withal]1696-withal [it]325-the house was overgrown with ash - trees and quicken - beam , and other berry - trees and key - trees , which had many years ago seeded in the rent walls , and now grew there great and flourishing . But in the innermost nook of this mighty remnant , and using for [its]325-the house lowly walls two sides of the ancient ashlar ones , stood a cot builded not over trimly of small wood , and now much overgrown with roses and woodbine . In front of [it]325-the house was a piece of garden ground , wherein waxed potherbs , and a little deal of wheat ; and therein was a goodly row of bee- skeps ; and all without it was [the pleasant greensward]1697-the pleasant greensward aforesaid , wherein stood three great ancient oaks , and divers thorns , which also were ancient after their kind .

[The elder]1698-the elder led [[his]1698-the elder guest]1699-his guest into the cot , which had but simple plenishing of stools and benches , and a table unartful , and then went to tether [his]1698-the elder goats in [the ruined hall of [the house]325-the house]1700-the ruined hall of the house , and [the children]1649-the children must needs with [him]1698-the elder , though [Birdalone]101-birdalone had been glad of one of [them]1649-the children at least ; but there was no nay , but that [they]1649-the children must go see [their]1649-the children dear white goat in [her]101-birdalone stall . Howsoever [all three]1245-all three came back again presently , [the old carle]1675-the old carle with a courteous word in [his]1675-the old carle mouth , and [he]1675-the old carle took [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's hand , and kissed it and bade [her]101-birdalone welcome to [[his]1675-the old carle house]1705-his house , as though [he]1675-the old carle had been [a great lord at [home]387-home in [[his]1675-the old carle own castle]1708-his own castle]1706-a great lord at home in his own castle . Therewith must [the little ones]1622-the little ones also kiss [her]101-birdalone hand and be courteous ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone suffered it , laughing , and then caught [them]1622-the little ones up in [her]101-birdalone arms , and clipped and kissed [them]1622-the little ones well - favouredly ; wherewith belike [they]1622-the little ones were not over - well pleased , though [the boy]1710-the boy endured it kindly . Thereafter [the elder]1698-the elder set forth [his]1698-the elder banquet , which was simple enough : upland cheer of cream and honey , and rough bread ; but sweet it was to [Birdalone]101-birdalone to eat it with good welcome , and the courtesy of [the old man]7080-the old man .

When [they]1622-the little ones were done , [they]1622-the little ones went out - a - doors , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone and [the old man]7080-the old man laid [them]1622-the little ones down under an oak - tree , and [the children]1649-the children sported about anigh [them]1622-the little ones . Then spake [Birdalone]101-birdalone : [Old man]1715-old man , [thou]1716-thou hast been kind unto [me]0-i ; but now wouldest [thou]1716-thou tell [me]0-i about [thee]1716-thou , what [thou]1716-thou art , and what are these walls about [us]1622-the little ones here ? Said [he]7080-the old man : [I]0-i doubt if [I]0-i may do so , this day at least . But belike [thou]1716-thou shalt abide with [us]1622-the little ones , and then some day the word may come into [my]0-i mouth . [She]101-birdalone held [her]101-birdalone peace , and into [her]101-birdalone mind it came that it would be sweet to dwell [there]232-there , and watch [those fair children]1718-those fair children waxing , and [the lad]1619-the lad growing up and loving [her]101-birdalone ; yea , even [she]101-birdalone fell to telling up the years which would make [him]1619-the lad [a man]234-a man , and tried to see [herself]101-birdalone , how [she]101-birdalone would look , when the years were worn thereto . Then [she]101-birdalone reddened at the untold thought , and looked down and was silent . But [the elder]1698-the elder looked on [her]101-birdalone anxiously , and said : It will be no such hard life for [thee]101-birdalone , for [I]0-i have still some work in [me]0-i , and [thou]1722-thou mayst do something in spite of [thy]1722-thou slender and delicate fashion . [She]101-birdalone laughed merrily , and said : Forsooth , [good sire]1723-good sire , [I]0-i might do somewhat more than something ; for [I]0-i am deft in all such work as here [ye]1723-good sire need ; so fear not but [I]0-i should earn [my]0-i livelihood , and that with joy . Merry days shall [we]1724-we have then , said [he]1698-the elder .

But therewith [her]101-birdalone eye caught the gleam of [her]101-birdalone golden sleeve , and [she]101-birdalone thought of [Aurea]116-viridis , and [her]101-birdalone heart smote [her]101-birdalone for [her]101-birdalone errand ; then [she]101-birdalone laid [her]101-birdalone hand on [her]101-birdalone girdle and called to mind [little Viridis]116-viridis , and the glitter of the ring on [her]101-birdalone finger brought the image of [Atra]117-atra before [her]101-birdalone ; then [she]101-birdalone rose up and said : [Thou]1725-thou art kind , [father]1726-father , but [I]0-i may not ; [I]0-i have an errand ; this day must [I]0-i depart from [thee]1726-father . [He]1726-father said : [Thou]1725-thou hast broken [my]0-i heart ; if [I]0-i were not so old , [I]0-i would weep . And [he]1726-father hung adown [his]1726-father head .

[She]101-birdalone stood before [him]1726-father abashed , as if [she]101-birdalone had done [him]1726-father a wrong . At last [he]1726-father looked up and said : Must it be to - day ? Wilt [thou]1725-thou not abide with [us]1727-us night - long , and go [thy]1725-thou ways in the early morning ?

Now [she]101-birdalone scarce knew how to gainsay [him]1726-father , so wretched as [the old carle]1675-the old carle looked ; so it came to this , that [she]101-birdalone yeasaid the abiding till to- morrow . Then suddenly [he]1726-father became gay and merry , and [he]1726-father kissed [her]101-birdalone hand , and fell to much speaking , telling tales of little import concerning [his]1726-father earlier days . But when [she]101-birdalone asked [him]1726-father again of how [he]1726-father came [there]232-there , and what meant [the great ruined house]1730-the great ruined house , then [he]1726-father became foolish and wandering , and might scarce answer [her]101-birdalone ; whereas otherwise [he]1726-father was [a well - spoken old carle of many words , and those of the grandest]1731-a well - spoken old carle of many words , and those of the grandest .

Then changed [his]1726-father mood again , and [he]1726-father fell to bewailing [her]101-birdalone departure , and how that henceforth [he]1726-father should have none to speak to [him]1726-father with understanding . Then [she]101-birdalone smiled on [him]1726-father and said : But yonder babes will grow up ; month by month [they]1732-they will be better fellows unto [thee]1726-father . [Fair child]958-fair child , [he]1726-father said , [thou]101-birdalone dost not know . [My]0-i days to come are but few , so that [I]0-i should see but little of [their]1732-they waxing in any case . But furthermore , wax [they]1732-they will not ; such as [they]1732-they be now , such shall [they]1732-they be till [I]0-i at least see the last of them and [the earth]445-the earth .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone wondered at this word , and the place seemed changed to [her]101-birdalone , [yea]1735-yea , was grown somewhat dreary ; but [she]101-birdalone said to [the carle]1736-the carle : And [thou]1736-the carle , dost [thou]1736-the carle change in any wise , since these change not ? [He]1726-father laughed somewhat grimly , and said : [The old that be here]1737-the old that be here change from old to dead ; how could [I]0-i change to better ? Yea , the first thing [I]0-i had to do [here]259-here was to bury [an old man]1739-an old man . Quoth [she]101-birdalone : And were there [any children]1740-any children [here]259-here then ? [Yea]1735-yea , said [he]1726-father ; these same , or [I]0-i can see no difference in them . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : And how long ago is that ? And how camest [thou]1736-the carle hither ? [His]1726-father face became foolish , and [he]1726-father gibbered rather than spake : No , [I]0-i wot not ; no , no , no , not a whit , a whit . But presently after was [he]1726-father [himself]1726-father again , and telling [her]101-birdalone a tale of [a great lady of the earl - folk]1742-a great lady of the earl - folk , [[a baron]1743-a baron 's dame]1744-a baron 's dame , and how dear [he]1726-father was unto [her]101-birdalone . [He]1726-father lay yet on the grass , and [she]101-birdalone stood before [him]1726-father , and presently [he]1726-father put forth a hand to [her]101-birdalone gown - hem and drew [her]101-birdalone to [him]1726-father thereby , and fell to caressing [her]101-birdalone feet ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone was ashamed thereat , and a little angry . [He]1726-father was nought abashed , but sat up and said : Well , since [thou]1745-thou must needs depart to - morrow , be [we]1746-we merry to - day . And [I]0-i pray [thee]101-birdalone talk much with [me]0-i , [fair child]958-fair child , for sweet and sweet is [thy]101-birdalone voice to hearken . Then [he]1726-father arose and said : Now will [I]0-i fetch [thee]101-birdalone somewhat to eke the joy of [us]1746-we both . And [he]1726-father turned therewith and went into [the house]325-the house .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone stood there , and was now perplexed and downhearted ; for now the look of [the elder scarce]1749-the elder scarce liked [her]101-birdalone , and [the children]1649-the children began to seem to [her]101-birdalone as images , or at the best not more to [her]101-birdalone than the rabbits or the goats ; and [she]101-birdalone rued [her]101-birdalone word that [she]101-birdalone would abide there the night through . For [she]101-birdalone said to [herself]101-birdalone : [I]0-i fear some trap or guile ; is [the witch behind this]1751-the witch behind this also ? for [the old man]7080-the old man is yet stark , and though [he]7080-the old man be foolish at whiles , yet may wizardry have learned [him]7080-the old man some guile .

With that cometh out the carle again , bearing a little keg and a mazer roughly wrought ; and [he]1726-father came to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and sat down , and bade [her]101-birdalone sit by [him]1726-father , and said to [her]101-birdalone : Maybe [I]0-i shall hear more of [thy]101-birdalone sweet voice when [thy]101-birdalone sweet lips have been in the cup . Therewith [he]1726-father poured forth into the mazer , and handed it to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and lo ! it was clear and good mead . [She]101-birdalone sipped thereof daintily , and , to say sooth , was well - pleased therewith , and it stirred the heart in [her]101-birdalone . But then [she]101-birdalone gave back the cup to [the elder]1698-the elder , and would no more of it . As for [him]1726-father , [he]1726-father drank what was left in the cup , looking over the rim thereof meanwhile ; and then filled [himself]1726-father another , and another , and yet more . But whereas it might have been looked for that [his]1726-father tongue should be loosened by the good mead into foolishness and gibbering , [he]1726-father became rather few - spoken , and more courteous and stately even than [he]1726-father had been at the first . But in the end , forsooth , [he]1726-father was forgetting [Birdalone]101-birdalone , what [she]101-birdalone was , and [he]1726-father fell a - talking , always with much pomp and state , as if to [barons]1754-barons and [earls]1755-earls , and [great ladies]1756-great ladies ; till suddenly [his]1726-father head fell back , [he]1726-father turned over on [his]1726-father face , and all wit was gone from [him]1726-father .

At first , then , [Birdalone]101-birdalone was afraid that [he]1726-father was dead , or nigh unto death , and [she]101-birdalone knelt down and raised [his]1726-father head , and fetched water and cast it over [his]1726-father face . But when [she]101-birdalone saw that [he]1726-father was breathing not so ill , and that the colour was little changed in [his]1726-father lips and cheeks , [she]101-birdalone knew that it was but the might of the mead that had overcome [him]1726-father . Wherefore [she]101-birdalone laid [him]1726-father so that [he]1726-father was easy , and then stood up and looked about [her]101-birdalone , and saw [the children]1649-the children playing together a little way off ; and nought else anigh [her]101-birdalone , save the birds in the brake , or flying on [their]1649-the children errands eagerly from place to place . Then , as it were , without [her]101-birdalone will being told [them]1649-the children , [her]101-birdalone limbs and [her]101-birdalone feet turned [her]101-birdalone about to the shore where lay [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , and [she]101-birdalone went speedily but quietly thitherward , [her]101-birdalone heart beating quick , for fear lest something should yet stay [her]101-birdalone , and [her]101-birdalone eyes glancing from brake to bush , as if [she]101-birdalone looked to see [some enemy , old or new]1759-some enemy , old or new , come out thence .

So now [her]101-birdalone will was clear enough to [her]101-birdalone feet , and [they]1649-the children brought [her]101-birdalone down to the water - side and [the long strand]1760-the long strand , past which [the wide water]1087-the wide water lay windless and gleaming in the hot afternoon . Then lightly [she]101-birdalone stepped aboard , and awoke the Sending Boat with blood - offering , and it obeyed [her]101-birdalone , and sped swiftly on the way to the southward .

CHAPTER X. [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone COMES TO THE ISLE OF [THE QUEENS

Birdalone]101-birdalone awoke the next morning while [the boat]859-the boat was yet speeding over [the water]361-the water , and the sun was up : but [she]101-birdalone was hard on [the land]213-the land , which sat low and green , like [a meadow exceeding fair]1765-a meadow exceeding fair , on the bosom of [the water]361-the water , and many goodly trees were sprinkled about the greenland . But from amidst the trees , no great way from [the water]361-the water 's edge , rose [a great house]1694-a great house , white and fair , as if [it]1694-a great house were new - builded , and all glorious with pinnacles , and tabernacles set with imagery .

Presently [the boat]859-the boat 's bows ran into the reed and rush at the brim of [the water]361-the water , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone stepped ashore without more ado , and the scent of the meadow - sweet amongst which [she]101-birdalone landed brought back unto [her]101-birdalone the image of Green Eyot that while agone .

But now when [she]101-birdalone was ashore the dread took hold of [her]101-birdalone again , and [her]101-birdalone knees trembled under [her]101-birdalone , so that [she]101-birdalone might scarce stand , so fearful was [she]101-birdalone of walking into some trap ; especially when [she]101-birdalone beheld [that goodly house]1771-that goodly house , lest therein awaited [her]101-birdalone [some proud and cruel lady]1772-some proud and cruel lady , and no kind damsels to deliver [her]101-birdalone .

[She]101-birdalone looked about [her]101-birdalone , and saw in all [the fair meadow]1773-the fair meadow neither [man]548-man nor [woman]1775-woman , nor draught - beast nor milch - beast , nought but the little creatures of the brake and the bent - grass , which were but as the blossoms thereof ; and the birds running in the herbage or singing amidst the tree - boughs .

Then [she]101-birdalone thought that [she]101-birdalone must needs go forward , or belike [her]101-birdalone errand would not speed ; that the Sending Boat might not obey [her]101-birdalone , unless [she]101-birdalone saw through the adventure to the end ; so [she]101-birdalone went on toward [the house]325-the house quaking .

Soon was [she]101-birdalone at [the porch of [the white palace]1778-the white palace]1777-the porch of the white palace , and had seen [no man]545-no man nor heard any voice of [men]219-men ; much [she]101-birdalone marvelled , despite [her]101-birdalone dread , at the beauty of [the said house]386-the said house , and the newness thereof ; for it was as one flower arisen out of [the earth]445-the earth , and every part of it made the beauty of the other parts more excellent ; and so new it was , that it would have seemed as if [the masons]1783-the masons thereof had but struck [their]1783-the masons scaffold yesterday , save that under the very feet of the walls the sweet garden flowers grew all uncrushed .

Now comes [Birdalone]101-birdalone through [the porch]664-the porch unto the screens of [the great hall]1785-the great hall ; and [she]101-birdalone stopped a little to recover [her]101-birdalone breath , that [she]101-birdalone might be the quieter and calmer amongst [the great folk]1786-the great folk and mighty whom [she]101-birdalone looked to find therein . So [she]101-birdalone gathered heart ; but one thing daunted [her]101-birdalone , to wit , that [she]101-birdalone heard no sound come from [that great and goodly hall]1787-that great and goodly hall , so that [she]101-birdalone doubted if it were perchance left desert by [them]1788-them who had been [its lords]1789-its lords .

[She]101-birdalone raised [her]101-birdalone hand to the door of the screen , and it opened easily before [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone entered , and there indeed [she]101-birdalone saw new tidings . For the boards end - long and over - thwart were set , and thereat were sitting [a many folk]1790-a many folk , and [their]1790-a many folk hands were reached out to knife and to dish , and to platter and cup ; but such a hush there was within , that the song of the garden birds without sounded to [her]101-birdalone as loud as [they]1791-they were the voices of [the children of Adam]562-the children of adam .

Next [she]101-birdalone saw that [all that company]1793-all that company , from [the great folk on the dais]1794-the great folk on the dais down to [those who stood about the hall to do the service]1795-those who stood about the hall to do the service , were [women , one and all]1796-women , one and all ; [not one carle]1797-not one carle might [she]101-birdalone see from where [she]101-birdalone stood : lovely were [they]1796-women , one and all many of [them]1796-women , one and all , and [none less than comely]1798-none less than comely ; [their]1796-women , one and all cheeks were bright , and [their]1796-women , one and all eyes gleamed , and [their]1796-women , one and all hair flowed down fair of fashion . And [she]101-birdalone stood , and durst not move a long while , but expected when [someone]496-someone would speak a word , and [all]889-all should turn [their]889-all heads toward [the new - comer]518-the new - comer . But [none]1226-none moved nor spake . And the fear increased in [her]101-birdalone amidst that hush , and weighed so heavy on [her]101-birdalone heart , that at last [she]101-birdalone might endure it no longer , but fell swooning to the floor .

When [she]101-birdalone came to [herself]101-birdalone ; and the swoon - dreams had left [her]101-birdalone , [she]101-birdalone saw by the changing of the sun through [the hall]1202-the hall - windows , that [she]101-birdalone had lain there long , more nearly two hours than one ; and at first [she]101-birdalone covered [her]101-birdalone face with [her]101-birdalone hands as [she]101-birdalone crouched there , that [she]101-birdalone might not see the sight of [the silent hall]1804-the silent hall , for yet was it as hushed as before . Then slowly [she]101-birdalone arose , and the sound of [her]101-birdalone raiment and [her]101-birdalone stirring feet was loud in [her]101-birdalone ears . But when [she]101-birdalone was upright on [her]101-birdalone feet , [she]101-birdalone hardened [her]101-birdalone heart , and went forth into [the hall]1202-the hall , and no less was [her]101-birdalone wonder than erst . For when [she]101-birdalone came close to [those ladies]1806-those ladies as [they]1806-those ladies sat at table , and [her]101-birdalone raiment brushed the raiment of [the serving - women]1807-the serving - women as [she]101-birdalone passed by , then saw [she]101-birdalone how no breath came from any of these , and that [they]1806-those ladies neither spake nor moved , because [they]1806-those ladies were dead .

At first , then , [she]101-birdalone thought to flee away at once , but again [she]101-birdalone had mind of [her]101-birdalone errand , and so went up [the hall]1202-the hall , and so forth on to the dais ; and there again , close by the high table , [she]101-birdalone saw new tidings . For there was set a bier , covered with gold and pall , and on it was laid [a tall man]1809-a tall man , [a king]1810-a king , belted and crowned ; and beside the said bier , by the head of [the king]1345-the king , knelt [a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin]1812-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin ; and [her]1812-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin hands were clasped together , and [her]1812-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin mouth was drawn , and [her]1812-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin brow knit with the anguish of [her]1812-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin grief . But athwart [the king]1345-the king 's breast lay a naked sword all bloody ; and this [Birdalone]101-birdalone noted , that whereas [the lady]1157-the lady was of skin and hue as if [she]1157-the lady were alive , [the king]1345-the king was yellow as wax , and [his]1345-the king cheeks were shrunken , and [his]1345-the king eyes had been closed by the wakers of the dead .

Long [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked and wondered ; and now if [her]101-birdalone fear were less , [her]101-birdalone sorrow was more for [all that folk sitting there dead in [their]1816-all that folk sitting there dead in their ancient state and pomp ancient state and pomp]1816-all that folk sitting there dead in their ancient state and pomp . And was not the thought clean out of [her]101-birdalone head , that yet [they]1816-all that folk sitting there dead in their ancient state and pomp might awake and challenge [her]101-birdalone , and that [she]101-birdalone might be made [one of that silent company]1817-one of that silent company . Withal [she]101-birdalone felt [her]101-birdalone head beginning to fail [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone feared that [she]101-birdalone might swoon again and never waken more , but lie for ever beside that image of [the dead king]1818-the dead king .

So then [she]101-birdalone refrained [her]101-birdalone both of fear and sorrow , and walked speedily down [the hall]1202-the hall , looking neither to the right nor left : and [she]101-birdalone came forth into the pleasance , but stayed there nought , so nigh it seemed to [that hushed company]1820-that hushed company . Thence came [she]101-birdalone forth into [the open meadow]1821-the open meadow , and sweet and dear seemed its hot sunshine and noisy birds and rustling leaves . Nevertheless , so great was the tumult of [her]101-birdalone spirits , that once more [she]101-birdalone grew faint , and felt that [she]101-birdalone might scarce go further . So [she]101-birdalone dragged [herself]101-birdalone into the shade of a thorn- tree , and let [her]101-birdalone body sink unto the ground , and lay there long unwitting .

CHAPTER XI . AND NOW [SHE]101-birdalone COMES TO [THE ISLE]26-the isle OF [THE KINGS]27-the kings

When [Birdalone]101-birdalone came to [herself]101-birdalone it was drawing toward the glooming , and [she]101-birdalone rose up hastily , and went down to [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , for [she]101-birdalone would not for aught abide the night in [that fearful isle]1823-that fearful isle , lest [the flock of the hall]1824-the flock of the hall should come alive and walk in the dusk and the dark . [She]101-birdalone stepped aboard lightly , and yielded [her]101-birdalone blood to the pride of [that ferry]1825-that ferry , and it awoke and bore [her]101-birdalone forth , and [she]101-birdalone went through the night till [she]101-birdalone fell asleep .

When [she]101-birdalone awoke it was broad day and the sun just arising , and lo ! before [her]101-birdalone , some half mile off , [an isle rugged and rocky , and going up steep from the shore]1826-an isle rugged and rocky , and going up steep from the shore ; and then , held as it were by the fangs of the rocks and pikes of [the higher land]1827-the higher land , was [a castle]1828-a castle , white , high , and hugely builded , though , because of [the rock - land belike]1829-the rock - land belike , [it]1828-a castle spread not much abroad . Like to [the lovely house of yesterday]1830-the lovely house of yesterday , [it]1828-a castle seemed new - builded ; and , little as [Birdalone]101-birdalone knew of such matters , [her]101-birdalone heart told [her]101-birdalone that [this new house]1831-this new house was fashioned for battle .

[She]101-birdalone was downcast when [she]101-birdalone saw [the isle]642-the isle so rugged and forbidding , but when [the boat]859-the boat came aland in [a stony bight]1834-a stony bight , whence the ground went up somewhat steeply toward [the heights]1835-the heights , [she]101-birdalone went ashore straightway , and toiled up toward [the white battlement]1836-the white battlement . Presently [she]101-birdalone found [herself]101-birdalone in [a strait and rugged path betwixt two walls of rock]1837-a strait and rugged path betwixt two walls of rock , so that [she]101-birdalone lost sight of [the castle]1838-the castle a while , till [she]101-birdalone came out on to [a level place which looked down from aloft on to [the blue water]1840-the blue water]1839-a level place which looked down from aloft on to the blue water , but all over against [her]101-birdalone close at hand were the great towers and walls . [She]101-birdalone was worn by [the rough road]1841-the rough road , and over helpless [she]101-birdalone felt [her]101-birdalone , and all too little to deal with that huge morsel of [the world]430-the world ; and [her]101-birdalone valiancy gave way , and [her]101-birdalone trust in [her]101-birdalone errand . [She]101-birdalone sat down on a stone and wept abundantly .

After a while [she]101-birdalone was amended , and [she]101-birdalone looked up and saw the huge hold , and said : Yea , but if it were less by the half than it is , it would still be big enough to cow [me]0-i . Yet [she]101-birdalone stood not up . Then [she]101-birdalone put forth a foot of [her]101-birdalone , and said aloud : Sorely hath [this rough road]1843-this rough road tried [[Atra]117-atra 's shoon]1844-atra 's shoon and [their]1844-atra 's shoon goodly window - work ; if they are to be known [I]0-i must be speedy on [my]0-i journey or go barefoot .

As [she]101-birdalone spoke [she]101-birdalone stood up , and the sound of [her]101-birdalone own voice frighted [her]101-birdalone , though nought noiseless was [the place]1845-the place ; for the wind was there , and beat to and fro [the castle]1838-the castle and [the rock]1847-the rock , and ran baffled into every corner of [that market - place of nothing]1848-that market - place of nothing . For in [that garth]1849-that garth was [neither knight]1850-neither knight nor [squire]1851-squire nor [sergeant]1852-sergeant ; no spear - head glittered from the wall , no gleam of helm showed from the war - swales ; [no porter]1853-no porter was at the gate ; the drawbridge over [the deep ghyll]1854-the deep ghyll was down , the portcullis was up , and the great door cast wide open .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone steeled [her]101-birdalone heart and went forward swiftly , and over [the bridge]1855-the bridge , and entered [the basecourt]1856-the basecourt , and came without more ado to the door of [the great hall]1785-the great hall , and opened [it]1858-it easily , as with the door of yesterday , looking to find another show like unto that one ; and even so it fell out .

Forsooth [the hall]1202-the hall was nought light and lovely , and gay with gold and bright colours , as that other , but beset with huge round pillars that bore aloft a wide vault of stone , and of stone were the tables ; and the hallings that hung on the wall were terrible pictures of battle and death , and the fall of [cities]1860-cities , and towers a - tumbling and houses a - flaming .

None the less there also were the shapes of [folk that moved not nor spake]1861-folk that moved not nor spake , though not so thronged was [that hall]1862-that hall as the other one ; and it seemed as if [men]219-men were sitting there at a council rather than a feast . Close by [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's right hand as [she]101-birdalone entered were standing in a row along [the screen]1864-the screen [big men - at - arms]1865-big men - at - arms all weaponed , and [their]1865-big men - at - arms faces hidden by [their]1865-big men - at - arms sallets ; and down below the dais on either side of the high table was again [a throng of all - armed men]1866-a throng of all - armed men ; and at the high - table itself ; and looking down [the hall]1202-the hall , sat [three crowned kings]1868-three crowned kings , each with [his]1868-three crowned kings drawn sword lying across [his]1868-three crowned kings knees , and [three long - hoary wise men]1869-three long - hoary wise men stood before [them]1868-three crowned kings at the nether side of the board .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone looked on it all , striving with [her]101-birdalone fear : but yet more there was , for [she]101-birdalone deemed that needs must [she]101-birdalone go through [the hall]1202-the hall up to [the dais]1871-the dais , lest [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat deny its obedience . Up toward [the dais]1871-the dais [she]101-birdalone went then , passing by [weaponed men who sat as if abiding [the council]1875-the council 's end at the end - long tables]1874-weaponed men who sat as if abiding the council 's end at the end - long tables . And now , though no shape of [man there spake or breathed , yet sound lacked not]1876-man there spake or breathed , yet sound lacked not ; for within [the hall]1202-the hall went the wind as without , and beat about from wall to wall , and drave clang and clash from the weapons hung up , and waved the arras , and fared moaning in the nooks , and hummed in the vault above .

Came [she]101-birdalone up to [the dais]1871-the dais then , and stood beside one of [the wise men]1373-the wise men , and looked on [the kings]1880-the kings , and saw the mightiness which had been in [them]1880-the kings , and quaked before [them]1880-the kings . Then [she]101-birdalone turned from [them]1880-the kings and looked down to the floor , and lo ! there , just below the dais , lay [a woman on a golden bier]1881-a woman on a golden bier ; exceeding fair had [she]1881-a woman on a golden bier been , with long yellow hair streaming down from [her]1881-a woman on a golden bier head ; but now waxen white [she]1881-a woman on a golden bier was , with ashen lips and sunken cheeks . Clad was [she]1881-a woman on a golden bier in raiment of purple and pall , but the bosom of [her]1881-a woman on a golden bier was bared on one side , and therein was the road whereby the steel had fared which had been [her]1881-a woman on a golden bier bane .

Now when [Birdalone]101-birdalone had gazed thereon a while , [she]101-birdalone deemed that if [she]101-birdalone tarried there long amidst [those fierce men]1882-those fierce men by [the dead woman]1883-the dead woman , [she]101-birdalone should lose [her]101-birdalone wit full soon , so sore the fear , held back , beset [her]101-birdalone now . Wherefore [she]101-birdalone turned and went hastily down [the hall]1202-the hall , and out - a- doors , and over [the bridge]1855-the bridge , and ran fleet - foot down the rocky way whereby [she]101-birdalone had come , till [she]101-birdalone could run no further , and lay down under [a great stone breathless and fordone]1886-a great stone breathless and fordone ; yet [her]101-birdalone heart upheld [her]101-birdalone and suffered [her]101-birdalone not to swoon , belike because [she]101-birdalone had given [her]101-birdalone limbs such hard work to do .

There [she]101-birdalone lay awake and troubled for an hour or more , and then [she]101-birdalone fell asleep , and slept till the day was worn toward sunset , and nought meddled with [her]101-birdalone . [She]101-birdalone arose and went to [[her]101-birdalone ship]1887-her ship somewhat downhearted , wondering how many such terrors should befall [her]101-birdalone ; nay , whether the Sending Boat would so lead [her]101-birdalone that henceforth [she]101-birdalone should happen on [no children of Adam but such as were dead images of the living]1888-no children of adam but such as were dead images of the living . Had all [the world]430-the world died since [she]101-birdalone left [the Isle of [the Young]126-the young]28-the isle of the young and [the Old]130-the old ?

Howsoever , [she]101-birdalone had nought to do save to board [[her]101-birdalone ferry]1512-her ferry , and content its greedy soul with [her]101-birdalone blood , and drive it with the spell - words . And thereafter , when it was speeding on , and the twilight dusking apace , [she]101-birdalone looked aback , and seemed to see [the far - off woodland]1891-the far - off woodland in [the northern ort]1892-the northern ort , and [the oak - clad ridge]1893-the oak - clad ridge , where [she]101-birdalone had met [[her]101-birdalone wood- mother]1894-her wood- mother ; and then it was as if [Habundia]106-habundia were saying to [her]101-birdalone : Meet again [we]1895-we shall . And therewith straightway became life sweeter unto [her]101-birdalone .

Deepened then the dusk , and became night , and [she]101-birdalone floated on through it , and was asleep alone on the bosom of [the water]361-the water .

CHAPTER XII . OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone , HOW [SHE]101-birdalone CAME UNTO [THE ISLE]26-the isle OF NOTHING

Long before sunrise , in the very morn - dusk , [she]101-birdalone awoke and found that [[her]101-birdalone ferry]1512-her ferry had taken [land]653-land again . Little might [she]101-birdalone see what [the said land]1899-the said land was like ; so [she]101-birdalone sat patiently and abode the day in [the boat]859-the boat ; but when day was come , little more was to see than erst . For flat was [the isle]642-the isle , and scarce raised above [the wash of [the leeward ripple]29-the leeward ripple]1902-the wash of the leeward ripple on a fair day ; nor was [it]642-the isle either timbered or bushed or grassed , and , so far as [Birdalone]101-birdalone might see , no one foot of [it]642-the isle differed in aught from another . [Natheless]131-natheless [she]101-birdalone deemed that [she]101-birdalone was bound to go ashore and seek out the adventure , or spoil [her]101-birdalone errand else .

Out of [the boat]859-the boat [she]101-birdalone stepped then , and found the earth all paved of a middling gravel , and nought at all growing there , not even the smallest of herbs ; and [she]101-birdalone stooped down and searched the gravel , and found neither worm nor beetle therein , nay nor any one of the sharp and slimy creatures which are wo nt in such ground .

A little further [she]101-birdalone went , and yet a little further , and no change there was in [the land]213-the land ; and yet [she]101-birdalone went on and found nothing ; and [she]101-birdalone wended [her]101-birdalone ways southward by the sun , and the day was windless .

At last [she]101-birdalone had gone a long way and had no sight of [water south of [the isle]642-the isle]1905-water south of the isle , nor had [she]101-birdalone seen [any hill]1907-any hill , nay , not so much as an ant - heap , whence [she]101-birdalone might look further around ; and it seemed to [her]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone might go on for ever , and reach [the heart of Nowhither]1908-the heart of nowhither at last . Wherefore [she]101-birdalone thought [she]101-birdalone would turn back and depart [this ugly isle]1909-this ugly isle , and that no other adventure abided [her]101-birdalone therein . And by now it was high noon ; and [she]101-birdalone turned about and took a few steps on [the backward road]1910-the backward road .

But even therewith it seemed as if the sun , which heretofore had been shining brightly in the heavens , went out as a burnt - down candle , and all was become dull grey over head , as all under foot was a dull dun . But [Birdalone]101-birdalone deemed [she]101-birdalone could follow a straight course back again , and so walked on sturdily . Hour after hour [she]101-birdalone went and stayed not , but saw before [her]101-birdalone no glimpse of [the northern shore]1911-the northern shore , and no change in the aspect of the ground about [her]101-birdalone .

It had so happened that a little before [she]101-birdalone had turned to go back , [she]101-birdalone had eaten [her]101-birdalone dinner of a piece of bread and a morsel of cheese , and now as [she]101-birdalone stooped and peered on the ground , looking for some sign of the way , as [her]101-birdalone foot - prints going south , and had [her]101-birdalone eyes low anigh [the earth]445-the earth , [she]101-birdalone saw something white at [her]101-birdalone feet in the gathering dusk for the day was wearing , and [she]101-birdalone put [her]101-birdalone hand to it and lifted it , and found it a crumb of bread , and knew that it must have come from [her]101-birdalone dinner of ' seven hours ago , whereas till that time [her]101-birdalone bread had lain unbroken in [her]101-birdalone scrip . Fear and anguish smote [her]101-birdalone therewith , for [she]101-birdalone saw that in [that dull land]7084-that dull land , every piece whereof was like every other piece , [she]101-birdalone must have gone about in a ring , and come back again to where [she]101-birdalone first turned to make for [the northern shore]1911-the northern shore .[101-birdalone]

Yet would [she]101-birdalone not cast aside all hope , but clad [herself]101-birdalone in [her]101-birdalone valiancy . [Forsooth]101-birdalone [she]101-birdalone knew it availed nought to try to move on in the twilight ; so [she]101-birdalone laid [herself]101-birdalone down on [that waste]1913-that waste , and made up [her]101-birdalone mind to sleep if [she]101-birdalone might , and abide the new day there , and then to strive with the way once more , for belike , [she]101-birdalone thought , it may be fair to - morrow , and the sun shining . And as [she]101-birdalone was very weary with tramping the waste all day , [she]101-birdalone fell asleep at once , and slept the short night through .

But when [she]101-birdalone awoke , and saw what the new day was , [her]101-birdalone heart fell indeed , for now was [she]101-birdalone encompassed and shut in with a thick dark mist though it seemed to be broad day , so that had there been aught to see [she]101-birdalone would not have seen it [her]101-birdalone own length away from [her]101-birdalone . So there [she]101-birdalone stood , hanging [her]101-birdalone head , and striving to think ; but the master - thought of death drawing nigh scattered all other thoughts , or made them dim and feeble .

Long [she]101-birdalone stood there ; but suddenly something came into [her]101-birdalone mind . [She]101-birdalone set [her]101-birdalone hand to the fair - broidered pouch which hung from [Viridis]116-viridis ' loin - girdle , and drew out thence flint and steel and tinder , which matters , [forsooth]101-birdalone , had served [her]101-birdalone before in [the boat]859-the boat to make fire withal . Then [she]101-birdalone set [her]101-birdalone hand to [her]101-birdalone head , and drew forth the tress of hair which [Habundia]106-habundia had given [her]101-birdalone , and which was coiled up in the crown of [her]101-birdalone own abundant locks which decked [her]101-birdalone so gloriously ; [she]101-birdalone drew two hairs from the said tress , and held them between [her]101-birdalone lips while [she]101-birdalone did up the tress in its place again , and then , pale and trembling , fell to striking a light , and when [she]101-birdalone had the tinder burning , [she]101-birdalone cried out :[101-birdalone]

[O wood - mother]1914-o wood - mother , [wood - mother]1915-wood - mother ! How then may [we]1916-we meet again as [thou]1917-thou didst promise [me]0-i , if [I]0-i die here in this empty waste ? [O wood - mother]1914-o wood - mother , if [thou]1917-thou mightest but come hither for [my]0-i deliverance !

Then [she]0-i burned the hairs one after another , and stood waiting , but nought befell a great while , and [her]0-i heart sickened , and there [she]0-i stood like a stone .

But in awhile , [lo]1919-lo ! there came as it were a shadow amidst the mist , or rather lying thereon , faint and colourless , and it was of the shape of [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother , with girt - up gown and bow in hand . [Birdalone]101-birdalone cried aloud with joy , and hastened toward the semblance , but came to it no nigher , and still [she]101-birdalone went , and the semblance still escaped [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone followed on and on ; and this lasted long , and faster and faster must [she]101-birdalone follow lest it vanish , and [she]101-birdalone gathered [her]101-birdalone skirts into [her]101-birdalone girdle , and fell to running fleet - foot after the fleeing shadow , which [she]101-birdalone loved dearly even amidst the jaws of death ; and all [her]101-birdalone fleetness of foot had [Birdalone]101-birdalone to put forth in following up the chase ; but even to die in the pain would [she]101-birdalone not miss that dear shadow .

But suddenly , as [she]101-birdalone ran , the mist was all gone from before [her]101-birdalone , the sun shone hot and cloudless ; there was no shadow or shape of [Habundia]106-habundia there , nought but [the blue lake]1921-the blue lake and [the ugly lip of [that hideous desert]1923-that hideous desert]1922-the ugly lip of that hideous desert , with [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat lying a half score yards from [her]101-birdalone feet ; and behind [her]101-birdalone stood up , as it were a wall , the mist from out of which [she]101-birdalone had come .

[Forsooth Birdalone]101-birdalone was too breathless to cry out [her]101-birdalone joy , but [her]101-birdalone heart went nigh to breaking therewith , and lovely indeed to [her]101-birdalone was the rippled water and the blue sky ; and [she]101-birdalone knew that [[her]101-birdalone wood - mother]908-her wood - mother had sped a sending to [her]101-birdalone help , and [she]101-birdalone fell a - weeping where [she]101-birdalone stood , for love of [[her]101-birdalone wise mother]1926-her wise mother , and for longing to behold [her]908-her wood - mother : [she]101-birdalone stretched out [her]101-birdalone arms to the north quarter , and said blessings on [her]908-her wood - mother in a voice faint for weariness . Then [she]101-birdalone laid [her]908-her wood - mother down on [the desert]1927-the desert , and rested [her]908-her wood - mother with sleep , despite the hot sun , and when [she]101-birdalone awoke , some three hours thereafter , all was as before , save that the sky had now some light - flying clouds , and still was the wall of mist behind [her]101-birdalone . Wherefore [she]101-birdalone deemed [she]101-birdalone had yet time , and the blue rippling water wooed [her]101-birdalone much - besweated limbs ; so [she]101-birdalone did off [her]101-birdalone raiment and took [the water]361-the water , and became happy and unweary therein . Then [she]101-birdalone landed and stood in the sun to dry [her]101-birdalone , and so , strengthened with that refreshing , clad [her]101-birdalone , and went aboard and did the due rites , and sped over [the waters]636-the waters , and had soon lost sight of that ugly blotch on the fair face of [the Great Water]30-the great water .

Here ends the Second Part of [the Water of [the Wondrous Isles]1-the wondrous isles]1065-the water of the wondrous isles , which is called Of [the Wondrous Isles]1-the wondrous isles , and begins the Third Part of the said tale , which is called Of [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest .

THE THIRD PART : OF [THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST]1931-the castle of the quest

CHAPTER I. [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone COMES TO [THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST

Empty]1933-the castle of the quest empty was the day to [Birdalone]101-birdalone save for [her]101-birdalone thoughts , and [she]101-birdalone slept not a good while of the night . When [she]101-birdalone awoke in the morning there was [no land]1073-no land before [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone began to fear somewhat that so it might be many days , and that [she]101-birdalone might have to fare [the water landless]1935-the water landless , and perchance till [she]101-birdalone starved for hunger ; for now was there but little victual left of that which the kind [Viridis]116-viridis had given [her]101-birdalone . So [she]101-birdalone wore the day somewhat uneasily , and by then night fell had eaten but little ; yet was that little the last crumb and gobbet of [her]101-birdalone store . Wherefore it is no wonder though [she]101-birdalone were dismayed when [she]101-birdalone awoke early on the morrow , and beheld nought before [her]101-birdalone save [the landless water]1936-the landless water .

But about noon [she]101-birdalone deemed [she]101-birdalone saw a little cloud in the offing that moved not as the other clouds , and [she]101-birdalone watched it closely at first , and it changed not any the more , and [she]101-birdalone grew weary of watching it and strove to sleep , turning [her]101-birdalone head to the after part of [her]101-birdalone ferry ; and thus betwixt sleeping and waking [she]101-birdalone wore away three hours : then [she]101-birdalone stood up and looked ahead , and lo , the white cloud had taken shape , and was a white castle far away for the day was exceeding clear , sitting , as it seemed , on [the very face of [the water]361-the water]1937-the very face of the water . [The boat]859-the boat sped on swiftly thitherward , so that it was not right long ere [Birdalone]101-birdalone beheld [the green shore]1940-the green shore on either side of [the said castle]1941-the said castle , and at last , three hours before sunset , [she]101-birdalone was drawing nigh thereto , and beheld it all clearly , what it was .

[It]1942-it was brand - new , and was fair enough , builded part of stone and lime , part of framed work , but was but middling big . As [she]101-birdalone drew nigher yet , [she]101-birdalone saw that there were [folk on the walls]1943-folk on the walls of [it]1941-the said castle , and [they]1943-folk on the walls seemed to see [her]101-birdalone , for a horn was winded from the battlement , and [folk]1529-folk were running together to somewhither . And now was [Birdalone]101-birdalone come so near , that [she]101-birdalone saw [the water - gate of [the castle]1838-the castle]1945-the water - gate of the castle , and [folk]1529-folk coming out thereby on to [the landing - place]1948-the landing - place ; and [she]101-birdalone saw presently , that [a very tall man with grizzled hair]1949-a very tall man with grizzled hair stood foremost of [them]1943-folk on the walls , and [he]1949-a very tall man with grizzled hair waved [his]1949-a very tall man with grizzled hair hand to [her]101-birdalone , and spake something , but the wind bore the words away from [her]101-birdalone ; yet [she]101-birdalone seemed to know that [this folk]1950-this folk would do [her]101-birdalone to wit that [they]1950-this folk would have none of [her]101-birdalone ; and [her]101-birdalone heart died within [her]101-birdalone , so faint and hungry as [she]101-birdalone was .

Howsoever [the ferry]1951-the ferry sped on [its]1951-the ferry way swiftly , and in a minute or two had stayed [itself]1951-the ferry at [the landing - stair]1952-the landing - stair , whereabout were gathered [a score of [men]219-men]1953-a score of men , some armed some unarmed , and [they]1953-a score of men seemed for the more part to be grey - headed and past middle - age .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone stood up in [[her]101-birdalone craft]1955-her craft , and [the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment]1956-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment , stood on the stair and spake unto [her]101-birdalone , and said : [Lady]504-lady , this is [an house where [women]433-women enter never since first the roof was done thereon]1958-an house where women enter never since first the roof was done thereon , which forsooth was but a year ago . [We]1960-we will pray [thee]1961-thee therefore to turn [[thy]1961-thee boat]1962-thy boat 's head away , and seek [some other lodging by the water]1963-some other lodging by the water , either eastward or westward .

[Little]132-little knew [Birdalone]101-birdalone of worldly courtesy , or [she]101-birdalone had made [him]1956-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment a sharp answer belike ; but [she]101-birdalone only looked on [him]1956-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment ruefully , and said : [Good warrior]1964-good warrior , [I]0-i am come a long way , and may not turn back from [mine]0-i errand ; and [I]0-i am now lacking victual and hungry , and if [ye]1964-good warrior help [me]0-i not , it is like that [I]0-i shall die . Much lieth on [mine]0-i errand , if [ye]1964-good warrior knew it . [She]101-birdalone was weeping - ripe , but refrained [her]101-birdalone tears , though [her]101-birdalone lip quivered . [She]101-birdalone stretched out [her]101-birdalone hands to [the greybeard]1965-the greybeard , and [he]1956-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment looked on [her]101-birdalone and found [her]101-birdalone exceeding fair ; and [he]1956-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment deemed [her]101-birdalone to be guileless , both because of [her]101-birdalone simple speech and sweet voice , and the goodliness of [her]101-birdalone face and eyes . But [he]1956-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment said : [Lady]504-lady , thine errand hath nought to do with it , it is [[thy]101-birdalone womanhood]1967-thy womanhood that bars [our]1968-our door . For all [we]1968-our are bound by oath not to suffer [a woman]250-a woman to abide in [this castle]1970-this castle till [[our]1968-our lords]1971-our lords take the bann off , and bid [us]1968-our open to [women]433-women . [She]101-birdalone smiled faintly , and said : If [I]0-i might but see [[thy]101-birdalone lords]1973-thy lords then , since [thou]101-birdalone art not master here . [He]1956-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment said : [They]1973-thy lords are away , and will not be back till to - morrow morning ; and [I]0-i wot not the hour of [their]1973-thy lords return . And yet , said [he]1956-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment , [I]0-i would [we]1968-our might help [thee]101-birdalone somewhat . O [I]0-i pray [thee]101-birdalone , [I]0-i pray [thee]101-birdalone ! [she]101-birdalone said , or [mine]101-birdalone errand will come to nought after all .

Therewith came [another man]1974-another man down the stair , and stood by [the old knight]1975-the old knight and plucked [his]1975-the old knight sleeve , and fell to talk with [him]1975-the old knight softly . [This man]1976-this man was by [his]1976-this man habit [a religious]1977-a religious , and was [a younger man than the others]1978-a younger man than the others , it might be of five and thirty winters , and [he]1976-this man was fair of favour . While [they]1979-they spake together [Birdalone]101-birdalone sat [her]101-birdalone down again , and was well - nigh spent .

At last [the old man]7080-the old man spake : [Damsel]133-damsel , [he]7080-the old man said , [we]1981-we deem [we]1981-we may suffer [thee]133-damsel to enter [the castle]1838-the castle since [thy]133-damsel need is so great , and have a meal 's meat at [our]1981-we hands , and yet save [our]1981-we oath , if [thou]133-damsel depart thence by the landward gate before sunset . Will this serve [thee]133-damsel ? Fair sir , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , it will save [my]0-i life and [mine]0-i errand ; [I]0-i may say no more words for [my]0-i faintness , else would [I]0-i thank [thee]7080-the old man .

[She]101-birdalone stood up on [her]101-birdalone feet , and [the old man - at - arms]1983-the old man - at - arms reached out [his]7080-the old man hand to [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone took it and came [her]101-birdalone ways up the stair , but found [herself]101-birdalone but feeble . But [the priest]1984-the priest forsooth [he]1984-the priest was [chaplain of [the castle]1838-the castle]1985-chaplain of the castle helped [her]101-birdalone on the other side . But when [she]101-birdalone stood on the level stones by the water - gate , [she]101-birdalone turned to [the old man]7080-the old man and said : One thing [I]0-i will ask of [thee]7080-the old man , Is [this place one of [the Wondrous Isles]1989-the wondrous isles]1988-this place one of the wondrous isles ? [The elder]1698-the elder shook [his]1698-the elder head . [We]1991-we know not [the Wondrous Isles]1-the wondrous isles , said [he]1698-the elder ; [this castle]1970-this castle is builded on [the mainland]1038-the mainland . [Her]101-birdalone face flushed for joy at the word , and [she]101-birdalone said : One thing [I]0-i will crave of [thee]7080-the old man , to wit , that [thou]1994-thou wilt leave [[my]0-i barge]1995-my barge lying here untouched till [[thy]1994-thou masters]1996-thy masters come back , and wilt give command that [none]1226-none meddle therewith .

[He]7080-the old man would have answered , but [the priest]1984-the priest brake in , and said : This will [he]7080-the old man do , [lady]504-lady , and [he]7080-the old man is [the castellan]2000-the castellan , and moreover [he]7080-the old man will swear to obey [thee]504-lady herein . And therewith [he]7080-the old man drew forth a cross with [God]120-god nailed thereon , and [the castellan]2000-the castellan swore on it with a good will .

Then [the priest]1984-the priest drew [Birdalone]101-birdalone on , and between [them]2003-them [they]2003-them brought [her]101-birdalone into [the great hall]1785-the great hall , and set [her]101-birdalone down in a chair and propped [her]101-birdalone with cushions . And when [she]101-birdalone was thus at rest , [she]101-birdalone began to weep somewhat , and [the castellan]2000-the castellan and [the priest]1984-the priest stood by and comforted [her]101-birdalone ; for themseemed , despite [her]101-birdalone grief , that [she]101-birdalone had brought the sun into [[their]2003-them house]2007-their house .

Next were victual brought unto [her]101-birdalone of broth and venison , and good wine and cates and strawberries ; and [she]101-birdalone was not so famished but [she]101-birdalone might eat and drink with a good will . But when [she]101-birdalone was done , and had rested a little , [the castellan]2000-the castellan stood up and said : [Lady]2009-lady , the sun is gone off the western windows now , and [I]0-i must save [mine]0-i oath ; but ere [thou]2010-thou depart , [I]0-i were fain to hear [thy]2010-thou voice giving [me]0-i pardon for [my]0-i evil cheer and the thrusting of [thee]2010-thou forth . And therewith [he]2000-the castellan put one knee to the ground , and took [her]101-birdalone hand and kissed it . But [Birdalone]101-birdalone was grown merry again , and [she]101-birdalone laughed and said : What pardon [thou]2010-thou canst have of [me]0-i , [kind knight]2011-kind knight , [thou]2010-thou hast ; but now methinks [thou]2010-thou makest overmuch of [me]0-i , because [I]0-i am [the only woman who hath come into [[thy]2010-thou castle]2013-thy castle]2012-the only woman who hath come into thy castle . [I]0-i am but [a simple maiden]2014-a simple maiden , though [mine]0-i errand be not little .

Forsooth [she]101-birdalone wondered that [the stark and gruff old man]2015-the stark and gruff old man was so changed to [her]101-birdalone in little space ; for nought [she]101-birdalone knew as yet how the sight of [her]101-birdalone cast a hot gleed of love into the hearts of [[them]2016-them who beheld [her]101-birdalone]2017-them who beheld her .

Now [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose ; but [the castellan]2000-the castellan knelt at [her]101-birdalone feet , and kissed [her]101-birdalone hand again , and again , and yet again . Then [he]2000-the castellan said : [Thou]2010-thou art gracious indeed . But methinks [the father]1628-the father here will lead [thee]2010-thou out - a- gates ; for [he]1628-the father may show [thee]2010-thou a lair , wherein [thou]2010-thou shalt be safe enough to - night ; and to - morrow may bring new tidings .

So [the priest]1984-the priest made obeisance to [her]101-birdalone and led [her]101-birdalone down [the hall]1202-the hall , and [the castellan]2000-the castellan 's eyes were following [them]2023-them till the screen hid [them]2023-them . [The priest]1984-the priest left [her]101-birdalone in [the hall - porch]2025-the hall - porch a while , and went into the buttery , and came back with a basket of meat and drink , and [they]2023-them went forth at the great gate together , and there was the last of the sun before [them]2023-them .

CHAPTER II . OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone , AND HOW [SHE]101-birdalone RESTED THE NIGHT THROUGH IN A BOWER WITHOUT [THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST]1931-the castle of the quest

On [a fair smooth road]2027-a fair smooth road went [they]2023-them amidst of [a goodly meadow - land]2028-a goodly meadow - land , wherein were little copses here and there . When [they]2023-them were fairly out of the gate , [the priest]1984-the priest reached for [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's hand , and [she]101-birdalone let [him]1984-the priest take it and lead [her]101-birdalone along thereby , thinking no evil ; but [he]1984-the priest might scarce speak for a while , so great was the stir in [his]1984-the priest heart at the touch of [her]101-birdalone bare flesh . But [Birdalone]101-birdalone spake and said : [Thou]2030-thou art kind , [father]1726-father , to lead [me]0-i on [my]0-i way thus .

[He]1984-the priest answered in a husky voice with [his]1984-the priest eyes cast down , and forsooth set on the feet of [her]101-birdalone : It is not far that [I]0-i am leading [thee]101-birdalone ; there is a broken cot by the copse at the turn of [the road yonder]2032-the road yonder , where [thou]2030-thou mayst abide to - night ; it is better lodging than none , evil as it is for such an one as [thou]2030-thou . [Birdalone]101-birdalone laughed : Worse have [I]0-i had , said [she]101-birdalone , than would be the copse without the cot . And [she]101-birdalone thought withal of [the prison in [the Isle of [Increase Unsought]32-increase unsought]2034-the isle of increase unsought]2033-the prison in the isle of increase unsought .
