So [he]2413-the chaplain sighed heavily and went into [the chapel]2832-the chapel , wherein was an altar of [St. Leonard]137-leonard ; and [he]2413-the chaplain knelt thereat , and prayed [the saint]3348-the saint , as [he]2413-the chaplain had erst delivered [folk from captivity]3349-folk from captivity , now to deliver both [him]2413-the chaplain and [Birdalone]145-birdalone from peril and bonds ; but though [he]2413-the chaplain was long a - praying and made many words , it lightened [his]2413-the chaplain heart little or nothing ; so that when [he]2413-the chaplain rose up again , that if anything evil happened to this pearl of [women]433-women , [he]2413-the chaplain wished heartily that [some one]3351-some one might take [his]2413-the chaplain life and [he]2413-the chaplain be done with it .

Now was [the house astir]3352-the house astir , and [the chaplain]2413-the chaplain came from out [the chapel]2832-the chapel , and thinking all things over , [he]2413-the chaplain thought [he]2413-the chaplain would go straight to [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris and make a clean breast of it , so that [weaponed men]2107-weaponed men might be sent at once to seek [Birdalone]145-birdalone . And [he]2413-the chaplain said to [himself]2413-the chaplain : What matter if [he]138-sir aymeris slay [me]0-i or cast [me]0-i into [prison]1209-prison , if [Birdalone]145-birdalone be lost ?

So [he]2413-the chaplain went [his]2413-the chaplain ways to [the highest tower]3357-the highest tower , which looked landward and hight the Open Eye , deeming to find [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris ; but when [he]2413-the chaplain got to the topmost , [he]2413-the chaplain found neither [captain]3358-captain nor carle there : wherefore [he]2413-the chaplain stayed a little and looked forth betwixt the battlements , if perchance there were some wild chance of seeing [Birdalone]145-birdalone 's coming [home]387-home again ; but [his]2413-the chaplain keen eyes beheld nothing more than [he]2413-the chaplain looked to see , as [sheep and neat]3360-sheep and neat , and [the field - folk of thereabouts]3361-the field - folk of thereabouts . So [he]2413-the chaplain turned away and went by the swale toward [the next tallest tower]3362-the next tallest tower , which looked lakewards , and was called [Hearts]154-hearts ' Hope ; and as [he]2413-the chaplain went [he]2413-the chaplain fell to framing in [his]2413-the chaplain mind the words which [he]2413-the chaplain should say to [the castellan]2000-the castellan .[154-hearts]

Thus came [he]2413-the chaplain , haggard and hapless , on the leads of [the tower]3363-the tower , which were nought small ; and there gathered together in a knot , and all gazing eagerly out over [the lake]369-the lake , [he]2413-the chaplain found a dozen of [men - at - arms]2059-men - at - arms and [the castellan]2000-the castellan amongst [them]3367-them . [They]3368-they took no heed of [him]2413-the chaplain as [he]2413-the chaplain came up , though [he]2413-the chaplain stumbled as [he]2413-the chaplain crossed the threshold and came clattering over the lead floor , and [he]2413-the chaplain saw at once that there was something unwonted toward ; but [he]2413-the chaplain had but one thought in [his]2413-the chaplain mind , to wit , the rescuing of [Birdalone]145-birdalone .

[He]2413-the chaplain went up now behind where [the castellan]2000-the castellan was leaning over the battlement , and pulled [his]2413-the chaplain skirt , and when [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris turned round , [he]2413-the chaplain said : [Lord]2620-lord , [I]0-i have a word for [thine]3371-thine ear . But [the old knight]1975-the old knight did but half turn round , and then spake peevishly : Tush , [man]548-man ! another time ! seest [thou]3374-thou not [I]0-i have got no eyes for aught save what [we]3375-our see on [the lake]369-the lake ? [Yea]3377-yea , but what then ? said [the priest]1984-the priest . There cometh [a boat]688-a boat , said [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris , not looking back at [him]1975-the old knight , and [our]3375-our thought is that therein be [[our]3375-our lords]1971-our lords .

When [the priest]1984-the priest heard that word , it was to [him]1984-the priest as if hell had opened underneath [his]1984-the priest feet ; and [he]1984-the priest had no might to speak for a minute ; then [he]1984-the priest cried out : [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris , hearken , [I]0-i pray [thee]138-sir aymeris . But [the old knight]1975-the old knight but thrust [him]1984-the priest back with [his]1975-the old knight hand , and even therewith one of [the men- at - arms]3383-the men- at - arms cried out : [I]0-i hear the voice of [their]3383-the men- at - arms horn ! Then shouted [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris : Where art [thou]3384-thou , Noise ? Blow , [man]548-man , blow , if ever [thou]3384-thou blewest in all [thy]3384-thou life ! And therewithal came the blare of the brass , and [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris nodded to [the trumpeter , who blew blast after blast]3386-the trumpeter , who blew blast after blast with all [his]3386-the trumpeter , who blew blast after blast might , so that [the priest]1984-the priest might as well have been dumb for any hearing [he]3386-the trumpeter , who blew blast after blast might get ; and all the while to [Leonard]145-birdalone the minutes seemed hours , and [he]145-birdalone was well - nigh distraught .

And then when [the knight]2120-the knight held up [his]2120-the knight hand for the Noise to stay [his]2120-the knight blowing , and [Leonard]145-birdalone strove to speak , [the castellan]2000-the castellan turned on [him]145-birdalone and said : Peace , [Sir Leonard]145-birdalone ; dost [thou]3384-thou not know that now [we]3384-thou would listen with [our]3384-thou ears to heed if [they]2000-the castellan answer [us]3384-thou ? Not a word [any one man of [you]3391-you]3390-any one man of you , learned or lewd , or [ye]3391-you shall rue it !

Even therewith came clearly the sound of the horn from [the water]361-the water , and again and yet again ; and [no man]545-no man spake but [the chaplain]2413-the chaplain , who cried out : Hearken , [knight]2610-knight , it is of [Birdalone]101-birdalone . But [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris laid [his]138-sir aymeris hand on [his]145-birdalone shoulder and said in an angry whisper : [Thou]3384-thou shalt be put [downstairs]1556-downstairs , [priest]3397-priest , if [thou]3384-thou hold not [thy]3384-thou peace .

[Leonard]145-birdalone drew aback scowling , and went out of the door , and so slowly down [the stair]3398-the stair , and withdrew [him]145-birdalone into the cover of the door of the first chamber down from the tower - top , with the mind to waylay [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris as [he]145-birdalone came down ; and meanwhile [he]145-birdalone cursed [him]138-sir aymeris for [a fool]493-a fool and [a dull - wit]3400-a dull - wit , and [himself]145-birdalone yet more , as was but right , for [a fool]493-a fool and [a licorous traitor]3402-a licorous traitor .

But [he]145-birdalone had not tarried there more than a score of minutes , ere [he]145-birdalone heard a great shout from [those up above]3403-those up above : [They]3403-those up above are come ! [they]3403-those up above are come ! And next thereafter came [all the men]3404-all the men clattering down the stair past [him]145-birdalone , scarce refraining [them]3404-all the men from shoving [each [his]145-birdalone neighbour]3405-each his neighbour on to the next one ; [Leonard]145-birdalone followed on [them]3404-all the men , and presently arose great shouting and tumult through all [the house]325-the house , and [all folk]3407-all folk , [men]219-men and [women]433-women , hurried [flock - meal]3410-flock - meal toward the water - gate , and with [them]3407-all folk went [Leonard]145-birdalone perforce ; and sick of heart [he]145-birdalone was , calling to mind the first coming thither of [Birdalone]101-birdalone .

But now when [they]3407-all folk came to the water - gate , there verily was the Sending Boat just coming to hand ; and in the stern stood [the three knights]3411-the three knights together , all clad in [their]3411-the three knights armour , and before [them]3411-the three knights sat [three lovely ladies , clad one in gold , one in green , and one in black]3412-three lovely ladies , clad one in gold , one in green , and one in black : and lo , there was [the Quest]3235-the quest come [home]387-home .

CHAPTER II . NOW ASK [THEY]3407-all folk OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone , AND [SIR LEONARD]145-birdalone SPEAKS

Now the prow touched the stones of the stair , and [folk]1529-folk were busy to lay hold of it that [the wayfarers]3416-the wayfarers might land , but [Sir Baudoin]123-baudoin cried out in a great voice : Let [none]1226-none be so hardy as to touch [this ferry]3418-this ferry , either now or hereafter ; for there is peril therein . And therewith [he]145-birdalone took [Aurea]116-viridis by the hand , and led [her]116-viridis out of [the boat]859-the boat and up the stair , and [she]116-viridis all joyous and wondering ; and thereafter came [Hugh]124-hugh and [[his]145-birdalone darling]3420-his darling , and last of all [Arthur]125-arthur and [Atra]117-atra , and [she]116-viridis alone of [the three women]3421-the three women looked downcast , and [her]116-viridis eyes wandered about the throng that was before [them]3421-the three women there , as though [she]116-viridis sought something , yet feared to see it .

But when [they]3421-the three women were all standing together on [the landing - plain]3422-the landing - plain , and [the folk]244-the folk were all about [them]3421-the three women in a ring , [Sir Baudoin]123-baudoin spake to [the castellan]2000-the castellan and said : [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris , [thee]138-sir aymeris and other folk [I]0-i see here , the sight of whom doth [me]0-i great joy ; but where , [I]0-i pray [thee]138-sir aymeris , is [the lady]1157-the lady , [[our]3421-the three women friend]3426-our friend [Birdalone]145-birdalone , by whom it is that all [we]3421-the three women are come happily hither ? And [he]123-baudoin looked around with an anxious face ; but [Arthur]125-arthur was as pale as ashes , yet [he]125-arthur spake nought , and [Atra]117-atra let [her]117-atra hand fall away from [his]125-arthur .

Then spake [the castellan]2000-the castellan , and said : No harm hath befallen [the Lady Birdalone]155-birdalone ; but whiles [she]155-birdalone hath been somewhat ailing of late , and it is like that [she]155-birdalone wotteth not what is toward , and keepeth [[her]155-birdalone chamber]2512-her chamber now , for it is yet betimes in the morning .

As [he]123-baudoin spake , came thrusting [a man through the throng]3429-a man through the throng , eager and pale- faced ; who but [the chaplain]2413-the chaplain ; and [he]2413-the chaplain said : [He]2413-the chaplain would not let [me]0-i speak , [this fool]3431-this fool ; [I]0-i can not choose [my]0-i time . [Lords]2319-lords , [I]0-i bear evil tidings and an ugly welcome [home]387-home . [The Lady Birdalone]155-birdalone is in peril , and [she]155-birdalone is not in [the castle]1838-the castle ; [I]0-i wot not where [she]155-birdalone is . [Ye]3435-ye must send [armed men]3436-armed men to seek [her]155-birdalone out .

Thereat fell the silence of woe upon [the throng]248-the throng ; but [Arthur]125-arthur ran forward on [the priest with drawn sword]3438-the priest with drawn sword , and cried out : [I]0-i misdoubt [me]0-i that [thou]3439-ye art [a traitor]3440-a traitor ; speak ! or [I]0-i will slay [thee]3439-ye here and now . If [I]0-i be [a traitor]3440-a traitor , quoth [Leonard]145-birdalone , [I]0-i shall tell [thee]3439-ye in little while what [ye]3439-ye must do to undo [my]0-i treason , if there be yet time thereto ; so slay [me]0-i not till [ye]3439-ye have heard , and then do what [ye]3439-ye will with [me]0-i .

But [Baudoin]123-baudoin put [Arthur]125-arthur aside , and said : Refrain [thee]125-arthur a little , [fair brother]3442-fair brother , else shall words tumble over each other and [we]3443-we shall know nothing clear . [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris , bring [[our]3443-we dear ladies]3444-our dear ladies to [the fairest chambers]3445-the fairest chambers , and do all honour and courtesy to [them]3444-our dear ladies . And [ye]3439-ye , [sweetlings]1645-sweetlings , [ye]3439-ye will not begrudge [us]3443-we that [we]3443-we go to seek [[your]3439-ye friend]3447-your friend . [[Thou]3448-thou priest]3449-thou priest , come with [us]3443-we a little apart , and tell [thy]3448-thou tale as shortly as [thou]3448-thou mayst , and fear nought ; [we]3443-we be not [God]120-god 's dastards , as [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight and [[his]2539-the red knight men]3451-his men .

[Viridis]116-viridis wept and kissed [her]116-viridis love before [all folk]3407-all folk , and bade [him]2539-the red knight go and do [his]2539-the red knight best to find [[her]116-viridis friend]446-her friend , or never come back to [her]116-viridis else . Much moved , even to tears , was [Aurea withal]116-viridis , and reached [her]116-viridis hand to [Baudoin]123-baudoin , and said : If [any man on earth]3454-any man on earth can help [us]3443-we it is [thou]3454-any man on earth . Go [thou]3454-any man on earth . But [Atra]117-atra wept not , and but said to [Arthur]125-arthur : Go [thou]3454-any man on earth , it is meet .

Therewith were [the ladies]2309-the ladies brought to [fair chambers]3456-fair chambers ; but [the three knights]3411-the three knights went with [the priest]1984-the priest and [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris into the solar , and set a guard at the door that [their]3411-the three knights talk should be privy .

CHAPTER III . HOW [THEY]3411-the three knights FOLLOW [THE SLOT OF [BIRDALONE]145-birdalone]3459-the slot of birdalone AND [THE BLACK KNIGHT]2114-the black knight

It was but five minutes ere [the priest]1984-the priest had told [them]3411-the three knights all that need was ; so [they]3411-the three knights let [him]1984-the priest abide alone there , though sooth to say there was none of [them]3411-the three knights but had good will to break [his]1984-the priest neck ; and [the same rede]3462-the same rede had all three , that there was nought for it but to go [their]3411-the three knights ways with all speed to [[the Black Valley]43-the black valley of [the Greywethers]42-the greywethers]2748-the black valley of the greywethers , and follow up the slot of [Birdalone]101-birdalone if it might yet be found ; wherefore [they]3411-the three knights bade saddle [their]3411-the three knights horses straightway ; and while that was a - doing [they]3411-the three knights ate a morsel , and bade farewell to [[their]3411-the three knights lovelings]3464-their lovelings . And [they]3411-the three knights dight [them]3411-the three knights to go , [they]3411-the three knights three together , with but [one squire]3465-one squire and [a sergeant]3466-a sergeant , who were both of [them]3411-the three knights [keen trackers]3467-keen trackers and [fell woodsmen]3468-fell woodsmen . But ere [they]3411-the three knights went , by the rede of [Arthur]125-arthur [they]3411-the three knights bade [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris to arm [a two score of [men]219-men]3469-a two score of men and ride toward [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold , and beset the ways ' twixt that and [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest ; for one and all [they]3411-the three knights deemed that if any harm befell [Birdalone]145-birdalone , [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight would be at the bottom of it .[3411-the three knights]

So rode [those fellows]3472-those fellows , and came unto [the dale]2735-the dale but some four hours after [Birdalone]145-birdalone had happened on [the stranger knight]3474-the stranger knight ; and [they]3411-the three knights took up the slot of [her]3474-the stranger knight , but not easily , whereas the ground was hard and stony ; howbeit , [they]3411-the three knights found tokens of [the knight]2120-the knight also , finding here and there what [they]3411-the three knights deemed the footprints of [a tall man]1809-a tall man . And this was grievous to [those fellows]3472-those fellows , since now [they]3472-those fellows could not but deem that somewhat untoward had befallen [Birdalone]145-birdalone . But [they]3411-the three knights went on making out the slot , and [they]3411-the three knights followed it with much toil until [they]3411-the three knights came to the doom - ring in [the head of [the dale]2735-the dale]3009-the head of the dale , whereas [Birdalone]145-birdalone and [the stranger]301-the stranger had sat down to meat ; but by that time , so toilsome had been [their]3411-the three knights going , it was somewhat more than dusk , and there was nought for it but to abide there night - long . So a while [they]3411-the three knights sat talking , [all of [them]3411-the three knights]3481-all of them , and [the squire]3482-the squire and [the sergeant aforesaid]3483-the sergeant aforesaid were not a little timorous of the adventure of making that stead unkenned [[their]3411-the three knights sleeping chamber]3484-their sleeping chamber ; and to while away the time , [[their]3411-the three knights lords]3485-their lords made [them]3411-the three knights tell tales such as [they]3411-the three knights knew concerning [that place]645-that place ; and both [they]3411-the three knights said that [they]3411-the three knights had never erst come into [the dale]2735-the dale but a very little way , and said that [they]3411-the three knights had done so then but trusting in [[their]3411-the three knights lords]3485-their lords ' bidding and the luck of the Quest . Thereafter turned the talk as to what had befallen [Birdalone]145-birdalone , and the chances of coming on [her]7123-her ; and , as [folk]1529-folk will in such a plight , [they]3411-the three knights talked the matter over and over again till [they]3411-the three knights were weary and could say no more .[3411-the three knights]

Then [they]3411-the three knights went to sleep , and nought befell [them]3411-the three knights till [they]3411-the three knights awoke in the broad daylight ; but [they]3411-the three knights had little inkling of what hour it was , for all [the dale]2735-the dale was full of thick white mist that came rolling down from [the mountains]215-the mountains , so that [they]3411-the three knights could scarce see [their]3411-the three knights hands before [them]3411-the three knights , and there [they]3411-the three knights had to tarry still , would [they]3411-the three knights , would [they]3411-the three knights not ; and [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant fell to telling tales of [folk who had been lost in that stony maze]3492-folk who had been lost in that stony maze ; and [all of [them]3481-all of them]3481-all of them deemed , more or less , that this was the work either of [evil wights]2950-evil wights , or it might be of [the wizardry of [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight]3495-the wizardry of the red knight ; and , to be short , [they]3481-all of them all deemed that [he]2539-the red knight it was who had wielded it , save [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant , who said that [the mountain wights]3498-the mountain wights were [the masters]3499-the masters and not [the servants of [him]2539-the red knight of the Red Hold]3500-the servants of him of the red hold .

Thus , then , it betided ; but when the said mist had been hanging upon [them]3411-the three knights for some six hours , it rolled up like a curtain , and lo the blue sky and the sun , and [the mountains]215-the mountains as clear blue as in a picture ; and [they]3411-the three knights saw by the sun that it was but a little after high noon .

But as [they]3411-the three knights rejoiced herein , and betook [them]3411-the three knights once more to tracking out [the slot of [Birdalone]101-birdalone]3459-the slot of birdalone and the other , the sky became suddenly overcast , and down from the jaws of [the mountain]3503-the mountain came a storm of wind and rain , and thunder and lightning , so great that [they]3411-the three knights might scarce see [each other]580-each other 's faces , and when it cleared off , in about an hour and a half , and went down the wind to the south - east , the stream was waxen great , and ran brown and furious down [the dale]2735-the dale , so that it was fordable only here and there ; and as for tracking the slot of those twain , there was no need to talk thereof , for the fury of the driving rain had washed all away .

Thus fared [they]3411-the three knights the whole day betwixt fog and clear weather , and [they]3411-the three knights laid [them]3411-the three knights down to rest at night sore disheartened . When the day broke [they]3411-the three knights talked together as to what was best to do ; and [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant aforesaid spake : [Lords]2319-lords , said [he]3491-the sergeant , meseemeth [I]0-i am more at home in [the Black Valley]43-the black valley than [ye]2319-lords be ; heed [ye]2319-lords not wherefore . Now so it is that if [we]3411-the three knights tarry here till night come [we]3411-the three knights wot not what of evil may betide [us]3411-the three knights , or at the least [we]3411-the three knights do nought . Or if [we]3411-the three knights turn back and go southward out of [the dale]2735-the dale [we]3411-the three knights shall be safe indeed ; but safe should [we]3411-the three knights have been at [[your]2319-lords house]3509-your house , [lords]2319-lords , and should have done no less . But now [I]0-i shall tell [you]2319-lords that , if [ye]2319-lords will , [lords]2319-lords , [I]0-i shall guide [you]2319-lords to a pass that goeth out of [the head of [the dale]2735-the dale to [our]3411-the three knights right hands]3512-the head of the dale to our right hands , and so turneth the flank of [the mountains]215-the mountains , and cometh out into [the country which lieth about [the Red Hold]49-the red hold]3515-the country which lieth about the red hold ; and meseemeth it is thitherward that [we]3411-the three knights must seek if [we]3411-the three knights would hear any tidings of [the lady]1157-the lady ; for there may [we]3411-the three knights lay in ambush and beset the ways that lead up to the Hold , by which [she]1157-the lady must have been brought if [she]1157-the lady hath not been carried through the air . How say [ye]2319-lords , [lords]2319-lords ? Soothly there is peril therein ; yet [meseemeth]119-meseemeth peril no more than in [our]3411-the three knights abiding another night in [the Black Valley]43-the black valley .

Said [Arthur]125-arthur : [We]3411-the three knights heed not the peril if there be aught to be done ; wherefore let [us]3411-the three knights be stirring straightway . And so said [they]3411-the three knights all . Wherefore [they]3411-the three knights gat to horse , and rode up to [the very head of [the valley]2729-the valley]3518-the very head of the valley , and the weather was now calm and bright .

But [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant brought [them]3411-the three knights to the pass whereof [the stranger knight]3474-the stranger knight had spoken to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , which led into [the Red Knight 's country]3522-the red knight 's country , and without more ado [they]3411-the three knights entered [it]3523-it when it was now about three hours after noon . But the way was both steep and rough , so that [they]3411-the three knights had much toil , and went not very far ere night fell upon [them]3411-the three knights , and the moon was not yet up . So when [they]3411-the three knights had stumbled on another two hours , and [their]3411-the three knights horses were much spent and [they]3411-the three knights [themselves]3411-the three knights not a little weary , [they]3411-the three knights laid [them]3411-the three knights down to sleep , after [they]3411-the three knights had eaten such meat as [they]3411-the three knights had with [them]3411-the three knights , in a place where was a little grass for the horses to bite ; for all [the road]2103-the road hitherto had been mere grim stones and big rocks , walled on either side by stony screes , above which rose [steep and beetling crags]3525-steep and beetling crags .

In the dawn [they]3411-the three knights arose again , and made no ado till [they]3411-the three knights were in the saddle , and rode till [they]3411-the three knights came to [the crest of [the pass]3096-the pass]3526-the crest of the pass , and came out thence after a while on to the swelling flank of a huge mountain as it might be the side of [the mountain of [Plinlimmon]51-plinlimmon in [Wales]52-wales]3528-the mountain of plinlimmon in wales , which was grassed and nought craggy , but utterly treeless .

Now [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant led [them]3411-the three knights somewhat athwart [the said mountain]3530-the said mountain till [they]3411-the three knights began to go down , and saw below [them]3411-the three knights [a country of [little hills much covered with wood]3532-little hills much covered with wood]3531-a country of little hills much covered with wood , and in a while , and ere it was noon , [they]3411-the three knights were among [the said woods]3533-the said woods , which were grown mostly with big trees , as oak here and beech there , and the going was good for [them]3411-the three knights .

CHAPTER IV . OF THE SLAYING OF FRIEND AND FOE

So came [they]3411-the three knights , three hours after noon , to where was [a clearing in the woodland]3534-a clearing in the woodland , and [a long narrow plain some furlong over]3535-a long narrow plain some furlong over lay before [them]3411-the three knights , with [a river]3536-a river running along [it]3535-a long narrow plain some furlong over , and the wood rose on the other side high and thick , so that [the said plain]3537-the said plain looked even as a wide green highway leading from somewhence to somewhither .

At the edge hereof [their]3411-the three knights way - leader , [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant , bade draw rein , and said : [Lords]2319-lords , [we]3411-the three knights are now in [the lands of [the Red Hold]49-the red hold]3540-the lands of the red hold , and therein is mickle peril and dread to any save stout hearts as [ye]2319-lords be ; but meseems [we]3411-the three knights are so steaded , that whatever may come out of [the Black Valley]43-the black valley of [the Greywethers]42-the greywethers to [the Red Hold]49-the red hold , [ye]2319-lords now may scarce miss . Yonder along [this plain to the north]3541-this plain to the north lies the way to [the said Hold]3542-the said hold , and [any man coming from [the head of [the valley]2729-the valley]3544-the head of the valley]3543-any man coming from the head of the valley is sure to come by the way [we]3411-the three knights have come , and will pass [us]3411-the three knights not many yards at the worst from where [we]3411-the three knights now be . On the other hand , if any come to the Hold from [the mouth of [the Black Valley]43-the black valley]3546-the mouth of the black valley , then along [this green road]3547-this green road must [they]3548-they needs pass under [your]2319-lords very eyes . Lastly , if [we]3411-the three knights do what [we]3411-the three knights are come to do , to wit , to deliver [the lady]1157-the lady from [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight , then , the deed done , [we]3411-the three knights have to take [the green road]3551-the green road southward , and ride it for a league and then turn east , and [we]3411-the three knights shall have [our]3411-the three knights heads turned toward [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest , and shall speedily fall in with [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris and [[our]3411-the three knights men who be guarding the out - gates of [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight 's country toward [[our]3411-the three knights house]1679-our house]3553-our men who be guarding the out - gates of the red knight 's country toward our house . So now , by [my]0-i rede , [ye]2319-lords shall lay in covert here and abide a while what may befall ; if nought come hereby ere two hours be lacking of sunset , then may [we]3411-the three knights seek further .

[They]3556-they all yeasaid this , and gat off [their]3556-they horses , and lay quiet on the grass , not even speaking save softly . And when [they]3556-they had abided thus scarce an hour 's space , [the squire]3482-the squire , who was [a man of very fine ear]3558-a man of very fine ear , held up [his]3482-the squire hand as though to bid utter silence , and all hearkened eagerly . Presently [he]3482-the squire said : Hear [ye]3559-ye not ? Said [Arthur]125-arthur : [Meseemeth]119-meseemeth [I]0-i hear a faint tinkle as of a sheep - bell . Said [the squire]3482-the squire : ' Tis the clashing of swords down [the plain]2727-the plain to the south , and meseemeth '[3482-the squire] tis but of two : ride [we]3411-the three knights thither ?

[Quoth Baudoin]143-baudoin : Nay , not by [my]0-i rede ; for if [we]3411-the three knights can hear [them]3556-they [they]3556-they can hear [us]3411-the three knights ; let [us]3411-the three knights quietly edge along afoot somewhat nigher [their]3556-they way , ever keeping the cover of the wood betwixt [us]3411-the three knights and [the open plain]3561-the open plain . Now then to it ; and let [each man]3562-each man keep [his]3562-each man weapons ready .

Even so did [they]3556-they , and spread out in a line as [they]3556-they went , in such wise that there was some six paces betwixt [each man of [them]3556-they]3274-each man of them , and [they]3556-they went softly forward ; [Baudoin]143-baudoin went first , [Hugh]124-hugh second , then [Arthur]125-arthur ; then [the squire]3482-the squire and [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant last of all .

Now when [they]3556-they had gone but a quarter of an hour , [the squire]3482-the squire caught up with [Arthur]125-arthur , and spake to [him]125-arthur softly , and said : The voice of the swords has been silent now a while , and [I]0-i heard [a voice crying out e'en]3567-a voice crying out e'en now , [a woman]250-a woman 's voice . And now again [I]0-i could well - nigh deem that [I]0-i hear horse - hoofs .

[Arthur]125-arthur nodded to [him]3482-the squire , and [they]3556-they went but a little further ere [he]125-arthur said : Lo , lo ! ' tis the time of the eyes now ! Here come [folk]1529-folk . And therewithal [they]3556-they stayed [them]1529-folk . For [the wood]348-the wood turned somewhat here , so as to hide all but a little of [the plain]2727-the plain , and round the wood neb [the new - comers]7129-the new - comers hove in sight , and were close on [them]7129-the new - comers at once , so that [they]3556-they might see [them]7129-the new - comers clearly , to wit , [a knight weaponed , clad all in red]7130-a knight weaponed , clad all in red , [a very big man]7131-a very big man , riding on a great bay horse , and behind [him]7131-a very big man [a woman going afoot in very piteous plight]7132-a woman going afoot in very piteous plight ; for [she]3569-she was tethered to the horse 's crupper by a thong that bound [her]3569-she wrists together , so that [she]3569-she had but just room left '[125-arthur] twixt [her]3569-she and the horse that [she]3569-she might walk , and round about [her]3569-she neck was hung [a man]234-a man 's head newly hewn off .

This sight [they]3571-they all saw at once , and were out of the wood in a trice with weapons aloft , for [they]3571-they knew both [the man]2926-the man and [the woman]252-the woman , that [they]3571-they were [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight and [Birdalone]145-birdalone .

So swift and sudden had [they]3571-they been , that [he]2926-the man had no time either to spur or even to draw [his]2926-the man sword ; but [he]2926-the man had a heavy steel axe in [his]2926-the man hand as [the first man]3575-the first man came up to [him]2926-the man , which was [the tall Baudoin]143-baudoin ; and therewith [he]2926-the man smote down on [Baudoin]143-baudoin so fierce and huge a stroke , that came on [him]2926-the man betwixt neck and shoulder , that all gave way before it , and [the Golden Knight]1329-the golden knight fell to earth all carven and stark dead : but even therewith fell [Hugh]124-hugh , [the squire]3482-the squire , and [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant on [the Red Knight]141-the red knight ; for [Arthur]125-arthur had run to [Birdalone]145-birdalone and sheared [her]3579-her loose from [her]3579-her tether . [The sergeant]3491-the sergeant smote [him]2926-the man on the right arm with a maul , so that the axe fell to the ground ; [the squire]3482-the squire 's sword came on the side of [his]2926-the man head , and , as it was cast back beneath the stroke , [Hugh]124-hugh thrust [his]124-hugh sword through the throat of [him]2926-the man , and down [he]2926-the man fell unto [the earth]445-the earth and was dead in less than a minute .

Then gathered [the others]1301-the others round about [Baudoin]143-baudoin , and saw at once that [he]143-baudoin was dead ; and [Birdalone]145-birdalone came thrusting through the press of [them]1301-the others , and knelt down beside [him]143-baudoin , and when [she]3579-her saw [[her]3579-her friend]446-her friend so piteously dight , [she]3579-her wept and wailed over [him]143-baudoin as one who might not be comforted ; and [Hugh]124-hugh stood over [her]3579-her and let [his]124-hugh tears fall down upon [the dead man]3585-the dead man ; and withal [the squire]3482-the squire and [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant did not refrain [their]1301-the others lamentations , for sore beloved was [Sir Baudoin the Golden Knight]123-baudoin .

But [Arthur]125-arthur spake dry - eyed , though there was grief in [his]125-arthur countenance , and [he]125-arthur said : [Fellows]156-fellows , and [thou]156-fellows , [lady]504-lady , let [us]3589-us lament afterwards , but now is time for [us]3589-us to get [us]3589-us gone hence as speedily as may be . Yet [I]0-i will ask , doth any know whose is this head that [the slain tyrant here]3590-the slain tyrant here had hung about [the lady]1157-the lady 's neck ? May [the fiends]3592-the fiends curse [him]3585-the dead man therefor !

Said [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant : [Yea]3594-yea , [lords]2319-lords , that wot [I]0-i ; this is [the head of [[the Red Knight]2539-the red knight 's captain]3598-the red knight 's captain and head man , [Sir Thomas of [Estcliffe]53-estcliffe]3599-sir thomas of estcliffe]3596-the head of the red knight 's captain and head man , sir thomas of estcliffe ; [one of the hardiest of [knights]3601-knights [he]3585-the dead man was while [he]3585-the dead man was alive , as [ye]2319-lords surely wot , [lords]2319-lords]3600-one of the hardiest of knights he was while he was alive , as ye surely wot , lords ; neither , as [I]0-i have heard say , was [he]3585-the dead man as cruel a tyrant as [[his]3585-the dead man lord]3224-his lord that lieth there ready for the ravens .

Now had [Birdalone]145-birdalone arisen and was standing facing [Arthur]125-arthur ; [her]3604-her face was pale and full of anguish , and [she]3604-her was dabbled with blood from [the dead man]3585-the dead man 's neck ; but there was nought of shame in [her]3604-her face as [she]3604-her stood there and spoke : [O [[my]0-i living friends]3607-my living friends , who have but now saved [me]0-i , [ye]2319-lords and [[my]0-i dead friends]3608-my dead friends]3606-o my living friends , who have but now saved me , ye and my dead friends , from what shame and death [I]0-i know not , the tale of [this woeful hap]3609-this woeful hap is over long to tell if there be peril at hand , and [I]0-i scarce alive from dread and sorrow ; but shortly thus it is : [This man , whose head here lieth]3610-this man , whose head here lieth , entrapped [me]0-i as [I]0-i foolishly wandered in [the Black Valley]43-the black valley , and afterwards delivered [me]0-i , and was leading [me]0-i to [[your]2319-lords castle]3611-your castle , [[my]0-i friends]2100-my friends , when [this other one]3613-this other one , [[his]3613-this other one master]3614-his master , [the tyrant of the Red Hold]3615-the tyrant of the red hold , came upon [him]3613-this other one , and fell upon [him]3613-this other one and slew [him]3613-this other one as [a traitor]3440-a traitor , and dighted [me]0-i as [ye]2319-lords saw . And woe 's [me]0-i ! [I]0-i am [the fool whose folly has slain [[your]2319-lords friend]3447-your friend and [mine]3619-mine]3617-the fool whose folly has slain your friend and mine . Wherefore [I]0-i am not worthy of [your]2319-lords fellowship , and [ye]2319-lords shall cast [me]0-i forth of it ; or to slay [me]0-i were better .

So [she]3620-her spake , gazing earnestly on [Arthur]125-arthur ; and so troubled and grieved , that [she]3620-her might well have died but for [her]3620-her woodland breeding , and the toil of the days [she]3620-her had won through in [the House under [the Wood]6-the wood]2453-the house under the wood .

But [Hugh spake]124-hugh gently to [her]3620-her and said : Keep up [thine]3622-thine heart yet , [maiden]1117-maiden ; for the hand of Fate it is that led [thee]3620-her , and none doeth grievously amiss but if [he]125-arthur mean wrong - doing in [his]125-arthur heart ; and [we]3624-our know [thee]3620-her for true ; and [thou]3620-her hast been [[our]3624-our helper]3625-our helper , and brought [[our]3624-our lovelings]3626-our lovelings unto [us]3624-our to make [us]3624-our happy .

But [she]3620-her brake out weeping afresh , and said : O no , no ! it is but woe and weariness [I]0-i have brought unto [[my]0-i friends]2100-my friends ; and to [myself]0-i woe and weariness yet more .

And [she]3620-her looked piteously into [Arthur]125-arthur 's face , and hard and stern it seemed unto [her]3620-her ; and [she]3620-her writhed and wrung [her]3620-her hands for anguish . But [he]125-arthur spake and said : This will [we]3624-our look into when [we]3624-our be safe behind [our]3624-our walls , and see what [she]3620-her hath done amiss and what not amiss . But now is there but one thing to do , and that is to get [us]3624-our speedily on [our]3624-our way to [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest , and bind [[our]3624-our fellow]3629-our fellow 's body on [his]125-arthur horse that [he]125-arthur also may ride with [us]3624-our , and [the lady]1157-the lady shall ride the horse of [the accursed thief]3631-the accursed thief . Then [they]3624-our turned to go toward [their]3624-our horses ; but therewith [Birdalone]145-birdalone smote [her]3620-her foot against [the slain knight]3632-the slain knight 's head , and shrank aback from it , and pointed down toward it and spake no word ; and [Hugh]124-hugh said : [Friends]416-friends , [the lady]1157-the lady is right , this at least [we]3624-our will cover with earth . Do [ye]416-friends go fetch hither [[our]3624-our horses]3635-our horses , since [we]3624-our be on [the road]2103-the road , and [I]0-i will do here what need is meanwhile .

So [they]3624-our went on that errand , and then [Hugh]124-hugh and [Birdalone]145-birdalone between [them]3624-our dug a hole with the swords and laid the head of [the captain of the Red Knight therein]3637-the captain of the red knight therein . And forsooth , somewhat would [Birdalone]145-birdalone have wept for [him]3632-the slain knight had [she]3620-her had a tear to spare .

Then [they]3624-our fell to and bound the dead [Baudoin]123-baudoin on [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight 's mighty bay steed , so that no time might be wasted ; and when that was done , and [the others]1301-the others had not come back with [their]1301-the others horses , [Hugh]124-hugh took [Birdalone]145-birdalone 's hand and led [her]3620-her down to [the stream]2085-the stream and washed the gore off [her]3620-her bosom , and [she]3620-her washed [her]3620-her face and [her]3620-her hands and let [him]124-hugh lead [her]3620-her back again in such wise that now [she]3620-her could hearken to the words of comfort [he]124-hugh spake to [her]3620-her , and piteous kind [he]124-hugh seemed unto [her]3620-her ; so that at last [she]3620-her plucked up heart , and asked [him]124-hugh how [Viridis]116-viridis did . Quoth [he]124-hugh : [They]3641-they be all safe at [home]387-home in [the castle]1838-the castle , and [Viridis]116-viridis is well and loveth [thee]3644-thee well . And [Aurea]116-viridis was well , woe worth the while for [her]116-viridis now ! As for [Atra]117-atra , [she]117-atra has not been so glad as [the other twain]1532-the other twain , [I]0-i wot not wherefore .

Even as [he]124-hugh spake were [the others]1301-the others come up with the horses , and [Arthur]125-arthur nodded yeasay when [he]125-arthur saw what had been done with [Baudoin]123-baudoin dead ; and so [they]3641-they gat to horse , and [Birdalone]145-birdalone it was that rode [Baudoin]123-baudoin 's steed . Then [they]3641-they went [their]3641-they ways , crossing [the river]2277-the river into [the wood]348-the wood ; and [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant was ever way - leader , but [the squire]3482-the squire led the horse which bore the sorrowful burden of [the dead Knight of the Quest]3651-the dead knight of the quest .

CHAPTER V. [THEY]3641-they COME HOME TO [THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST]1931-the castle of the quest

Now [they]3641-they had gone but some three hours , riding dreary and nigh speechless all of [them]3641-they , ere [they]3641-they began to know [the land]213-the land [they]3641-they were in , and that [they]3641-they were coming to the place where [they]3641-they might look presently to fall in with [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris and [[his]138-sir aymeris company]2804-his company ; and even so the meeting betid , that [they]3641-they saw [men]219-men standing and going about [their]219-men horses beside [a little wood]3656-a little wood , and knew [them]219-men presently for [[their]219-men folk]3657-their folk , who mounted at once and spurred forward to meet [them]219-men , spears aloft . Speedily then was the joy of those abiders turned into sorrow , nor may the grief of [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris be told , so great it was ; and [Birdalone]145-birdalone looked on and saw the mourning and lamentation of [the warriors]3658-the warriors , and eked was [her]3659-her anguish of mind ; and [she]3659-her beheld [Arthur the Black Squire]125-arthur , how [he]125-arthur sat still upon [his]125-arthur horse with a hard and dreary countenance , and looked on [those mourners]3660-those mourners almost as if [he]125-arthur contemned [them]3660-those mourners . But [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris came up to [Birdalone]145-birdalone , and knelt before [her]3659-her and kissed [her]3659-her hand , and said : If [my]0-i heart might rejoice in aught , as some day it will , it would rejoice in seeing [thee]3659-her safe and sound , [lady]504-lady ; here at least is gain to set beside the loss .

[She]3659-her thanked [him]138-sir aymeris , but looked askance toward [Arthur]125-arthur , who said : If that be gain , yet is there more , for [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight lieth in [the green plain]638-the green plain for a supper to the wolf and the crow . Vengeance there hath been , and belike more yet may come . But now , if [ye]3659-her have lamented as much as [ye]3659-her deem befitteth [warriors]2117-warriors , let [us]3665-they tarry here no longer ; for even yet meseemeth shall [we]3665-they be safer behind walls , now that [[our]3665-they chief]3666-our chief and [captain]3358-captain is slain , [I]0-i scarce know in what quarrel .

[None]1226-none naysaid it , so [they]3665-they all rode forth together , and [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant and [the squire]3482-the squire and [Sir Hugh]124-hugh told of [their]3665-they tale what [they]3665-they might to [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris and [the others]1301-the others ; but [Arthur]125-arthur held [his]125-arthur peace , and rode aloof from [Birdalone]101-birdalone , whereas [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris and [Hugh]124-hugh rode on either side of [her]101-birdalone , and did not spare to comfort [her]101-birdalone what [they]3665-they might .

[They]3665-they rode straight on , and made no stay for nightfall , and thus came [home]387-home to [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest before the day was full ; and woeful was [their]3665-they entry as [they]3665-they went in the dawn underneath the gate of [the said castle]1941-the said castle , and soon was [the whole house]3675-the whole house astir and lamenting .

As for [Birdalone]145-birdalone , when [she]101-birdalone got down from [her]101-birdalone horse in the gateway , and was stiff and weary of body , and all dazed and confused of mind , there was but little life in [her]101-birdalone ; nor could [she]101-birdalone so much as think of the new day and [Aurea]116-viridis 's awakening , but crept up unto [[her]101-birdalone own chamber]3676-her own chamber , so long as it seemed since [she]101-birdalone had left [it]3676-her own chamber , though it was but a little while ; and [she]101-birdalone cast [herself]101-birdalone upon the bed and fell asleep whether [she]101-birdalone would or not , and so forgat [her]101-birdalone much sorrow and [her]101-birdalone little hope .

CHAPTER VI . OF THE TALK BETWIXT [BIRDALONE]145-birdalone AND [VIRIDIS]116-viridis

When [she]101-birdalone woke again , [she]101-birdalone had slept the night away , and it was broad day , and for a moment [she]101-birdalone lay wondering what was the burden upon [her]101-birdalone ; but presently [she]101-birdalone called it all to mind , and deemed it were well might [she]101-birdalone forget it all again . Anon [she]101-birdalone became aware of [someone]496-someone moving about [the chamber]306-the chamber , and [she]101-birdalone looked about unhappily ; and lo ! [a woman , fair and dainty , clad all in green]3679-a woman , fair and dainty , clad all in green , and it was [Viridis]116-viridis that had come [there]232-there . But when [she]101-birdalone saw [Birdalone]145-birdalone stirring , [she]101-birdalone came up to [her]101-birdalone and kissed [her]101-birdalone sweetly and kindly , and wept over [her]101-birdalone , so that [Birdalone]145-birdalone might nowise refrain [her]101-birdalone tears . But when [she]101-birdalone might cease weeping , [she]101-birdalone said to [Viridis]116-viridis : Tell [me]0-i , art [thou]3681-thou weeping for [[thy]3681-thou friend]2239-thy friend who is lost , and who shall be [[thy]3681-thou friend]2239-thy friend no more ; or [[thy]3681-thou friend whom [thou]3681-thou hast found]3684-thy friend whom thou hast found ? Said [Viridis]116-viridis : Forsooth [I]0-i have wept for [Baudoin]123-baudoin plenteously , and [he]123-baudoin is worthy of it , for [he]123-baudoin was valiant and true and kind . Said [Birdalone]145-birdalone : True is that ; but [I]0-i meant not [my]0-i question so ; but rather [I]0-i would ask [thee]3685-thee if [thou]3681-thou weepest because [thine]3681-thou heart must needs cast [me]0-i away , or because [thou]3681-thou hast found [me]0-i again ? Quoth Viridis : Whoso may be dead , or whoso alive , but if it were [Hugh]124-hugh , [[my]0-i loveling]3686-my loveling , [I]0-i were rejoiced beyond measure to find [thee]3685-thee , [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend . And again [she]0-i kissed [her]3685-thee as [one who was glad and kind]3688-one who was glad and kind . But for [new rest of soul and for joy]3689-new rest of soul and for joy , [Birdalone]145-birdalone fell a - weeping afresh .

Again [she]0-i spake : And what mind have [the others]1301-the others about [me]0-i ? For [thou]3681-thou art but one , though the dearest , save . . . And would [they]1301-the others punish [me]0-i for [my]0-i fault and folly that has slain [the best man in [the world]430-the world]3691-the best man in the world ? If the punishment be short of putting [me]0-i forth of [their]1301-the others fellowship , [I]0-i were fain thereof .

[Viridis]116-viridis laughed : Forsooth , [she]116-viridis said , [they]1301-the others have much to punish [thee]3681-thou for ! whereas it was by [thy]3681-thou doing and [thy]3681-thou valiance that [we]3693-we all came together again and the Quest was accomplished . Nay , but tell [me]0-i , said [Birdalone]145-birdalone , what do [they]1301-the others say of [me]0-i , [each one of [them]1301-the others]2350-each one of them ?

[Viridis]116-viridis reddened ; [she]116-viridis said : [Hugh]124-hugh , [[my]0-i mate]3695-my mate , saith all good of [thee]3681-thou ; though [no one of carl - folk]3696-no one of carl - folk may be sorrier of the loss of [[his]3696-no one of carl - folk fellow]3697-his fellow . [Aurea]116-viridis layeth not the death of [[her]116-viridis man]3698-her man upon [thee]3681-thou ; and [she]116-viridis saith : When the fountain of tears is dried up in [me]0-i , [I]0-i will see [her]116-viridis and comfort [her]116-viridis , as [she]116-viridis [me]0-i . [Atra]117-atra saith : [she]117-atra saith but little , yet [she]117-atra saith : So is it fated . [I]0-i had done belike no better , but worse than [she]117-atra .

Now turned [Birdalone]145-birdalone red and then pale again , and [she]117-atra said , but in a quavering voice : And [the Black Squire]125-arthur , [Arthur]125-arthur , what sayeth [he]125-arthur ? Said [Viridis]116-viridis : [He]125-arthur sayeth nought of [thee]3681-thou , but that [he]125-arthur would hear all the tale of what befell [thee]3681-thou in [the Black Valley]43-the black valley . [Sweet friend]1574-sweet friend , said [Birdalone]145-birdalone , [I]0-i pray [thee]1574-sweet friend of [thy]1574-sweet friend kindness and sweetness that [thou]1574-sweet friend go unto [him]125-arthur presently and bring [him]125-arthur in hither , and then [I]0-i will tell [him]125-arthur all ; and [he]125-arthur and [thou]1574-sweet friend and [I]0-i together .

[Viridis]116-viridis said : There is this to be said , that when [a man]234-a man loveth [a woman]250-a woman [he]234-a man coveteth [her]250-a woman , to have [her]250-a woman all wholly to [himself]234-a man , and hard and evil [he]234-a man groweth for the time that [he]234-a man misdoubteth [her]250-a woman whom [he]234-a man loveth . And [I]0-i will tell [thee]3702-thee that [this man]1976-this man is jealous lest [thou]1574-sweet friend wert never so little kind to [the slain stranger knight whose head [the tyrant]3705-the tyrant hung about [thee]3702-thee]3704-the slain stranger knight whose head the tyrant hung about thee . Furthermore , [I]0-i fear there is no help for it that [thou]1574-sweet friend wilt undo the happiness of one of [us]3706-our , that is [Atra]117-atra ; yet were it better that that befell later than sooner . And if [Sir Arthur]157-arthur come in here to [thee]3702-thee , and hath [thy]157-arthur tale with none beside save [me]0-i , meseems [the poor [Atra]117-atra]3707-the poor atra will feel a bitter smart because of it . Were it not better that [we]3706-our all meet presently in the solar , and that there [thou]1574-sweet friend tell [thy]157-arthur tale to [us]3706-our all ? and thereafter shall [we]3706-our tell the tale of [our]3706-our deliverance and [our]3706-our coming hither . And thus doing , it will seem less like to the breaking up of [our]3706-our fellowship .

Said [Birdalone]145-birdalone : It will be hard for [me]0-i to tell [my]0-i tale before [Atra]117-atra and before [him]157-arthur . Might it not be that [thou]1574-sweet friend hearken to it here and now , and tell it to [the others hereafter]3708-the others hereafter ? Nay , nay , said [Viridis]116-viridis , [I]0-i am not [a proper minstrel]3709-a proper minstrel to take the word out of [thy]1574-sweet friend mouth . Never shall [I]0-i be able to tell it so that [they]3708-the others hereafter shall trow it as if [they]3708-the others hereafter had seen it all . Besides , when all is told , then shall [we]3706-our be more bound together again . [I]0-i pray [thee]1574-sweet friend , and [I]0-i pray [thee]1574-sweet friend , sweet , do so much for [me]0-i as to tell [thy]1574-sweet friend tale to [the fellowship of [us]3706-our]3710-the fellowship of us . And if it be hard to [thee]1574-sweet friend , look upon it as [my]0-i share of the punishment which is due to [thee]1574-sweet friend for falling into that mishap .

Smiled [Birdalone]145-birdalone ruefully , and said : So be it ; and may the share of [the others]1301-the others be as light as thine , [sister]783-sister . Yet soothly were [I]0-i liefer that [my]0-i body and [my]0-i skin should pay the forfeit . But now , since [I]0-i must needs do this , the sooner is [the better meseemeth]3713-the better meseemeth .

In a little half hour , said [Viridis]116-viridis , will [I]0-i bring what is left of [[our]3706-our fellowship]3714-our fellowship into [the solar]3715-the solar to hearken [thee]1574-sweet friend . So come [thou]1574-sweet friend there unto [us]3706-our when [thou]1574-sweet friend art clad . And hear [thou]1574-sweet friend ! be not too meek and humble , and bow [thyself]3716-thyself to [us]3706-our in fear of [our]3706-our sorrow . For whereas [thou]1574-sweet friend didst speak of [our]3706-our punishing [thee]1574-sweet friend , there will be one there whom [thou]1574-sweet friend mayst easily punish to [thy]1574-sweet friend pleasure ; forsooth , [friend]2809-friend , [I]0-i rue that so it is ; but since it will not better be , what may [I]0-i do but wish [thee]1574-sweet friend happy and [him]3718-him also .

Therewith [she]0-i turned and went out of [the chamber]306-the chamber , and [Birdalone]145-birdalone , left to [herself]145-birdalone , felt a secret joy in [her]0-i soul that [she]0-i might not master , despite the sorrow of [[her]0-i friends]1314-her friends , whatever it might be .

CHAPTER VII . [BIRDALONE]145-birdalone TELLETH THE TALE OF [HER]0-i WANDERING UP [THE VALLEY]43-the black valley OF [THE GREYWETHERS]149-the greywethers

Now [Viridis]116-viridis did as [she]116-viridis said , and brought [them]1314-her friends all in to the solar ; there was none lacking save [Baudoin]123-baudoin , and [they]1314-her friends sat silently in a half ring , till the door opened and [Birdalone]145-birdalone came in to [them]1314-her friends , clad all simply in but a black coat ; and [she]116-viridis made obeisance to [them]1314-her friends , and stood there with [her]116-viridis head bent down as if [they]1314-her friends were [[her]116-viridis judges]3721-her judges , for so in sooth [she]116-viridis deemed [them]1314-her friends . Then [Hugh]124-hugh bade [her]116-viridis sit down amongst [them]1314-her friends ; but [she]116-viridis said : Nay , [I]0-i will not sit amongst [you]124-hugh till [ye]124-hugh have heard [my]0-i story , and [ye]124-hugh have told [me]0-i that [I]0-i am yet of [your]124-hugh fellowship . None said aught ; [Atra]117-atra looked straight before [her]117-atra , and [her]117-atra eyes met not [Birdalone]145-birdalone 's eyes ; [Arthur]157-arthur looked down on the ground ; but [Hugh]124-hugh and [Viridis]116-viridis looked kindly on [Birdalone]145-birdalone , and to [Viridis]116-viridis ' eyes the tears were come .[124-hugh]

Then spake [Birdalone]145-birdalone and said : [I]0-i am here as one that hath done amiss ; but [I]0-i will tell [you]145-birdalone , so that [ye]145-birdalone may not think worse of [me]0-i than [ye]145-birdalone should , that when [ye]145-birdalone were gone , [ye]145-birdalone Champions , and the time wore long that [ye]145-birdalone came not again , it lay heavy on [my]0-i heart , and hope waned and fear waxed , and [my]0-i soul so grieved [my]0-i body that [I]0-i thought to fall sick thereof , and [I]0-i knew that it would be ill for [you]145-birdalone to come [home]387-home hither and find [me]0-i sick ; so that [I]0-i longed sore to do somewhat which should make [me]0-i whole again . Then weird would that [I]0-i should hear all the tale of [the Black Valley of the Greywethers]2748-the black valley of the greywethers , and of how therein is whiles granted fulfilment of desire ; and methought how well it were if [I]0-i might seek the adventure there and accomplish it . [Thereof]3724-thereof , doubtless , [hath]3725-hath [the chaplain]2413-the chaplain , [Sir Leonard]145-birdalone , told [you]145-birdalone ; but this furthermore would [I]0-i say , that [his]2413-the chaplain doing herein was nought ; all was done by [my]0-i doing and by [my]0-i bidding , and [he]2413-the chaplain might not choose but do it . Wherefore [I]0-i do pray [you]145-birdalone all earnestly that [ye]145-birdalone keep no grudge against [him]2413-the chaplain , but pardon [him]2413-the chaplain all . Tell [me]0-i , then , will [ye]145-birdalone do thus much ?

Said [Hugh]124-hugh : Let [him]2413-the chaplain be pardoned , if [he]2413-the chaplain can take pardon . But [Arthur]157-arthur spake not , and [Birdalone]145-birdalone looked on [him]2413-the chaplain anxiously , and [her]3727-she face was moved , and it was with [her]3727-she throat as if [she]3727-she had swallowed something down . Then [she]3727-she spake again , and fell to tell [them]3728-we all that had betid to [her]3727-she when [she]3727-she went to [the Black Valley]43-the black valley , even as is hereafore writ , hiding nought that had been done and said ; and freely [she]3727-she told it , without fear or shame , and with such clearness and sweetness of words that [no one of [them]3728-we]3729-no one of them doubted [her]3727-she aught ; and [Arthur]157-arthur lifted up [his]157-arthur head , and once and again [his]157-arthur eyes met [hers]3727-she , and there was nought of hardness in them , though [they]3730-they turned away at once .

So at last fell [Birdalone]145-birdalone to telling what betid after [they]3728-we two , [the stranger knight]3474-the stranger knight and [she]3727-she , left [the valley of the force]3732-the valley of the force and fell to riding the wildwood with [their]3728-we heads turned toward [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest ; and [she]3727-she said :

When [we]3728-we turned into [the wood]348-the wood away from [the said valley]2721-the said valley [it]3736-it lacked some four hours of noon ; and [we]3728-we rode till noon was , and rested by a stream - side and ate , for [we]3728-we knew no cause wherefore [we]3728-we should hasten overmuch ; but [[my]0-i fellow]3737-my fellow [the strange knight]3738-the strange knight was downcast and heavy , and some might have called [him]3738-the strange knight sullen . But [I]0-i strove to make [him]3738-the strange knight of better cheer , and spake to [him]3738-the strange knight kindly , as to one who of [an enemy]3739-an enemy had become [a friend]520-a friend ; but [he]3738-the strange knight answered [me]0-i : [Lady]504-lady , it availeth not ; [I]0-i grieve that [I]0-i am no better company than [thou]3742-thou seest [me]0-i , and [I]0-i have striven to be merrier ; but apart from all that [I]0-i wot and that [thou]3742-thou wottest which should make [me]0-i of evil cheer , there is now a weight upon [my]0-i heart which [I]0-i can not lift , such as never have [I]0-i felt erst . So by [thy]3742-thou leave [we]3743-we will to horse at once , that [we]3743-we may [the speedier]3744-the speedier come to [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest and [[Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris ' prison]7133-sir aymeris ' prison .[138-sir aymeris]

So [I]0-i arose , but smiled on [him]138-sir aymeris and said : Hold up [thine]3746-thine heart , [friend]2809-friend ! for [thee]3742-thou shall be no prison at [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest , but the fair welcome of [friends]416-friends . [He]138-sir aymeris said nought , and mended not [his]138-sir aymeris cheer ; and in this plight [we]3743-we gat to horse and rode on for some three hours more , till [we]3743-we came out of [the thick forest]3750-the thick forest into a long clearing , which went like a wide highway of greensward between the thicket , and it seemed as if [the hand of man]3751-the hand of man had cleared [that said green road]3752-that said green road . Thereto [we]3743-we had come , following [a little river which came out on to [the clearing]3754-the clearing with [us]3743-we]3753-a little river which came out on to the clearing with us , and then , turning , ran well - nigh amidst [it]3753-a little river which came out on to the clearing with us toward [the north]678-the north .

Now when [we]3743-we were come thither , and were betwixt [the thicket]3756-the thicket and [the water]361-the water 's edge , [we]3743-we drew rein , and it seemed to [me]0-i as fair a stead as might be in [the woodland]669-the woodland , and [I]0-i looked thereon well pleased and with a happy heart . But [the knight]2120-the knight said : [Lady]504-lady , art [thou]3761-thou not exceeding weary ? Nay , said [I]0-i , not in any wise . Said [he]2120-the knight : It is strange then , for so weary am [I]0-i , that [I]0-i must in any case get off [my]0-i horse and lay [me]0-i down on the grass here , or [I]0-i shall drop from the saddle . And therewith [he]2120-the knight lighted down and stood by [me]0-i a little , as to help [me]0-i off [my]0-i horse ; but [I]0-i said to [him]2120-the knight : [Knight]124-hugh , [I]0-i pray [thee]2120-the knight , even if [ye]2120-the knight be weary , to struggle forward a little , lest [we]3762-we be in peril here . In peril ? quoth [he]2120-the knight ; [yea]3763-yea , that might be if [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight knew of [our]3762-we whereabouts ; but how should that be ? [He]2120-the knight spoke this heavily , as [one scarce awake]3765-one scarce awake ; and then [he]2120-the knight said : [I]0-i pray [thee]0-i pardon [me]0-i , [lady]504-lady , but for nought may [I]0-i hold [my]0-i head up ; suffer [me]0-i to sleep but a little , and then will [I]0-i arise and lead [thee]0-i straight to [thy]0-i journey 's end . Therewithal [he]2120-the knight laid [him]2120-the knight down on [the grass]3767-the grass and was presently asleep , and [I]0-i sat down by [him]2120-the knight all dismayed . At first , indeed , [I]0-i doubted some treachery in [him]2120-the knight , for how might [I]0-i trust [him]2120-the knight wholly after all that had come and gone ? but when [I]0-i saw that there was no feigning in [his]2120-the knight sleep , [I]0-i set that doubt aside , and knew not what to make of it .

Thus passed an hour , and from time to time [I]0-i shook [him]2120-the knight and strove to waken [him]2120-the knight , but it was all in vain ; so [I]0-i knew none other rede than to abide [his]2120-the knight awakening ; for [I]0-i knew not the way to take toward [this castle]1970-this castle ; and , moreover , though [he]2120-the knight were [a knight , and armed]3769-a knight , and armed , yet might it be perilous for [him]2120-the knight if [he]2120-the knight were left there alone and unguarded ; so [I]0-i abode .

But now came new tidings . Methought [I]0-i heard the sound of the tinkling of weapons and armour ; [the green highway]3770-the green highway so turned that [a wood neb about an hundred yards to the north]3771-a wood neb about an hundred yards to the north hid it from [my]0-i sight , so that [a man]234-a man might have drawn somewhat near to [us]3773-us without being seen , came [he]234-a man on [the hither side of [the river]2277-the river]3774-the hither side of the river . So [I]0-i stood up hastily , and strung [my]0-i bow , and took a shaft in [my]0-i fingers , and no sooner was it done than there came [a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb . [He]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb was all - armed and had a red surcoat , and rode a great shining bay horse . [I]0-i kept [my]0-i eye upon [him]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb while [I]0-i stirred [the sleeping knight]3777-the sleeping knight with [my]0-i foot , and cried to [him]3777-the sleeping knight to wake , but [he]3777-the sleeping knight scarce moved , and but uttered words without sense .

Now [the new - comer]518-the new - comer drew rein for a moment when [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb saw [us]3773-us , and then moved on a little toward [me]0-i , but [I]0-i nocked a shaft and pointed it at [him]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb , and cried out to [him]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb to stay . Then [I]0-i heard a great rattling laugh come from [him]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb , and [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb shouted : Nay , do [thou]3779-thy stay , [fair wood- wife]3780-fair wood- wife , and [I]0-i will risk [thy]3779-thy shafts to come at [thee]3779-thy . But why doth not the sluggard at [thy]3779-thy feet rise up and stand before [me]0-i , if [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb be [thy]3779-thy loveling ? Or is [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb dead ? [His]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb voice was harsh and big , and [I]0-i feared [him]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb sore ; and it was as much because of fear as of hardihood , that [I]0-i drew and loosed straightway ; and doubtless it was because of fear that [I]0-i saw [my]0-i shaft fly an inch or so over [his]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb right shoulder . [I]0-i heard [his]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb rattling laugh again , and saw [him]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb bend forward as [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb spurred ; [I]0-i knew that time lacked for drawing another shaft , so [I]0-i caught up [my]0-i skirts and ran all [I]0-i might ; but swift - foot as [I]0-i be , it availed [me]0-i nought , for [I]0-i was cumbered with [my]0-i gown , and moreover [I]0-i was confused with not knowing whither to run , since [I]0-i wotted that in the water the horse would do better than [I.]0-i

So [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb was up with [me]0-i in a twinkling , and reached out [his]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb hand and caught hold of [me]0-i by the hair , and tugged [me]0-i to [him]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb as [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb reined back [his]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb horse . Then [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb laughed again and said : Forsooth [she]3781-she will look better when [she]3781-she is no longer reddened and roughened with fleeing ; and , by [Red Peter]158-red peter ! what limbs [she]3781-she hath . Then [he]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb let [me]0-i loose and got off [his]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb horse , and shoved [me]0-i on before [him]3776-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb till [we]3782-we came to where [the Black One]3783-the black one lay still sleeping heavily . Then [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight stood against [me]0-i , and looked hard into [my]0-i face ; and [I]0-i saw how huge [a man]234-a man [he]2539-the red knight was , and how a lock of bright red hair came out from under [his]2539-the red knight sallet . [His]2539-the red knight eyes were green and fierce underneath shaggy red eyebrows ; terrible [he]2539-the red knight was to look on .

Now [he]2539-the red knight spake fiercely and roughly , and as though [he]2539-the red knight had something against [me]0-i : Tell [me]0-i , [thou]3786-thou , who [thou]3786-thou art and who this is ? [I]0-i answered nought , for fear had frozen [my]0-i speech . [He]2539-the red knight stamped [his]2539-the red knight foot on the ground and cried : Hah ! art [thou]3786-thou gone dumb ? Speak ! [thou]3786-thou wert best ! [I]0-i said , all quaking : [My]0-i name is [Birdalone]145-birdalone ; [I]0-i belong to [no one]824-no one ; [I]0-i have [no kindred]3788-no kindred : as for [this man]1976-this man , [I]0-i know not [his]1976-this man name . [He]2539-the red knight said : Comest [thou]3786-thou from [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest ? Art [thou]3786-thou [the whore of those lily - and - rose champions there]3791-the whore of those lily - and - rose champions there ? [My]0-i heart was hot with anger in spite of [my]0-i dread , but [I]0-i spake : [I]0-i came from [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest . [He]2539-the red knight said : And [this man]1976-this man therewith [he]2539-the red knight turned about and spurned [him]1976-this man in the side , where didst [thou]3786-thou happen upon [him]1976-this man ? Again [I]0-i was silent , and [he]2539-the red knight roared out at [me]0-i : So [thou]3786-thou wilt not answer ! Beware , or [I]0-i may see how to compel the speech of [thee]3786-thou . Now answer [me]0-i this : Was it in [the Black Valley]43-the black valley of [the Greywethers]42-the greywethers that [ye]3786-thou two came together ? Again [I]0-i knew not how to answer , lest [I]0-i might do a wrong to [him]2539-the red knight who had repented [him]2539-the red knight of the wrong [he]2539-the red knight had done [me]0-i . But [the Red Knight]141-the red knight burst out a - laughing and said : It shall be remembered against [thee]3786-thou , first , that [thou]3786-thou didst let fly a shaft at [me]0-i ; second , that [thou]3786-thou didst run from [me]0-i ; and thirdly , that [thou]3786-thou hast been slack in answering [my]0-i questions . But all this scathes [me]0-i nought ; first , because [thy]3786-thou shaft missed [me]0-i ; second , because [thy]3786-thou legs failed [thee]3786-thou though they were fair to look on , running ; and third , because all [thou]3786-thou canst tell [me]0-i [I]0-i know without thine answering . Now [thee]3786-thou will [I]0-i tell that this is Friday , and that [ye]3786-thou two first met in [the Black Valley]43-the black valley on Tuesday ; now [I]0-i will ask this last question , and [thou]3786-thou mayst answer it or not as [thou]3786-thou wilt ; for presently [I]0-i shall wake [this brisk and stirring knight]3794-this brisk and stirring knight , and [I]0-i deem that [he]3794-this brisk and stirring knight will tell [me]0-i the truth of this if of nought else . Tell [me]0-i , [[thou]3786-thou whore of the Questing Champions]3795-thou whore of the questing champions , where and how many times [thou]3786-thou hast lain in [this good knight]3796-this good knight 's arms since last Tuesday ? Nowhere and never , quoth [I.]0-i [Thou]3786-thou liest , [I]0-i doubt [thee]3786-thou , said [the Red Knight]141-the red knight ; howsoever , let [us]3797-us see what [this doughty one]3798-this doughty one will say . Hah ! [thou]3786-thou deemest [he]3798-this doughty one shall be hard to wake up , dost [thou]3786-thou not ! Well , [I]0-i shall see to that . [He]3798-this doughty one who giveth sleep may take it away again .

Therewith [he]141-the red knight went up to the Black One and stooped adown over [his]3798-this doughty one head , and spake some words over [him]3798-this doughty one , but so softly that [I]0-i heard not their import ; and straightway [the sleeper]3799-the sleeper rose up so suddenly that [he]141-the red knight wellnigh smote against [the Red Knight]141-the red knight . [He]141-the red knight stood awhile staggering , and blinking at [the other one]2972-the other one , but somehow got [his]141-the red knight sword drawn forth , and [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight hindered [him]141-the red knight nought therein , but spake anon when [the other]265-the other was come to [himself]265-the other somewhat : The sele of the day to [thee]3786-thou , [Sir Thomas]159-sir thomas , [True Thomas]160-true thomas ! Fair is [thy]3786-thou bed , and most fair [thy]3786-thou bedfellow .

[The Black Knight]2114-the black knight drew aback from [him]141-the red knight and was now come awake , wherefore [he]2114-the black knight stood on [his]2114-the black knight guard , but said nought . Then said [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight : [Sir Thomas]159-sir thomas , [I]0-i have been asking [this fair lady]3805-this fair lady a question , but [her]3805-this fair lady memory faileth [her]3805-this fair lady and [she]3805-this fair lady may not answer it ; perchance [thou]3786-thou mayst do better . Tell [me]0-i where and how many times hast [thou]3786-thou bedded [her]3805-this fair lady betwixt last Tuesday and this ? Nowhere and never , cried [Sir Thomas]159-sir thomas , knitting [his]159-sir thomas brows and handling [his]159-sir thomas sword . [Hah]3806-hah , said [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight , an echo of [her]3805-this fair lady speech is this . [Lo]128-lo , the tale [ye]3808-ye have made up betwixt [you]3808-ye . But at least , having done [mine]0-i errand , though [meseemeth]3809-meseemeth somewhat leisurely , and having gotten [the woman]252-the woman for [me]0-i , [thou]3786-thou art now bringing [her]252-the woman on to the Red Hold , whatever [thou]3786-thou hast done with [her]252-the woman on [the road]2103-the road ? [I]0-i am not , said [[my]0-i fellow]3737-my fellow , [I]0-i am leading [her]252-the woman away from [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold . Pity of [thee]252-the woman , quoth the other , that [thou]3786-thou hast fallen in with [me]0-i , and [thou]3786-thou but half - armed . And [he]3737-my fellow raised aloft [his]3737-my fellow sword ; but presently sank it again , and let the point rest on [the earth]445-the earth .

Then [he]3737-my fellow spoke again , not mockingly as erst : A word before [we]3815-we end it , [Thomas]159-sir thomas : [thou]3786-thou hast hitherto done well by [me]0-i , as [I]0-i by [thee]252-the woman . [I]0-i say [thou]3786-thou hast gotten [this woman]425-this woman , and [I]0-i doubt not that at first [thou]3786-thou hadst the mind to bring [her]425-this woman to [me]0-i unminished ; but then [thou]3786-thou wert overcome by [her]425-this woman beauty , as forsooth [I]0-i know [thee]252-the woman woman - mad , and [thou]3786-thou hadst meant to keep [her]425-this woman for thyself , as forsooth [I]0-i marvel not . But in [thy]252-the woman love - making [thou]3786-thou hast not bethought [thee]252-the woman that keep [her]425-this woman to [thyself]3817-thyself [thou]3786-thou mayst not while [I]0-i am above ground , save [thou]3786-thou bewray [me]0-i , and join [thee]252-the woman to [[my]0-i foemen]1378-my foemen and thine . Because [I]0-i am such [a man]234-a man , that what [I]0-i desire that will [I]0-i have . For this reason , when [I]0-i misdoubted [me]0-i of [thee]252-the woman for [thy]252-the woman much - tarrying , [I]0-i cast the sleep over [thee]252-the woman , and have caught [thee]252-the woman . For what wilt [thou]3786-thou do ? Doubt it not , that if [our]3820-our swords meet , [I]0-i shall pay [thee]252-the woman for trying to take [my]0-i bedthrall from [me]0-i by taking from [thee]252-the woman no more than [thy]252-the woman life . But now will [I]0-i forgive [thee]252-the woman all if [thou]252-the woman wilt ride [home]387-home quietly with [me]0-i and [this damsel- errant to the Red Hold]3822-this damsel- errant to the red hold , and let [her]3822-this damsel- errant to the red hold be [mine]0-i and not thine so long as [I]0-i will ; and then afterwards , if [thou]252-the woman wilt , [she]3822-this damsel- errant to the red hold shall be thine as long as [thou]252-the woman wilt . Now behold , both this chance and [thy]252-the woman life is a mere gift of [me]0-i to [thee]252-the woman , for otherwise [thou]252-the woman shalt have neither damsel nor life .

Yea , yea , said [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend , [I]0-i know what [thou]252-the woman wouldest : [I]0-i have been no unhandy devil to [thee]252-the woman this long while , and [thou]252-the woman wouldst fain keep [me]0-i still ; but now [I]0-i will be devil no longer , on [this earth]3824-this earth at least , but will die and take [my]0-i luck of it . And do [thou]252-the woman , [God]120-god , see to the saving of [this damsel]2325-this damsel , since [thou]252-the woman hast taken the matter out of [my]0-i hands . Farewell , [dear maiden]1206-dear maiden !

Scarce was the word out of [his]318-my friend mouth ere [his]318-my friend sword was in the air , and [he]318-my friend smote so fierce and straight that [he]318-my friend beat down [the huge man]3827-the huge man 's blade , and , ere [he]318-my friend could master it again , smote [the Red Knight]141-the red knight so heavily on the crest that [he]318-my friend fell to [his]318-my friend knees ; and the heart rose in [me]0-i , for [I]0-i deemed that [he]318-my friend might yet prevail ; and in as ' twere a flash [I]0-i bethought [me]0-i of the knife at [my]0-i girdlestead , and drew it and ran to [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight , and tore aside [his]318-my friend mail hood with one hand and thrust the knife into [his]318-my friend shoulder with the other ; but so mighty was [he]318-my friend that [he]318-my friend heeded nought the hurt , but swept [his]318-my friend sword back - handed at [the Black Knight]2114-the black knight 's unarmed leg , and smote [him]318-my friend so sore a wound that down [he]318-my friend fell clattering . Then arose [the Red Knight]2539-the red knight , and thrust [me]0-i from [him]318-my friend with the left hand , and strode over [[my]0-i fellow - farer]7137-my fellow - farer and thrust [his]3829-he sword through [his]318-my friend throat . Then [he]3829-he turned to [me]0-i , and spake in a braying voice as if a harsh horn were blown :[0-i]

Abide [thou]3828-thee ; if [thou]3828-thee takest one step [I]0-i will slay [thee]3828-thee at once . So [he]3829-he went and sat down on a bank a little way from [the dead man]3585-the dead man , and wiped [his]3829-he sword on the grass and laid it beside [him]3829-he , and so sat pondering a while . Thereafter [he]3829-he called [me]0-i to [him]3829-he , and bade [me]0-i stand in face of [him]3829-he with [my]0-i hands clasped before [me]0-i . Then [he]3829-he spake to [me]0-i : [Thou]3828-thee art [my]0-i thrall and [my]0-i having , since [I]0-i had thus doomed it no few days ago ; and [thou]3828-thee art now in [my]0-i hands for [me]0-i to do with as [I]0-i will . Now instead of being meek and obedient to [me]0-i [thou]3828-thee hast rebelled against [me]0-i , shot an arrow at [me]0-i , run from [me]0-i , denied answer to [my]0-i questions , and thrust a knife into [me]0-i . To be short , [thou]3828-thee hast made [thyself]3831-thyself [[my]0-i foe]3832-my foe . Furthermore , it is by [thy]3828-thee doing that [I]0-i have lost [a right good servant]3833-a right good servant and [a trusty fellow]3834-a trusty fellow , and one that [I]0-i loved ; it is [thou]3828-thee that hast slain [him]3835-him . Now have [I]0-i been pondering what [I]0-i shall do with [thee]3828-thee . [I]0-i said : If [I]0-i have deserved the death , then make an end and slay [me]0-i presently ; but bring [me]0-i not to [thine house]275-thine house , [I]0-i pray [thee]3828-thee . [I]0-i pray by [the mother that bore [thee]3828-thee]3837-the mother that bore thee !

Quoth [he]3835-him : Hold [thy]3828-thee peace , it is not what [thou]3828-thee deservest that [I]0-i am looking to , but what shall pleasure [me]0-i .
