[We]4299-we arose then , and came to [her]407-the witch as if nought had happened ; and [she]407-the witch bade [us]4299-we walk [the garden]1086-the garden with [her]407-the witch , and [we]4299-we yeasaid it , and went with [her]407-the witch , and paced about amidst the flowers and lay on the blossomed grass . [Forsooth]101-birdalone , both to [her]407-the witch and to [us]4299-we the time hung heavy on hand . And meseemed that the sleekness and fairness of [her]407-the witch body was worsened since yesterday , and [she]407-the witch was pale and haggard , and [her]407-the witch eyes were wandering and afraid .

Now [she]407-the witch bade [us]4299-we come a little further into [the garden]1086-the garden and eat a morsel at noon ; and [we]4299-we arose , and [she]407-the witch brought [us]4299-we to where were vines trellised all about and overhead , so that it was like a fair green cloister ; and there was a board laid and spread with many dainties of meat and drink . And [she]407-the witch bade [us]4299-we sit . Verily [we]4299-we had but little stomach to that dinner ; and [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i , Poison ! poison ! and even so [[my]0-i fellows]4300-my fellows deemed , as afterwards [they]4300-my fellows told [me]0-i . And [I]0-i saw [Baudoin]123-baudoin loosen [his]123-baudoin sword in the sheath , and [I]0-i knew that [his]123-baudoin mind was to smite at once if [he]123-baudoin saw aught amiss . And [I]0-i , who sat next to [the witch]407-the witch , laid [my]0-i hand on a little dagger which [I]0-i wore at [my]0-i girdle . [She]407-the witch also saw this , and turned as pale as death , and sat trembling before [us]4299-we ; and whatso [we]4299-we ate or drank at that board under the rustling vine - leaves , [she]407-the witch gave unto [us]4299-we with [her]407-the witch own hand ; and then [we]4299-we wotted full surely that [she]407-the witch had meant [our]4299-we deaths there and then , but was cowed by the fierce eyes of [Baudoin]123-baudoin and the threat of [my]0-i hand .

[Withal]114-withal it seemed that [she]407-the witch might not bear it to sit there long amongst [us]4299-we . [She]407-the witch rose up and smiled on [us]4299-we as ghastly as a corpse , and gave [us]4299-we leave , and went hurrying into [the house]325-the house . And right glad [we]4299-we were to be at rest from [her]407-the witch . Yet as [we]4299-we [ourselves]4299-we durst not go far away from [the house]325-the house , lest some new thing might happen , neither could [she]407-the witch leave [us]4299-we quite alone , but thrice again that afternoon at some turn of [the garden]1086-the garden , or [orchard]1083-orchard , or [meadow]773-meadow , [we]4299-we came upon [her]407-the witch wan face and eyes full of all hate and staring pride , and [she]407-the witch enforced [her]407-the witch to smile upon [us]4299-we , and turned away with some idle word .

At last the sun began to sink , and [we]4299-we went to [the perron of [the house]325-the house]4222-the perron of the house , and found [her]407-the witch standing to meet [us]4299-we in [her]407-the witch wonted way . But when [we]4299-we came up [she]407-the witch gave no hand to [any one of [us]4299-we]4324-any one of us but went up the stairs before [us]4299-we , and [we]4299-we followed with no word spoken .

There was [the hall]1202-the hall with the lordly service on the board , and the wax- candles lighted all about , and the great vault of stone fair and stately over [it]1202-the hall . [We]4299-we went to the dais and the board and sat down , [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife in [her]349-the witch - wife gold and ivory chair at the board 's end , and [I]0-i at [her]407-the witch right hand and looking down [the hall]1202-the hall , [[my]0-i two fellows]4328-my two fellows facing [me]0-i , with [their]4328-my two fellows backs to the clear of [the hall]1202-the hall .

There [we]4299-we sat , and the meats and drinks were before [us]4299-we as dainty as ever erst ; but [we]4299-we put forth no hand to [them]4330-them , but sat staring at each other for some two minutes it might be , and [the witch]407-the witch looked from one to the other of [us]4299-we , and quaked that [her]407-the witch hands shook like palsy .

Then [I]0-i rose up and put [my]0-i hand to [my]0-i bosom for [Baudoin]123-baudoin had given [me]0-i the flasket ere [we]4299-we came to [the perron]4332-the perron : [I]0-i spake in a loud voice , and it sounded wild and hard in [the goodly hall]4333-the goodly hall : [[My]0-i lady]615-my lady , [I]0-i said , [thou]4335-thou art looking but pale now , and sick and downcast . Drink now to [me]0-i out of this precious flasket , and [thou]4335-thou shalt be whole and well .

And therewith [I]0-i held the flasket aloft ; but [her]615-my lady face changed horribly ; [she]615-my lady sprang up in [her]615-my lady chair and reached out [her]615-my lady arm to clutch at the flasket , screaming like an eagle therewith . But [I]0-i thrust [her]615-my lady back into the chair with [my]0-i left hand ; and therewith arose [Baudoin]123-baudoin and [Arthur]125-arthur , and caught [her]615-my lady by the shoulders , and bound [her]615-my lady fast to the chair with cords that [they]4336-they had gotten thereto . But when [she]615-my lady got [her]615-my lady breath [she]615-my lady yelled out : Ah , now shall all tumble together , [[my]0-i proudful house]4337-my proudful house and [I]0-i under it ! Loose [me]0-i , [traitors]4338-traitors ! loose [me]0-i , [fools]3046-fools ! and give [me]0-i one draught of the water of might , and then shall [I]0-i tell [you]3046-fools all , and [ye]3046-fools shall go free with [your]3046-fools thralls if [ye]3046-fools will . Ah ! [ye]3046-fools will not loose [me]0-i ? [ye]3046-fools will not ? Well then , at least [ye]3046-fools , [the fools]4340-the fools , shall be under it , and [they]4340-the fools also , [the she - traitors]4341-the she - traitors , [the scourged and tormented fools that might not save [themselves]4340-the fools from [me]0-i]4342-the scourged and tormented fools that might not save themselves from me . O loose [me]0-i ! loose [me]0-i ! [thou]4343-thou in whose arms [I]0-i have lain so many a night , and give [me]0-i to drink of the proud water of might !

So [she]0-i yelled ; and now had all the fairness gone from [her]0-i body : flaggy and yellow were [her]0-i limbs , and [she]0-i looked all over as [her]0-i face , a lump of stupid and cruel pride , and [her]0-i words lost meaning and changed into mere bestial howling . But for [me]0-i , since [she]0-i so desired that water , [I]0-i knew that it was good for [us]4344-us to drink , and [I]0-i took out the stopple and drank , and it was as if fire ran through all [my]0-i veins , and [I]0-i felt [my]0-i strength three - folded straightway , and most wondrous clear was [my]0-i sight grown therewith ; and [I]0-i raised [my]0-i eyes now and looked down [the hall]1202-the hall , and lo , there was [Aurea]116-viridis , chained by the ankle to the third pillar from the dais ; and over against [her]116-viridis , [Viridis]116-viridis ; and next , to the fourth pillar , [Atra]117-atra . Then [I]0-i cried in a loud voice that rang through [[the witch]407-the witch 's hall]4347-the witch 's hall : [Lo]128-lo what [I]0-i see ! And [I]0-i ran round the head of the board , and thrust and dragged [Baudoin]123-baudoin and [Arthur]125-arthur along with [me]0-i , crying out : Come , come ! [they]4348-they are found ! [they]4348-they are here ! And [I]0-i came to [[my]0-i sweetling]2218-my sweetling , and found [her]2218-my sweetling clad but in [her]2218-my sweetling white smock , which was flecked with blood all about , and [her]2218-my sweetling face was wan and pined , and the tears began to run when [she]2218-my sweetling saw [me]0-i , but no word came from [her]2218-my sweetling lips though the kissing of them was sweet .

Then [I]0-i turned about to [[my]0-i two fellows]4328-my two fellows , and [they]4328-my two fellows stood bewildered , not knowing what was toward ; and [I]0-i came to [them]4328-my two fellows and made [them]4328-my two fellows drink of the flasket , and [their]4328-my two fellows eyes were opened and the strength of [giants]4351-giants came to [them]4328-my two fellows , and [they]4328-my two fellows ran each to [his]4352-his sweetling ; but [Baudoin]123-baudoin , before ever [he]123-baudoin kissed [Aurea]116-viridis , caught hold of the chain that bound [her]116-viridis to the pillar , and by main force dragged it out . Wise was that , meseemed , for words were again come into [the witch]407-the witch 's howls , and [I]0-i heard [her]116-viridis : Ah , long may [ye]4354-ye be playing with the chains , long ! for now [the house]325-the house rumbleth toward its fall . Ah , [the bitches]4356-the bitches are loose ! Woe 's [me]0-i ! to die alone ! And once more [she]116-viridis howled wordless , as both [I]0-i and [Arthur]125-arthur had [our]4357-we loves in [our]4357-we arms , and fell to following [Baudoin]123-baudoin out on to [the perron]4332-the perron and down into [the fresh fragrant garden]4359-the fresh fragrant garden wherein now was the moon beginning to cast shadows .

Stood [we]4357-we then aloof from [the house]325-the house , and the rumbling whereof [the evil hag]4361-the evil hag had howled waxed into a thunder , and under [our]4357-we very eyes the great white walls and gold - adorned roofs fell together , and a great cloud of dust rose under the clear moonlit sky .

[We]4357-we looked and wondered , and [our]4357-we loves also , but no word [they]4362-their spake ; but ere [the other two]2291-the other two had time to grieve thereat , [I]0-i gave [Viridis]116-viridis to drink of the water of might , and [she]116-viridis fell to sweet speech straightway , of such sort and such wise as [I]0-i will not tell [you]4364-you . Then [I]0-i did the same by [Aurea]116-viridis and [Atra]117-atra , and forthwith the speech flowed from [them]2291-the other two to [[their]2291-the other two friends]4365-their friends .

Full happy were [we]4357-we then in the early night - season , for the water of might gave [them]4362-their strength also , as to [us]4357-we , and healed all the stripes and wounds [their]4362-their bodies had suffered of [the foul witch]4366-the foul witch , and made [their]4362-their eyes bright , and [their]4362-their cheeks full and firm , and [their]4362-their lips most sweet , and [their]4362-their hands strong and delicious .

Now when [we]4357-we had stood gazing toward the melting of [the beauteous palace]4367-the beauteous palace for a little , [we]4357-we took [[our]4357-we darlings]4368-our darlings in [our]4357-we arms again , whereas the chains would have hindered [their]4362-their walking , and went down to [the lip of the water]4369-the lip of the water whereas lay [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , so that [we]4357-we might be anigh [[our]4357-we ferry]3967-our ferry in case of need ; for [we]4357-we knew not what might betide [the isle]642-the isle now [its mistress]4373-its mistress had perished . Then [we]4357-we fell to and sawed off the chains from the dear ankles with [our]4357-we swords , and took [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's lendings from the mail . And [Aurea]116-viridis had [her]116-viridis gown again , and [Viridis]116-viridis [her]116-viridis smock , and [my]0-i green surcoat over it , and [Atra]117-atra wore the battle - coat of [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire . As for [their]4362-their bare feet for [Atra]117-atra would not have [hers]117-atra dight prouder than [[her]117-atra sisters]4375-her sisters ' , [we]4357-we so clad [them]4362-their with kisses that [they]4362-their were not ill - covered belike .[117-atra]

So gat [we]4357-we aboard [[our]4357-we ferry]3967-our ferry , and did blood - offering to the wight thereof , and so sped merrily and lovingly over [the wide lake]4377-the wide lake back on [[our]4357-we homeward road]4378-our homeward road . And [we]4357-we said : This hath the dear [Birdalone]101-birdalone done for [us]4357-we .

And now , [[my]0-i Viridis]4379-my viridis , [I]0-i will that [thou]4380-thou fill up the tale by telling to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , as [ye]4381-you told [us]4357-we , how it fared with [you]4381-you three and [the evil one]4382-the evil one from the time that [ye]4381-you sped [Birdalone]101-birdalone on [her]101-birdalone way till the moment when [mine]0-i eyes first beheld [you]4381-you made fast to the pillars of [the palace]4383-the palace which has crumbled into dust .

CHAPTER X. HOW IT FARED WITH [THE THREE LADIES]4384-the three ladies AFTER THE ESCAPE OF [BIRDALONE

Viridis]170-birdalone took up the word without more ado , and said : [I]0-i will do [my]0-i best herein , and [ye]4384-the three ladies , [sisters]1144-sisters , must set [me]0-i right if [I]0-i err . When [we]4357-we had seen the last of [you]4381-you , dear [Birdalone]170-birdalone , that early morning , [we]4357-we turned back again to [the house]325-the house as speedily and as covertly as [we]4357-we might , lest [the witch]407-the witch might espy [our]4357-we disarray and question [us]4357-we thereover . Then [we]4357-we went to [the wonder - coffer]4388-the wonder - coffer , and gat thereout raiment for that which [we]4357-we had given away , which was easy for [us]4357-we to do , whereas [the witch - mistress]4389-the witch - mistress was so slothful that [she]4389-the witch - mistress had given to [us]4357-we the words of might wherewith to compel [the coffer]4390-the coffer to yield , so that [we]4357-we might do all the service thereof , and [she]4389-the witch - mistress not to move hand or foot in the matter . So when [we]4357-we were clad , and the time was come , [we]4357-we went into [the hall]1202-the hall , by no means well assured of [[our]4357-we mistress]1119-our mistress .

When [we]4357-we came before [her]4389-the witch - mistress , [she]4389-the witch - mistress looked on [us]4357-we in surly wise , as [her]4389-the witch - mistress wo nt was , and said nought for a while ; [she]4389-the witch - mistress stared on [us]4357-we and knit [her]4389-the witch - mistress brows , as if [she]4389-the witch - mistress strove to call to mind something that ran to and fro in [her]4389-the witch - mistress memory ; and [I]0-i noted that , and for [my]0-i part [I]0-i trembled before [her]4389-the witch - mistress . But [she]4389-the witch - mistress spake at last : [Meseemeth]4393-meseemeth as if there is [a woman in [the isle]642-the isle besides [[you]4396-you three]4397-you three]4394-a woman in the isle besides you three ; [some misdoer that [I]0-i was minded to punish]4398-some misdoer that i was minded to punish . Tell [me]0-i , [you]4396-you ! was there not [a naked one who came into [this hall]4111-this hall a while ago , one whom [I]0-i threatened with pining ? [Atra]117-atra , who was the boldest of [us]4401-we]4399-a naked one who came into this hall a while ago , one whom i threatened with pining ? atra , who was the boldest of us , bowed the knee before [her]4389-the witch - mistress , and said : Nay , [[our]4401-we lady]488-our lady , since when do [stranger women]4403-stranger women come naked into [thine hall]4404-thine hall , and dare [thee]4389-the witch - mistress there ?

Said [the witch]407-the witch : Yet have [I]0-i an image of [a naked woman]4406-a naked woman standing down there before [me]0-i ; and if [I]0-i have it in [mine]0-i eye , so should [ye]4396-you . Tell [me]0-i therefore , and beware , for [We]4401-we are not bidden to hold [Our]4401-we hand from [you]4396-you if [We]4401-we take [you]4396-you in misdeeds .

If [I]0-i quaked before , now much more [I]0-i quaked , till [my]0-i legs well - nigh failed [me]0-i for fear ; but [Atra]117-atra said : [Great lady]4407-great lady , this image will belike be of [that one whom a while ago [ye]4396-you had stripped and tied to a pillar here , and tormented while [ye]4396-you feasted]4408-that one whom a while ago ye had stripped and tied to a pillar here , and tormented while ye feasted .

[The lady]1157-the lady looked on [her]1157-the lady hard , and again seemed striving to gather up the thrums of some memory , and then [her]1157-the lady face became smooth again , and [she]1157-the lady spake lightly : All that may well be ; so do [ye]4396-you go about [your]4396-you due service , and trouble [Our]4401-we rest here no longer ; for [We]4401-we love not to look on folk who be not wholly [Our]4401-we own to pine or to spare , to slay or let live , as [We]4401-we will ; and [We]4401-we would that the winds and the waves would send [Us]4401-we some such now ; for it is like to living all alone to have but such as [you]4396-you with [Us]4401-we , and none to cower before [Us]4401-we and entreat [Us]4401-we of mercy . So begone , [I]0-i bid [you]4396-you .

Thus for that time were [we]4401-we saved from [the witch]407-the witch 's cruelty ; but [our]4401-we time came before long . The days wore heavily , nor kept [we]4401-we count of them lest [we]4401-we should lose heart for the weariness of waiting . But on a day as [we]4401-we stood on the steps of [the perron]4332-the perron and served [[my]0-i lady]615-my lady with dainties , of a hot afternoon , came two great white doves a - flying , who pitched down right before [[our]4401-we mistress]1119-our mistress 's feet ; and each had a gold ring about [his]4414-his neck , and a scroll tied thereto , and [the witch]407-the witch bade [us]4401-we take the doves and take off the scrolls and give them unto [her]407-the witch ; and [she]407-the witch looked on the gold rings which the doves bore , and for a moment on the scrolls , and then [she]407-the witch said : Take [ye]4396-you the doves and cherish them , lest [We]4401-we have need of [them]4416-them ; take also the two scrolls and keep them till to - morrow morning , and then give them into [Our]4401-we hands . And look [ye]4396-you to this , that if [ye]4396-you give [them]4416-them not unto [Us]4401-we it will be treason against [Us]4401-we , and [We]4401-we shall have a case against [you]4396-you , and [your]4396-you bodies will be [Ours]4401-we .

Then [she]407-the witch rose up slowly , and bade [me]0-i to [her]407-the witch that [she]407-the witch might lean upon [my]0-i shoulder and be helped [upstairs]4417-upstairs , so slothful a beast as [she]407-the witch was ; and as [we]4401-we went up [I]0-i heard [her]407-the witch say softly to [herself]407-the witch : Weary on it , now must [I]0-i drink a sup of the Water of Might , that [I]0-i may remember and do and desire . But dear is [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister , and without doubt [she]1171-my sister hath matters of import to tell [me]0-i by these doves .

So when [we]4401-we were together alone [I]0-i told [the others]1301-the others hereof , and [we]4401-we talked it over ; and [they]1301-the others deemed the tidings ill , even as [I]0-i did ; for [we]4401-we might not doubt but that the doves were a sending from [the witch- sister who dwelt at [the House under the Wood]2453-the house under the wood]4420-the witch- sister who dwelt at the house under the wood ; and sore [we]4401-we misdoubted that [they]4422-they were sped to [[our]4401-we mistress]1119-our mistress to tell [her]1119-our mistress of [thee]4424-thee , [Birdalone]170-birdalone , and [mayhappen of the Quest]4425-mayhappen of the quest , so wise as [we]4401-we knew [she]1119-our mistress was . As to the two scrolls , forsooth , they were open , and not sealed ; but when [we]4401-we looked on them [we]4401-we could make nought of it ; for though they were writ fairly in Latin script , so that [we]4401-we read them , yet of the words no whit might [we]4401-we understand , so [we]4401-we feared the worst . But what might [we]4401-we do ? [we]4401-we had but two choices , either to cast [ourselves]4401-we into the water , or abide what should befall ; and this last one [we]4401-we chose because of the hope of deliverance .

Next morning , therefore , [we]4401-we came before [[our]4401-we mistress]1119-our mistress in [the hall]1202-the hall , and [we]4401-we found [her]1119-our mistress pacing up and down before the dais ; though [her]1119-our mistress wo nt was at that hour to be sitting in [her]1119-our mistress throne of gold and ivory , lying back on the cushions half asleep .

So [Atra]117-atra went up to [her]1119-our mistress , and knelt before [her]1119-our mistress and gave [her]1119-our mistress the scrolls , and [she]117-atra looked on [her]1119-our mistress grimly , and smiled evilly , and said : Kneel there yet ; and [ye]1119-our mistress [others]2441-others kneel also , till [I]0-i see what befitteth [you]1119-our mistress . So did [we]4401-we , and indeed [I]0-i was fain to kneel , for [I]0-i might scarce stand up for terror ; and all of [us]4401-we , [our]4401-we hearts died within [us]4401-we .

But [the witch]407-the witch read those scrolls to [herself]407-the witch , sitting in [her]407-the witch throne , and spake not a long while ; then [she]407-the witch said : Come hither , and grovel before [Us]4401-we , and hearken ! Even so [we]4401-we did ; and [she]407-the witch said again : [[Our]4401-we sister]2341-our sister , who hath been so kind unto [you]1119-our mistress , and saved [you]1119-our mistress from so many pains , here telleth [Us]4401-we , by the message of the two doves , that [ye]1119-our mistress have betrayed [Us]4401-we and [her]2341-our sister , and have stolen [her]2341-our sister thrall and [her]2341-our sister Sending [Boat]4431-boat , and sent [her]2341-our sister an errand for [Our]4401-we destruction ; and therewith [she]2341-our sister delivereth [you]1119-our mistress into [Our]4401-we hands , and [ye]1119-our mistress are [Ours]4401-we henceforward ; nor is it to be thought that [ye]1119-our mistress may escape [Us]4401-we . Now , for [your]1119-our mistress treason , [some]229-some would slay [you]1119-our mistress outright here and now , but [We]4401-we will be merciful , and let [you]1119-our mistress live , and do no more than chastise [you]1119-our mistress sharply now ; and thereafter shall [ye]1119-our mistress be [Our]4401-we very thralls to do as [We]4401-we will with : thereafter , that is to say , when [they]4433-they whom [ye]1119-our mistress have sent [[Our]4401-we sister]2341-our sister 's thrall to fetch have come hither as belike [I]0-i may scarce stay them , and [I]0-i have foiled them and used them , and sent them away empty . Now [I]0-i tell [you]1119-our mistress , that meanwhile of [their]4433-they coming shall [ye]1119-our mistress suffer such things as [We]4401-we will ; and when [they]4433-they be [here]259-here [We]4401-we will not forbid [you]1119-our mistress to be anigh them ; but [We]4401-we shall see that there will be little joy to [you]1119-our mistress in that nighness . [Yea]4436-yea , [ye]1119-our mistress shall know now to what market [ye]1119-our mistress have brought [your]1119-our mistress wares , and what the price of treason is therein .

Verily then [we]4401-we suffered at [her]2341-our sister hand what [she]2341-our sister would , whereof it would shame [me]0-i to tell more as at this present ; and thereafter did [she]2341-our sister chain [us]4401-we to those three pillars of [the hall]1202-the hall whereas [ye]1119-our mistress found [us]4401-we chained ; and [we]4401-we were fed as dogs be , and served as dogs , but [we]4401-we endured all for the sake of hope ; and when [we]4401-we durst , and deemed [the witch]407-the witch would not hear [us]4401-we , [we]4401-we spake together and enheartened each other .

But on the fourth day of [our]4401-we torment came [the witch]407-the witch to [us]4401-we , and gave [us]4401-we to drink a certain red water from out of a leaden flasket ; and when [I]0-i drank [I]0-i deemed it was poison , and was glad , if gladness might be in [me]0-i at such a tide ; and when [I]0-i had drunk [I]0-i felt an icy chill go through all [my]0-i body , and all things swam before [my]0-i eyes , and deadly sickness came over [me]0-i . But that passed away from [me]0-i presently , and [I]0-i felt helpless and yet not feeble ; all sounds heard [I]0-i clearer than ever yet in [my]0-i life ; also [I]0-i saw [the hall]1202-the hall , every arch and pillar and fret , and the gleam on the pavement from the bright sun that might not enter ; and [the witch]407-the witch [I]0-i saw walking up and down [the hall]1202-the hall by [the dais]1871-the dais ; but [[my]0-i sisters]1124-my sisters [I]0-i saw not when [I]0-i looked across to [their]1124-my sisters pillars . Moreover , [I]0-i might not see [myself]0-i when [I]0-i reached out [my]0-i hand or [my]0-i foot , though [I]0-i saw the chain which made [my]0-i ankle fast to the pillar ; and withal , when [I]0-i set [my]0-i hand on [my]0-i face , or any other part of [my]0-i body , or what else [I]0-i might touch , [I]0-i felt there what [I]0-i looked to feel , were it flesh or linen , or the cold iron of [my]0-i fetter , or the polished face of the marble pillar .

Now [I]0-i knew scarce if [I]0-i were alive or dead , or if [I]0-i were but beginning to be dead ; but there came upon [me]0-i the desire of life , and [I]0-i strove to cry out to [the sisters]4445-the sisters , but though [I]0-i formed the words in [my]0-i mouth , and did with [my]0-i throat as when one cries out aloud , yet no sound of a voice came from [me]0-i , and more helpless did [I]0-i feel than erst .

But even therewith [I]0-i saw [the witch]407-the witch come toward [me]0-i , and therewith all [my]0-i body felt such fear of [her]407-the witch that [I]0-i knew [I]0-i was not dead . Then [she]407-the witch came before [me]0-i and said : [O shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but [them]4448-them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have [I]0-i tidings for [thee]0-i and [[thy]0-i sisters]4449-thy sisters , to wit , that [[your]0-i lovers]1305-your lovers and seekers]4447-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers are at hand ; and presently [I]0-i shall bring [them]4448-them into [this hall]4111-this hall , and [they]4448-them shall be so nigh unto [you]0-i that [ye]0-i might touch [them]4448-them if [I]0-i did not forbid it ; but [they]4448-them shall not see [you]0-i , but shall wonder where [I]0-i have hidden [you]0-i , and shall go seeking [you]0-i to - day and many days , and shall find [you]0-i not at all . So make [ye]0-i the most of the sight of [them]4448-them , for in [them]4448-them henceforward [ye]0-i have no other part or lot .

Therewith [she]0-i spat out at [me]0-i , and went over to [[my]0-i sisters]1124-my sisters , and said words of like import to those which [she]0-i had said unto [me]0-i . And presently [she]0-i went out of [the hall]1202-the hall ; and not long afterwards [I]0-i heard voices speaking on the perron , and knew one for the voice of [the witch]407-the witch , and the other for the voice of [[my]0-i lord]2574-my lord [Baudoin]123-baudoin ; and then again wore a little while , and [I]0-i saw [the witch]407-the witch come through the great door of [the hall]1202-the hall leading [Sir Arthur]157-arthur by the hand , as if [she]407-the witch were [[his]157-arthur dear friend]4458-his dear friend , and [Baudoin]123-baudoin and [Hugh]124-hugh , [[my]0-i man]268-my man , following [them]4460-them . And [the said witch]4231-the said witch was clad full fair , and had laid by [her]4231-the said witch sloth and stupid pride , as meseemed ; and [her]4231-the said witch limbs were grown rounder and sleeker , and [her]4231-the said witch skin fairer , so that to [them]4462-them that knew [her]4231-the said witch not [she]4231-the said witch might well seem to be [a goodly woman]4463-a goodly woman .

Now [they]4462-them sat to meat as [[my]0-i man]268-my man hath told [you]4465-you , and then departed from [the hall]1202-the hall , and [the witch]407-the witch also . But after a while [she]4231-the said witch came back again and loosed [us]4468-we , and grimly bade [us]4468-we go with [her]4231-the said witch , and needs must [we]4468-we , though [we]4468-we could not so much as see [our]4468-we own feet upon the floor . And [she]4231-the said witch set [us]4468-we to tasks about [the house]325-the house , and stood by while [we]4468-we toiled for [her]4231-the said witch , and mocked [us]4468-we not without stripes , and in all ways was as rough and cruel and hard with [us]4468-we as [she]4231-the said witch had been smooth and debonair to [[our]4468-we lords]1971-our lords ; but after noon [she]4231-the said witch brought [us]4468-we back and chained [us]4468-we to [our]4468-we pillars again . And when the evening came and the banquet was , it was [we]4468-we who were [the unseen players of the string - play]4471-the unseen players of the string - play ; and [we]4468-we might play no other melody than what [the witch]407-the witch bade [us]4468-we ; else belike , could [we]4468-we have held converse , [we]4468-we might have played such tunes as would have smitten the hearts of [[our]4468-we loves]4473-our loves , and told [them]4473-our loves that [we]4468-we were anigh . To make a short story of it , thus did [she]4231-the said witch day by day , and no comfort or converse might [we]4468-we [sisters]1144-sisters have of [each other]580-each other , or of aught else save the sight of [[our]4468-we beloved ones]4476-our beloved ones , and a glimmer of hope therewith . And , forsooth , for as grievously as [my]0-i heart was wrung by the yearning of [me]0-i for [my]0-i love , yet was it a joy unto [me]0-i to think that [he]4477-he went there desiring [me]0-i , and that whom [he]4477-he desired was not [the poor wretched creature chained there in [her]4231-the said witch nakedness , with [her]4231-the said witch body spoiled by torment and misery]4478-the poor wretched creature chained there in her nakedness , with her body spoiled by torment and misery , but [the glad maiden whom [he]4477-he had so often called fair and lovesome]4479-the glad maiden whom he had so often called fair and lovesome .

So passed the days , and at last hope had grown so pale and wan , that [she]4231-the said witch was no more to be seen by [us]4468-we than [we]4468-we were by [[our]4468-we lords]1971-our lords ; and now it seemed to [me]0-i that death was coming , so feeble and wretched as [I]0-i grew . But [the witch]407-the witch would not let [us]4468-we die , but sustained [us]4468-we from time to time with some little draughts of a witch - drink that revived [us]4468-we .

So wore the time till that evening , when came hope together with the fulfilment of hope , so that one minute [we]4468-we durst hope for deliverance , and the next [we]4468-we were delivered .

Nor is there more to tell , [Birdalone]170-birdalone , [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear , save that [we]4468-we came safely to [the Isle of [the Young]1670-the young]1669-the isle of the young and the Old in the full morning - tide ; and as [[our]4468-we ferry]3967-our ferry drew nigh [the green shore]1940-the green shore , there were [the two younglings]4487-the two younglings whereof [thou]4488-thou didst tell [us]4468-we awaiting [our]4468-we landing , and when [we]4468-we stepped [ashore]4489-ashore [they]4487-the two younglings came to [us]4468-we bearing cakes and fruit in a fair basket , and [they]4487-the two younglings made much of [us]4468-we and [we]4468-we of [them]4487-the two younglings . And so [we]4468-we came to [the old man]7080-the old man , who was exceeding fain of [us]4468-we , and grand and courteous , till [he]7080-the old man became [a little drunk]4491-a little drunk , and then [he]7080-the old man was somewhat over - kind to [[us]4468-we women]4492-us women . Nevertheless , there in [that pleasant isle]4493-that pleasant isle [we]4468-we rested [us]4468-we for three days , that [we]4468-we might somewhat calm and refresh [our]4468-we spirits with what was small and of little account . And when [we]4468-we departed , [the old man]7080-the old man followed [us]4468-we down to [the strand]660-the strand , and lamented [our]4468-we departure , as [he]7080-the old man had done with [[our]4468-we lords]1971-our lords erewhile ; only this time yet greater was [his]7080-the old man lamentation , and needs must [we]4468-we kiss [him]7080-the old man , [each one of [us]4468-we]4497-each one of us , or never had [he]7080-the old man been done . So [he]7080-the old man turned up landward , bewailing [the miss of [us]4468-we]4498-the miss of us , but presently , before [we]4468-we had seen the last of [him]7080-the old man , was cheerful again and singing .

So [we]4468-we went on [our]4468-we way ; and [we]4468-we also , [[we]4468-we maidens]4499-we maidens , in [our]4468-we turn , saw those woeful images of [the Isle of Queens]58-the isle of queens and [the Isle of Kings]2472-the isle of kings ; and [we]4468-we came to [the Isle of Nothing]41-the isle of nothing , and abode warily by [[our]4468-we ferry]3967-our ferry , and so came away safe , and thus , as [thou]4502-thou wottest , [home]387-home to [the castle]1838-the castle to hear evil tidings of [thee]4505-thee . Now is this all [my]0-i tale .

[Birdalone]170-birdalone sat shyly and hushed when all was done ; and then all [they]4506-they did somewhat to comfort [her]170-birdalone , each after [their]4506-they own fashion ; and now sorrow for [the slain man]3840-the slain man was made softer and sweeter for [them]4506-they , whereas [they]4506-they had to lose not [two fellows]4508-two fellows , but one only . Yet , despite of all , trouble and care was on [Birdalone]170-birdalone 's soul betwixt the joy of loving and being beloved , and the pain and fear of robbing [a friend]520-a friend of [her]170-birdalone love . For [Atra]117-atra 's face , which [she]117-atra might not hate , and scarce might love , was a threat to [her]117-atra day by day .

CHAPTER XI . [BIRDALONE]170-birdalone AND [THE BLACK SQUIRE]125-arthur TALK TOGETHER IN [THE HALL OF THE CASTLE]4510-the hall of the castle .

Now within a few days was the body of [Baudoin]123-baudoin laid in earth in [the chapel of [the castle]1838-the castle]4511-the chapel of the castle ; and in the solemnest of fashions was the burial done . When it was over , [the two knights]4513-the two knights and [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris turned [them]4506-they heartily to dighting the war against the Red Hold , and less than a month thereafter was the hosting at [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]59-the castle of the quest , and if [the host]4514-the host were not very many for it went not above sixteen [hundreds of men]4515-hundreds of men all told , yet [the men]2426-the men were of the choicest , both of [knights]3601-knights and [sergeants and archers]4518-sergeants and archers . [There]232-there then [they]2426-the men held a mote without [the castle]1838-the castle , whereas [Arthur]125-arthur [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire was chosen for [captain]3358-captain , and in three days [they]2426-the men were to depart for [the Red Hold]49-the red hold .

Now this while [Birdalone]170-birdalone had seen but little of [Arthur]125-arthur , who was ever busy about many matters , and never had [she]170-birdalone had any privy talk with [him]125-arthur , though sore [she]170-birdalone longed for it ; yet indeed it was more by [her]170-birdalone will than [his]125-arthur that so it was . But when it was come to the very last day before the departure , [she]170-birdalone said that [she]170-birdalone must needs see [him]125-arthur before [he]125-arthur went , and [he]125-arthur perchance never to come back again . So when [men]219-men were quiet after dinner [she]170-birdalone went into [the hall]1202-the hall and found [him]125-arthur there , pacing up and down the floor . For indeed [she]170-birdalone had sent a word to [him]125-arthur by [[Leonard]145-birdalone [the priest]1984-the priest]4525-leonard the priest that [he]125-arthur should be [there]232-there .

So [she]170-birdalone went up to [him]125-arthur , and all simply [she]170-birdalone took [him]125-arthur by the hand and led [him]125-arthur into a shot - window and set [him]125-arthur down by [her]170-birdalone ; and [he]125-arthur , all trembling for love and fear of [her]170-birdalone , might not forbear , but kissed [her]170-birdalone face and [her]170-birdalone mouth many times ; and [she]170-birdalone grew as hot as fire , and somewhat [she]170-birdalone wept .

Then [she]170-birdalone spake after a while : [Dear friend]1232-dear friend , [I]0-i had it in [my]0-i mind to say to [thee]1232-dear friend many things that [meseems]4529-meseems were sage , but now neither will the thought of them come into [my]0-i mind , nor the words into [my]0-i mouth . And this is a short hour . And therewith [she]170-birdalone fell to kissing [him]125-arthur , till [he]125-arthur was well - nigh beside [himself]125-arthur betwixt desire and joy and the grief of departure , and the hardness of the case .

But at last [she]170-birdalone forbore and said : Will it not be when [thou]4530-thou art gone to - morrow as it was when [ye]1232-dear friend were away upon the Quest , and [I]0-i knew not how to bear [myself]0-i , so heavy lay all [the world]430-the world and its doings and its fashion upon [me]0-i ? It will be hard to [me]0-i , [he]125-arthur said ; evil and grim will be the days . [She]170-birdalone said : And yet , even now in these last days , when [I]0-i see [thee]125-arthur oft , every day [my]0-i soul is worn with grief , and [I]0-i know not what to do with [myself]0-i . [I]0-i shall come back , [he]125-arthur said , and bear [my]0-i love with [me]0-i , and then belike [we]4532-we shall seek some remedy . [She]170-birdalone was silent a while , and then [she]170-birdalone said : Meanwhile of [thy]125-arthur coming , and [I]0-i see [thee]125-arthur not at all for many days , how will it be with [my]0-i grief then ? Quoth [he]125-arthur : More than enough of grief [no soul]4533-no soul may bear ; for either death comes , or else some dullness of the pain , and then by little and little the pain weareth . Then [she]170-birdalone said : And how would it be if [thou]125-arthur come not back and [I]0-i see [thee]125-arthur never again , or if when [thou]125-arthur come back [thou]125-arthur find [me]0-i not , for that [I]0-i be either dead or gone away out of [thy]125-arthur reach ? [He]125-arthur said : [I]0-i know not how it would be . When [thou]125-arthur sayest [thou]125-arthur shalt die , dost [thou]125-arthur wholly believe it in [thy]125-arthur sense or [thy]125-arthur body otherwise than [Holy Church]171-holy church would ? [I]0-i will tell [thee]125-arthur , [she]170-birdalone said , that now [I]0-i am sitting by [thee]125-arthur and seeing [thy]125-arthur face and hearing [thy]125-arthur voice , it is that only which [I]0-i believe in ; for [I]0-i may think of nought else of either grief or joy . Yea , when [I]0-i wept e'en now , it was not for sorrow that [I]0-i wept , but for [I]0-i can not rightly tell what . And [she]170-birdalone took [his]125-arthur hand and looked fondly upon [him]125-arthur .

But presently [she]170-birdalone looked on [his]125-arthur hand , and said : And now [meseemeth]4534-meseemeth that [we]4535-we twain are grown to be such [close friends]4536-close friends that [I]0-i may ask [thee]125-arthur what [I]0-i will , and [thou]125-arthur be neither angry , nor wonder thereat . [I]0-i see on [thy]125-arthur finger here the ring that [I]0-i brought with [me]0-i from [the Isle of [Increase]25-increase]1601-the isle of increase , and which thereafter [thou]125-arthur hadst of [me]0-i when [I]0-i gave [thee]125-arthur back also the shoon which were lent unto [me]0-i . Tell [me]0-i how [thou]125-arthur hadst it back from [Atra]117-atra , as [I]0-i suppose [thou]125-arthur gavest it unto [her]117-atra . But how now art [thou]125-arthur angry ? for [I]0-i see the blood come up in [thy]125-arthur face . Nay , [beloved]4538-beloved , said [he]125-arthur , [I]0-i am not angry , but whenso [I]0-i hear of [Atra]117-atra , or think of [her]117-atra closely , shame comes on [me]0-i and confusion , and maybe fear . But now will [I]0-i answer [thee]125-arthur . For even in those hours which [we]4539-us wore on [the Isle of [the Young and the Old]2476-the young and the old]2475-the isle of the young and the old , when all [we]4539-us should have been so happy together , [she]117-atra divined somewhat of [my]0-i case , or indeed , why do [I]0-i not say it out , all thereof . And [she]117-atra spake to [me]0-i such words for [she]117-atra is both tender and wise and strong of heart that [I]0-i cowered before [her]117-atra and [her]117-atra grief and pain ; and [she]117-atra gave [me]0-i back the said ring , which forsooth [I]0-i gave to [her]117-atra in the Sending Boat in the first hour that [the Isle of [Increase]25-increase]1601-the isle of increase lay astern of [us]4539-us . And [I]0-i wear it now as a token of [my]0-i grief for [her]117-atra grief . See now , love , since [I]0-i have answered [thee]117-atra this question without anger or amaze , [thou]117-atra needest not fear to ask [me]0-i any other ; for this of all things lies closest to [my]0-i heart .

[Birdalone]145-birdalone drooped [her]117-atra head , and [she]117-atra spake in a low voice : Lo now ! the shadow of parting and the shadow of death could not come between [our]4539-us present joy ; but this shadow of [the third one]4543-the third one cometh between [us]4539-us and is present between [us]4539-us . Woe 's [me]0-i ! how little did [I]0-i think of this when [thou]117-atra wert away and [I]0-i was sick of longing for the sight of [thee]117-atra , and deemed that that would heal it all .

[He]4544-he spake not , but took [her]117-atra hand and held it ; and presently [she]117-atra looked up again and said : [Thou]117-atra art good , and wilt not be angry if [I]0-i ask [thee]4544-he something else ; this it is : Why wert [thou]117-atra so grim with [me]0-i that other day when [ye]117-atra found [me]0-i in that evil plight in tow of [the Red Tyrant]4545-the red tyrant , so that [I]0-i deemed that [thou]117-atra of all others hadst cast [me]0-i off ? That was worse to [me]0-i than [the witch]407-the witch 's stripes , and [I]0-i kept thinking to [myself]0-i : How simple was [my]0-i trouble once , and now how tangled and weary !

Then [he]4544-he might not refrain [him]4544-he , but threw [himself]4544-he upon [her]117-atra , and clipped [her]117-atra and kissed [her]117-atra all [he]4544-he might , and [she]117-atra felt all the sweetness of love , and lacked nought of kindness and love to [him]4544-he . And thereafter [they]4547-they sat still awhile , and [he]4544-he said , as if [her]117-atra question had but that moment left [her]117-atra lips : This , forsooth , was the cause that [I]0-i looked grim on [thee]117-atra : first , that from the time [I]0-i first saw [thee]117-atra and heard [thy]117-atra tale , and of [thy]117-atra deeds , [I]0-i had deemed [thee]117-atra wise above the wisdom of [women]433-women . But this going forth of [thee]117-atra to [the Black Valley]2966-the black valley , whereof came the slaying of [Baudoin]123-baudoin , seemed unto [me]0-i a mere folly , till again [I]0-i had heard [thy]117-atra tale of that also ; and then the tale and [thy]117-atra speech overcame [me]0-i . But again , though [I]0-i was grieved and disappointed hereat , belike that had passed from [me]0-i speedily , but then there was this also which would not let [my]0-i soul rest , to wit , that [I]0-i feared concerning [that slain knight whose head the Red One]4550-that slain knight whose head the red one had hung about [thy]117-atra neck ; for how else , methought , might [he]4550-that slain knight whose head the red one have been so wroth with [him]4550-that slain knight whose head the red one and [thee]117-atra ; and meseemed , moreover , that [thou]4551-thou wert kind in [thine]4552-thine heart to [the dead man]3585-the dead man , even when [we]4554-we were come to [thee]117-atra ; and then , seest [thou]117-atra , [my]0-i desire for [thee]117-atra and the trouble of [Baudoin]123-baudoin 's slaying , and the black trouble aforesaid . [Lo]128-lo now , [I]0-i have told [thee]117-atra this . When wilt [thou]4551-thou cease to be angry with [me]0-i ?

[She]0-i said : [I]0-i ceased to be grieved with thine anger when thine anger died ; yet strange , meseemeth , that [thou]4551-thou shouldst trust [me]0-i so little when [thou]4551-thou lovest [me]0-i so much !

And [she]0-i leaned against [him]3585-the dead man and caressed [him]3585-the dead man gently , and again was [he]3585-the dead man at point to take [her]0-i in [his]3585-the dead man arms , when lo ! the sound of [men]219-men coming unto the screen of [the hall]1202-the hall ; so then [those two]2209-those two stood up and went to meet [them]2209-those two , and there was the speech of [their]2209-those two sundering done . Yet belike for a little while [both those twain]4558-both those twain were happy .

CHAPTER XII . [THE KNIGHTS]4559-the knights AND [THEIR]4559-the knights FELLOWS BETAKE [THEM]4559-the knights TO THE ASSAULTING OF THE RED HOLD

On the morrow , when the day was yet young , [the knights]4559-the knights were ready for departure , and in the very gate [they]4559-the knights bade farewell to [the ladies]2309-the ladies , who kissed [them]4559-the knights kindly one and all , and [Viridis]170-birdalone wept sore ; and [Atra]117-atra constrained [herself]117-atra to do even as [the others]1301-the others did ; but pale [she]117-atra was and quaking when [she]117-atra kissed [Arthur]125-arthur and watched [him]125-arthur get a - horseback .

But [the knights]4559-the knights bade [[their]4559-the knights ladies]4564-their ladies be of good cheer , for that [they]4559-the knights would send [them]4564-their ladies tidings of how [they]4564-their ladies sped every seven days at least , whereas it was no long way thence to [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold , save there were battle on [the road]2103-the road , and [they]4559-the knights deemed [their]4559-the knights host which should beset [the Hold]61-the hold would be enough to clear all the ways behind [it]61-the hold . For that same cause withal [they]4559-the knights had [Sir Aymeris]138-sir aymeris with [them]4559-the knights , nor left a many men behind [them]4559-the knights , and [they]4559-the knights under the rule of [three squires]4567-three squires , whereof [two were but young]4568-two were but young , and [the third]4569-the third , who was made [the captain of [the castle]1838-the castle]4570-the captain of the castle , was [an old and wise man of war]4572-an old and wise man of war , who had to name [Geoffrey of Lea]172-sir geoffrey of lea . There , [withal]114-withal , was [the priest Sir Leonard , who went about now much hushed and abashed , and seemed to fear to give a word to [Birdalone]145-birdalone]145-birdalone ; albeit [she]4573-she deemed of [him]145-birdalone that [his]145-birdalone thoughts of [her]4573-she were the same as erst they had been .

So now when [the knights]4559-the knights were departed , and [all the host]4575-all the host was gone out of sight , it was heavy time indeed in [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest till [they]4577-they should hear tidings of [them]4559-the knights again . Both [Aurea]116-viridis and [Atra]117-atra kept much to [themselves]4578-they , and did [I]0-i know not what to wear away the time ; for now it was not to be looked for that [they]4578-they should venture out - a- gates . But as for [Viridis]116-viridis , [she]116-viridis waxed of better cheer after a while , but whatever betid [she]116-viridis would not sunder [herself]116-viridis from [Birdalone]145-birdalone ; nay , not for an hour ; and [Birdalone]145-birdalone took all [her]116-viridis kindness kindly , though forsooth it was somewhat of a pain unto [her]116-viridis ; it shall be told wherefore ere long .

[Withal]114-withal , as if to wear the time , [Birdalone]145-birdalone betook [her]116-viridis diligently to [her]116-viridis needlework , and fell to the cunningest of broidery ; so that [Viridis]116-viridis and [the others]1301-the others wondered at [her]116-viridis , for when [they]4578-they were done it seemed indeed that the flowers and creatures and knots had grown of [themselves]4578-they upon the cloth , such wondrous work it was .

Moreover , to [his]145-birdalone great joy , the very first day of the departure of [the host]4514-the host [she]116-viridis called [Sir Leonard]145-birdalone unto [her]116-viridis , and prayed to go on again with the learning [[her]116-viridis fair scribe]4581-her fair scribe - craft ; and therein also was [she]116-viridis diligent hours of every day ; and [Viridis]116-viridis would sit beside [her]116-viridis wondering at the deftness of [her]116-viridis fingers , and crying out for joy as the page grew fair and well - learned under [them]4578-they .

Thus wore a week , and at the end thereof came a messenger from [the host]4514-the host and told how [they]4578-they had come before [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold and had summoned [them]4578-they thereof to yield , which [they]4578-they had utterly denied to do , but defied [the host]4514-the host ; wherefore [the host]4514-the host had now beset the Hold , and [more folk]4586-more folk were daily flocking unto [them]4578-they ; but that [the said Hold]3542-the said hold would be hard to win by plain assault , whereas [it]3542-the said hold was both strong and well- manned ; but [few of [the host]4514-the host]4588-few of the host had been slain or hurt as yet , and of [the chieftains]4590-the chieftains not one .

Right glad were [they]4578-they of [the castle]1838-the castle because of these tidings ; though , forsooth , [the men - at - arms]2679-the men - at - arms knew well enough that the time would soon come when some fierce assault would be made , and then , forsooth , would be sore peril of life and limb unto [the chieftains]4590-the chieftains .

CHAPTER XIII . [BIRDALONE BETHINKS]145-birdalone [HER]4594-her TO FULFIL THE PROMISE MADE UNTO [ATRA]117-atra

Again wore a week , and once more came [the messenger]4595-the messenger , and did [them]4578-they of [the castle]1838-the castle to wit that there had been nought more done at [the Red Hold]49-the red hold , save skirmishing at the barriers , wherein [few were hurt on either side]4597-few were hurt on either side ; and also that the engines for battering the walls were now well - nigh all dight , and [they]4578-they would begin to play upon the Hold , and in especial one which hight Wall - wolf , which had been set up by [the crafts of [Greenford]45-greenford]4598-the crafts of greenford .

This tidings also was deemed good by all , save it might be by [Atra]117-atra , who , as [Birdalone]145-birdalone deemed , pined and fretted [herself]4594-her at the delay , and would fain that , one way or other , all were over . [Atra]117-atra spake but little to [Birdalone]145-birdalone , but watched [her]117-atra closely now ; oft would [she]117-atra gaze on [her]117-atra wistfully , as if [she]117-atra would that [Birdalone]145-birdalone would speak unto [her]117-atra ; and [Birdalone]145-birdalone noted that , but [she]117-atra might not pluck up heart thereto .

Wore a third week , and again came [the messenger]4595-the messenger , and told how three days ago , whenas [Wall - wolf]173-wall - wolf had sorely battered one of [the great towers which hight [the Poison - jar]4601-the poison - jar]4600-the great towers which hight the poison - jar , and overthrown a pan of the wall there beside , [they]4578-they had tried an assault on the breach , and hard had been the battle there , and in the end , after fierce give and take , [they]4578-they of the Hold had done so valiantly that [they]4578-they had thrust back [the assailants]4602-the assailants , and that in the hottest brunt [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire had been hurt in the shoulder by a spear - thrust , but not very grievously ; but withal that [he]1334-the black squire sent , in so many words , forbidding [the ladies]2309-the ladies to make any account of so small a matter . And , quoth [the sergeant]3491-the sergeant , most like [[my]0-i lord]2574-my lord will wear [his]3491-the sergeant armour in four days ' time ; also now [we]4578-they have reared another great slinger , which [we]4578-they call [Stone]174-stone - fretter , and soon , without doubt , [we]4578-they shall be standing victorious within [that den of [thieves]7144-thieves]7143-that den of thieves .[1334-the black squire]

Now though these tidings were not so altogether ill , yet were [those ladies]1806-those ladies sore troubled thereby , and especially [Atra]117-atra , who swooned outright when [she]117-atra had heard the last word thereof .

As for [Birdalone]145-birdalone , [she]117-atra made as little semblance of [her]117-atra trouble as [she]117-atra might , but when all was quiet again [she]117-atra went to find [Viridis]116-viridis , and brought [her]116-viridis to [[her]116-viridis chamber]2512-her chamber and spake to [her]116-viridis , saying : [Viridis]116-viridis , [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister , [thou]4610-thou hast been piteous kind unto [me]0-i from the first minute that [thou]4610-thou sawest [me]0-i naked and helpless , and fleeing from evil unto worse evil ; nowise mightest [thou]4610-thou have done better by [me]0-i hadst [thou]4610-thou been verily [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister of blood ; and [I]0-i know it that [thou]4610-thou wouldst be loth to part from [me]0-i .

[Viridis]116-viridis wept and said : Why dost [thou]4610-thou speak of parting from [me]0-i , when [thou]4610-thou knowest it would break [my]0-i heart ?

Said [Birdalone]145-birdalone : To say it as short as may be , because the parting must now come to pass . [Viridis]116-viridis waxed pale and then red , and [she]116-viridis stamped [her]116-viridis foot and said : It is unkind of [thee]4610-thou to grieve [me]0-i thus , and [thou]4610-thou doest wrong herein .

Hearken , [dear sister]791-dear sister , said [Birdalone]145-birdalone : [thou]4610-thou knowest , for [thou]4610-thou [thyself]4610-thou wast the first to tell [me]0-i thereof , that [I]0-i am the supplanter in [our]4613-our fellowship , and that [I]0-i have undone [Atra]117-atra 's hope . This [I]0-i did not of [mine]0-i own will , but it came unto [me]0-i ; yet of [mine]0-i own will [I]0-i can do the best [I]0-i may to amend it ; and this is the best , that [I]0-i depart hence before the Red Hold is taken and [[my]0-i lords]2037-my lords come back ; for if [they]2037-my lords come back and [I]0-i see [[my]0-i lord]2574-my lord [Arthur]125-arthur , so fair and beauteous as [he]125-arthur is , before [me]0-i , never shall [I]0-i be able to go away from [him]125-arthur . And lo [thou]4616-he , [I]0-i have promised [Atra]117-atra by all the kindness [she]117-atra did [me]0-i when [we]4617-we were come to [the Wailing Tower]20-the wailing - tower , and [I]0-i naked and quaking and half - dead with terror , that if occasion served [I]0-i would do [my]0-i utmost to help [her]117-atra , even if it were to [my]0-i own grief . Now behold this that now is , is the occasion , and there will not be another ; for when [my]0-i love comes home hither and beholdeth [me]0-i , think [thou]4616-he how all the desire which has been gathering in [his]4616-he heart this while will blossom and break forth toward [me]0-i ; and mayhappen [he]4616-he will make but little semblance of it before [other folk]346-other folk , for proud and high of heart is [he]4616-he ; but [he]4616-he will seek occasion to find [me]0-i alone , and then shall [I]0-i be with [him]4616-he as the lark in the talons of the sparrow - hawk , and [he]4616-he will do [his]4616-he pleasure of [me]0-i , and that with all the good - will of [my]0-i heart . And then shall [I]0-i be forsworn to [Atra]117-atra , and [she]117-atra will hate [me]0-i , as now [she]117-atra doth not , and then is all the fellowship riven , and that by [my]0-i deed .

Yet was [Viridis]116-viridis wrath , and [she]116-viridis said : Meseemeth this is [fool]4619-fool 's talk . Will not the fellowship be all the more riven if [thou]4620-thou depart and [we]4621-we see [thee]4620-thou no more ?

O nay , said [Birdalone]145-birdalone ; for when [I]0-i am gone [thy]4620-thou love shall be no less for [me]0-i , though as now [thou]4620-thou art angry ; and [Atra]117-atra will love [me]0-i for that [I]0-i shall have held to [my]0-i promise to [mine]0-i own scathe ; and [[thy]4620-thou man]4622-thy man and [Aurea]116-viridis will lay it to [me]0-i that [I]0-i have done valiantly and knightly . And [Arthur]125-arthur , how can [he]125-arthur choose but love [me]0-i ; and maybe [we]4621-we shall yet meet again .

And therewithal [she]0-i did at last bow down [her]0-i head and fall to weeping , and [Viridis]116-viridis was moved by [her]0-i tears and fell to kissing and caressing [her]0-i .

After a little [Birdalone]145-birdalone lifted up [her]0-i head and spake again : Moreover , how can [I]0-i dare to abide [him]125-arthur ? didst [thou]4623-thou not see how grim [he]125-arthur was to [me]0-i when [they]4624-they delivered [me]0-i and brought [me]0-i back ? and [he]125-arthur with [his]125-arthur own lips told [me]0-i so much , that it was because [he]125-arthur doubted that [I]0-i had done amiss ; and now if [I]0-i do amiss again , even if it be at [his]125-arthur bidding , will it not be so that [he]125-arthur will speedily weary of [me]0-i , and curse [me]0-i and cast [me]0-i off ? What sayest [thou]4623-thou , [Viridis]116-viridis [mine]116-viridis ?

What is to say , said [Viridis]116-viridis , save that [thou]4623-thou hast broken [my]0-i heart ? But [thou]4623-thou mayst heal it if [thou]4623-thou wilt take [thy]4623-thou words back , and tell [me]0-i that [thou]4623-thou wilt not sunder [thee]4623-thou from [us]4625-us .

But [Birdalone]145-birdalone brake out weeping and lamenting aloud , and [she]116-viridis cried out : Nay , nay , it may not be ; [I]0-i must depart , and [Atra]117-atra hath smitten [me]0-i amidst of [[my]0-i friends]2100-my friends . And [Viridis]116-viridis knew not what to say or to do .

At last came [Birdalone]145-birdalone to [herself]145-birdalone again , and [she]116-viridis looked sweetly on [Viridis]116-viridis and smiled on [her]116-viridis from out [her]116-viridis tears , and said : [Thou]4623-thou seest , [sister]783-sister , how little a loss [thou]4623-thou wilt have of [me]0-i , [a mere wild woman]4628-a mere wild woman . And now nought availeth either [me]0-i or [thee]4623-thou but [I]0-i must begone , and that speedily . Let it be to - morrow then . And when [the messenger]4595-the messenger comes at the end of this week , send word by [him]4595-the messenger of what [I]0-i have done ; and look [thou]4623-thou to it but [both [our]4631-our lords]4630-both our lords will praise [me]0-i for the deed .

Said [Viridis]116-viridis : But whither wilt [thou]4623-thou , or what wilt [thou]4623-thou do ? To [Greenford]45-greenford first , said [Birdalone]145-birdalone , and after [whither]4632-whither [the Good Lord]175-the good lord shall lead [me]0-i ; and as for what [I]0-i will do , [I]0-i am now deft in two crafts , script and broidery to wit ; and , wheresoever [I]0-i be , [folk]1529-folk shall pay [me]0-i to work herein for [them]1529-folk , whereby [I]0-i shall earn [my]0-i bread . [Hearken]176-hearken also , [[my]0-i sister]1171-my sister , canst [thou]4623-thou give [me]0-i any deal of money ? for though [I]0-i wot little of such matters , yet [I]0-i wot that [I]0-i shall need the same . And [I]0-i ask this whereas , as [e'en]4635-e'en now [I]0-i said , [I]0-i deem [[our]4636-our lords]1971-our lords shall praise [my]0-i deed , and that , therefore , [they]1971-our lords would not that [I]0-i should depart hence as [an outcast]752-an outcast , wherefore [they]1971-our lords shall not begrudge it to [me]0-i . Moreover , for the same cause [I]0-i would [thee]4639-thee speak to [the old squire [Geoffrey of Lea]172-sir geoffrey of lea]4640-the old squire geoffrey of lea , and tell [him]4640-the old squire geoffrey of lea that [I]0-i have an errand to [Greenford]45-greenford , and crave of [him]4640-the old squire geoffrey of lea that [he]4640-the old squire geoffrey of lea lend [me]0-i one of [the two younglings]4487-the two younglings , [Arnold]177-arnold or Anselm , and [two or three men - at - arms]4642-two or three men - at - arms to bring [me]0-i safely thither ; since now , forsooth , [I]0-i need no more adventures on [the road]2103-the road .

[She]0-i smiled as [she]0-i spake ; and now all the passion of anguish seemed to have left [her]0-i for that while ; but [Viridis]116-viridis cast [her]116-viridis arms about [her]116-viridis neck and wept upon [her]116-viridis bosom , and said : Woe 's [me]0-i ! for [I]0-i see that [thou]4644-thou wilt go whatsoever [I]0-i may say or do ; [I]0-i strove to be angry with [thee]4644-thou , but [I]0-i might not , and now [I]0-i see that [thou]4644-thou constrainest [me]0-i as [thou]4644-thou dost all else . [I]0-i will go now straightway and do thine errand .

Thus then [they]4645-they parted for that time ; but it was not till the day after the morrow that [Birdalone]145-birdalone was alboun . [Viridis]116-viridis told of [her]0-i departure both to [Aurea]116-viridis and [Atra]117-atra ; and [Aurea]116-viridis lamented it , but would not do aught to stay [her]116-viridis ; for [she]116-viridis was waxen weary and listless since the death of [[her]116-viridis man]3698-her man . As for [Atra]117-atra , [she]116-viridis spake but little concerning it , but to [Viridis]116-viridis praised [Birdalone]145-birdalone 's valiance and kindness . Yet unto [herself]116-viridis [she]116-viridis said : Verily [she]117-atra understood [my]0-i word that [I]0-i spake to [her]117-atra about the occasion of [her]117-atra helping . Yet woe 's [me]0-i ! for [she]117-atra shall carry [his]3698-her man love with [her]117-atra whithersoever [she]117-atra wendeth ; and [a happy woman]3910-a happy woman is [she]3910-a happy woman .

But when [Geoffrey]172-sir geoffrey of lea [the squire]3482-the squire knew that [the ladies , all three]4649-the ladies , all three , were at one with [Birdalone]145-birdalone as to [her]117-atra departure , [he]172-sir geoffrey of lea doubted nothing , but bade [Arnold]177-arnold , [[his]172-sir geoffrey of lea mate]4650-his mate , take [four good men]4651-four good men with [him]172-sir geoffrey of lea , and bring [the Lady [Birdalone]155-birdalone unto [Greenford]45-greenford]155-birdalone and do [her]155-birdalone bidding there . [Albeit]178-albeit , [he]172-sir geoffrey of lea deemed no less but [they]4651-four good men would bring [her]117-atra back again .

CHAPTER XIV . [BIRDALONE]155-birdalone LEAVES THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST

On the morrow morn , then , [Birdalone]155-birdalone spake farewell both to [Aurea]116-viridis and [Atra]117-atra ; but as for [Viridis]116-viridis , [she]116-viridis sent [her]116-viridis word that [she]116-viridis had no heart thereto , and yet [she]116-viridis sent [her]116-viridis a word of comfort , to wit , that [she]116-viridis deemed that [they]4652-they would one day meet again . [Aurea]116-viridis , in [her]116-viridis parting words , part praised [her]116-viridis , part chid [her]116-viridis ; saying that [she]116-viridis did well and kindly and valiantly , as [her]116-viridis wo nt was . Yet , said [she]116-viridis , when all is said , [thou]4653-thy mightest have abided this tangle and trouble , which at the worst had not been so evil as death between [us]4654-us . Yea , [sister]783-sister , said [Birdalone]155-birdalone , but might not death have come of [my]0-i abiding ?

As [she]116-viridis spake , in came [Atra]117-atra , with [her]117-atra head somewhat drooped , meek and humble , [her]117-atra cheeks red , [her]117-atra hands trembling ; and [she]117-atra said : Wilt [thou]4653-thy take now [my]0-i word of farewell and blessing , and the kiss of peace betwixt [us]4654-us , and bear away the memory of [our]4654-us kindness together ?

[Birdalone]155-birdalone stood up proud and straight , and was somewhat pale as [she]155-birdalone suffered [Atra]117-atra to kiss [her]155-birdalone cheeks and mouth , and said : Now hast [thou]4653-thy forgiven [me]0-i that weird dragged [me]0-i in betwixt [thy]4653-thy love and [thy]4653-thy goodhap ; and [I]0-i have forgiven [thee]4653-thy that [I]0-i am led away by weird into [the waste]4656-the waste and [the wilderness of love]4657-the wilderness of love . Farewell . Therewith [she]155-birdalone went [her]155-birdalone way to the gate , and [the others]1301-the others followed [her]155-birdalone not .

Without abode [her]155-birdalone [Arnold]177-arnold and [the four men - at - arms]4659-the four men - at - arms , and [her]155-birdalone palfrey and a sumpter - horse bearing two goodly coffers , wherein [Viridis]116-viridis had let load raiment and other havings for [her]155-birdalone ; and [Arnold]177-arnold came up to [her]155-birdalone smiling , and said : [[My]0-i lady]615-my lady [Viridis]116-viridis hath given [me]0-i a pouch wherein is money to bear for [thee]4653-thy to [Greenford]45-greenford and hand over to [thee]4653-thy there when [we]4661-they be safe ; and [she]116-viridis hath bidden [me]0-i to be in all wise obedient unto [thee]4653-thy , [lady]504-lady , which needed not , whereas now and from hence forth am [I]0-i by [mine]0-i own will [[thy]4653-thy very servant]4663-thy very servant to do [thy]4653-thy pleasure always and everywhere .

[She]155-birdalone thanked [him]177-arnold and smiled on [him]177-arnold kindly , so that [his]177-arnold heart beat fast for joy and love of [her]155-birdalone ; and therewith [she]155-birdalone gat into the saddle and [they]4661-they rode [their]4661-they ways together , and [Birdalone]155-birdalone looked back never till [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest was shut from [their]4661-they eyes by [the nesses of [the little hills]4666-the little hills]4665-the nesses of the little hills .

Here ends the Fifth Part of [the Water of [the Wondrous Isles]1-the wondrous isles]1065-the water of the wondrous isles , which is called The Tale of [the Quest]31-the quest 's Ending , and begins the Sixth Part of the said tale , which is called The Days of Absence .

THE SIXTH PART : [THE DAYS OF ABSENCE]63-the days of absence

CHAPTER I. [BIRDALONE]155-birdalone RIDES TO [GREENFORD]45-greenford AND THERE TAKES LEAVE OF [ARNOLD]177-arnold AND [HIS]177-arnold MEN

On [the road]2103-the road to [Greenford]45-greenford nought befell to tell of ; [they]4661-they came thither when the sun was at point to set , for [they]4661-they had ridden diligently all day .

As [they]4661-they rode [the streets of [the good town]4670-the good town]4669-the streets of the good town , [they]4661-they noted of [them]4661-they , that though it was evening wherein [folk]1529-folk do much disport [them]4661-they abroad , there were [women]433-women and [children]1288-children enough in [the streets]4674-the streets or standing at [their]4661-they doors , but of [carles]4675-carles very few , and [they]4661-they for the more part grey - heads .

Now did [Arnold]177-arnold bring [Birdalone]155-birdalone to [the town hall]4676-the town hall , wherein yet sat [the deputy of the burgrave , who [himself]4677-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold was in the leaguer at [the Red Hold]49-the red hold]4677-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold ; [this man , who was old and wise and nothing feeble of body]4678-this man , who was old and wise and nothing feeble of body , made much of [Birdalone]155-birdalone and [[her]155-birdalone folk]3999-her folk , and was glad of [them]4661-they when [he]4677-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold knew that [they]4661-they had the seal and let - pass of [Geoffrey of [Lea]64-lea]4680-geoffrey of lea ; wherefore [he]4677-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold gave [them]4661-they to eat and drink , and lodged them in [[his]4677-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold own house]4681-his own house , and made [them]4661-they the best of cheer .

But betimes on the morrow did [Birdalone]155-birdalone send back [Arnold]177-arnold and [the four men - at - arms]4659-the four men - at - arms , with no tale but that such was [her]155-birdalone will ; and bidding farewell to [the said Arnold]177-arnold , [she]155-birdalone suffered [him]177-arnold to kiss [her]155-birdalone hands , and gave [him]177-arnold a ring from off [her]155-birdalone finger , so that [he]177-arnold went on [his]177-arnold way rejoicing .

So soon as [she]155-birdalone saw [him]177-arnold and [[his]177-arnold men]3451-his men well on [the road]2103-the road , [she]155-birdalone went to [the old man]7080-the old man , [the vice - ruler of [the town]319-the town , who was of [the aldermen thereof]4688-the aldermen thereof]4686-the vice - ruler of the town , who was of the aldermen thereof , and did [him]7080-the old man to wit that [she]155-birdalone would wage [two or three carles who could deal with horses and beasts , and withal handle weapons if need were , to be both as [servants and guards]4690-servants and guards for [her]155-birdalone]4689-two or three carles who could deal with horses and beasts , and withal handle weapons if need were , to be both as servants and guards for her , as [she]155-birdalone had errands in [that country - side]4691-that country - side , and belike might well have to go from [town]4692-town to [town]4692-town thereabout . [He]177-arnold took [her]155-birdalone asking kindly , but said it was none so easy to find [men who for any wage]4694-men who for any wage would fare forth of [Greenford]45-greenford at that stour , whereas well - nigh all [[their]4694-men who for any wage fighting - men]4695-their fighting - men were lying before [the Red Hold]49-the red hold as now . Howsoever , ere noontide [he]177-arnold brought before [her]155-birdalone [a man of over three score , but yet wayworthy]4696-a man of over three score , but yet wayworthy , and [two stout young men]4697-two stout young men , [[his]177-arnold sons]4698-his sons , and told [her]155-birdalone that [these men]2990-these men were trusty and would go with [her]155-birdalone to [the world]430-the world 's end if need were .

[She]155-birdalone took [these men]2990-these men readily , and agreed with [them]2990-these men for a good wage ; and whereas [each one]343-each one had bow and arrows and short sword , [she]155-birdalone had but to buy for [them]2990-these men jacks , sallets , and bucklers , and [they]2990-these men were well armed as for [their]2990-these men condition . Withal [she]155-birdalone bought [them]2990-these men three good horses and another sumpter - horse ; which last was loaded with sundry wares that [she]155-birdalone deemed that [she]155-birdalone needed , and with victual . Then [she]155-birdalone took leave of [the alderman]4703-the alderman , thanking [him]4703-the alderman much for [his]4703-the alderman good - will , and so departed from [Greenford]45-greenford at all adventure , when the day was yet young .

[The alderman]4703-the alderman had asked [her]155-birdalone whither away , and [she]155-birdalone had told [him]4703-the alderman that [she]155-birdalone was boun for [Mostwyke]66-mostwyke first , and thereafter for [Shifford - on - the- Strand]65-shifford - on - the- strand ; whereas [she]155-birdalone had heard talk of [these two towns]4705-these two towns as being on one and [the same highway]4706-the same highway , and [Mostwyke]66-mostwyke about [a score of miles from [Greenford]45-greenford]4707-a score of miles from greenford ; but when [she]155-birdalone was well out - [a - gates]4708-a - gates [she]155-birdalone came to [a little road]4709-a little road on the right hand which turned clean away from [Mostwyke]66-mostwyke , and [she]155-birdalone took [the said road]4710-the said road ; and when [she]155-birdalone had followed [it]4710-the said road some three miles , [she]155-birdalone asked [the old carle whither]130-the old it led . [He]130-the old looked on [her]155-birdalone and smiled somewhat , and [she]155-birdalone on [him]130-the old in turn ; and [she]155-birdalone said : Wonder not , [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend , that [I]0-i am not clear about [my]0-i ways , for [I]0-i shall tell the sooth that [I]0-i am [a damsel adventurous]4712-a damsel adventurous , and am but seeking some place where [I]0-i may dwell and earn [my]0-i livelihood till better days come ; and this is the whole truth , and [thou]4713-thou shalt know it at once , to wit , that [I]0-i am indeed fleeing , and were fain to hide the footsteps of [me]0-i , and [I]0-i bid [you]4714-you three to help [me]0-i therein . But [ye]4714-you must know that [I]0-i am fleeing , not from [[my]0-i foes]4715-my foes , but from [[my]0-i friends]2100-my friends ; and , if [ye]4714-you will , as [we]4717-we go by the way , [I]0-i will tell [you]4714-you all the story of [me]0-i , and [we]4717-we will be [friends]416-friends while [we]4717-we are together , [yea]4714-you , and thereafter if it may be .

Now [she]0-i said this because [she]0-i had looked carefully on [these men]2990-these men , and herseemed that [they]2990-these men were [good men]4720-good men and true , and not dull of wit . Forsooth [the old man]7080-the old man , who hight [Gerard of the Clee]187-gerard , was no weakling , and was nought loathly to look on , and [[his]7080-the old man two sons]4722-his two sons were goodly and great of fashion , clear - eyed , and well - carven of visage ; [they]4722-his two sons hight [Robert]181-robert and [Giles]182-giles gerardson .

Now spake [old Gerard]187-gerard : [Lady]504-lady , [I]0-i thank [thee]504-lady heartily of [thy]504-lady much grace unto [me]0-i ; now would [I]0-i get off [my]0-i nag and kneel to [thee]504-lady in [the highway therefor]4724-the highway therefor , but that [I]0-i see that [thou]504-lady wert fain to make as much way as may be to - day ; wherefore , by [thy]504-lady leave , [I]0-i will tarry [my]0-i homaging till [we]4725-we rest [our]4725-we horses by the wayside . [She]504-lady laughed , and praised [his]187-gerard wisdom ; and [the young men]2410-the young men looked on [her]504-lady and worshipped [her]504-lady in [their]2410-the young men hearts . [Forsooth]101-birdalone , the fellowship of [these good and true folk]4727-these good and true folk was soft and sweet to [her]504-lady , and soothed the trouble of [her]504-lady spirit . And [she]504-lady enforced [herself]504-lady to talk cheerfully with [them]2410-the young men , and asked [them]2410-the young men many things , and learned much of them .

But now went on [Gerard]187-gerard to say : [Lady]504-lady , if [thou]4729-thou wilt hide [thy]4729-thou ways from whomsoever it may be , [thou]4729-thou hast happened on no ill way ; for though [this road]2043-this road be good to ride , it is but a byway through the sheep - walks that [folk]1529-folk may drive [[their]1529-folk wains]4732-their wains hereby in the wet season of winter and spring ; and for a great way [we]4733-we shall come to but little save [the cots of [the sheep - carles]4735-the sheep - carles]4734-the cots of the sheep - carles ; scarce a hamlet or two for the space of two days ' riding ; and on the third day [a little town]7145-a little town , hight Upham , where are but [few folk]2884-few folk save at the midsummer wool - fair , which is now gone by .[4735-the sheep - carles]

Now there is [a highway]4736-a highway cometh into [this road]2043-this road from out of [the tilled country]4738-the tilled country and [Appleham]67-appleham , [a good town]4739-a good town , and goeth through [it]2043-this road toward [the tillage]4740-the tillage , and [the City of the Bridges]4741-the city of the bridges and the liberties thereof ; and all [the land]213-the land is much builded and plentiful ; but , if [thou]4729-thou wilt , [we]4733-we will not take [either highway]4743-either highway , but wend over [the downland which lieth north - east of [Upham]68-upham]4744-the downland which lieth north - east of upham , and though it be roadless , yet is it not ill- going , and [I]0-i know [it]4744-the downland which lieth north - east of upham well and [[its]4744-the downland which lieth north - east of upham watering - places]4745-its watering - places , little dales and waters therein all running north - east , wherein be certain little thorps here and there , which shall refresh [us]4733-we mightily . Over [that downland]4746-that downland [we]4733-we may wend a four days , and then [the land]213-the land will swell up high , and from the end of [that high land]4748-that high land [we]4733-we shall behold below [us]4733-we [a fair land of tillage , well watered and wooded]4749-a fair land of tillage , well watered and wooded , and much builded ; and in the midst thereof [a great city with walls and towers]4750-a great city with walls and towers , and [a great white castle]4751-a great white castle and a minster , and [lovely houses a many]4752-lovely houses a many . In [that city]4753-that city mayst [thou]4754-thee dwell and earn [thy]4754-thee livelihood if [thou]4754-thee canst do aught of crafts . And if [thou]4754-thee mayst not , then may [we]4733-we find somewhat to swink at for a wage , and so maintain [thee]4754-thee and [us]4733-we . But [the said city]4755-the said city is called [the City of the Five Crafts]4756-the city of the five crafts , and [the land round about [it]4755-the said city]4757-the land round about it is the frank thereof ; and oftenest , frank and [city]4758-city and all , [it]4755-the said city is called the Five Crafts all simply . Now what sayest [thou]4754-thee hereof , [[my]0-i lady]615-my lady ?

[She]615-my lady said : [I]0-i say that [we]4733-we will go thither , and that [I]0-i thank [thee]4754-thee and [[thy]4754-thee sons]4760-thy sons of [thy]4754-thee good - will , and so may [God]120-god do to [me]0-i as [I]0-i reward [you]4754-thee well therefor . But tell [me]0-i , [good Gerard]187-gerard , how it is that [thou]4754-thee art so willing to leave [kith]4761-kith and kin to follow [a gangrel wife]4762-a gangrel wife along the ways ? Said [Gerard]187-gerard : [Dame]98-dame , [I]0-i think that the face and body of [thee]4754-thee might lead [any man that yet had manhood in [him]4763-any man that yet had manhood in him to follow thee , even if he left house and all to go with thee to follow [thee]4754-thee , even if [he]4763-any man that yet had manhood in him to follow thee , even if he left house and all to go with thee left [house]928-house and all to go with [thee]4754-thee]4763-any man that yet had manhood in him to follow thee , even if he left house and all to go with thee . But as for [us]4765-us , [we]4765-us have no longer [a house]4766-a house or gear , whereas [[they]4767-they of [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold]4768-they of the red hold lifted all [my]0-i bestial , and burned [[my]0-i house]4770-my house and all that was therein a month ago .
