[Yea]4771-yea , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and how befalleth it , then , that [ye]4754-thee are not before the Red Hold to avenge [thee]4754-thee ? [Dame]98-dame , said [he]4763-any man that yet had manhood in him to follow thee , even if he left house and all to go with thee , when the muster was [I]0-i was deemed somewhat over old , wherefore [the sheriff]4772-the sheriff took [me]0-i not , but suffered [[my]0-i sons]4773-my sons also to abide behind to earn a living for [me]0-i ; may [God]120-god be good to [him]4763-any man that yet had manhood in him to follow thee , even if he left house and all to go with thee therefor , and [St. Leonard]137-leonard ! But as to [my]0-i kindred , [I]0-i must tell [thee]4754-thee that [I]0-i am not kinned hereabout , but in [a good town hight Utterhay]4774-a good town hight utterhay , and that when [[our]4775-our alderman]4776-our alderman sent for [me]0-i to bring [me]0-i to [thee]4754-thee , [I]0-i was more than half - minded to get [me]0-i back thither . Now sooth it is that the best way thither , though it may be indeed the safest rather than the shortest , lies through [the Five Crafts]4777-the five crafts ; for [the road]2103-the road goes thence to [Utterhay]3-utterhay a three score miles or so , making the longer of [it]2103-the road , as [it]2103-the road skirteth ever some way off [a perilous forest]4779-a perilous forest , [a place of sore dread and devilish]4780-a place of sore dread and devilish , which hight [Evilshaw]4-evilshaw , on the edge whereof lieth [Utterhay]3-utterhay , a merry cheaping - stead and a plenteous , and [the home of [[my]0-i kindred]4782-my kindred]4781-the home of my kindred . Wherefore now is [the City of [the Five Crafts handy to [us]4785-they]4784-the five crafts handy to us]4783-the city of the five crafts handy to us ; because when [thou]4786-thou hast done with [us]4785-they , as [I]0-i hope it may be long first , then are [we]4785-they [others]2441-others nigh [home]387-home , and may all simply wend [our]4785-they way thither .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone thanked [him]4789-him again full heartily ; but therewithal as [they]4785-they rode along there seemed to stir in [her]101-birdalone some memory of the earliest of [her]101-birdalone days in [[the witch]407-the witch 's house]4791-the witch 's house , and [she]101-birdalone began to have a longing to betake [her]101-birdalone to [Utterhay]3-utterhay and the skirts of [Evilshaw]4-evilshaw .

CHAPTER II . OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone AND [HER]101-birdalone FELLOWSHIP , [THEIR]4785-they FARING OVER [THE DOWNLAND]69-the downland

Thus rode [they]4785-they along and loitered not , though [they]4785-they talked blithely together ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone wondered to [herself]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone might so much as hold up [her]101-birdalone head for bitter thoughts of the days and the longings but late passed away , but so it was , that it was only now and again that [they]4785-they stung [her]101-birdalone into despair and silence , and for the most part [she]101-birdalone hearkened to the talk of [the old man]7080-the old man and [the lads]4793-the lads about the days of [Greenford]45-greenford and the alarms of lifting and unpeace , and the ways of [the chapmen]4794-the chapmen and [the craftsmen]4795-the craftsmen .

An hour after noon [they]4785-they rested in [a little dale of [the downland]4797-the downland]4796-a little dale of the downland where was [a pool and three thorn - bushes thereby]4798-a pool and three thorn - bushes thereby ; and when [they]4785-they had lighted down , [the old man]7080-the old man knelt before [Birdalone]101-birdalone and took [her]101-birdalone hand , and swore [himself]7080-the old man [[her]101-birdalone man]3698-her man to do [her]101-birdalone will , whatso it were ; and then [he]7080-the old man stood up and bade [[his]7080-the old man sons]4698-his sons do likewise ; so [they]4785-they two knelt before [her]101-birdalone in turn , somewhat shy and abashed , for all that [they]4785-they were [such stout , bold fellows]4802-such stout , bold fellows , and found it hard to take [her]101-birdalone hand , and then when [they]4785-they had it in [theirs]4785-they , hard to let it go again .

A score of miles and five [they]4785-they rode that day , and had no roof over [them]4785-they at night save the naked heaven , but to [Birdalone]101-birdalone that was but little scathe : [they]4785-they made a shift to have some fire by [them]4785-they , and [the three men]4803-the three men sat long about it that even while [Birdalone]101-birdalone told [them]4803-the three men somewhat of [her]101-birdalone life ; and as [she]101-birdalone told of [the House under the Wood]2453-the house under the wood and the Great Water , [Gerard]187-gerard had some inkling of whereabouts it was ; but was nought so sure , because , as abovesaid in this tale , seldom did any from [the world of [men]219-men]4805-the world of men venture in [Evilshaw]4-evilshaw , or know of [the Great Water]4807-the great water from [[its]4807-the great water banks that gave unto [the forest]4809-the forest]4808-its banks that gave unto the forest .

In like wise [they]4785-they rode the next day , and came at eventide to [a thorp in [a fair little dale of the downland]4811-a fair little dale of the downland]4810-a thorp in a fair little dale of the downland , and there [they]4785-they guested with [the shepherd - folk]4812-the shepherd - folk , who wondered much at the beauty of [Birdalone]101-birdalone , so that at first [they]4785-they scarce durst venture to draw nigh unto [her]101-birdalone until [Gerard]187-gerard and [[his]187-gerard sons]4698-his sons had had some familiar converse with [them]4785-they ; then indeed [they]4785-they exceeded in kindness toward [them]4785-they , in [their]4785-they rough upland fashion , but ever found it hard to keep [their]4785-they eyes off [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and that the more after [they]4785-they had heard the full sweetness of [her]101-birdalone voice ; whereas [she]101-birdalone sang to [them]4785-they certain songs which [she]101-birdalone had learned in [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest , though it made [her]101-birdalone heart sore ; but [she]101-birdalone deemed [she]101-birdalone must needs pay [that kindly folk]4815-that kindly folk for [their]4815-that kindly folk guestful and blithe ways . And thereafter [they]4785-they sang to the pipe and the harp [their]4785-they own downland songs ; and this [she]101-birdalone found strange , that whereas [her]101-birdalone eyes were dry when [she]101-birdalone was singing the songs of love of [the knighthood]4816-the knighthood , the wildness of [the shepherd - music]4817-the shepherd - music drew the tears from [her]101-birdalone , would [she]101-birdalone , would [she]101-birdalone not . Homelike and dear seemed [the green willowy dale]4818-the green willowy dale to [her]101-birdalone , and in the night ere [she]101-birdalone slept , and [she]101-birdalone lay quiet amidst of [the peaceful people]4819-the peaceful people , [she]101-birdalone could not choose but weep again , for pity of the bitter - sweet of [her]101-birdalone own love , and for pity of [the wide world]4820-the wide world withal , and all the ways of its many folk that lay so new before [her]101-birdalone .

CHAPTER III . [THEY]4785-they COME TO [THE CITY]70-the city OF THE FIVE CRAFTS , AND [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone MEETS WITH [THE POOR - WIFE]262-the poor - wife

[They]4785-they made not so much way that [they]4785-they came to [the Five Crafts]71-the five crafts on the fourth day , but lay under the bare heavens in a dale below [the big swell of [the downland]4797-the downland]4822-the big swell of the downland , whereof [Gerard]187-gerard spake . But betimes in the morning [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose and stirred up [[her]101-birdalone men]4824-her men , and [they]4824-her men gat to horse , and rode [the hill before [them]4824-her men]4825-the hill before them till [they]4824-her men came on to [the crest thereof]4826-the crest thereof . Then [Birdalone]101-birdalone cried aloud with joy to see [the lovely land]4827-the lovely land before [her]101-birdalone , and the white walls and [the towers of [the great city]4829-the great city]4828-the towers of the great city , whereas [Greenford]45-greenford was but small beside [it]45-greenford .

So [they]4785-they rode down into [the frank]4830-the frank , and entered the gates of [the city]4831-the city a little after noon , and again was [Birdalone]101-birdalone in all amaze at the going to and fro in [the streets]4674-the streets and the thronging of [the markets]4833-the markets , and [the divers folk]4834-the divers folk , as [chapmen]4835-chapmen and [men - at - arms]2059-men - at - arms , and [craftsmen]4837-craftsmen and [lords]2319-lords , who used [the said city]4755-the said city ; and to say sooth , somewhat [her]101-birdalone heart sank within [her]101-birdalone , and it seemed to [her]101-birdalone that it would be hard and troublous to have to deal with [so much folk]4840-so much folk , and that [they]4840-so much folk must needs go past [her]101-birdalone on the right hand and the left without heeding [her]101-birdalone life .

Howsoever , [Gerard]187-gerard , who knew [the city]4831-the city , brought [her]101-birdalone to [a fair hostel]4842-a fair hostel , where [she]101-birdalone was well lodged , [she]101-birdalone and [[her]101-birdalone men]4824-her men . Straightway , then , before [she]101-birdalone went out into [the streets]4674-the streets again , [she]101-birdalone fell to getting together what [she]101-birdalone had of fine broidered work and of fair script , and to finishing what [she]101-birdalone had unfinished . And [she]101-birdalone sent forth [Gerard]187-gerard and [[his]187-gerard sons]4698-his sons to find out where was the market for such goods , and if [she]101-birdalone would have leave to sell the same therein , or anywhere in [the town]319-the town ; and [Gerard]187-gerard found [the hall of [the embroiderers]4848-the embroiderers]4847-the hall of the embroiderers , and therein [the master of the craft]4849-the master of the craft , and [he]187-gerard received the carle courteously when [he]187-gerard heard that there was fine work come to [town]4692-town , and did [him]187-gerard to wit that [none in any such craft]4851-none in any such craft might have freedom of [the market]328-the market save by leave of [the guild of the craft]4853-the guild of the craft ; but , said [he]187-gerard , [the guilds]4854-the guilds were open - handed and courteous , and were nowise wo nt to refuse the said leave , were the work good and true ; and [he]187-gerard bade [Gerard]187-gerard withal tell [[his]187-gerard mistress]4855-his mistress that [she]4855-his mistress were best to bring samplings of [her]4855-his mistress work to [the Guildhall]4856-the guildhall so soon as [she]4855-his mistress might . So the very next day went [Birdalone thither]101-birdalone , and found [the master]2638-the master [a well - looked tall man of some five - and - forty winters]4858-a well - looked tall man of some five - and - forty winters , who looked on [her]4855-his mistress from the first as if [he]2638-the master deemed it were no ill way of wearing the time . To [this man]1976-this man [she]4855-his mistress showed [her]4855-his mistress work , and though [he]2638-the master found it not easy to take [his]2638-the master eyes off [Birdalone]101-birdalone [herself]4855-his mistress , yet when [he]2638-the master looked at [her]4855-his mistress handiwork , [he]2638-the master found it better than very good , and [he]2638-the master said to [her]4855-his mistress : [Damsel]2961-damsel , here is what will be sought for at a great price by [the great lords]4861-the great lords and [ladies of [the land]213-the land]4862-ladies of the land , and [the rich burgesses]4864-the rich burgesses , and especially by [the high prelates]4865-the high prelates ; and so much of it as [thou]4866-thou hast a mind to do is so much coined gold unto [thee]4855-his mistress ; and now [I]0-i see [thee]4855-his mistress what [thou]4866-thou art , [I]0-i were fain that [thou]4866-thou gathered good to [thee]4855-his mistress . But as diligent as [thou]4866-thou mayst be , [thou]4866-thou hast but one pair of hands , wonderful soothly , and yet but one pair . [He]2638-the master broke off at that word , for [he]2638-the master was verily staring at [her]4855-his mistress hands , and longing to see more of [her]4855-his mistress arms than the wrists only , so that [he]2638-the master scarce knew what [he]2638-the master was saying . Then [he]2638-the master turned red and said : Soothly [I]0-i wot that [no other hands save [thine]4868-thine]4867-no other hands save thine may do such needlework , or make the draughts for [them]4868-thine . But [thou]4866-thou wilt need [women]433-women - [servants]1103-servants to help [thee]4866-thou , both in dighting [the house]325-the house for [thee]4866-thou for this big old carle here will be scarce meet thereto and as [apprentices]4872-apprentices to help [thee]4866-thou about the work itself ; and if [thou]4866-thou wilt , [I]0-i shall seek the best ones out for [thee]4866-thou . Moreover [I]0-i must tell [thee]4866-thou , that though [I]0-i know for sure how that [no woman in [the world]430-the world]4873-no woman in the world may work such needlework as thine , yet whiles there cometh hither [a woman of middle age]4875-a woman of middle age , [a woman worn by troubles , pious , meek , and kind]4876-a woman worn by troubles , pious , meek , and kind ; and by [St. Lucia]183-st. lucia ! now [I]0-i look on [thee]4866-thou again , [she]4866-thou might be somewhat like unto [thee]4866-thou , were [she]4866-thou young and fresh- looking and strong as [thou]4866-thou art . Now [this woman]425-this woman [I]0-i say , and thereat [I]0-i marvel , doeth needlework that is somewhat after the manner of thine , and which seemed to [us]4878-our excellent till [I]0-i had seen thine . Good livelihood [she]4866-thou earneth thereby , and is diligent therein ; but [she]4866-thou hath no heart to get [apprentices]4872-apprentices , or be made one of [[our]4878-our guild]4880-our guild , both of which were lawful to [her]4866-thou as to [thee]4866-thou , [lovely damsel]4881-lovely damsel . But now [I]0-i shall counsel [her]4866-thou to be made of [[our]4878-our guild]4880-our guild along with [thee]4866-thou , if [thou]4866-thou wilt have it so , and then may [ye]4866-thou both have [three apprentices]4883-three apprentices each , and may make in [[our]4878-our city]4884-our city [a goodly school]4885-a goodly school , so that [[our]4878-our guild]4880-our guild shall be glorified thereby , for there will be none such work in [the world]430-the world . How sayest [thou]4866-thou ?

[She]4866-thou thanked [him]4866-thou much , and yeasaid [him]4866-thou , and thought in [her]4866-thou heart that such work which would keep [her]4866-thou hands and [her]4866-thou head both busy , would solace the grief of [her]4866-thou heart , and wear away the time , that [she]4866-thou might live till hope might peradventure arise in [her]4866-thou .

Then said [the master]2638-the master : There is one thing else , that is , [[thy]4866-thou dwelling - place]4889-thy dwelling - place ; and if [thou]4866-thou wilt [I]0-i shall hire [thee]4866-thou [a house in [the street of the Broiderers]4891-the street of the broiderers]4890-a house in the street of the broiderers , [a goodly one]4892-a goodly one : sooth to say , that same is [mine]0-i own , so [thou]4866-thou mayst deem that [I]0-i tell [thee]4866-thou hereof to [mine]0-i own gain ; and that may be and [he]4866-thou reddened therewith ; but there is this in it , that if [thou]4866-thou lackest money [I]0-i shall let [thee]4866-thou live therein without price till [thou]4866-thou shalt have earned more than enough to pay [me]0-i .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone thanked [him]4866-thou well , but [she]101-birdalone did [him]4866-thou to wit that [she]101-birdalone was nowise penniless ; and presently [she]101-birdalone departed well pleased , though [she]101-birdalone deemed that [the said master]4893-the said master was well - nigh more friendly than might be looked for . And the next day [he]4866-thou came to [her]101-birdalone in [the hostelry]4894-the hostelry , and without more ado brought [her]101-birdalone to [the house in [the street of the Broiderers]4891-the street of the broiderers]4895-the house in the street of the broiderers , and [she]101-birdalone found [it]4895-the house in the street of the broiderers fair and well plenished , and so [she]101-birdalone fell to work to get all things ready .

Now the next week was the day appointed when [she]101-birdalone should be received into [[the broiderers]4897-the broiderers ' guild]7147-the broiderers ' guild , and the day before came [the master]2638-the master aforesaid to see [Birdalone]101-birdalone . [Sooth]184-sooth to say , [he]4866-thou had not failed to come to see [her]101-birdalone every day , on one pretence or another , since the first day [they]7149-they had met , but ever [he]4866-thou did to [her]101-birdalone with all honour and simply . But on this day [he]4866-thou brought with [him]4866-thou [the woman]252-the woman skilful of [her]101-birdalone hands , to show [her]101-birdalone unto [Birdalone]101-birdalone , who received [her]101-birdalone gladly , and thereafter [Master Jacobus]185-jacobus left [them]7151-them alone together .[4898-the said woman]

[The said woman]4898-the said woman looked worn and aged indeed , but was not of more than five - and - forty winters even by seeming , after the first look at [her]4898-the said woman ; [she]4898-the said woman was somewhat tall and well - knit , [her]4898-the said woman face well shapen , and [her]4898-the said woman hair yet goodly . There was a kind look in the eyes of [her]4898-the said woman , as if [she]4898-the said woman might love anyone with whom [she]4898-the said woman lived that would be kind to [her]4898-the said woman . Meek , or rather over - meek , of mien [she]4898-the said woman was , and it seemed of [her]4898-the said woman that [she]4898-the said woman had been sore scared and oppressed one while or another .

So when [Master Jacobus]185-jacobus was gone , [Birdalone]101-birdalone set [her]4898-the said woman down on the settle beside [her]4898-the said woman , and spake to [her]4898-the said woman full sweetly and kindly , and [the woman]252-the woman spake little in turn save answering simply to [her]4898-the said woman questions . [Birdalone]101-birdalone asked where [she]252-the woman was kinned , and [she]252-the woman answered : In Utterhay . Then said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : Within these last few days [I]0-i have heard [that town]4900-that town named twice or thrice , and never before , as [meseemeth]4901-meseemeth ; and yet , hearing the name from [thy]4900-that town mouth , it seemeth to stir something in [me]0-i , as if [I]0-i had been [there]232-there one time and longed to be [there]232-there again . Is there aught in the place whereof [folk]1529-folk tell wide about , so that [I]0-i might have heard it told of and not noted it at the time ? Nay , [lady]504-lady , said [the dame]415-the dame , save perchance that [it]4907-it is on the verge of [a very great and very evil wood]4908-a very great and very evil wood , otherwise [it]4907-it was once [a merry town]4909-a merry town and of much resort from [the country - side]2227-the country - side .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone looked on [her]415-the dame , and saw that the tears were coming from [her]415-the dame eyes and running down [her]415-the dame cheeks as [she]415-the dame spake ; so [she]101-birdalone said to [her]415-the dame : Why dost [thou]415-the dame weep , [mother]740-mother ? Is there aught [I]0-i may do to assuage [thy]415-the dame grief ? Said [the dame]415-the dame : [Thou]415-the dame art so kind to [me]0-i , and [thy]415-the dame voice is so dear and sweet , that [I]0-i can not choose but weep . Meseems it is because love of [thee]415-the dame hath taken [mine]0-i heart , and therewith is blended memory of past sorrow of [mine]0-i . [Thou]415-the dame askest [me]0-i if [thou]415-the dame mayest do aught to assuage [my]0-i grief ; [dear lady]4913-dear lady , [I]0-i am not grieved now , that has gone by ; nay , now [I]0-i am more than not grieved , [I]0-i am made happy , because [I]0-i am with [thee]415-the dame . But since [thou]415-the dame art so debonair with [me]0-i , [I]0-i will ask [thee]415-the dame to do somewhat for [me]0-i ; and that is , to tell [me]0-i of [thy]415-the dame life gone by ; [I]0-i mean , [sweet young damsel]4914-sweet young damsel , of [thy]415-the dame life when [thou]415-the dame wert [a little child]4915-a little child .

Then [Birdalone]101-birdalone kissed [her]4913-dear lady and said : It goes to [my]0-i heart that [thou]415-the dame lovest [me]0-i ; for soon as [I]0-i set eyes on [thee]415-the dame [my]0-i heart went out to [thee]415-the dame ; and now belike [we]4916-we shall be [dear friends]1325-dear friends ; and that is a thing that shall avail [me]0-i much , to have [a friend who is so much older than [I]0-i , so that nought can come between [us]4916-we , of the love of [men]219-men and other griefs]4918-a friend who is so much older than i , so that nought can come between us , of the love of men and other griefs . [Yea]4920-yea , now , said [the dame]415-the dame , smiling somewhat sadly ; now do [I]0-i see the water standing in thine eyes , and [thy]415-the dame voice quavers . Is it so , [[thou]415-the dame lovely kind damsel]4922-thou lovely kind damsel , that [thou]415-the dame hast been grieved by love of [a man]234-a man ? Who then may prevail in love if [thou]415-the dame prevail not ? And [she]415-the dame fell to fondling [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's hand ; but [Birdalone]101-birdalone said : It is over - long to tell of all [my]0-i life , [mother]740-mother , though [I]0-i be so young ; but now [I]0-i will do as [thou]415-the dame badest [me]0-i , and tell [thee]740-mother somewhat of [my]0-i days when [I]0-i was little .

And therewith [she]101-birdalone fell to telling [her]740-mother of [her]101-birdalone days in [the House under the Wood]2453-the house under the wood , and [the witch]407-the witch and [her]101-birdalone surliness and grimness , and of [her]101-birdalone love of the wild things , and how [she]101-birdalone waxed there . And [she]101-birdalone spake a long while , for the memory of those days seemed to lead [her]101-birdalone along , as though [she]101-birdalone verily were alive now in them ; and [the woman]252-the woman sat before [her]101-birdalone , gazing on [her]101-birdalone lovingly , till [Birdalone]101-birdalone stayed [her]101-birdalone tale at last and said : Now have [I]0-i told [thee]740-mother more than enough of a simple matter , and a life that was as that of a wild creature of [the woods]463-the woods . Now shalt [thou]740-mother , [mother]740-mother , tell [me]0-i somewhat of [thee]740-mother , and what was [thy]740-mother grief of [Utterhay]3-utterhay : for [thou]740-mother shalt find that the telling thereof shall solace [thee]740-mother . Ah ! so think [young folk]4930-young folk , said [the woman]252-the woman sadly , because there are many days left for [them]4930-young folk to hope in . But though the telling of [my]0-i sorrow be a fresh sorrow to [me]0-i , yet shalt [thou]740-mother hear it . It is but of the loss of [[my]0-i babe]4932-my babe ; but [she]252-the woman was of all [babes the fairest and the sweetest]4933-babes the fairest and the sweetest .

Then [she]252-the woman fell to telling [Birdalone]101-birdalone all that concerning [the witch]407-the witch at [Utterhay]3-utterhay and [the poor - wife]262-the poor - wife that [ye]4936-ye have heard in the beginning of this book , until the time when [she]252-the woman left [the house]325-the house to buy meat for [the witch]407-the witch ; for [she]252-the woman [herself]252-the woman was [the said poor - wife]4939-the said poor - wife . And then [she]252-the woman told how [she]252-the woman came back again and found [[her]252-the woman guest]4940-her guest gone and [the child withal]4941-the child withal ; and though [she]252-the woman had wept for love of [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]252-the woman wept not at telling of this grief , but told it as a tale which had befallen some other one . And [she]252-the woman said : And so when [I]0-i had done running up and down like a wild thing , and asking of [the neighbours]2575-the neighbours with lack of breath and fierceness of speech who had taken [[my]0-i child]915-my child away from [me]0-i ; and when [I]0-i had gone up to the wood and even some way into it , and when [I]0-i had wandered up and down again , and night was falling , [I]0-i came back at last again to [[my]0-i poor house]4095-my poor house so weary with [my]0-i woe , that [I]0-i scarce knew what had befallen [me]0-i . And there upon the board lay the victual and drink which [I]0-i had brought , and the money which [the witch]407-the witch had given unto [me]0-i ; and despite of grief , hunger flamed up in [me]0-i at the sight , and [I]0-i threw [myself]0-i on to it and ate and drank , and so came to [myself]0-i , that is , to [my]0-i grief . But the next day [I]0-i ran about hither and thither , and wearied [folk]1529-folk with [my]0-i asking and [my]0-i woe ; but it was all of none avail . [The child]253-the child was gone away from [me]0-i . There is little more to tell of [me]0-i , [sweet lady]4948-sweet lady . If [I]0-i were to live , needs must [I]0-i take the poor price of [[my]0-i little one]279-my little one , to wit , [the witch]407-the witch 's money , and deal with [folk]1529-folk for [my]0-i livelihood ; wherefore [I]0-i bought [me]0-i cloth and silks , having now the wherewithal , and set to work on broidery , for even then was [I]0-i [a cunning needle - woman]4952-a cunning needle - woman . So were [God]120-god and the saints good to [me]0-i , and inclined [the folk]244-the folk to [me]0-i , that [they]244-the folk were good and piteous , and [I]0-i lacked not work nor due livelihood ; but after a while [I]0-i wearied of [Utterhay]3-utterhay , where [[my]0-i dear child]4954-my dear child should have been running about before [my]0-i feet ; and having by this time gotten a little money together , and being exceeding deft in [my]0-i craft , [I]0-i came on hither to live , and , praise be to [St. Ursula]186-st. ursula ! [I]0-i have found it easy to live : and praise be to All - hallows withal that [I]0-i have found [thee]4955-thou , who art so kind and lovely ; and [thou]4955-thou by seeming of the very age [[my]0-i child]915-my child should be if [she]915-my child be living : or how old art [thou]4955-thou , [dear lady]4913-dear lady ?

[Birdalone]101-birdalone laid [her]101-birdalone hand on [her]101-birdalone breast , and [she]101-birdalone was turned pale , but [she]101-birdalone said in a low voice : [I]0-i deem that [I]0-i am of twenty summers .

Then [they]4958-they both sat silent , till [Birdalone]101-birdalone might master the fluttering of [her]101-birdalone heart , and [she]101-birdalone said : Now meseems [I]0-i have a memory even earlier than those [I]0-i told [thee]4959-thee erst . [A woman]250-a woman took [me]0-i out of a basket and set [me]0-i on the back of an ass , and [I]0-i looked about , and [I]0-i was in a grassy lawn of [the woods]463-the woods ; and [I]0-i saw a squirrel run up a tree - trunk before [me]0-i , and wind round the tree and hide [him]4962-him ; and then [I]0-i stretched out [my]0-i hands and cried out to [him]4962-him ; and then came [the woman]252-the woman unto [me]0-i , and gave [me]0-i wood - strawberries to eat out of [her]252-the woman hand .

Brake out [the poor - wife]262-the poor - wife thereat , pale and trembling : Tell [me]0-i now , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , hast [thou]915-my child any memory of what [the woman]252-the woman was who set [thee]915-my child on the ass and gave [thee]915-my child the strawberries ? [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked on [her]262-the poor - wife , and scanned [her]262-the poor - wife face closely , and then shook [her]262-the poor - wife head , and said : Nay , it was not [thou]915-my child , [mother]740-mother . Nay , surely ; nay , surely , said [the woman]252-the woman ; but think again . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , speaking slowly : Was it [[my]0-i mistress]1415-my mistress then ? [She]252-the woman was [a tall woman]4970-a tall woman , somewhat thin and bony , with goodly red hair and white - skinned , but thin - lipped . Quoth [the poor - wife]262-the poor - wife : No , no ; it is of no use ; nought such was [she]252-the woman . Then [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked up and said eagerly : Yea , but it was [her]252-the woman other shape belike : therein was [she]252-the woman [a tall woman , dark - haired , hook - nosed , and hawk - eyed , as if of thirty summers]4972-a tall woman , dark - haired , hook - nosed , and hawk - eyed , as if of thirty summers ; [a stark woman]4973-a stark woman . Hast [thou]915-my child seen such ? dost [thou]915-my child remember [her]252-the woman ?

[The woman]252-the woman sprang up and cried out , and was like to have fallen , but [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose and held [her]252-the woman in [her]101-birdalone arms and comforted [her]252-the woman , and set [her]252-the woman in [her]101-birdalone seat again and knelt before [her]252-the woman ; and presently [the poor- wife]4975-the poor- wife came to [herself]4975-the poor- wife and said : [[My]0-i child]915-my child , [thou]915-my child sayest do [I]0-i remember [her]252-the woman ; how shall [I]0-i ever forget [her]252-the woman ? [she]252-the woman was [the thief who stole [[my]0-i child]915-my child]4977-the thief who stole my child .

Therewith [she]4975-the poor- wife slid from off [her]4975-the poor- wife seat , and knelt by [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and stooped low down on the floor as if [the tall maiden]4979-the tall maiden were but [a little one]4980-a little one , and [she]4975-the poor- wife fell to kissing [her]252-the woman and patting [her]252-the woman , [her]252-the woman face and [her]252-the woman hands , and all about ; and said , sobbing and yet smiling : Suffer [me]0-i a little , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , [[mine]0-i own lovely child]4982-mine own lovely child ! For in good sooth [I]0-i am [[thy]915-my child mother]337-thy mother , and it is long since [I]0-i have seen [thee]915-my child : but hearken , when [I]0-i come quite to [myself]0-i [I]0-i shall pray [thee]915-my child not to leave [me]0-i yet awhile , and [I]0-i shall pray [thee]915-my child to love [me]0-i .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone clipped and kissed [her]915-my child , and said : [I]0-i love [thee]915-my child dearly , and never , never shall [I]0-i leave [thee]915-my child .

Then [they]4984-they stood up , and [the mother]267-the mother took [Birdalone]101-birdalone by the shoulders , and held [her]101-birdalone a little aloof , and devoured [her]101-birdalone with [her]267-the mother eyes ; and [she]267-the mother said : [Yea]4986-yea , [thou]4987-thou hast grown tall , and belike wilt grow no taller : and how fair and lovely [thou]4987-thou hast grown ; and [thou]4987-thou that [wert]4988-wert born in [[a poor man]4989-a poor man 's house]4990-a poor man 's house ! no wonder that any should covet [thee]4987-thou . And [I]0-i , [I]0-i wonder if ever [I]0-i was as fair as [thou]4987-thou art ; forsooth many called [me]0-i fair for a little while ; and now behold [me]0-i ! Nay , [child]297-child and darling , let not [thy]4987-thou face grow downcast , for now shall [I]0-i know nought more of fear and grief ; and is it not like that [I]0-i shall grow fairer of flesh , and shapelier , in the happy days [we]4992-we shall dwell together ? And therewith [she]267-the mother took [her]4987-thou to [her]267-the mother arms , and it seemed as if [she]267-the mother might never have enough of clipping and embracing [her]4987-thou ; and [she]267-the mother would look at [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's hands and [her]101-birdalone feet and [her]101-birdalone arms , and stroke them and caress them ; and [she]267-the mother wondered at [her]101-birdalone body , as if [she]101-birdalone had been [a young mother]4993-a young mother eaten up with the love of [[her]101-birdalone firstborn]4994-her firstborn . And as for [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]101-birdalone was as glad of [[her]101-birdalone mother]332-her mother as might be ; and yet in [her]101-birdalone heart [she]101-birdalone wondered if perchance [one of [the fellowship]3883-the fellowship]4996-one of the fellowship might stray that way , and be partaker in [her]101-birdalone joy of [this newfound dear friend]4998-this newfound dear friend ; and [she]101-birdalone said , might it be [Viridis]116-viridis ; but in [her]101-birdalone inmost heart , though [she]101-birdalone told it not to [herself]101-birdalone , [she]101-birdalone longed that [the Black Squire]125-arthur might find [her]101-birdalone out at last .

CHAPTER IV . OF THE LOVE OF [GERARD 'S SONS]187-gerard AND OF [JACOBUS]185-jacobus FOR [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone[101-birdalone]

Now dwelt [Birdalone]101-birdalone in rest and peace when [she]101-birdalone had been taken into the guild along with [[her]101-birdalone mother]332-her mother , and [they]5000-they had taken [the due apprentices]5001-the due apprentices to [them]5000-they ; and [they]5000-they began to gather much of goods to [them]5000-they , for of fine broidery there was little done in the Five Crafts , and none at all that could be put beside [their]5000-they work , either for beauty of the draught of it , or for skill of handiwork . [She]101-birdalone declared unto all folk how that [the poor - wife who had to name [Audrey]188-audrey]5002-the poor - wife who had to name audrey was [[her]101-birdalone very mother]5003-her very mother , from whom [she]101-birdalone had been stolen in [her]101-birdalone youngest days ; but [she]101-birdalone told none any tale of how [she]101-birdalone was stolen . And [the twain]5004-the twain dwelt together in the greatest loving - kindness ; and it was with [Audrey]188-audrey as [she]101-birdalone had forecast , that now [her]188-audrey days were happy , and [she]188-audrey living in all ease and content , that the goodliness of [her]188-audrey youth came back to [her]188-audrey , and [she]188-audrey became [a fair woman]591-a fair woman as for [her]188-audrey years ; and therewith it grew to be clear that [the two]3240-the two were so much alike one to [the other]265-the other , that [all]889-all might see that [they]3240-the two were [mother]740-mother and [daughter]5010-daughter .

[Gerard]187-gerard and [[his]187-gerard two sons]4722-his two sons [she]188-audrey maintained yet as [[her]188-audrey men]4824-her men ; and not only were [they]3240-the two of much use to [her]188-audrey in fetching and carrying , but also true it is that [her]188-audrey beauty was so manifest , that [she]188-audrey whiles needed [a stout lad]5013-a stout lad weaponed at [her]188-audrey back when [she]188-audrey was in [the streets]4674-the streets or amidst the throng of [the market]328-the market ; and many were [they]3240-the two , and [whiles of the highest]5016-whiles of the highest , who craved love of [her]188-audrey , [some with honour]5017-some with honour , and [some with lack of it]5018-some with lack of it .

Of these , forsooth , were but two that anywise troubled [her]188-audrey ; and the most trouble was this , that [she]188-audrey might not fail to see that the love of [her]188-audrey had entered into the hearts of the two [Gerardsons]189-gerardsons , [Robert]181-robert and [Giles]182-giles gerardson ; so that times were when [she]188-audrey deemed [she]188-audrey must even send [them]5019-their away , but when it came to the point [she]188-audrey had not the heart thereto ; though none other remedy there seemed , so sorely as [their]5019-their souls were wounded by longing for [her]188-audrey . It is not to be said that [they]5019-their ever spake to [her]188-audrey thereof , or wittingly wearied [her]188-audrey with signs of love ; but [they]5019-their could not so easily cover it up but that it was ever before [her]188-audrey eyes . But [she]188-audrey suffered it all for friendship 's sake and for [their]5019-their true service , and in all friendliness did what [she]188-audrey might to solace [their]5019-their grief . [Forsooth]101-birdalone so good and true [she]188-audrey found that [father- kind]5020-father- kind , and [the young men so goodly and kind]5021-the young men so goodly and kind , that [she]188-audrey said to [herself]188-audrey , had [she]188-audrey not [another man lying in [her]188-audrey heart]5022-another man lying in her heart , [she]188-audrey might well have chosen one of those twain for [her]188-audrey very speech - friend and [true lover]5023-true lover .

The second wooer that troubled [her]188-audrey was [the master]2638-the master , [Jacobus]185-jacobus , who , when but three months were worn of [her]188-audrey dwelling in [[her]188-audrey house]5025-her house , did all openly crave [her]188-audrey love and offer [her]188-audrey marriage , [he]2638-the master being [a man unwedded]5026-a man unwedded . Sore was [her]188-audrey heart that [she]188-audrey must needs gainsay [him]2638-the master , so kind and courteous as [he]2638-the master had been to [her]188-audrey at [their]5027-their first coming together ; though this indeed is sooth , that straightway , so soon as [he]2638-the master saw [her]188-audrey , [he]2638-the master fell into the captivity of [her]188-audrey love . Howsoever , gainsay [him]2638-the master [she]188-audrey needs must , and [he]2638-the master took the naysay so hardly that [he]2638-the master was scarce like [a man before [her]188-audrey]5028-a man before her , and wept and prayed and lamented many times over , till [she]188-audrey wearied of it , and well - nigh fell to loathing [him]2638-the master . So that it came to this at last , that one day [she]188-audrey spake to [him]2638-the master and said that [she]188-audrey might no longer bear it , but must seek [another house]5029-another house and leave [his]2638-the master . There then was the to - do , for [he]2638-the master fell on [his]2638-the master knees before [her]188-audrey , and kissed [her]188-audrey feet , would [she]188-audrey , would [she]188-audrey not , and cried out in [his]2638-the master grief , till at last for pure weariness of [his]2638-the master folly [she]188-audrey gave way unto [him]2638-the master , and said that [she]188-audrey would still abide [there]232-there ; whereon [he]2638-the master rose up from [her]188-audrey and went away with all the grief run off [him]2638-the master for that time , and as glad [a man]234-a man to look on as [you]5032-you might see on a summer 's day .

But the next morning [he]2638-the master came unto [her]188-audrey again , and [she]188-audrey thinking all was begun afresh , made [him]2638-the master no glad countenance ; but [he]2638-the master stood up before [her]188-audrey and spake friendly , and said how that [she]188-audrey was in the right of it , and that if [they]5033-they both dwelt in [one house]5034-one house together [they]5033-they were like to have but a weary time of it , both [she]188-audrey and [he]2638-the master . But , said [he]2638-the master , [I]0-i will not that [thou]5035-thou shouldst depart out of [this house]4104-this house , for a goodly one it is , and full meet for [thee]188-audrey ; it is for [me]0-i to depart , and not for [thee]188-audrey . [I]0-i tell [thee]188-audrey , forsooth , that [I]0-i had from the first meant [this house]4104-this house as a gift from [me]0-i to [thee]188-audrey . And therewith [he]2638-the master drew from [his]2638-the master pouch a scroll , which was a deed of gift of [the said house]386-the said house , duly sealed and attested , and [he]2638-the master gave it into [her]188-audrey hands ; but [she]188-audrey was sore moved thereat , and at the demeanour of [him]2638-the master that morning , and [she]188-audrey let the scroll fall to the floor and wept for pity of [him]2638-the master , and reached out both [her]188-audrey hands , and [he]2638-the master kissed them , and then [her]188-audrey lips also , and sithence [he]2638-the master sat down beside [her]188-audrey . But [she]188-audrey said : Alas ! that [thou]188-audrey wilt give [me]0-i what [I]0-i may not take , and wouldst have of [me]0-i what [I]0-i may not give .

But now [he]2638-the master waxed hotter , and said : This once [I]0-i command [thee]188-audrey to do [my]0-i will , and take [my]0-i gift . It will be nought to [my]0-i gain if [thou]188-audrey take it not ; for [I]0-i may not live in [this house]4104-this house when [thou]188-audrey art gone from [it]4104-this house ; and [I]0-i swear by [All - hallows]2944-all - hallows that [I]0-i will not let any have it to hire , nor will [I]0-i sell it , since [thou]188-audrey hast made it holy by dwelling therein .

Yet was [she]188-audrey sore moved by [his]2638-the master generous fashion , and [she]188-audrey said : [I]0-i will take [thy]2638-the master gift then , and live here in honour of [thee]2638-the master and [thy]2638-the master friendship ; for well [I]0-i wot [thou]188-audrey hadst no mind to buy [me]0-i with [thy]2638-the master gift .

So [she]188-audrey spake , and [he]2638-the master stood up stark and stern , and so departed , and kissed [her]188-audrey not again ; though meseems [she]188-audrey would have suffered [him]2638-the master had [he]2638-the master offered it . Nay , belike had [he]2638-the master at that moment pressed [his]2638-the master wooing somewhat masterfully , it is not so sure but [she]188-audrey might have yeasaid it , and suffered [him]2638-the master to [we]5041-we d [her]188-audrey and lead [her]188-audrey to bed ; though it would have gone ill both with [him]2638-the master and with [her]188-audrey thereafter .

Thenceforth dwelt [Birdalone]101-birdalone with [[her]188-audrey mother]332-her mother and [[her]332-her mother maidens]5043-her maidens and [[her]332-her mother men]4824-her men in [that house]1470-that house , and it became famous in the Five Crafts because of [her]188-audrey beauty and [her]188-audrey wisdom , which minished not , but waxed day by day ; but therewithal as the time wore , waxed [her]188-audrey longing and sadness . But all this [she]188-audrey hid in [her]188-audrey own heart , and was debonair to all about [her]188-audrey , and so good to [poor folk]292-poor folk that [none]1226-none had a word save of blessing on [her]188-audrey beauty and [her]188-audrey wisdom .

CHAPTER V. OF THE DEATH OF [AUDREY]188-audrey , [MOTHER]740-mother TO [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone . [SHE]188-audrey IS WARNED IN A DREAM TO SEEK [THE BLACK SQUIRE]125-arthur , AND IS MINDED TO [DEPART]73-depart [THE CITY OF THE FIVE CRAFTS]4756-the city of the five crafts , AND SEEK AGAIN [THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST]1931-the castle of the quest

Thus dwelt [Birdalone]101-birdalone in [the Five Crafts]71-the five crafts in such rest and peace as [her]101-birdalone heart would let [her]101-birdalone ; and dear and good friends [she]101-birdalone had about [her]101-birdalone ; [[her]101-birdalone mother]332-her mother first , whose love and desire for love of [her]101-birdalone made all things soft and dear unto [her]101-birdalone . [Gerard]187-gerard and [the Gerardsons]5052-the gerardsons were next , who were ever faithful and true unto [her]101-birdalone , and deft both of hand and of mind , so that [they]5053-they wrought many things for [her]101-birdalone avail . Then came [the master]2638-the master , [Jacobus]185-jacobus , who held [himself]185-jacobus unwedded for [her]101-birdalone sake , and though [he]185-jacobus no longer dwelt in [the same house]5055-the same house with [her]101-birdalone , might scarce endure to miss the sight of [her]101-birdalone for two days running : a dear friend [she]101-birdalone deemed [him]185-jacobus , as forsooth [he]185-jacobus was , though whiles [he]185-jacobus tormented and wearied [her]101-birdalone , and belike had wearied [her]101-birdalone more , but for the sorrow which lay on [her]101-birdalone own heart , whereof it came that [she]101-birdalone might not think of [any man]2089-any man as of one who might be [a lover]543-a lover , and so felt safe even with so kind [a friend]520-a friend and so stubborn in [his]185-jacobus love as was [this one]399-this one . Moreover [he]185-jacobus never again craved love of [her]101-birdalone in so many words , but only in [his]185-jacobus goings and comings so did , that it was clear how [he]185-jacobus had [her]101-birdalone , and the love of [her]101-birdalone , ever in [his]185-jacobus heart .

Wore thus a five years ; and then came a sickness on [the city]4831-the city , and [many died thereof]5061-many died thereof ; and the said sickness entered into [[Birdalone]101-birdalone 's house]5062-birdalone 's house , and slew [Audrey]188-audrey [[her]188-audrey mother]332-her mother , but spared all else therein . Thereby at the first was [Birdalone]101-birdalone so overwhelmed that [she]101-birdalone might heed nought , neither [her]101-birdalone craft nor [[her]101-birdalone friends]1314-her friends , nor the days to come on [the earth]445-the earth for [her]101-birdalone . And moreover when [she]101-birdalone came more to [herself]101-birdalone , which was not for many days , and asked why [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend [Jacobus]185-jacobus had not been to see [her]101-birdalone the last days , [she]101-birdalone was told that [he]185-jacobus also was dead of the pestilence ; and [she]101-birdalone sorrowed for [him]185-jacobus sorely , for [she]101-birdalone loved [him]185-jacobus much , though not in the way [he]185-jacobus would .

And now did [[the city]4831-the city and land of [the Five Crafts]4777-the five crafts]5068-the city and land of the five crafts begin to look unfriendly to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone fell to thinking that [she]101-birdalone must needs depart thence , as [she]101-birdalone well might do , whereas [she]101-birdalone had foison of goods : and at first it was in [her]101-birdalone mind to go with [Gerard]187-gerard and [[his]187-gerard sons]4698-his sons unto [Utterhay]3-utterhay ; but then [she]101-birdalone deemed the thought of [[her]101-birdalone mother]332-her mother , and how [she]101-birdalone would be ever thinking of the loss and the gain , and the loss once more stood in the way ; and [she]101-birdalone turned one thing and another over in [her]101-birdalone mind , and might not face it .

On a night , as [she]101-birdalone slept , came to [her]101-birdalone dreams of [her]101-birdalone days in [the House under the Wood]2453-the house under the wood as very seldom betid , and [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife was speaking to [her]101-birdalone in friendly fashion as for [her]101-birdalone and blaming [her]101-birdalone for fleeing away , and was taunting [her]101-birdalone with the failure of [her]101-birdalone love , and therewith telling [her]101-birdalone how fair [a man]234-a man and [lovesome]5075-lovesome was [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire , and what a loss [she]101-birdalone had of [him]234-a man ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone was hearkening and weeping for tenderness ' sake , while [the witch]407-the witch was unto [her]101-birdalone neither fearful nor irksome , and forsooth nought save a mouthpiece for words that both grieved [Birdalone]101-birdalone and yet were an eager pleasure unto [her]101-birdalone . But in the midst thereof , and ere the dream had time to change , [Birdalone]101-birdalone awoke , and it was an early morning of later spring , and the sky was clear blue and the sun shining bright , and the birds singing in [the garden of [the house]325-the house]7153-the garden of the house , and in [the street]287-the street was the sound of [the early market - folk]7156-the early market - folk passing through [the street]287-the street with [their]7156-the early market - folk wares ; and all was fresh and lovely .[101-birdalone]

[She]101-birdalone awoke sobbing , and the pillow was wet with [her]101-birdalone tears , and yet [she]101-birdalone felt as if something strange and joyous were going to betide [her]101-birdalone , and for joy of the love of life the heart beat fast in [her]101-birdalone bosom .

[She]101-birdalone arose all darling naked as [she]101-birdalone was , and went to the window and looked out on the beauty of [the spring]5077-the spring , while the sound of the market - wains brought to [her]101-birdalone mind the thought of the meads , and [the streams of [the river]2277-the river]5078-the streams of the river , and [the woodsides]5080-the woodsides beyond [the city]4831-the city ; and [she]101-birdalone fell a - longing for [them]5082-them , as a while [she]101-birdalone knelt on the window - seat , half dreaming and asleep again , till the sun came round that way , and its beams fell upon [her]101-birdalone bosom and [her]101-birdalone arms ; and [she]101-birdalone stood up and looked on the fairness of [her]101-birdalone body , and a great desire took hold of [her]101-birdalone heart that it might be loved as it deserved by [him]5083-him whom [she]101-birdalone desired . And thus [she]101-birdalone stood [there]232-there till [she]101-birdalone became ashamed , and hastened to do on [her]101-birdalone raiment ; but even as [she]101-birdalone was about it , it came upon [her]101-birdalone that what [she]101-birdalone had will to do was to seek to [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest , and find out where was [her]101-birdalone love if there [he]5083-him were not , and so to seek [him]5083-him [the world]430-the world over till [she]101-birdalone found [him]5083-him . And such a flood of joy possessed [her]101-birdalone when [she]101-birdalone thought this , and so eager to begone [she]101-birdalone was , that [she]101-birdalone deemed every minute wasted till [she]101-birdalone were on [the road]2103-the road .

Nevertheless , in a while , when [her]101-birdalone mind was steadied , [she]101-birdalone knew that [she]101-birdalone had somewhat to do ere [she]101-birdalone might be gone , and that here , as oft , it would be more haste less speed .

So [she]101-birdalone abode a little , and then came into [[her]101-birdalone hall]2481-her hall duly dight , and found [Gerard]187-gerard and [[his]187-gerard sons]4698-his sons there to serve [her]101-birdalone ; and [she]101-birdalone brake [her]101-birdalone fast , and bade [them]5090-them sit by [her]101-birdalone at table , as oft [she]101-birdalone did ; and [she]101-birdalone spake to [them]5090-them of this and that , and [Gerard]187-gerard answered lightly again ; but [the two Gerardsons]5091-the two gerardsons looked at [one another]2289-one another , as though [they]5091-the two gerardsons would speak and ask a question from time to time , but forbore because [they]5091-the two gerardsons durst not . But [Gerard]187-gerard looked on [them]5090-them , and deemed [he]187-gerard wotted what was in [their]5090-them minds ; so at last [he]187-gerard spake : [[Our]5093-our lady]488-our lady , both [I]0-i , and meseemeth [[my]0-i sons]4773-my sons also , deem that there is some tidings toward which are great unto [thee]488-our lady ; for thine eyes sparkle , and the red burns in [thy]488-our lady cheeks , and thine hands may not be quiet , nor [thy]488-our lady feet abide in one place ; wherefore [I]0-i see that [thou]488-our lady hast something in [thy]488-our lady mind which strives to be forth of it . Now [thou]488-our lady wilt pardon [us]5093-our , [[our]5093-our dear lady]5096-our dear lady , that [we]5093-our ask concerning this , because it is in [our]5093-our love for [thee]488-our lady that [we]5093-our speak , lest there be some change toward which shall be a grief to [some of [us]5093-our]5097-some of us .

[[My]0-i men]5098-my men , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , flushing red , sooth it is that there is a change at hand , and [I]0-i shall tell [you]5098-my men straightway what it is . Years ago [I]0-i told [you]5098-my men that [I]0-i was fleeing from [[my]0-i friends]2100-my friends ; now the change hath betid that [I]0-i would seek [them]2100-my friends again ; and needs must [I]0-i leave [the Five Crafts]4777-the five crafts behind to do so . And moreover there is this ill word to be said , which [I]0-i will say at once , to wit , that when [I]0-i am but a little way gone from the Five Crafts [I]0-i must wend the other deal of [my]0-i journey birdalone , as [my]0-i name is .

[All those three]5101-all those three sat silent and aghast at that word , and [the young men]2410-the young men grew pale ; but after a while spake [Gerard]187-gerard : [[Our]5103-our lady]488-our lady most well- beloved , this word which [thou]5105-thou hast spoken , to wit , that [thou]5105-thou needest [us]5103-our no longer , [I]0-i have looked to hear any time this five years ; and praise be to [the saints that it hath come late and not soon]5106-the saints that it hath come late and not soon . Now there is no more to be said but that [thou]5105-thou tell [us]5103-our what is [thy]5105-thou will that [we]5103-our should do .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone hung [her]101-birdalone head awhile for sorrow of sundering from [these men]2990-these men ; then [she]101-birdalone looked up and said : It seemeth , [[my]0-i friends]2100-my friends , as if [ye]2990-these men deem [I]0-i have done [you]2990-these men a wrong in sundering [our]5103-our fellowship ; but all [I]0-i may say hereon is to pray [you]2990-these men to pardon [me]0-i , that [I]0-i needs must go alone on [my]0-i quest . And now what [I]0-i would have [you]2990-these men do , is first of all to fetch hither [a notary and scrivener]5109-a notary and scrivener , that [he]5109-a notary and scrivener may draw up a deed of gift to [you]2990-these men , [Gerard]187-gerard and [Gerardsons]189-gerardsons , of [this house]4104-this house and all that is therein , saving what money [I]0-i may need for [my]0-i journey , and gifts such as [I]0-i shall bid [you]2990-these men to be given to [[my]0-i workwomen]5111-my workwomen . [Ye]2990-these men must needs [yeasay]5112-yeasay this , or [ye]2990-these men are forsworn of [your]2990-these men behest to do [my]0-i will . But furthermore , [I]0-i will have [you]2990-these men to let [the workwomen of mine]5113-the workwomen of mine and [the head one]5114-the head one ruling to hire [the aforesaid house]5115-the aforesaid house , if so [they]5113-the workwomen of mine will ; for now are [they]5113-the workwomen of mine skilled , and may well earn good livelihood by the work . But the next work is simple ; it is to furnish for [me]0-i the array of [a young man]5116-a young man , with such armour as [I]0-i may easily bear , to dight [me]0-i for [[my]0-i road]5117-my road . Forsooth [ye]2990-these men wot that not unseldom do [women]433-women use the custom of going arrayed like [men]219-men , when [they]433-women would journey with hidden head ; and [ye]2990-these men may happen upon such gear as hath been made for [such a woman]5120-such a woman rather than [any man]2089-any man ; but [thou]5122-thou shalt get [me]0-i also a short bow and a quiver of arrows , for verily these be [my]0-i proper weapons that [I]0-i can deal with deftly . Now [my]0-i last command is that , when all is done , maybe to - morrow , or maybe the next day , [ye]2990-these men bring [me]0-i out of [the city]4831-the city and the frank of the Five Crafts , and bring [me]0-i somewhat on [my]0-i way over [the downs]5124-the downs , for [loth]5125-loth am [I]0-i to part from [you]2990-these men ere needs must . Then [they]2990-these men knelt before [her]5120-such a woman and kissed [her]5120-such a woman hands , and [they]2990-these men were full of grief ; but [they]2990-these men saw that so it had to be .

Thereafter [Gerard]187-gerard spake with [[his]187-gerard sons]4698-his sons apart , and in a while came to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and said : [[Our]5127-we lady]488-our lady , [we]5127-we will do [your]5120-such a woman will in all wise ; but [we]5127-we shall tell [thee]5120-such a woman , that the Five Crafts will look but strange to [us]5127-we when [thou]5129-thou art gone , and that [we]5127-we have a mind to betake [us]5127-we to [Utterhay]3-utterhay and the land of [[our]5127-we kindred]5130-our kindred . Wherefore [we]5127-we pray [thee]5120-such a woman to give [this house that hath been so dear to [us]5127-we]5131-this house that hath been so dear to us unto [[thy]5120-such a woman workwoman]5132-thy workwoman and [[her]5132-thy workwoman mates]5133-her mates ; for [we]5127-we need it not , nor the hire thereof , but shall do well enough with what money or good [thou]5129-thou mayst give [us]5127-we . Is this according to [thy]5120-such a woman will , or have [I]0-i spoken rashly ?

[She]0-i said : [Ye]5134-ye are good and ungreedy , and [I]0-i bless [you]5134-ye for it ; be it as [ye]5134-ye will ; and this the more , as [I]0-i were fain that [ye]5134-ye go to [Utterhay]3-utterhay ; for whiles [I]0-i have deemed that [I]0-i [myself]0-i am drawn thitherward , wherefore it may be that [we]5127-we shall meet again in [that place]645-that place .

And when [she]0-i had so spoken , [she]0-i might not refrain [her]0-i tears ; and [the Gerardsons]189-gerardsons turned away , for [they]189-gerardsons were ashamed , both that [they]189-gerardsons should see [her]0-i weep , or [she]0-i [them]189-gerardsons . But at last [she]0-i called to [them]189-gerardsons and said : Now make [we]5127-we the speediest end [we]5127-we may of this , for sorry work is the tarrying of farewell ; so [I]0-i pray [you]189-gerardsons , [[my]0-i friends]2100-my friends , to go about the work [I]0-i have bidden [you]189-gerardsons .

So all was done as [she]0-i would , and the day after the morrow was [Birdalone]101-birdalone abiding the coming of [Gerard]187-gerard and [[his]187-gerard sons]4698-his sons with the horses ; and despite of the sundering of [friends]416-friends and the perils that belike lay before [her]0-i , [the world]430-the world seemed fair to [her]0-i , and life beginning anew . And [she]0-i made no doubt that [she]0-i would soon be at [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest , and there find all things much as [she]0-i had left [them]5141-them ; and there at least would be the welcome of [[her]0-i dear friend]5142-her dear friend [Viridis]116-viridis .

CHAPTER VI . OF THE SUNDERING OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone FROM [GERARD]187-gerard AND [[HIS]187-gerard SONS]4698-his sons

Presently were the horses come with [Gerard]187-gerard and [[his]187-gerard sons]4698-his sons , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone gat to horse amongst [them]5145-them . [She]0-i was armed in a light hauberk , and over it a long and loose surcoat that came down beneath the knee of [her]0-i ; and a sallet [she]0-i had upon [her]0-i head , wide but light , so that not very much of [her]0-i face was to be seen . [She]0-i had made up [her]0-i mind to this tale upon [the road]2103-the road , when [she]0-i was among [folk]1529-folk , that [she]0-i was under a vow not to do off [her]0-i helm for a seven days ' space . Withal [she]0-i had covered up the lovely shapeliness of [her]0-i legs with long boots of deer - leather , and [her]0-i surcoat was wide - sleeved ; [she]0-i was well hidden , and whereas [she]0-i was [a tall and strong woman]7158-a tall and strong woman , [she]0-i might well pass for [a young man]5116-a young man , slender and fair - faced . [She]0-i was girt with a good sword , and [Gerard]187-gerard had gotten [her]0-i [a strong horseman]7160-a strong horseman 's bow and a quiver full of arrows , wherewith , as aforesaid , [she]0-i knew well how to deal ; wherefore [she]0-i was by no means without defence .[0-i]

So [they]5148-they went [their]5148-they ways through [the streets]4674-the streets and out - a - gates ; and it must be said , that were not [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's thoughts turned toward [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest , and what [she]101-birdalone should meet [there]232-there , [her]101-birdalone heart had been somewhat sore at leaving [the city]4831-the city which had cherished [her]101-birdalone so well these years past ; nay , as it was , the shadow of the southern gate , as [she]101-birdalone past thereunder , smote somewhat cold upon [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone silently bade farewell to [the City of the Five Crafts]4756-the city of the five crafts with some sorrow , though with no fear .

Forth [they]5148-they rode then through [the frank]4830-the frank and up on to [the shepherd country]5155-the shepherd country , and whereas [their]5148-they horses were of the best , and [they]5148-they had no sumpter - beast with [them]5148-they till [they]5148-they came to [Upham]68-upham , where [they]5148-they must needs have victual , [they]5148-they made but five days of it to [the place where [the road]2103-the road turned aside from [the country of Mostwyke]5158-the country of mostwyke]5156-the place where the road turned aside from the country of mostwyke . There then [they]5148-they drew rein , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone lighted down from [her]101-birdalone horse , and [they]5148-they all , and [they]5148-they lay upon the grass and ate and drank together .

But when [they]5148-they were done , [spake Birdalone]101-birdalone and said : [Dear friends]1325-dear friends , this is the hour and the place when [we]5148-they must needs part ; for [ye]1325-dear friends shall go back again to [Five Crafts]5160-five crafts , and do what [I]0-i have bidden of [you]1325-dear friends , and do [your]1325-dear friends will , and wend [your]1325-dear friends ways with [your]1325-dear friends livelihood unto [Utterhay]3-utterhay . But as for [me]0-i , [I]0-i must go [my]0-i ways first unto [Greenford]45-greenford , and thence to seek [[my]0-i friends from whom erst [I]0-i was fleeing when [ye]1325-dear friends first became [my]0-i friends]5161-my friends from whom erst i was fleeing when ye first became my friends . Now perchance [ye]1325-dear friends will say that [I]0-i have taken [you]1325-dear friends up in [my]0-i need , and cast [you]1325-dear friends aside at [my]0-i pleasure ; but [I]0-i may only say that there be at present two deals of [my]0-i life , and of one of them have [ye]1325-dear friends been partakers , and of the other [ye]1325-dear friends may not be . Forsooth that is a grief unto [me]0-i , as [I]0-i suppose unto [you]1325-dear friends is it a greater one . But unto [me]0-i also were it heavier but that [my]0-i heart tells [me]0-i it shall not ever be so ; for as [I]0-i said to [you]1325-dear friends some days agone , [I]0-i have a hope that [we]5162-we shall yet meet again , be it in [Utterhay]3-utterhay or in [some other place]5163-some other place . And now [I]0-i pray [you]1325-dear friends to pardon [me]0-i wherein [I]0-i may have done amiss unto [you]1325-dear friends , and begrudge it not that there be [others , who indeed were first- comers]5164-others , who indeed were first- comers in regard to [you]1325-dear friends , and whom [I]0-i love better than [you]1325-dear friends ; for of [your]1325-dear friends truth and [your]1325-dear friends good - will and loving - kindness will [I]0-i bear witness wheresoever [I]0-i may be .

Then spake [Gerard]187-gerard : Do [ye]1325-dear friends speak , [[my]0-i sons]4773-my sons ; for [I]0-i have no grudge against [her]5166-thee , nor aught to bewail [me]0-i as to [her]5166-thee , save , it may be , that [I]0-i am now so well on in years that it may well befall that [I]0-i shall not live till the time of the meeting in [Utterhay]3-utterhay . But [I]0-i will pray [thee]5166-thee this , [dear lady]4913-dear lady , that if [thou]5168-thou come to the place where [I]0-i lie dead [thou]5168-thou wilt kiss [my]0-i burial - stone , and sing due masses for [me]0-i . Nay , [she]5166-thee said , but this is the worst shall betide betwixt [us]5169-us .

Then spake [Robert Gerardson]181-robert : [I]0-i am not deft of speech , but this parting makes [me]0-i bold to say this : that from the time when first [I]0-i set eyes on [thee]5166-thee [I]0-i have loved [thee]5166-thee in such wise that never mayst [thou]5168-thou love [me]0-i as much as [I]0-i love [thee]5166-thee , if [thou]5168-thou hast anywhere , as [I]0-i deem [thou]5168-thou hast , [a lover of [thy]5168-thou body , whom [thou]5168-thou lovest]5170-a lover of thy body , whom thou lovest . Now [I]0-i have seen that for a long while [thou]5168-thou hast known this , and hast ever because of it been as meek and kind with [me]0-i as [thou]5168-thou mightest be . And this hath partly grieved [me]0-i the more , because it hath eked [my]0-i longing for [thee]5166-thee ; and yet it hath comforted [me]0-i the more , because it hath made [me]0-i deem better of [thee]5166-thee , and deem [thee]5166-thee worthier of worship and holier ; therefore have [thou]5166-thee all [my]0-i blessing for it . And now [I]0-i know that [thou]5168-thou sunderest from [us]5171-we that [thou]5168-thou mayst go seek [thy]5168-thou very bodily lover ; and [I]0-i say , that if the sundering had been for any lighter cause , grieved at heart should [I]0-i have been ; but since it is even so , once more [I]0-i bless [thee]5166-thee , and ever shall [I]0-i be happy in the thought of [thee]5166-thee ; and if ever [we]5171-we meet again , still shalt [thou]5168-thou find [me]0-i as now [I]0-i am in heart and in soul .

[She]0-i turned to [him]5172-he , not dry - eyed , and said : [I]0-i know that what [thou]5168-thou sayest is sooth ; and [thou]5168-thou hast guessed right as to [my]0-i goings ; and [I]0-i take [thy]5168-thou blessing with love and joy .

Then were [they]5173-they silent ; but [Giles Gerardson]182-giles gerardson was struggling with words , for [he]5172-he was slow to speech ; at last [he]5172-he said : [I]0-i say much as saith [[my]0-i brother]4044-my brother : but see [thou]5166-thee , [[our]5171-we lady]488-our lady , how ill it had gone if [thou]5168-thou hadst loved one of [us]5171-we with an equal love ; woe worth the strife then ! But now [I]0-i will crave this of [thee]5166-thee , that [thou]5168-thou kiss [me]0-i on the lips , now whenas [we]5171-we part ; and again , that [thou]5168-thou wilt do as much when first [we]5171-we meet again hereafter . And [I]0-i tell [thee]5166-thee right out , that if [thou]5168-thou gainsay this , [I]0-i shall deem it unfriendly in [thee]5166-thee , and that those lovely words which [thou]5168-thou didst speak e'en now were but words alone , and that [thou]5168-thou art not as true as [I]0-i have deemed [thee]5166-thee .

[She]0-i laughed amidst [her]0-i tears , and said : [Dear lad]5176-dear lad , doom [me]0-i not till [I]0-i have been found guilty ! [I]0-i shall nowise naysay [thee]5166-thee this , for [I]0-i love [thee]5166-thee , and now and ever shalt [thou]5168-thou be unto [me]0-i as [a brother]5177-a brother , [thou]5168-thou and [Robert]181-robert also ; for even so have [ye]5166-thee done by [me]0-i . But [thou]5168-thou wottest , [dear lad]5176-dear lad , that whiles and again must [sister]118-sister sunder from [brother]2145-brother , and even so it has to be now .

Then [they]5180-they sat silent all four ; and thereafter [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose and did off [her]101-birdalone sallet , and kissed and embraced [Gerard]187-gerard and [[his]187-gerard sons]4698-his sons , and bade [them]5180-they farewell , and [she]101-birdalone and [the young men]2410-the young men wept . Then [she]101-birdalone armed [herself]101-birdalone and gat to horse , and went [her]101-birdalone ways towards [Greenford]45-greenford , having nought with [her]101-birdalone but the raiment and arms that [her]101-birdalone body bore , and [her]101-birdalone horse , and some gold pieces and gems in a little pouch . So rode [she]101-birdalone ; and [the others]1301-the others turned back sadly toward [the Five Crafts]4777-the five crafts .

CHAPTER VII . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone COMETH TO [GREENFORD]45-greenford , AND HEARS OF THE WASTING OF [THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST]59-the castle of the quest

Now came [Birdalone]101-birdalone riding into [Greenford]45-greenford an hour before sunset on a day of the latter end of May ; and [she]101-birdalone had no doubt but to go straight to [the hostelry]4894-the hostelry , and that the less as [she]101-birdalone had not abided [there]232-there before , as hath been told . To [them]5187-them that served [her]101-birdalone [she]101-birdalone told the tale of [her]101-birdalone vow , that [she]101-birdalone might not do off [her]101-birdalone sallet that seven days ; and [some]229-some trowed [her]101-birdalone , and [some]229-some deemed [her]101-birdalone [a woman]250-a woman , but whereas [she]101-birdalone seemed by [her]101-birdalone raiment to be of condition [none]1226-none meddled with [her]101-birdalone . Moreover , as [she]101-birdalone told [her]101-birdalone intent to ride on betimes in the morning , it mattered the less unto [them]5187-them : withal [she]101-birdalone gave out that [she]101-birdalone came from foreign parts , as sooth it was .

In the evening [she]101-birdalone sat in [the hall]1202-the hall , and with [her]101-birdalone were [three chapmen]5193-three chapmen travelling with [their]5193-three chapmen wares , and [two good men of [the town]319-the town]5194-two good men of the town sitting ; and [they]5193-three chapmen were talking together , and were courteous and blithe , and amidst [their]5193-three chapmen talk [they]5193-three chapmen threw many a glance at [the slim and fair young squire]5196-the slim and fair young squire , as [Birdalone]101-birdalone seemed , and were fain to speak unto [him]5196-the slim and fair young squire , but refrained [them]5193-three chapmen for courtesy 's sake . For [her]101-birdalone part , [Birdalone]101-birdalone longed sore to ask [them]5187-them somewhat of [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest , but the words clave to [her]101-birdalone throat for very fear ; and [she]101-birdalone sat restless and ill at ease . However at last said [a townsman]5198-a townsman to [a chapman]5199-a chapman : Art [thou]5200-thou for [the Red Hold]49-the red hold , [Master Peter]191-master peter , when [thou]5200-thou art done here ? [Birdalone]101-birdalone turned very pale at that word ; and [Master Peter spake]191-master peter : [Yea]5201-yea , surely , [neighbour]5202-neighbour , if [the folk]244-the folk leave aught in [my]0-i packs for [others]2441-others to buy . [He]191-master peter spake in a jovial voice , as if [he]191-master peter were merry , and [the others]1301-the others all laughed together , as though [they]1301-the others were well pleased and in good contentment . And now , deemed [Birdalone]101-birdalone , would be [her]101-birdalone time to speak if [she]101-birdalone would learn aught ; so [she]101-birdalone constrained [herself]101-birdalone at last , and spake , though in a quavering voice : Meseems then , [masters]5206-masters , [this good town]5207-this good town is thriving as now ? This [I]0-i ask because [I]0-i am a stranger in [these parts]5208-these parts this long while , and now [I]0-i am come back hither fain were [I]0-i to find [the land]213-the land in good peace ; for [I]0-i may chance to take up [[my]0-i abode hereby]5210-my abode hereby .

[The goodmen]5211-the goodmen turned to [her]101-birdalone and smiled kindly when [they]5211-the goodmen heard the sweetness of [her]101-birdalone voice ; and [one of [them]5211-the goodmen]5212-one of them said : [Sir of the sallet]5213-sir of the sallet , [ye]5213-sir of the sallet shall be content with the peace in [this land]1264-this land , and the thriving of [[its]1264-this land folk]5215-its folk ; the very villeins hereabout live as well as franklins in [most lands]5216-most lands , and [the yeomen and vavassours]5217-the yeomen and vavassours are clad as if [they]5217-the yeomen and vavassours were [knights of [[a good lord]5219-a good lord 's household]5220-a good lord 's household]5218-knights of a good lord 's household . Forsooth [[their]5217-the yeomen and vavassours houses]5221-their houses are both goodly and easy to enter ; and well is that , whereas there lacks never good meat and drink on the board therein . And moreover [[their]5217-the yeomen and vavassours women]5222-their women are for ever seeking whatso is fair and goodly , whatso is far - fetched and dear - bought , whereof [we]5223-we chapmen also thrive , as [thou]5224-thou mayst well deem . Ah ! it is [a goodly land]5225-a goodly land now !

[The others]1301-the others nodded and smiled . But [Birdalone]101-birdalone spake , hardening [her]101-birdalone heart thereto for very need : Belike then there is a change of days here , for when [I]0-i last knew of [the land]213-the land there was little peace therein . And that will not be so long agone , said [a townsman]5198-a townsman , smiling , for [I]0-i doubt [we]5223-we should see no grey hair in thine head if [thy]5224-thou sallet were off it . [Birdalone]101-birdalone reddened : It will be some five years agone , said [she]101-birdalone . [Yea]5229-yea , yea , said [the townsman]5230-the townsman , [we]5223-we were beginning to end the unpeace then , and it was the darkest hour before the dawn ; for five years agone [we]5223-we and [the good knights of the Castle of the Quest]5231-the good knights of the castle of the quest were lying before the walls of [the Red Hold]49-the red hold . Forsooth [we]5223-we cleared out that den of devils then and there . What betid unto it after [ye]5230-the townsman won it ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone trembled withal . Said [the townsman]5230-the townsman : Heard [ye]101-birdalone never of [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire , [a very valiant knight]5234-a very valiant knight , since [thou]5235-thou sayest that [thou]5235-thou hast known [this country - side]2049-this country - side ? [She]101-birdalone bowed a yeasay , for this time [she]101-birdalone found it hard to speak .

Well , said [the townsman]5230-the townsman , [we]5223-we held garrison in [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold for some three months , and thereafter [we]5223-we craved of [him]1334-the black squire to come and be [[our]5223-we captain]5239-our captain therein ; for , even after the Hold was won , there was yet a sort of runagates that haunted [the country - side]2227-the country - side , [men who had no craft save lifting and slaying]5241-men who had no craft save lifting and slaying . And forsooth [we]5223-we knew [this Lord Arthur]192-this lord arthur for the keenest and deftest of [men - at - arms]2059-men - at - arms ; so [he]192-this lord arthur yeasaid [our]5223-we asking , and did all [he]192-this lord arthur might herein , and forsooth that was all there was to do ; for [he]192-this lord arthur was ever in the saddle , and at the work . [Forsooth]101-birdalone [he]192-this lord arthur was not [a merry man]5243-a merry man , save when [he]192-this lord arthur was at [his]192-this lord arthur busiest ; and little [he]192-this lord arthur spake in [hall]5244-hall or [chamber]4176-chamber , else had [he]192-this lord arthur been better beloved . But at least by [no man]545-no man better might [the land]213-the land have been served .

There was silence a little , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone waxed deadly pale ; then [she]101-birdalone strove with [herself]101-birdalone and said : [Thou]5248-thou sayest [he]192-this lord arthur was and [he]192-this lord arthur was ; is [he]192-this lord arthur dead then ? Said [the townsman]5230-the townsman : Not to [our]5250-our knowledge . When [he]192-this lord arthur had brought [the land]213-the land into good peace , which is some three years and a half agone , [he]192-this lord arthur went [his]192-this lord arthur ways from [the Red Hold all alone]5252-the red hold all alone , and [we]5250-our saw [him]192-this lord arthur no more . But [some folk]5253-some folk deem that [he]192-this lord arthur hath entered into religion .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone 's heart sickened , and [she]101-birdalone thought to [herself]101-birdalone that now all was to begin again ; yet [she]101-birdalone felt that the worst was over since [he]192-this lord arthur was not dead , and [she]101-birdalone was able to think what [she]101-birdalone should do . So [she]101-birdalone said : Mayhappen [he]192-this lord arthur hath gone back to [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest ? Nay , nay , said [the townsman]5230-the townsman , that may not be ; for waste is [that house]1470-that house now ; there is none dwelleth there , save , it may be , now and again [a wandering carle or carline]5257-a wandering carle or carline abideth there a day or two . Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : How hath that befallen ? or where is gone [Sir Hugh]124-hugh , [the Green Knight]1331-the green knight ? Said [the townsman]5230-the townsman : [We]5260-we knew [the Green Knight]124-hugh well ; frank and free and joyous was [he]124-hugh ; [all men]228-all men loved [him]124-hugh ; and [[his]124-hugh lady]1388-his lady and speech - friend , [none]1226-none ever saw [a lovelier]5264-a lovelier , and as kind as was [he]124-hugh . But [we]5260-we might not keep [them]5265-them with [us]5260-we ; [they]5265-them are gone into [[their]5265-them own country]5266-their own country . [Sir Hugh]124-hugh left [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest some three months after [the Black Squire]125-arthur came to [us]5260-we for [captain]3358-captain , and [he]124-hugh gave over [the castle]1838-the castle to [Sir Geoffrey of Lea]172-sir geoffrey of lea , [an old and wise man of war]4572-an old and wise man of war . But not many months thereafter [we]5260-we heard that [he]124-hugh also had departed , leaving it ungarnished of [men]219-men ; and [we]5260-we deem that the cause thereof is that something uncouth is seen and heard therein , which [folk]1529-folk may not endure . Is it not so , [[my]0-i masters]5273-my masters ?

[They]5273-my masters all yeasaid that , and the talk went on to other matters . As for [Birdalone]101-birdalone , though [her]101-birdalone hope to come amongst [friends]416-friends was so utterly overthrown , yet [she]101-birdalone saw not what to do save to go [her]101-birdalone ways to [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest , and see if perchance [she]101-birdalone might find any tidings there . And [she]101-birdalone said to [herself]101-birdalone , that if the worst came to the worst , [she]101-birdalone would [herself]101-birdalone dwell [there]232-there as [an hermit of love]5277-an hermit of love ; or , maybe , to face those uncouth things and see if any tidings might be compelled out of them .

CHAPTER VIII . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone COMETH TO [THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST]1931-the castle of the quest , HEARETH THE TALE THEREOF FROM [LEONARD]137-leonard , AND DEPARTETH THENCE BY THE SENDING BOAT
