[She]101-birdalone arose betimes on the morrow , and was out of [Greenford]45-greenford so soon as the gates were open , and at first made all speed that [she]101-birdalone might toward [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest ; and nothing hindered [her]101-birdalone , for [the land]213-the land was verily in good peace , and [she]101-birdalone might have come [there]232-there if [she]101-birdalone would before sunset , for all whom [she]101-birdalone met furthered [her]101-birdalone . But as the day waned [her]101-birdalone courage waned with it , so that at last [she]101-birdalone stayed some six miles short of [the house]325-the house , and craved shelter at [[a yeoman]5283-a yeoman 's stead there]5284-a yeoman 's stead there , which was granted [her]101-birdalone with all kindness ; and [they]5283-a yeoman made much of [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone told [them]5283-a yeoman [her]101-birdalone vow of the sallet , and [they]5283-a yeoman deemed nought save that [she]101-birdalone was [a young man]5116-a young man .

[She]101-birdalone departed early in the morning with [their]5283-a yeoman God - speed , and while the day was yet young came into [the meadows before [the castle]1838-the castle]5286-the meadows before the castle , and saw the towers thereof rising up before [her]101-birdalone : then [she]101-birdalone checked [her]101-birdalone horse , and rode on no faster than a foot 's pace ; yet as slow as [she]101-birdalone might ride , needs must [she]101-birdalone get to the gate while the day was yet young .

So came [Birdalone]101-birdalone by that bower wherein [she]101-birdalone had slept that first night [she]101-birdalone came to [the castle]1838-the castle ; and [she]101-birdalone reined up to look on [it]5289-it ; and as [she]101-birdalone sat there gazing , came [a man]234-a man out from it clad as [a man of religion]5291-a man of religion ; and [her]101-birdalone heart beat quick , and [she]101-birdalone was like to fall from [her]101-birdalone horse , for there came into [her]101-birdalone mind what [the townsman]5230-the townsman had said , that [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire had gone into religion . But [the hermit]5294-the hermit came towards [her]101-birdalone with a cup of water in [his]5294-the hermit hand , and [he]5294-the hermit cast [his]5294-the hermit hood aback from [him]5294-the hermit , and [she]101-birdalone saw at once that it was [Leonard]137-leonard [the priest]1984-the priest , and though it was not [the friend whom [she]101-birdalone sought]5296-the friend whom she sought , yet was [she]101-birdalone glad that it was [a friend]520-a friend ; but [he]5294-the hermit came and stood by [her]101-birdalone , and said : Hail , [wayfarer]1241-wayfarer ! wilt [thou]5299-thou drink of [our]5300-our well and rest [thee]5299-thou a while ? So [she]101-birdalone took the cup and drank of the water , looking kindly on [him]5294-the hermit , while [he]5294-the hermit wondered at the beauty of [her]101-birdalone hand , and misdoubted [him]5294-the hermit . Then [she]101-birdalone gave [him]5294-the hermit back the cup and lighted down off [her]101-birdalone horse , and took the sallet from [her]101-birdalone head , and spake : [I]0-i may not pass by [a friend]520-a friend without a word ; think if [thou]5299-thou hast not seen [me]0-i before ?

Then [he]5294-the hermit knew [her]101-birdalone , and might not refrain [him]5294-the hermit , but cast [his]5294-the hermit arms about [her]101-birdalone and kissed [her]101-birdalone , weeping ; and [she]101-birdalone said : It is sweet to [me]0-i to find [a friend]520-a friend after what [I]0-i have been told of [yonder house]1484-yonder house . [Yea]5304-yea , said [he]5294-the hermit , and art [thou]5299-thou going up thither ? [Certes]146-certes , said [she]101-birdalone , and why not ? Said [he]5294-the hermit : [They]5305-they are gone , and all gone ! How and whither ? said [she]101-birdalone . But [I]0-i must full certainly go thither at once ; [I]0-i will go afoot with [thee]101-birdalone ; do [thou]5299-thou tether [my]0-i horse till [thou]101-birdalone comest back .

[He]5294-the hermit said : But wilt not [thou]101-birdalone come back ? [I]0-i know not , [she]101-birdalone said : [I]0-i know nought save that [I]0-i would go thither ; let it be enough that [I]0-i suffer [thee]101-birdalone to go with [me]0-i , and on the way [thou]101-birdalone shalt tell [me]0-i what [thou]101-birdalone canst of the tale .

Then went [Leonard]137-leonard and tethered the horse , and [they]5306-they went together afoot to the gate ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone told what [she]101-birdalone had heard of [Arthur]125-arthur and [Hugh]124-hugh ; and [Leonard]137-leonard said : This is true , and there is not much else to be said . When [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire came back from [the leaguer of [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold]5308-the leaguer of the red hold , and had heard before of [thy]101-birdalone departure , [he]1334-the black squire was heavy of mood and few - spoken , and wandered about as [one who might find no rest]5310-one who might find no rest ; yet was [he]1334-the black squire not stern with [Atra]117-atra , who for [her]117-atra part was no less heavy- hearted : soothly a sad company [we]5306-they were , and it was somewhat better when [[my]0-i Lord]2574-my lord [Arthur]125-arthur went [his]125-arthur ways from [us]5306-they ; and indeed eager [he]125-arthur was to be gone ; and it could be seen of [him]125-arthur that [he]125-arthur was fain of the toil and peril which [they]5312-they of [Greenford]45-greenford offered [him]125-arthur . Then in some four months spake [[my]0-i lord]2574-my lord [Hugh]124-hugh that [he]125-arthur also would be gone to [a place where were both [a land]5315-a land and folk that would look friendly on [him]125-arthur]5314-a place where were both a land and folk that would look friendly on him ; so [he]125-arthur went with [[my]0-i lady]615-my lady [Viridis]116-viridis and [[my]0-i lady]615-my lady [Aurea]116-viridis , and [they]5312-they had [Atra]117-atra also with [them]5312-they ; and [me]0-i also [they]5312-they would have had , but [my]0-i heart failed [me]0-i to leave [the place where [I]0-i had been so glad and so sorry with [thee]5319-thee]5318-the place where i had been so glad and so sorry with thee ; death had been better ; wherefore in yonder bower as in an hermitage [I]0-i serve [God]120-god and abide [my]0-i time . But though [I]0-i wot nought of where is gone [the Black Squire]1334-the black squire , [I]0-i know whereto those four are gone , and it is but a seven days ' ride hence , and [the land]213-the land is goodly and peaceable , and if [they]5312-they be not dead , most like [they]5312-they be there yet . How sayest [thou]7162-thou then , [thou]7162-thou dearest and kindest , wilt [thou]7162-thou thither to [them]5312-they ? For if so , [I]101-birdalone may well lead [thee]101-birdalone thither .[101-birdalone]

[Birdalone]101-birdalone shook [her]101-birdalone head . Nay , [she]101-birdalone said , [I]0-i deem that [I]0-i am drawn elsewhither , but soon [I]0-i shall tell [thee]101-birdalone . Lo now the gate . But ere [we]5321-we enter , tell [me]0-i of [Sir Geoffrey of [Lea]64-lea]172-sir geoffrey of lea , and why it was that [they]5322-they might not abide the uncouth things , or if there were any such . [Spake Leonard]137-leonard : Things uncouth there were , and [I]0-i was called upon to lay them , and [I]0-i did as biddeth Holy Church in all wise , but prevailed not against [them]5322-they , and still were [they]5322-they seen and heard , till [folk]1529-folk might endure it no longer .

And what like were these things ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and are [they]5322-they yet seen and heard ? Said [Leonard]137-leonard : Strange it is , but last night [I]0-i went into [the great hall]1785-the great hall where [they]5322-they mostly betid , and laid [me]0-i down there , as whiles [I]0-i do , for [I]0-i fear [them]5322-they not , and would see if [they]5322-they yet appear ; but all night came nothing at all . As to the likeness of [them]5322-they . . . Then [he]137-leonard stopped , but said presently : Hard it is to tell [thee]5325-thee of them , but needs must [I.]137-leonard There be two of these things ; and one is an image of [a tall woman of middle - age]5326-a tall woman of middle - age , red - haired , white- skinned , and meagre , and whiles [she]5326-a tall woman of middle - age has a twiggen rod in [her]5326-a tall woman of middle - age hand , and whiles a naked short sword , and whiles nought at all . But the voice of [her]5326-a tall woman of middle - age is cursing and blaspheming and ill - saying .

Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : This is then a fetch of [[my]0-i witch - mistress of whom [I]0-i told [thee]5325-thee erst , and the image of [her]5326-a tall woman of middle - age]5327-my witch - mistress of whom i told thee erst , and the image of her ; what is the other ? Said [Leonard]137-leonard : [I]0-i were fain not to tell [thee]5325-thee . Yet needs must [thou]5325-thee , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . [Dear lady]4913-dear lady , said [Leonard]137-leonard , the other is an image of [thee]5325-thee , and even most like unto [thee]5325-thee ; but [whiles clad in a scanty grey coat and barefoot]5329-whiles clad in a scanty grey coat and barefoot , and [whiles clad in a fair green gown goodly broidered , and broidered shoon]5330-whiles clad in a fair green gown goodly broidered , and broidered shoon ; and whiles all mother - naked .

And what voice cometh from [mine]0-i image ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , smiling , yet somewhat pale withal . Said [Leonard]137-leonard : One while [a voice of sweet singing , as of a bird in the brake]5331-a voice of sweet singing , as of a bird in the brake , and that is when [thou]5325-thee art clad ; and again , when [thou]5325-thee art naked , a voice of shrieking and wailing , as of one enduring torments .

[Spake Birdalone]101-birdalone : And when did these wonders begin ? Said [he]137-leonard : Not till after [Sir Hugh]124-hugh and [[thy]5325-thee she - friends]5332-thy she - friends were gone hence .

[Pondered Birdalone]101-birdalone a little ; then [she]101-birdalone said : [I]0-i see herein the malice of [[my]0-i witch - mistress]5333-my witch - mistress ; [she]5333-my witch - mistress would not send these fetches while [Hugh]124-hugh was [here]259-here , lest [he]124-hugh should turn to seeking [me]0-i with all [his]124-hugh might . But when [they]5335-they departed , [she]101-birdalone would have [the castle]1838-the castle waste , and then [she]101-birdalone sent [them]5335-they , wotting that thereby [she]101-birdalone would rid [her]101-birdalone of [Sir Geoffrey of Lea]172-sir geoffrey of lea ; while , on the other hand , [I]0-i was nought so much unto [him]172-sir geoffrey of lea that [he]172-sir geoffrey of lea would spend all [his]172-sir geoffrey of lea life seeking [me]0-i . But now [I]0-i deem [I]0-i know so much of [her]101-birdalone that [I]0-i may bid [thee]5337-thou to look on [her]101-birdalone as dead if these fetches come not again within a little while . Then mayst [thou]5337-thou send and do [Sir Geoffrey]172-sir geoffrey of lea to wit thereof , and belike [he]172-sir geoffrey of lea will come back again ; and fain were [I]0-i thereof for it will be merrier if [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest be dwelt in once more .

[Yea]5339-yea , verily , said [Leonard]137-leonard ; but far merrier yet [wert]5340-wert [thou]5337-thou to dwell [there]232-there . Nay , [she]101-birdalone said , but now [I]0-i see that it is not fated for [me]0-i . Let [us]5342-us go in , for [I]0-i would get to what [I]0-i would do .

So therewith [they]5342-us passed under the shadow of the archway , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone stayed not but went straightway into [the hall]1202-the hall , and through [it]1202-the hall ; and [the priest]1984-the priest , who lagged somewhat behind [her]101-birdalone speedy feet , cried out unto [her]101-birdalone : Whither wilt [thou]1984-the priest ? what chamber wilt [thou]1984-the priest visit first ? But [she]101-birdalone stayed not , and spake to [him]1984-the priest over [her]101-birdalone shoulder as [she]101-birdalone went : Follow [me]0-i if [thou]1984-the priest wilt ; [I]0-i have but one place only to come to ere [I]0-i leave [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest , save [I]0-i must needs turn back on [my]0-i footsteps .

Then [Leonard]137-leonard came up with [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone went [her]101-birdalone ways out of [the hall]1202-the hall , and out on to the waterswale of [the castle]1838-the castle , and so to [the little haven of the water - gate]5348-the little haven of the water - gate . There [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked about [her]101-birdalone eagerly ; then [she]101-birdalone turned to [Leonard]137-leonard and pointed with [her]101-birdalone finger and said : Lo [thou]1984-the priest ! there yet lieth [[my]0-i ferry]5349-my ferry of old time , [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat ; now wot [I]0-i wherefore [I]0-i was drawn hither . And [her]101-birdalone eyes glittered and [her]101-birdalone body quivered as [she]101-birdalone spake .

[Yea]5351-yea forsooth , said [Leonard]137-leonard , there it lieth ; who of [all folk in [the castle]1838-the castle]5352-all folk in the castle had durst to touch it ? But what hath it to do with [thee]1984-the priest , [[O]1984-the priest kindest lady]5354-o kindest lady ?

[Friend]2809-friend , [she]101-birdalone said , if this day weareth , and [I]0-i am yet within these walls , then [meseemeth]5356-meseemeth there must [I]0-i abide for evermore ; and there perchance shall [I]0-i meet that seeming of [myself]0-i , maybe for this night , maybe for ever , till [I]0-i die here in [this castle]1970-this castle void of all that [I]0-i love , and [I]0-i over - young for it , [friend]2809-friend . And [I]0-i know now that there is hope within [me]0-i ; for [I]0-i bethink [me]0-i of [a dear friend over yonder water of whom [I]0-i have never told any]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , nor will tell [thee]5360-thee now , save this , that [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any is the wisdom of [my]0-i life .

Wherefore now [I]0-i will try [this ferry]3418-this ferry and wot if the wight thereof will yet obey the voice of [the speaker of the spell]5362-the speaker of the spell , who has shed of [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any blood to pay therefor . Put not forth a hand therefore nor speak a word to let [me]0-i , but take this farewell of [me]0-i , with [my]0-i pity and such love as [I]0-i may give [thee]5360-thee , and let [me]0-i go , and think kindly of [me]0-i .

Then [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any went up to [him]5363-him , and laid [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any hands upon [his]5363-him shoulders , and kissed [him]5363-him , and turned about without more ado and stepped into [the boat]859-the boat ; then [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any sat down and stripped [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any arm of its sleeve , and drew forth a knife and let blood of [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any arm , and then arose and smeared stem and stern therewith , and then sat down with [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any face to the stern and sang :

The red raven - wine now Hast [thou]5365-thou drunk , stern and bow ; Wake then and awake And the Northward way take : The way of [the Wenders]5366-the wenders forth over [the flood]1033-the flood , For the will of [the Senders]2467-the senders is blent with the blood .

Then [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any abode a little , while [Leonard]137-leonard stood staring on [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any speechless with grief and blinded with [his]137-leonard bitter tears , till [the boat]859-the boat began to move under [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , and presently glided out of [the little haven]5370-the little haven into [the wide lake]4377-the wide lake ; then [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any turned [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any face back unto [him]5363-him and waved [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any hand , and [he]5363-him knelt down and blessed [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , weeping . And so [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any vanished away from before [him]5363-him .

CHAPTER IX . BIRDALONE FINDETH [THE ISLE OF NOTHING]41-the isle of nothing GREATLY BETTERED , AND IS KINDLY ENTREATED THERE

Now it was scarce noon when [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any departed , and the dark night came upon [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any in the midst of [the water]361-the water ; and [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any fell asleep in [the boat]859-the boat ere the night had grown very old , and woke up in the morning , not exceeding early , maybe about six o'clock ; then [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any looked ahead and thought presently to see the ill - favoured blotch of [the Isle of Nothing]2471-the isle of nothing on [the bosom of [the blue waters]5376-the blue waters]5375-the bosom of the blue waters , whereas it was a fair and cloudless morning of latter May. Sure enough [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw [land ahead]5377-land ahead , and it lay low down on [the water]361-the water , but [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any deemed from the first that it was green of hue , and as [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any neared it [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw that it was verily as green as emerald . Thereat [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any was a little troubled , because [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any thought that mayhappen the Sending Boat had gone astray , and that if [the wight thereof]5379-the wight thereof were not wending [the old road]5380-the old road , maybe [he]5379-the wight thereof was not making for [the old haven]5381-the old haven . For now indeed [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any told [herself]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any right out that [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any will was to go back again to [the House under [the Wood]6-the wood]2453-the house under the wood , and see what might betide there , and if [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any and [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother together might not overcome [the witch]407-the witch .

But whatever might happen nought could [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any do but sit in [[her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any place]5385-her place and wend as [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat would ; and in an hour 's space [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any was right under the lee of [the land]213-the land , and [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw that it was shapen even as [the Isle of Nothing]41-the isle of nothing had been aforetime . But this made [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any wonder , that now the grass grew thick down to the lip of [the water]361-the water , and all about from the water up were many little slim trees , and some of them with the May - tide blossom yet on them , as though it were a fair and great orchard that [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any was nearing ; and moreover , beyond all that [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw the thatched roofs of [houses]5389-houses rising up .

Presently then [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat had brought [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any to [the land]213-the land , and [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any stepped ashore , but was wary , and gat [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any bow bent and set an arrow thereto [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any began to go up from [the water]361-the water . Yet [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any thought within [herself]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , it will be nought ill if [I]0-i be come amongst [folk]1529-folk , so long as [they]1529-folk be peaceful , or else how might [I]0-i live the journey out to [all the isles]5394-all the isles and so [home]387-home to [the House under [the Wood]6-the wood]2453-the house under the wood ?

So [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any turned [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any face to where [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any had seen [those roofs]5397-those roofs , which now [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw no longer because of the thick leaves of the little trees , and so went along [a narrow path]5398-a narrow path , which grew to be more and more closely beset with trees , and were now no longer apple and pear and quince and medlar , but a young - grown thicket of woodland trees , as oak and hornbeam and beech and holly .

At last as [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any went [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any heard voices before [her]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , so [she]5359-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any stole warily to the edge of the copse , finger on shaft ; and presently could see clear of the saplings and out on to [a wide space of greensward]5399-a wide space of greensward , beyond which was [a homestead of many houses]5400-a homestead of many houses and bowers , like unto that of [a good yeoman]5401-a good yeoman in [peaceful lands]5402-peaceful lands , save that [the main building]5403-the main building was longer , though [it]5403-the main building were low . But amidst [the said greensward]5404-the said greensward was [a goodly flock of sheep that had been but of late washed for the shearing]5405-a goodly flock of sheep that had been but of late washed for the shearing , and along with [the sheep]5406-the sheep [four folk]5407-four folk , [two carles]5408-two carles and [two queans]5409-two queans , [all of [them]5407-four folk in [their]5407-four folk first youth]5410-all of them in their first youth , [not one by seeming of over a score and two of summers]5411-not one by seeming of over a score and two of summers . [These folk]1545-these folk were clad but simply , [man]548-man and [woman]1775-woman , in short coats of white woollen but [the women]2418-the women 's coats a little longer than [the men]2426-the men 's , without [shoon or hosen]5417-shoon or hosen ; [they]1545-these folk had garlands of green leaves on [their]1545-these folk heads , and were wholly unarmed , save that [one of [the men]2426-the men]5418-one of the men bore an ashen wand in [his]5418-one of the men hand . As for [their]1545-these folk bodies , [they]1545-these folk were goodly of fashion , tanned indeed by the sun 's burning , but all sweet of flesh were [they]1545-these folk , shapely and trim , clean- made , and light and slim .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone 's heart yearned toward [them]1545-these folk , and [she]101-birdalone stepped straightway from out of the cover of the coppice , and the sun flamed from [her]101-birdalone sallet and glittered in the rings of [her]101-birdalone hauberk , so that [the folk]244-the folk might not fail to see [her]101-birdalone ; the sheep fled bundling from [her]101-birdalone past [[their]1545-these folk keepers]5421-their keepers , who stood firm , but seemed somewhat scared , and moved not toward [Birdalone]101-birdalone . [She]101-birdalone gave [them]1545-these folk the sele of the day and stood still [herself]101-birdalone ; but [the man with the ash - wand]5422-the man with the ash - wand said : Hail , [[thou]101-birdalone man]5423-thou man ; but [we]5424-we would have [thee]101-birdalone come no nearer a while , though [thy]101-birdalone voice be sweet : for [we]5424-we know what things they be which [thou]101-birdalone bearest , and that [thou]101-birdalone art [a warrior]3864-a warrior . Wilt [thou]101-birdalone hurt [us]5424-we ?

[Birdalone]101-birdalone laughed as sweetly as the blackbird sings , and [she]101-birdalone did off [her]101-birdalone sallet and shook the plenteous hair down over [her]101-birdalone , and then drew forth [her]101-birdalone sword and dagger and cast them to earth , and laid [her]101-birdalone bow and quiver of arrows upon [them]1545-these folk , and said : Now will [I]0-i come to [you]5426-you , or [ye]5426-you shall come to [me]0-i , whereas [I]0-i am unweaponed , and [no warrior]5427-no warrior , but [a woman]250-a woman , and [ye]5426-you are four to one , and two of [[you]5426-you carles]5429-you carles ; wherefore now [ye]5426-you may bind [me]0-i or slay [me]0-i if [you]5426-you will ; but in any case [I]0-i pray [you]5426-you first to give [me]0-i a mouthful of meat .

When [she]101-birdalone had done [her]101-birdalone speech , [she]101-birdalone went up to [the fairest of [the women]2418-the women]5430-the fairest of the women and kissed [her]5430-the fairest of the women ; but [the two carles]5432-the two carles made no more ado but came to [Birdalone]101-birdalone and kissed [her]101-birdalone one after other , and that as [men who needed nought to compel [them]5432-the two carles therein]5433-men who needed nought to compel them therein , and [each thereafter]5434-each thereafter took a hand of [her]101-birdalone and held it and caressed it . But [the other woman]5435-the other woman had run into [the house]325-the house as soon as [Birdalone]101-birdalone spoke , and came back again with a treen bowl full of milk and a little loaf , not white but brown ; and there blundered about [her]101-birdalone legs as [she]101-birdalone came [a little lad of some three winters old]5437-a little lad of some three winters old , naked and brown , who was shy of [the gleaming new - comer]5438-the gleaming new - comer , and hid [him]5437-a little lad of some three winters old behind [the woman]252-the woman one while , and [the other while]5440-the other while came forth to see the new thing . But [the woman]252-the woman said : [Dear woman]5442-dear woman , here is for [thee]5442-dear woman some of the ewes ' milk , and a bite of bread , and a little deal of cheese ; the said milk is yet warm , so that it is not yet clottered ; but if [thou]7163-thou wilt come with [us]5443-us [thou]7163-thou mayest speedily drink cows '[252-the woman] milk , and [we]5443-us be now at point to go milk them .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone thanked [her]252-the woman with a heart full of content , and was not ill- pleased to get [her]101-birdalone hands free from [the two carles]5432-the two carles ; so [she]101-birdalone sat down and ate [her]101-birdalone breakfast while [they]5432-the two carles talked with [her]101-birdalone , and told [her]101-birdalone of diverse work of [theirs]5432-the two carles ; as to how [their]5432-the two carles trees were waxing , and new tillage [they]5432-the two carles had done the past spring , and how it befell to the kine and the goats ; of [[their]5432-the two carles children]5445-their children also [they]5432-the two carles spake , and how there were already four thereof , and [one of [the women]2418-the women]5446-one of the women , [the meat - bringer]5448-the meat - bringer , already quickened with [child]297-child once more . So that ere [we]5443-us die , quoth [the carle who was speaking]5450-the carle who was speaking , [we]5443-us look to see [many grandchildren]5451-many grandchildren , and shall have some stout carles and queans here . And by that time will some of the trees be well grown , so that [we]5443-us may fell timber and make [us]5443-us some keel that will wend [the lake]369-the lake , and help [us]5443-us a - fishing ; or [we]5443-us may go to [other lands]5453-other lands ; or [whiles folk]5454-whiles folk may come to [us]5443-us , even as [thou]5455-thou hast , [thou]5455-thou dear- handed , [sweet - voiced woman]5456-sweet - voiced woman . But wilt [thou]5455-thou abide here ever ?

[Yea]5457-yea , said [the other]265-the other , but that is looking forward a long while , that building of [ships]5459-ships . What is nearer and well to think of is , that these apple and pear trees be so well fruited , small as they be , that this harvest [we]5443-us shall be able to make [us]5443-us cider and perry ; yea , and no little deal thereof . But art [thou]5455-thou minded to abide with [us]5443-us ever ? That were dear to [us]5443-us ; and belike [thou]5455-thou wouldest bear [us]5443-us [children]1288-children , [thou]5455-thou also .

Then spake [the meat - fetching woman]5461-the meat - fetching woman and laughed withal : Nay , [thou]5455-thou also lookest aloof a pretty deal ; whereas what is now to do is to go milk the kine , and to take [this guest]5462-this guest with [us]5443-us , so that [she]5462-this guest may drink somewhat better than ewes ' milk though the cider be not ready to hand . But tell [me]252-the woman , [[our]5443-us dear guest]7164-our dear guest , art [thou]5455-thou verily going to abide with [us]5443-us a long while ? that were sweet to [us]5443-us , and [we]5443-us will do all [we]5443-us may to pleasure [thee]5461-the meat - fetching woman .[252-the woman]

Nay , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , it will no better be but that [I]0-i depart on the morrow ; and all thanks do [I]0-i give [you]5461-the meat - fetching woman for [your]5461-the meat - fetching woman kindness .

[The woman]252-the woman kissed [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone arose , and all [they]5464-they went together to the milking of the kine some half mile inland ; and [they]5464-they passed through much of orchard , and some deal of tillage , wherein the wheat was already growing high ; and so came [they]5464-they to [a wide meadow]5465-a wide meadow through which ran [a little stream]5466-a little stream , and therein was a goodly herd of kine . So [they]5464-they fell to the milking , and made [Birdalone]101-birdalone drink of the sweet cows ' milk , and then went and lay down under the shade of the little young trees , and talked and were merry together . But [the men]2426-the men were both of [them]2426-the men somewhat willing at first to kiss [Birdalone]101-birdalone and toy with [her]101-birdalone , but when [she]101-birdalone let [them]2426-the men know that [she]101-birdalone desired it not [they]2426-the men refrained [them]2426-the men without grudging .[5464-they]

All this while of [their]5464-they talk [they]5464-they asked [Birdalone]101-birdalone nought of whence and whither , and [she]101-birdalone would not ask [them]5464-they , lest it might stir [their]5464-they asking , and then [she]101-birdalone would have to tell [them]5464-they some deal of [her]101-birdalone story ; and telling it was now become unto [her]101-birdalone somewhat weary work .

In a while [they]5464-they arose all , and [the men]2426-the men and [one woman]5468-one woman went [their]5464-they ways to deal with [the acre - land]467-the acre - land , but [the meat - fetcher]5470-the meat - fetcher went back with [Birdalone]101-birdalone into [the house]325-the house ; and [she]5470-the meat - fetcher showed [her]5470-the meat - fetcher all that was therein , which was for the more part , forsooth , [the four babes]5472-the four babes aforesaid . [The others]1301-the others came back in the eventide , bearing with [them]1301-the others foison of blue hare - bells , and telling joyously how [they]1301-the others had found [them]1301-the others anigh the coppice edge in such a place : and thereafter [they]1301-the others were merry , and sang and talked the evening away , and showed [Birdalone]101-birdalone at last to [a fair little chamber wherein was a bed of dry grass , where [she]101-birdalone lay down and slept in all content .

CHAPTER X. OF [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone]5474-a fair little chamber wherein was a bed of dry grass , where she lay down and slept in all content . chapter x. of birdalone 'S FLITTING FROM [THE ISLE OF NOTHING]41-the isle of nothing[101-birdalone]

On [the morrow]5475-the morrow [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose betimes , and would not tarry despite all the kindness of [that folk]5476-that folk and the change which had come over [the Isle of Nothing]41-the isle of nothing ; so [the friends]5477-the friends saw [her]101-birdalone down to [the boat]859-the boat all together , and bore down with [them]5477-the friends a deal of bread and cheese and late apples of the last year , for [her]101-birdalone provision on [the road]2103-the road , and a pail of milk withal ; and [men]219-men and [women]433-women [they]5477-the friends kissed [her]101-birdalone at departure , and [the meat - fetcher]5470-the meat - fetcher said : If by any means [thou]5483-thee mayst find a keel which will carry [thee]5483-thee hither , at some time , [I]0-i would [thou]5483-thee wouldst come ; for even if [thou]5483-thee be old , and [we]5484-we passed away , yet here shall be [[our]5484-we children]5485-our children or [[our]5484-we grandchildren]5486-our grandchildren to welcome [thee]5483-thee ; and [we]5484-we will tell [them]5477-the friends the tale of [thee]5483-thee that [they]5477-the friends remember it and long for [thee]5483-thee .

Then [Birdalone]101-birdalone kissed [her]101-birdalone again , and made much of [her]101-birdalone , and so stepped into [the boat]859-the boat , and fell to [her]101-birdalone sacrifice to the wight thereof ; and [those others]2092-those others stared at [her]101-birdalone and wondered , and spake nought unto [her]101-birdalone till [she]101-birdalone was gone gliding over the face of [the waters]636-the waters ; but as [they]2092-those others walked back to [the house]325-the house , [they]2092-those others spake amongst [themselves]2092-those others that this must be some goddess for of [Holy Church]171-holy church [they]2092-those others knew nought who had come to visit [them]2092-those others in [her]101-birdalone loveliness ; and in after times , when [this folk waxed a many]5491-this folk waxed a many , and tilled [all the isle]5492-all the isle and made [ships]5459-ships and spread to [other lands]5453-other lands and became great , [they]2092-those others yet had a memory of [Birdalone]101-birdalone as [[their]2092-those others own very lady]5495-their own very lady and goddess , who had come from [the fertile and wise lands]5496-the fertile and wise lands to bless [them]2092-those others , when first [they]2092-those others began to engender on [that isle]5497-that isle , and had broken bread with [them]2092-those others , and slept under [their]2092-those others roof , and then departed in a wonderful fashion , as might be looked for of [a goddess]5498-a goddess .

But as for [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]101-birdalone came not back ever , nor saw [that folk]5476-that folk again , and now [she]101-birdalone sped over [the water]361-the water toward [the Isle of Kings]2472-the isle of kings .

CHAPTER XI . COMING TO [THE ISLE]26-the isle OF [KINGS BIRDALONE]101-birdalone FINDETH THERE A SCORE AND TWO OF FAIR DAMSELS WHO WOULD FAIN HAVE [HER]101-birdalone COMPANY

[Birdalone]101-birdalone came ashore at [the said isle]2317-the said isle at the day - dawn , and saw but little change in [the isle]642-the isle when it grew light , and still [the castle]1838-the castle stood looking down awfully on to [the meadows]2079-the meadows . But when [she]101-birdalone had set foot on [the land]213-the land , [she]101-birdalone handled [her]101-birdalone bow lest the worst might befall , and looked about [her]101-birdalone , deeming that this time [she]101-birdalone would not go [her]101-birdalone ways to the dread show that was arrayed in [the castle]1838-the castle , if forsooth [those dead folk]5508-those dead folk yet abode [there]232-there .

So now as [she]101-birdalone looked across [the meadow]510-the meadow , [she]101-birdalone saw [one with light and fluttering raiment]5511-one with light and fluttering raiment come forth from the trees , and look toward [her]5511-one with light and fluttering raiment whereas [she]5511-one with light and fluttering raiment stood flashing and gleaming in the sun like an image of [the God of Love turned warrior]5512-the god of love turned warrior . Now [Birdalone]101-birdalone deemed for sure that this was [a woman]250-a woman ; [she]101-birdalone saw [her]250-a woman come a little nigher to [her]250-a woman , and then stand looking at [her]250-a woman under the sharp of [her]250-a woman hand ; then [she]101-birdalone turned about and ran back to the brake whence [she]101-birdalone came ; and presently [Birdalone]101-birdalone heard the sound of voices coming thence , and in a little while thereafter came forth from the said brake a rout of [women]433-women one score and two as [they]5515-they were told thereafter and walked over [the meadow]510-the meadow straight unto [her]101-birdalone . [She]101-birdalone stood where [she]101-birdalone was , so as to be nigh unto [her]101-birdalone ferry in case [they]5515-they willed [her]101-birdalone unpeace ; for though [they]5515-they were weaponless by seeming , [they]5515-they were [a many]2903-a many .

When [they]5515-they were come near [they]5515-they stood about [her]101-birdalone in a half ring , whispering and laughing each to [each]1584-each . [Birdalone]101-birdalone saw that [they]5515-they were [all young]5519-all young , and that none of [them]5515-they might be called ungoodly , and [some were full fair]5520-some were full fair . [They]5515-they were bright and fine of array . Most bore gold and gems on fingers and neck and arms ; [they]5515-they were clad in light , or it may be said wanton raiment of diverse colours , which had only this of [their]5515-they fashion in common , that [they]5515-they none of [them]5515-they hid over - much of [their]5515-they bare bodies ; for either the silk slipped from the shoulder of [her]101-birdalone , or danced away from [her]101-birdalone flank ; and [she]101-birdalone whose feet were shod , spared not to show knee and some deal of thigh ; and [she]101-birdalone whose gown reached unsheared from neck to heel , wore it of a web so thin and fine that it hid but little betwixt heel and neck .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone stood gazing on [them]5515-they and wondering , and [she]101-birdalone had a mind to think that [they]5515-they were some show sent by [[her]101-birdalone old mistress]2683-her old mistress [the witch]407-the witch for [her]2683-her old mistress undoing , and [she]101-birdalone loosened [her]101-birdalone sword in its sheath and nocked an arrow .

But then ran forward [two of [the damsels]1546-the damsels]5523-two of the damsels and knelt before [her]101-birdalone , and [each]1584-each took an hand of [her]101-birdalone and fell to kissing it , and [she]101-birdalone felt [their]5515-they hands that [they]5515-they were firm and [their]5515-they lips that they were soft and warm , and [they]5515-they were doubtless alive and real . Then spake one of [them]5515-they and said : Hail [[our]5526-we lord]5527-our lord ! How can words say how [we]5526-we rejoice in [thy]5527-our lord coming this happy morn ! Now do all [we]5526-we give [ourselves]5526-we to [thee]5527-our lord as [[thy]5527-our lord slaves]5528-thy slaves to do as [thou]5527-our lord wilt with . Yet [we]5526-we pray [thee]5527-our lord be merciful to [us]5526-we and [our]5526-we longings .

Therewith [all the sort of [them]5515-they]5529-all the sort of them knelt down on the grass before [Birdalone]101-birdalone and joined [their]5515-they hands as praying to [her]101-birdalone . And [Birdalone]101-birdalone was full ill at ease , and wotted not where [she]101-birdalone was . But [she]101-birdalone said : Hail ! and good days and fulfilment of wishes unto [you]5530-you , [fair damsels]5531-fair damsels ! But tell [me]0-i , is this [the Isle of [Kings]434-kings]76-the isle of kings , as [I]0-i deemed ; for strange it is for [me]0-i to see [[ye]5530-you womenfolk here]5533-ye womenfolk here ?

Said [she]101-birdalone who had spoken afore : [Yea]5534-yea verily this is [the Isle of [Kings]434-kings]2472-the isle of kings ; but long ago are [the kings]1880-the kings dead , and yet [they]1880-the kings sit dead in [the great hall of [the castle yonder]5539-the castle yonder]5538-the great hall of the castle yonder , as [thou]5540-thou mayst see if [thou]5540-thou , who art [a man]234-a man and [a valiant warrior]5542-a valiant warrior , durst follow up [yon mountain path thereto]5543-yon mountain path thereto ; but [we]5544-we , [weak women]5545-weak women and [little - hearted]5546-little - hearted , durst not go anigh it ; and [we]5544-we tremble when whiles a - nights cometh down thence the sound of clashing swords and clattering shields , and the cries of [men]219-men in battle . But , praise be to [the God of Love]5548-the god of love , nought cometh down from thence unto [us]5544-we . Therefore do [we]5544-we live peaceful lives and pleasant here , lacking nought but [thee]5549-thee , [lord]2620-lord ; and lo now [thou]5540-thou hast come unto [us]5544-we , and [we]5544-we are happy in [our]5544-we inmost hearts .

Now was [Birdalone]101-birdalone perplexed and knew not what to do ; but at last [she]101-birdalone said : [Gentle maidens]5551-gentle maidens , [I]0-i pray [you]5551-gentle maidens pardon [me]0-i , but [I]0-i must depart straightway ; for [I]0-i have an errand , and life or death lieth on it . In all else than [my]0-i abiding here may [ye]5551-gentle maidens have [your]5551-gentle maidens will .

Therewith did [she]101-birdalone move a little way toward [[her]101-birdalone ferry]1512-her ferry ; but forthwith all [they]5553-they brake out weeping and wailing and lamenting , and [some of [them]5553-they]5554-some of them came up to [Birdalone]101-birdalone and cast [themselves]5554-some of them down before [her]101-birdalone , and clasped [her]101-birdalone knees , and took hold of [her]101-birdalone skirts , and besought [her]101-birdalone piteously to abide with [them]5555-them . But [she]101-birdalone put [them]5555-them aside as well as [she]101-birdalone might , and stepped aboard [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , and stood amidst [it]832-the sending boat waiting on [their]5553-they departure ; but [they]5553-they went not , and stood along on the lip of [the land]213-the land crying out and beseeching with much clamour .

Then [Birdalone]101-birdalone waxed somewhat wrath at [their]5553-they noise and tumult , and [she]101-birdalone drew forth [her]101-birdalone knife and bared [her]101-birdalone arm and let blood from it . But when [they]5553-they saw the whiteness and roundness of it , and how fine and sleek it was , straightway [they]5553-they changed [their]5553-they tune , and cried out : [A woman]250-a woman , [a woman]250-a woman , [a fool of a woman]5560-a fool of a woman ! and [they]5553-they laughed in scorn and mockery . And [the speaker of [them]5553-they]5561-the speaker of them said : Now there is but one thing for [thee]5562-thou to do , and that is to come forth from [[thy]5562-thou boat]1962-thy boat and strip off [thy]5562-thou stolen raiment , and [we]5564-we shall make [thee]5562-thou as fine as [ourselves]5564-we , and [thou]5562-thou shalt come with [us]5564-we , and with [us]5564-we abide the coming of [[our]5564-we lord]5527-our lord . Nay , [thou]5562-thou art so fair and lovely , that [thou]5562-thou shalt be [the Lady]1157-the lady and [Queen of [us]5564-we]5567-queen of us , and [we]5564-we will do after [thy]5562-thou commands , and [thou]5562-thou mayst chastise [us]5564-we if [we]5564-we fail therein . But now if [thou]5562-thou wilt not come forth of [the boat]859-the boat uncompelled , [we]5564-we shall pluck [thee]5562-thou forth of it .

And therewith [she]5562-thou set [her]5562-thou foot on the gunwale of [the boat]859-the boat , and [two or three others]5570-two or three others did the like . But now had [Birdalone]101-birdalone [her]101-birdalone sword naked in [her]101-birdalone hand , and [she]101-birdalone waxed as red as blood , and cried out : Forbear [I]0-i bid [you]5571-ye ! [Yea]5572-yea verily [I]0-i am [a woman]250-a woman ; but [I]0-i will not take this offer either , whereas [I]0-i have an errand , as [I]0-i told [you]5571-ye . And so stern it is , that if [ye]5571-ye now let [my]0-i departure [I]0-i will not spare to smite with this sword whoso first cometh aboard [[my]0-i ferry]5349-my ferry , and though [I]0-i be not [a man]234-a man , yet shall [ye]5571-ye find that in this matter [I]0-i shall be little worse , whereas [I]0-i am armed and [ye]5571-ye be naked .

Then [they]5576-they drew back and stood gibing and jeering at [her]0-i ; but [she]0-i heeded it no whit , but reddened stem and stern of [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , and sang [her]0-i spell , and forth glided [the ferry]1951-the ferry , while [the damsels]1546-the damsels stood and stared astonished . As for [Birdalone]101-birdalone , as [she]0-i sped on [her]0-i way [she]0-i might not refrain [her]0-i laughter . Thus [she]0-i wended [the wet highway]5580-the wet highway .

CHAPTER XII . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone COMETH AGAIN TO [THE ISLE OF QUEENS]2473-the isle of queens , AND FINDETH A PERILOUS ADVENTURE THEREIN

It was not yet daybreak when [Birdalone]101-birdalone came ashore again , and the moon was down , and it was dark ; wherefore [she]101-birdalone durst not go up on [the land]213-the land , but lay down in [the ferry]1951-the ferry and fell asleep there . When [she]0-i woke again it was broad daylight , the sun was up , and a little ripple was running over the face of [the water]361-the water . [She]0-i stepped ashore straightway , and looked up [the land]213-the land and to the right hand and the left , and saw at once that it was indeed [the Isle of [Queens]101-birdalone]58-the isle of queens , and [the house]325-the house stood trim and lovely as of old time ; then [she]0-i longed somewhat to tread [the green meadow]5587-the green meadow a little , for yet young was the day , and [she]0-i saw nought stirring save the throstle and a few small beasts . However , [she]0-i said to [herself]0-i that [she]0-i would go nowhere nigh to [the goodly house wherein abode those images of death]5588-the goodly house wherein abode those images of death . Yet [her]0-i body longed so sore for the springtide freshness of the grass , and was so bewooed of the flowery scent thereof , that though [she]0-i durst not go unarmed , [she]0-i did off [her]0-i footgear and went stealing softly barefoot and with naked legs over the embroidered greensward , saying aloud to [herself]0-i : If run for [the ferry]1951-the ferry [I]0-i needs must , lighter shall [I]0-i run so dight .

Nonetheless , [she]0-i had gone but a little way ere a terror took hold of [her]0-i , though [she]0-i saw [no child of [Adam anigh]103-adam]5590-no child of adam anigh , and [she]0-i turned and ran back swiftly to [[her]0-i old place]5591-her old place and sat down under a twisted oak - tree hard by the Sending Boat , and abode there panting and quaking , and scarce daring to look up from the grass for a while . Then [her]0-i heart came back to [her]0-i , and [she]0-i laughed , and said to [herself]0-i : [I]0-i am [a fool]493-a fool , for [I]0-i need fear nought on [this Isle of [Queens]101-birdalone]5593-this isle of queens save [women like [myself]0-i]5594-women like myself .

Yet [she]0-i sat there a little while longer without stirring ; then [she]0-i stood up and looked keenly around , and , as aforesaid , exceeding far- sighted [she]0-i was ; but still [she]0-i saw [neither man]5595-neither man nor [maid]5596-maid nor [suckling child]5597-suckling child .

Then [her]0-i eyes sought the lips of [the lake]369-the lake , and rested on a little bight some stone 's throw ahead of [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , where , a little back from [the water]361-the water , slim willows made a veil betwixt [the water of [the meadow]510-the meadow]5601-the water of the meadow ; and [she]0-i looked , and saw how pleasant a place [it]5603-it were for [a one]5604-a one to stand and look on the ripple just left , while the water dripped from the clear body on to the grass . And [her]0-i bare feet fell to telling [her]0-i clad sides of the sweet coolness of the water , and waited for no naysay , but lightly bore [her]0-i toward [the willowy bight]5605-the willowy bight . And when [she]0-i was there , [she]0-i did off [her]0-i sallet and ungirt [her]0-i , and laid [her]0-i sword on the grass , and did off [her]0-i surcoat and hauberk , and so was [a woman]250-a woman again in one white coat above [her]0-i smock . Then [she]0-i looked heedfully betwixt [the willow - boughs]5607-the willow - boughs , and saw no more than before , nought but a little whitethorn brake , now white indeed with blossom , some fifty yards landward from where [she]0-i stood . So [she]0-i laughed , and did off [her]0-i other raiment , and slid swiftly into [the water]361-the water , that embraced [her]0-i body in all its fresh kindness ; and as for [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]0-i rewarded it well for its past toil by sporting and swimming to [her]0-i full .

Then [she]0-i came forth from [the water]361-the water , and clad [herself]0-i in no great haste , and did on [her]0-i hauberk and sallet and sword , and so went back to [her]0-i place , and sat down and began to do on [her]0-i foot - gear .

But as [she]0-i looked up from [her]0-i work a moment , lo ! [a tall man coming toward [her]0-i]5610-a tall man coming toward her , and just about the willows whereby [she]0-i had bathed . [Her]0-i heart beat quick and [her]0-i face changed , yet [she]0-i hastened , and was shod and stood up in knightly array by then [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her stayed [his]5610-a tall man coming toward her steps some five paces from [her]0-i , and gave [her]0-i the sele of the day in courteous wise ; and [she]0-i strove to think that [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her had not seen [her]0-i , or at least noted [her]0-i otherwise dight ; yet [her]0-i heart misgave [her]0-i .

[He]5610-a tall man coming toward her was [a grizzled - haired man of over fifty summers by seeming , but goodly enough and well - knit]5611-a grizzled - haired man of over fifty summers by seeming , but goodly enough and well - knit ; [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her was clad in a green coat more than a little worn , but made after the fashion of knighthood ; [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her had nought on [his]5610-a tall man coming toward her head but an oak - chaplet , and no weapons but a short sword by [his]5610-a tall man coming toward her side and a stout staff in [his]5610-a tall man coming toward her hand .

[She]0-i gave back [his]5610-a tall man coming toward her greeting in a quavering voice ; and [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her said : Welcome again , [young man]5612-young man . Art [thou]5613-thou come to dwell with [us]5614-us ? Truly [thou]5613-thou art trim now , but ere some few months [thine]5615-thine attire will be not so much fairer than [ours]5614-us , and thine hauberk will be rusted , for here be no joyous tiltings nor deeds of arms , and [no kind ladies to give the award of honour]5616-no kind ladies to give the award of honour , so that if [we]5614-us fight amongst [ourselves]5614-us it will be because [we]5614-us have fallen out , and spitefully . Yet and [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her laughed , mockingly , as [she]0-i thought [thou]5613-thou mayst bring [us]5614-us luck , and draw [some fair damsels]5617-some fair damsels unto [us]5614-us , for that is what [we]5614-us await in [this isle]1498-this isle , which is barren of [their]5617-some fair damsels fair bodies , despite of its deceitful name .

Thereat [Birdalone]101-birdalone reddened , deeming that [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her divined [her]101-birdalone womanhood , but [she]0-i enforced [her]0-i to speak hardily , and as manly as [she]0-i might , and said : [Yea]5619-yea , [fair sir]2215-fair sir , and if [I]0-i be [the God of Love]5548-the god of love , as [thou]5613-thou deemest , and not merely [a poor squire]5622-a poor squire [Louis Delahaye]196-louis delahaye , at [thy]5613-thou service , how many damsels shall [I]0-i send [thee]5613-thou if there must needs be one to [each man of [you]5613-thou]5623-each man of you ? Quoth [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her : [Thou]5613-thou must make up the tale to a score or more , or some of [us]5624-we must lack . Sooth to say , at this time [thou]5613-thou needest not haste overmuch for all the tale , whereas there is but one other of [the company near at hand]5625-the company near at hand , [a mere foolish young man]5626-a mere foolish young man ; the others are gone to [the leeward side of [the isle]642-the isle]5627-the leeward side of the isle , to fetch [us]5624-we venison and fish , both of which are more plenty there than here ; wherefore are [we]5624-we two somewhat lonesome in this stead , all the more as [we]5624-we be over - nigh to the sorcery in [the great house]5629-the great house , which [we]5624-we durst not enter ; for though nought cometh out thence down unto [us]5624-we , yet hear [we]5624-we a - night - tides , first songs , and then cries and shrieking , come out therefrom .

Then [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her stayed [his]5610-a tall man coming toward her speech , and drew a little nigher to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and then grinned , and said : Forsooth [we]5624-we can spare [him]5610-a tall man coming toward her , [we]5624-we twain . And [he]5610-a tall man coming toward her looked on [her]101-birdalone hard , and the colour came into [her]101-birdalone cheeks , and [she]101-birdalone laughed uneasily , as [a dainty lady]5630-a dainty lady when [she]101-birdalone heareth some unmeet tale .

But again [the old carle]1675-the old carle drew nigher to [her]101-birdalone , and said : [Thou]5632-thou seemest to have a good bow and store of arrows ; if [thou]5632-thou wouldst lend them to [me]0-i for a little , and come with [me]0-i into the wood hard by , [I]0-i might shoot [thee]101-birdalone some venison with little toil to [thee]101-birdalone ; whereas , forsooth , [thou]5632-thou lookest scarce like one who is meet for over - much toil . Again [she]101-birdalone reddened , and spake nought this time ; and [he]1675-the old carle said : Deem not there be no deer [this end of [the isle]642-the isle]5633-this end of the isle because [I]0-i said that [the others]1301-the others were gone to fetch [home venison]5636-home venison ; only the deer be tamer there and more , and [we]5637-we have but evil shooting - gear , whereas [thou]5632-thou art well found therein . Wilt [thou]5632-thou not come ? [we]5637-we shall have merry feast after the hunt .

Now had [Birdalone]101-birdalone come to [her]101-birdalone wits again , and [she]101-birdalone answered like [a merry youth]5638-a merry youth , with a flavour of mockery in [her]101-birdalone speech : Fair sir , [thou]5632-thou shalt not deem that [I]0-i need much help in slaying the dun deer ; for [I]0-i do [thee]5632-thou to wit that [I]0-i shoot not ill in the bow ; neither am [I]0-i heavy- footed . But [I]0-i will not hunt in [[your]5632-thou park]5639-your park to - day , for [I]0-i have an errand which calleth [me]0-i away , so that [I]0-i shall depart hence presently . Besides , [wise elder]5640-wise elder , there is thine errand to see to ; and if [I]0-i be [the God of Love]5548-the god of love , as [thou]5632-thou sayest , [I]0-i must not keep [thee]5632-thou and [[thy]5632-thou valiant fellows]5642-thy valiant fellows languishing mateless ; so with [thy]5632-thou leave [I]0-i will now depart , that [I]0-i may send [you]5632-thou a score of fair damsels for [your]5632-thou company .

And [she]0-i turned about and made a step toward [[her]0-i boat]5643-her boat ; but [the carle]1736-the carle drew nearer , laughing ; and [he]1736-the carle said : Truly sayest [thou]5632-thou that [thou]5632-thou art not heavy - footed , for never saw [I]0-i feet lighter or fairer than glided over [the meadow e'en]5645-the meadow e'en now ; nor a fairer body than came like rosy- tinted pearl fresh out of the water while [I]0-i lay hidden in yonder thorn - brake that while . Wherefore trouble not [thyself]5646-thyself to bring any more damsels than [thyself]5646-thyself , [fairest Goddess of Love]5647-fairest goddess of love , for [thou]5632-thou art enough for [me]0-i .

And therewith [he]1736-the carle ran forward , and stretched out a hand to [her]0-i ; but in that nick of time had [she]0-i [her]0-i sword naked in [her]0-i hand , and [the carle]1736-the carle drew back before the glitter thereof , and cried out : Ho , ho ! is it to be battle , [[my]0-i mistress]1415-my mistress ? Deemest [thou]5632-thou that [thou]5632-thou wilt slay [me]0-i as lightly as the dun deer , and [thou]5632-thou with [thy]5632-thou bow unstrung at [thy]5632-thou back ? Now shall [I]0-i show [thee]5632-thou a trick of fence ; but fear not that [I]0-i shall hurt [thee]5632-thou to spoil [thee]5632-thou .

[He]1736-the carle advanced on [her]0-i with [his]1736-the carle staff aloft , and [her]0-i heart failed [her]0-i , and [she]0-i quaked , and lightly [he]1736-the carle beat down [her]0-i guard and did the sword out of [her]0-i hand ; and again [he]1736-the carle turned on [her]0-i to take [her]0-i , but [she]0-i sprang aside and ran from [him]1736-the carle , but ran landward perforce , as [he]1736-the carle was betwixt [her]0-i and [the boat]859-the boat ; and [he]1736-the carle followed heavily , and had nought to do in the race .

But [she]0-i had not gone a two - score yards ere [she]0-i heard a great shout , and [another man]1974-another man came running over [the meadow]510-the meadow ; [a slim young man]5653-a slim young man was this , and worse of attire than [the old carle]1675-the old carle , for so tattered was [his]5653-a slim young man raiment that [he]5653-a slim young man was half naked ; but [he]5653-a slim young man was goodly of fashion , fresh- coloured and black - haired . [Birdalone]101-birdalone stayed [her]101-birdalone feet when [she]101-birdalone saw [him]5653-a slim young man , for though [she]101-birdalone doubted not to outrun [him]5653-a slim young man , yet whither should [she]101-birdalone run , since [her]101-birdalone ferry was behind [her]101-birdalone ?

So [the young man]5655-the young man came up to [her]101-birdalone , and [the old carle]1675-the old carle met [him]5655-the young man all panting , and [the young man]5655-the young man said : How now , [Antony]197-antony ! what battle is this ? and wherefore art [thou]5658-thou chasing [this fair knight]5659-this fair knight ? And [thou]5658-thou , [fair sir]2215-fair sir , why fleest [thou]5658-thou this grey dastard ?

Said [Antony]197-antony : [Thou]5658-thou art but [a young fool]2370-a young fool , [Otter]198-otter , this is [no man]545-no man , but [a woman]250-a woman , and [I]0-i have taken [her]250-a woman , and [she]250-a woman is mine .

Well , said [Otter]198-otter , [I]0-i say [she]250-a woman is as much mine as thine ; nay , more , if [she]250-a woman will give [herself]250-a woman unto [me]0-i . But if [she]250-a woman will not , [she]250-a woman shall go whither [she]250-a woman will in [thy]5658-thou despite . Or art [thou]5658-thou [a woman]250-a woman ?

Yea , yea , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; and [I]0-i pray [thee]5658-thou , by [[thy]5658-thou mother]337-thy mother 's head , suffer [me]0-i to depart ; for heavy and full of need is the errand that [I]0-i am about .

Go [thou]5658-thou shalt then , said [Otter]198-otter ; lead back to [[thy]5658-thou place]5666-thy place , and [I]0-i will walk with [thee]5658-thou . So did [they]5667-they : and [Birdalone]101-birdalone went beside [the young man quaking]5668-the young man quaking ; but [he]5668-the young man quaking put out no hand unto [her]101-birdalone ; and sooth to say , [she]101-birdalone deemed that [she]101-birdalone had seldom seen so fair [a young man]5116-a young man , but it were [Arthur]125-arthur or [Hugh]124-hugh .

Now [he]5668-the young man quaking , as [Antony]197-antony , was girt with a short sword , but [he]5668-the young man quaking let it be in its sheath ; and as [they]5667-they went , [Antony]197-antony drew [his]197-antony blade again , and hove it up to smite [Otter]198-otter , but as it befell [Birdalone]101-birdalone saw [him]5668-the young man quaking , and turned round sharp upon [him]5668-the young man quaking and gat hold of [his]5668-the young man quaking wrist , and therewith [Otter]198-otter turned also , and caught [the old carle]1675-the old carle by the nape as [he]5668-the young man quaking turned away , and put a foot before [his]5668-the young man quaking and shoved mightily , so that [he]5668-the young man quaking went noseling to [the earth]445-the earth .

Then turned [Otter]198-otter about again , laughing , and [he]198-otter said to [Birdalone]101-birdalone : By [Saint Giles]199-saint giles ! [thou]5672-thou art well - nigh too valiant for [a woman]250-a woman , and [I]0-i would that [we]5674-we two might be together ; and then between [us]5674-we [we]5674-we might achieve the adventure of [the dead ladies]5675-the dead ladies up yonder . [She]101-birdalone hung [her]101-birdalone head , and said : Fair sir , it may not anywise be ; yet [I]0-i thank [thee]198-otter , [I]0-i thank [thee]198-otter .

So came [they]5676-they to the water - side and the Sending Boat , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone stayed [her]101-birdalone feet there , and [the young man]5655-the young man said : What is this keel , that seemeth unto [me]0-i as if it were a ferry for [malefactors wending to a death of torment]5678-malefactors wending to a death of torment , so grey and bleared and water - logged and sun- bleached as it is , and smeared over with stains of [I]0-i know not what ?

Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : Such as it is , it is [[my]0-i ferry]5349-my ferry over [the water]361-the water to where [I]0-i would be . Strange ! said [Otter]198-otter ; to [my]0-i mind it is like to [our]5681-our fortunes on [this isle]1498-this isle , [we]5681-our who were once [knights]3601-knights and [merry squires]5684-merry squires and are now as [gangrel men , and of ill conditions]5685-gangrel men , and of ill conditions , thinking of nought save [our]5681-our first desires , even those which [we]5681-our share with the wolf and the kite .

[She]101-birdalone said : But art [thou]5686-thou of evil conditions , [thou]5686-thou who hast just delivered [me]0-i from trouble ? [He]5687-he smiled grimly : [Damsel]133-damsel , said [he]5687-he , [I]0-i have not delivered [thee]133-damsel yet from [me]0-i , though [I]0-i have from [him]5687-he . But tell [me]0-i , art [thou]5686-thou [a sorceress]5688-a sorceress ? Not a black one , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; but [I]0-i will tell [thee]133-damsel at once that [I]0-i have been bred by [a witch most mighty]5689-a witch most mighty , and some deal of lore have [I]0-i learned . And therewith [she]0-i told [him]5687-he of [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , and how [she]0-i would have to speed it on the way .

[He]5687-he looked on [her]0-i a little and then turned away , and saw [her]0-i sword lying on the grass ; so [he]5687-he went to it and picked it up and brought it to [her]0-i , and said : [Thou]133-damsel mayst yet need [this keen friend]5691-this keen friend . So [she]0-i took it and thrust it back into the scabbard , quaking somewhat because of [him]5687-he ; so feeble and frail as [she]0-i felt before [him]5687-he . Then [he]5687-he said : If [thou]133-damsel deemest [thou]133-damsel hast somewhat to reward [me]0-i for , [I]0-i have a boon to ask of [thee]0-i , and granting that , [we]5692-we shall be quits again . Yea , [she]0-i said faintly , and what is the boon ? [He]5687-he said : Art [thou]133-damsel pressed to depart now , this minute ? Nay , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , not for an hour if there be no peril here from [other men]5693-other men , and . . . and . . . And if [I]0-i be true to [thee]0-i and will let [thee]0-i go ? said [he]5687-he , laughing ; hah ! is that not [thy]0-i word ? fear not , [I]0-i swear by thine eyes that [thou]133-damsel shalt depart whenso [thou]133-damsel wilt . Now then , the boon [I]0-i crave is , that [thou]133-damsel wilt sit down here beside [me]0-i and tell [me]0-i the tale of [thy]133-damsel life that has been . Said [she]0-i : It wearies [me]0-i to think thereof ; yet hast [thou]133-damsel a right to crave somewhat of [me]0-i , and this is not hard to grant .

And [she]0-i sat down by [him]5687-he ; but [he]5687-he said : Do this also for [me]0-i , take off [thine]133-damsel headpiece , since now that [we]5694-we know [thee]133-damsel for [a woman]250-a woman it serveth [thee]133-damsel nought . So did [she]0-i , and began [her]0-i tale straightway , and told [him]5687-he all thereof , save as to [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife , and [he]5687-he sat hearkening and watching [her]0-i face ; and when [she]0-i had made an end , [he]5687-he said : Now shall [I]0-i ask none other boon of [thee]0-i , though [I]0-i long sore for it ; but best it is that [we]5694-we sunder straightway , else maybe [I]0-i might yet be for hindering [thee]0-i .

Therewith [he]5687-he stood up , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone also , and [he]5687-he looked on [her]0-i eagerly , and said : [I]0-i am now to bid [thee]0-i farewell , and it is most like that [I]0-i shall never see [thee]0-i again , wherefore [I]0-i will ask [thee]0-i yet to let one thing come from [thy]0-i mouth ; for [I]0-i deem [thee]0-i [the dearest of all women [I]0-i have ever seen]5697-the dearest of all women i have ever seen . What shall [I]0-i say ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , smiling on [him]5687-he kindly ; must [thou]5698-thou needs put the word in [my]0-i mouth ? [Thou]5698-thou hast been friendly with [me]0-i here when need was to [me]0-i of friendliness ; wherefore [I]0-i say , [I]0-i would [I]0-i might see [thee]0-i again , and [thou]5698-thou better bestead than now [thou]5698-thou art .

[The young man]5655-the young man 's face brightened , and [he]5655-the young man said : Spake [I]0-i not that [thou]5698-thou wert the dearest of all ? This was even the word [I]0-i would have put in [thy]0-i mouth . But now see [thou]0-i , one goeth on from one thing to another , and [I]0-i must now ask [thee]0-i , is there aught which [thou]5698-thou hast a mind to give [me]0-i ere [I]0-i depart , some keepsake which [I]0-i durst not ask for ?

[She]0-i flushed red and said : [I]0-i will with a good heart give [thee]5655-the young man [my]0-i bow and arrows for a keepsake ; whereas [the old carle]1675-the old carle told [me]0-i that [ye]5655-the young man be ill furnished of shooting - gear .

And [she]0-i would have taken [her]0-i bow from [her]0-i back , but [he]5655-the young man laughed aloud , and said : Nay , nay , [I]0-i will not have that ; for there be those who gird [them]5701-them to a sword and know not how to use it , but [few]3028-few will cumber [their]3028-few shoulders with bow and quiver who can not shoot therewith ; [I]0-i deem it like that [thou]5698-thou art [a fell bowman]5703-a fell bowman . Keep [thy]5698-thou bow therefore , and if [thou]5698-thou wilt go without any other gift , even so be it .

And [he]5655-the young man made as if [he]5655-the young man would turn away ; but [she]0-i put forth both [her]0-i hands and took [his]5655-the young man in them , and lifted up [her]0-i face and kissed [him]5655-the young man kindly , and then turned away to [[her]0-i ferry]1512-her ferry ; while [Otter]198-otter stood still and said in a merry voice : Now is it better than well , for [thou]5698-thou art in all ways what [I]0-i would have [thee]5698-thou , and there is nought like unto [thee]5698-thou . And therewith [he]5655-the young man turned away and departed ere [Birdalone]101-birdalone had stepped into [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat , and [she]101-birdalone blushing like a rose the while . Then [she]101-birdalone did due sacrifice to [the wight of [the witch - ferry]5707-the witch - ferry]5706-the wight of the witch - ferry , and sped on [her]101-birdalone way without any hindrance .

CHAPTER XIII . COMING TO [THE ISLE]26-the isle OF THE YOUNG AND [THE OLD]130-the old , [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone FINDETH [IT]26-the isle PEOPLED WITH [CHILDREN]1288-children

Midst all this had worn some hours , but yet it was barely noon ; wherefore it was yet dark by then [Birdalone]101-birdalone made [the Isle of [the Young]126-the young]28-the isle of the young and [the Old]1667-the old ; so [she]101-birdalone stepped out of [the boat]859-the boat , and lay down on the grass and abode the dawn sleeping . And [she]101-birdalone awoke with the clatter of shrill voices , and [she]101-birdalone rose up and looked , and lo [a multitude of [children]1288-children all about [her]101-birdalone]5711-a multitude of children all about her , both [men]219-men and [women children]5714-women children , and , as it seemed , from five years old upward to fifteen . [They]5711-a multitude of children all about her cried and crowed merrily when [they]5711-a multitude of children all about her saw [her]101-birdalone stand up , and pressed on [her]101-birdalone to see [her]101-birdalone the nearer and to touch [her]101-birdalone hands or [her]101-birdalone raiment . [They]5711-a multitude of children all about her were but little clad , and [the younger ones]5715-the younger ones not at all , but were [goodly younglings]5716-goodly younglings and merry . So great was the noise [they]5711-a multitude of children all about her raised , that loud were the thunder which had not been hushed thereby ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone stood looking on [them]5711-a multitude of children all about her , smiling , and knew not what to do . Anon [she]101-birdalone turned to [a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters , and said unto [him]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters : Wilt [thou]5718-thou now take [me]0-i unto [the house]325-the house , and the place where dwelleth [the old man]7080-the old man ? Quoth [he]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters : [I]0-i neither know of [an old man]1739-an old man , nor rightly what it means , the word . Am not [I]0-i old enough for [thee]101-birdalone ? [I]0-i am the oldest of these here . But belike [thou]101-birdalone art hungry ; wherefore if [thou]101-birdalone come to the place where [we]101-birdalone sleep a - nights , and where [we]101-birdalone shelter [us]101-birdalone from the storm and the rain when need is , [I]0-i will give [thee]101-birdalone to eat ; for [we]101-birdalone have both bread and milk and cheese , and raisins of the sun .

So [he]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters took [her]0-i hand and led [her]0-i along , and asked [her]0-i by the way concerning [her]0-i armour and weapons , and of the fashion of battle , and [she]0-i told [him]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters thereof what [she]0-i would .

Thus came [they]5722-they to the place where erst had been [the cot under the ruin of [the great ancient house]5724-the great ancient house]5723-the cot under the ruin of the great ancient house ; but now was gone all that ruin and the great grey walls , though the cot was left ; and all about [it]5723-the cot under the ruin of the great ancient house were low bowers built of small wood and thatched undeftly . But [the lad]1619-the lad smiled when [he]1619-the lad saw it , as if the sight thereof made [him]1619-the lad happy ; and [he]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters said : All these have [we]101-birdalone made since [I]0-i have dwelt here , and [no other home]5726-no other home have [I]0-i known .

And [he]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters led [her]0-i into [the cot]5727-the cot , and set [her]0-i down to eat and to drink , and through the open door [she]0-i could see [the children]1649-the children swarming , and [they]1649-the children that were nighest thrusting [each other]580-each other this way and that to catch a sight of [her]0-i .

Now [she]0-i said : [Fair child]958-fair child , how gattest [thou]958-fair child this victual if there be [no older folk]5731-no older folk to help [you]958-fair child ? Said [he]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters : [We]101-birdalone dig the ground and sow it , and the wheat comes up , and [we]101-birdalone reap it in harvest , and make bread of it ; and [we]101-birdalone have goats and kine , and [we]101-birdalone milk [them]5732-them , and turn the milk with a little blue flower , which is fair to see . And there are in [this isle little hills]5733-this isle little hills where the grapes grow plenty ; and [some]229-some [we]101-birdalone eat and some [we]101-birdalone dry for store . Lo [thou]5735-thou , such be [our]101-birdalone ways for victual . But tell [me]0-i , said [he]5717-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters , [thou]5735-thou sayest old , and [I]0-i know not the word ; art [thou]5735-thou old ? [She]5736-she laughed : Not very , said [she]5736-she , yet older than [thou]5735-thou .

Said [the lad]1619-the lad : [Thou]5735-thou art fair and dear to look on , and [thy]5735-thou voice is sweet ; wilt [thou]5735-thou not abide with [us]101-birdalone , and teach [us]101-birdalone what it is to be old ? Nay , said [she]5736-she , [I]0-i may not , for [I]0-i have an errand which driveth [me]0-i on ; wherefore [I]0-i must be gone within this hour .

Forsooth , [she]5736-she was growing eager now to be done with [her]5736-she journey and come to [the House under [the Wood]6-the wood]2453-the house under the wood , whatever should befall [her]5736-she there . Moreover [she]5736-she deemed it would not be restful to [her]5736-she to abide among [all these restless children]5739-all these restless children , with [their]5739-all these restless children ceaseless crying and yelping : if rest [she]5736-she might , [she]5736-she would rest , [she]5736-she deemed , in [the Isle of [Increase Unsought]32-increase unsought]2034-the isle of increase unsought , if there were no ill things abiding there .

Wherefore now [she]5736-she arose , when [she]5736-she had sat hearkening the sound of [the lad]1619-the lad 's prattle for a while , for as to the sense thereof [she]5736-she might not heed it over - much . [The youngling]390-the youngling would not leave [her]5736-she , but led [her]5736-she , holding [her]5736-she hand , down to [[her]5736-she ferry]1512-her ferry again ; [she]5736-she kissed [him]390-the youngling in thanks for [his]390-the youngling meat , and [he]390-the youngling reddened thereat but said nought . [All the whole rout of little ones]5744-all the whole rout of little ones had followed [her]5736-she down to [the water]361-the water , and now [they]5744-all the whole rout of little ones stood , as thick as bees on a honeycomb , on the bank , to watch [her]5736-she departure . But if [they]5744-all the whole rout of little ones were keen to see [her]5736-she doings before , how much keener were [they]5744-all the whole rout of little ones when it came to the baring of [her]5736-she arm and the smearing of [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat . To be short , so keen were [they]5744-all the whole rout of little ones , and pushed and shoved [each other]580-each other so sturdily , that [more than one or two]5748-more than one or two fell into the water , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone was frighted lest [they]5744-all the whole rout of little ones should drown ; but [they]5744-all the whole rout of little ones swam like ducks , and got on to [the land]213-the land when [they]5744-all the whole rout of little ones would , which was not so very soon , for [some of [them]5744-all the whole rout of little ones]5554-some of them hung unto the gunwale of [the boat]859-the boat , and hove [their]5554-some of them faces up to look over into it , and left not hold till [the ferry]1951-the ferry was fairly under weigh and beginning to quicken [its]1951-the ferry speed .

So left [Birdalone]101-birdalone [the isle]642-the isle , and nought befell [her]101-birdalone on the way to [the Isle of Increase Unsought]2034-the isle of increase unsought .

CHAPTER XIV . [THE SENDING BOAT]16-the sending boat [DISAPPEARETH FROM [THE ISLE]26-the isle OF INCREASE UNSOUGHT]78-disappeareth from the isle of increase unsought , AND [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone SEEKETH TO ESCAPE THENCE BY SWIMMING

It was as before that [Birdalone]101-birdalone came to [the shore of [the isle]642-the isle]5755-the shore of the isle while it was yet night ; but [the wizard keel]5757-the wizard keel was so loathsome to [her]101-birdalone , that [she]101-birdalone stepped out of it and laid [her]101-birdalone down on [the land]213-the land for what was left of the night ; yet hard [she]101-birdalone found [her]101-birdalone bed , and neither grassy nor flowery .

For all that , [she]101-birdalone slept , for [she]101-birdalone was weary , and it was broad day and not very early when [she]101-birdalone awoke . [She]101-birdalone stood up trembling , for [she]101-birdalone foreboded evil , so near as [she]101-birdalone was to [the dwelling of [[her]101-birdalone old mistress]2683-her old mistress]5759-the dwelling of her old mistress ; and [she]101-birdalone looked up to where in time past was [the fair and wicked house]5761-the fair and wicked house , and saw that all was changed indeed ; for no longer was [the isle]642-the isle goodly with meadow and [orchard]1083-orchard and [garden]1084-garden , but was waste and bare , and nought grew on [it]642-the isle save thin and wiry grass , already seeding even ere [June]100-june was born , and here and there hard and ugly herbs , with scarce aught that might be called a flower amongst them . Trees there were yet , but the most of them stark dead , and the best dying fast . No beasts [she]101-birdalone saw , nor fowl ; nothing but lizards and beetles , and now and again a dry grey adder coiled up about a sun - burned stone .
