But of great carrion flies , green and blue , were there a many , and whiles they buzzed about [her]101-birdalone head till [she]101-birdalone sickened with loathing of them . All this [she]101-birdalone found on [her]101-birdalone way as [she]101-birdalone went up toward the place where erst was the great perron . But when [she]101-birdalone came to the top there was no sign either of the stairs or [the house]325-the house , or aught that ever was builded ; there was nought but the bare bent top , ungrassed , parched by wind , scorched by sun , washed by rain .

[She]101-birdalone wandered about [the isle]642-the isle , to [places where [she]101-birdalone had not been [herself]101-birdalone , but which [she]101-birdalone deemed [she]101-birdalone might have known by the telling of [the Green Knight]124-hugh 's tale]5767-places where she had not been herself , but which she deemed she might have known by the telling of the green knight 's tale , had there been no change since those days ; but now was all changed , and [the whole isle]5768-the whole isle was a mere waste , and withal poisonous of aspect to [her]101-birdalone mind , as if many corpses lay underneath the wretched stones of [it]5768-the whole isle . Nevertheless , though it seemed so evil unto [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]101-birdalone lingered on [it]5768-the whole isle , wandering about till [she]101-birdalone was to - wearied , for [she]101-birdalone had no will to depart at such time as [she]101-birdalone would be like to come to [[her]101-birdalone old abiding - place]5769-her old abiding - place by night and cloud ; wherefore [she]101-birdalone dallied with the time , and came not back to [the haven of [[her]101-birdalone ferry]1512-her ferry]5770-the haven of her ferry till it was nigh sunset , and the westering sun was in [her]101-birdalone eyes when [she]101-birdalone came [there]232-there ; and [she]101-birdalone said to [herself]101-birdalone that this was the cause why [she]101-birdalone might not see [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat .

So [she]101-birdalone cleared [her]101-birdalone eyes and looked on the thin grass awhile , and then down over [the edge of [the land]213-the land]5774-the edge of the land , and still [she]101-birdalone saw not [[her]101-birdalone boat]5643-her boat . [She]101-birdalone turned pale , and a pang of anguish went to [her]101-birdalone heart ; but [she]101-birdalone walked a little east , deeming that perchance [she]101-birdalone had erred as to [the place of [the haven]5778-the haven on [that dull and empty shore]5779-that dull and empty shore]5777-the place of the haven on that dull and empty shore ; but yet there was [no boat]422-no boat . Then [she]101-birdalone turned back wild with terror , and sought where erst [she]101-birdalone had missed it , and found [neither boat]2584-neither boat nor [the world]430-the world 's end . And [she]101-birdalone deemed that there might be some devilish malice of [the wight of the Sending Boat]5783-the wight of the sending boat , to torment [her]101-birdalone with fear , and [she]101-birdalone walked along [the land]213-the land 's edge up and down , and down and up , further each time , and still there was [no boat]422-no boat .

Then [she]101-birdalone stood still and strove to think , and might not , nor might [she]101-birdalone do aught , but spread abroad [her]101-birdalone hands and moaned in [her]101-birdalone agony ; for now indeed [she]101-birdalone felt [herself]101-birdalone in the trap ; and [she]101-birdalone said that all [her]101-birdalone past life of hope and desire and love and honour was all for nought , and that [she]101-birdalone was but born to die miserably in [that foul ruin of [an isle]5787-an isle]5786-that foul ruin of an isle envenomed with the memories of bygone cruelty and shame .

But in a little while [she]101-birdalone came somewhat to [herself]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone said : At least [this hideous land]5788-this hideous land shall not mock [my]0-i dying anguish ; [I]0-i will give [myself]0-i to [the water]361-the water and let it do with [me]0-i as it will .

Therewith [she]101-birdalone cast off [her]101-birdalone helm and hauberk first , and [her]101-birdalone weapons , and [her]101-birdalone pouch with the treasure that could buy nought for [her]101-birdalone now , and thereafter all [her]101-birdalone raiment , till [she]101-birdalone was as naked as when [she]101-birdalone first came aland [there]232-there that other time . Again [she]101-birdalone moaned , and put up [her]101-birdalone hand to [her]101-birdalone bosom and felt a little gold box lying there betwixt the fragrant hills of [her]101-birdalone breasts , which hung to a thin golden thread about [her]101-birdalone neck ; and a thought came into [her]101-birdalone mind , and [she]101-birdalone stooped adown and drew from [her]101-birdalone pouch flint and fire - steel , and then opened the said golden box and drew thence the tress which [Habundia the wood - wife]5791-habundia the wood - wife had given to [her]101-birdalone those years agone , and all trembling [she]101-birdalone drew two hairs from it , as erst [she]101-birdalone did on [the Isle of Nothing]41-the isle of nothing , and struck fire and kindled tinder and burnt the said hairs , and then hung the golden box with the tress therein about [her]101-birdalone neck again ; and [she]101-birdalone said : [O wood - mother]1914-o wood - mother , if only [thou]5793-thou couldst know of [me]0-i and see [me]0-i , [thou]5793-thou wouldst help [me]0-i !

Thereafter [she]101-birdalone sought along [the bank]1043-the bank for bread which [she]101-birdalone had taken from [[her]101-birdalone store]5795-her store that morning , and [she]101-birdalone found it , and compelled [herself]101-birdalone to eat of it for the strengthening of [her]101-birdalone body , and then [she]101-birdalone stood and abode tidings ; and by then the sun had just sunk below the rim of [the lake]369-the lake , and the stars began to twinkle , for the night was cloudless , and exceeding fair , and very warm .

No visible token came to [her]101-birdalone , but [her]101-birdalone heart grew stronger , and [she]101-birdalone seemed to see [herself]101-birdalone yet alive and in hope on the other side of [the water]361-the water ; and [she]101-birdalone said : Who wotteth what Weird may do , or where [the waters]636-the waters may bear [me]0-i ? and there is no swimmer stronger than [I.]5799-i.

So then without more ado [Birdalone]101-birdalone slipped into the water , which lay before [her]101-birdalone as calm and plain as a great sheet of glass , and fell to rowing with [her]101-birdalone arms and [her]101-birdalone legs as though [she]101-birdalone were but swimming from [Green Eyot]8-green eyot to [the mainland]1038-the mainland , as so oft [she]101-birdalone had done in the other days .

CHAPTER XV . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone LACKETH LITTLE OF DROWNING , BUT COMETH LATTERLY TO [THE GREEN EYOT]79-the green eyot

On swam [Birdalone]101-birdalone , not as one who had a mind to drown [her]101-birdalone for the forgetting of troubles , but both strongly and wisely ; and [she]101-birdalone turned over on to [her]101-birdalone back , and looked on the stars above [her]101-birdalone , and steered [herself]101-birdalone by them thitherward whereas [she]101-birdalone deemed was [the land under the wood]5801-the land under the wood . When [she]101-birdalone had been gone from [the evil isle]5802-the evil isle for an hour or so , there rose a fair little wind behind [her]101-birdalone , which helped [her]101-birdalone forward , but scarce raised the water more than a little ripple .

Still [she]101-birdalone swam on , and it was some three hours [she]101-birdalone began to weary , and then [she]101-birdalone floated on [her]101-birdalone back and let the wind and water have its way with [her]101-birdalone ; and now the night was as dark as it would be ere dawn .

Thus it went for another hour , that whiles [she]101-birdalone swam on and whiles [she]101-birdalone floated ; and now [her]101-birdalone heart began to fail [her]101-birdalone , and the great water was no longer unto [her]101-birdalone a wet highway , but a terrible gulf over which [she]101-birdalone hung fainting .

Nevertheless [she]101-birdalone did not give up doing what [she]101-birdalone might : [she]101-birdalone floated supine a long while , and then , when [she]101-birdalone had gathered a little strength , turned over again and struck out , still steering [her]101-birdalone by the stars . But [she]101-birdalone had scarce made three strokes ere [her]101-birdalone arms met something hard and rough ; and at first in [her]101-birdalone forlornness [she]101-birdalone deemed [she]101-birdalone had happened on some dread water monster , and for terror of it [she]101-birdalone sank down into the deep , but came up presently blinded and breathless , and spread abroad [her]101-birdalone arms , and again [they]5803-they came on the thing aforesaid , and this time found that it was nought alive , but the bole of a tree sitting high out of [the water]361-the water . So [she]101-birdalone clomb up on to it with what might [she]101-birdalone had left , and sat [her]101-birdalone down , and saw in the dim light that it was big , and that there was a fork betwixt two limbs reaching up into the air , and [she]101-birdalone thrust [herself]101-birdalone in between these two limbs and embraced one of them , so that [she]101-birdalone might scarce tumble off ; and a great content and happiness came over [her]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone had thus escaped from the death of the deep ; but therewithal weariness overcame [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone slept , whether [she]101-birdalone would or not ; and the bole went on over [the waters]636-the waters no slower than might have been looked for , whether it were by the pushing on of the south wind , or by the hand of [Weird]161-weird that would not have [her]101-birdalone die .

Long [she]101-birdalone slumbered , for when [she]101-birdalone awoke it was broad day and the sun was shining high in the heavens , and [she]101-birdalone cleared [her]101-birdalone eyes and looked around , and saw before [her]101-birdalone [the land]213-the land , but yet blue in the offing . And the tree - bole was yet speeding on towards [the shore]358-the shore , as if it were being drawn there by some bidding of might .

Now indeed grew [Birdalone]101-birdalone happy , and [she]101-birdalone thought if any had helped [her]101-birdalone it must have been [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother once again ; and [she]101-birdalone said to [herself]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone should soon meet with [that helper]5809-that helper ; nor heeded [she]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone was naked and unfurnished of any goods , whereas [she]101-birdalone deemed indeed that it was but to ask and have of [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend .

For a while indeed [she]101-birdalone knew not whither [she]101-birdalone was wending , and if [her]101-birdalone face were verily turned toward [the land under the wood]5801-the land under the wood ; but as the morning wore the blue distance began to grow green , and then [she]101-birdalone saw that a great wood was indeed before [her]101-birdalone , and thereafter , as it cleared yet more , [she]101-birdalone knew [the land]213-the land [she]101-birdalone was nearing for [the meadows of [the House under the Wood]2453-the house under the wood]5813-the meadows of the house under the wood , and it was not long thence ere [she]101-birdalone saw clear and close [Green Eyot]8-green eyot and [Rocky Eyot]80-rocky eyot , though [the house]325-the house was yet hidden from [her]101-birdalone by [the green shores of the first of [those two isles]5817-those two isles]5816-the green shores of the first of those two isles .

Shortly to tell it , [her]101-birdalone tree - bole floated with [her]101-birdalone past [the outer ness of [Green Eyot]8-green eyot]5818-the outer ness of green eyot , and came ashore in [that same sandy bight]5819-that same sandy bight where erst [she]101-birdalone was wonted to make [her]101-birdalone body ready for [the water]361-the water . [She]101-birdalone stepped ashore all glad to feel the firm warm sand underneath [her]101-birdalone foot - soles , and as one drunk with joy [she]101-birdalone was when the tall flowery grass of the latter May was caressing [her]101-birdalone legs as they shook the seed - dust off the bents , and smote the fragrance out of the blossoms ; and [she]101-birdalone might scarce at first lift [her]101-birdalone eyes from [their]5821-their familiar loveliness . Glad [she]101-birdalone was indeed , but exceeding worn and weary with the long voyage , and all the longing and fear and hope which had encompassed [her]101-birdalone that while . [She]101-birdalone lifted up [her]101-birdalone eyes but once , and saw [[the witch]407-the witch 's house]4791-the witch 's house standing where [it]4791-the witch 's house was wo nt , but no shape of [man]548-man moving about [it]4791-the witch 's house ; then [she]101-birdalone turned aside to a little brake of thorn and eglantine in [the meadow]510-the meadow hard by , and laid [her]101-birdalone down on the grass in the shade thereof , and almost before [her]101-birdalone head touched [the ground]1690-the ground [she]101-birdalone fell asleep , and slept there long and peacefully .

CHAPTER XVI . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone FINDETH [[HER]5827-her WITCH]5828-her witch - MISTRESS DEAD

It was some while after noon when [she]101-birdalone wakened , and the sun was shining bright and hot . Somewhat [she]101-birdalone felt the burden of fear upon [her]101-birdalone , even before [she]101-birdalone was fully come to [herself]101-birdalone , and knew not what it was that [she]101-birdalone feared ; but when [she]101-birdalone called to mind that it was even the meeting with [[her]101-birdalone old mistress]2683-her old mistress , [her]101-birdalone flesh quaked indeed with the memory of bygone anguish , but valiantly [she]101-birdalone arose and faced the dwelling of [the witch]407-the witch despite [her]101-birdalone naked helplessness . As [she]101-birdalone went [she]101-birdalone looked up unto [it]5831-it , and saw no smoke coming from the chimney , but marvelled little thereat since it was not yet cooking - time and the weather hot . [She]101-birdalone drew nigher , and saw [someone sitting on the bench without the door]5832-someone sitting on the bench without the door whereas [the witch]407-the witch was wonted ; and [her]101-birdalone heart beat quick , for [she]101-birdalone saw presently that it was [none other than [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress]5834-none other than her mistress . Moreover , near to [her]101-birdalone stood three of [the milch - kine lowing uneasily and as in reproach , even as such beasts]5836-the milch - kine lowing uneasily and as in reproach , even as such beasts use when [their]5837-their udders be full and [they]5837-their desire to be milked .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone stayed a minute , and [her]101-birdalone legs nigh failed [her]101-birdalone for fear , and then because of the very fear [she]101-birdalone hastened on till [she]101-birdalone came within ten paces of [the said witch]4231-the said witch ; and sore [she]101-birdalone missed [her]101-birdalone bow and arrows , and the cutting blade of [her]101-birdalone feigned squirehood , lest the carline should arise and come raging and shrieking at [her]101-birdalone .

Then spake [Birdalone]101-birdalone in no feeble voice , and said : Dame , [I]0-i am come back unto [thee]101-birdalone , as [thou]101-birdalone seest , in even such plight as [I]0-i fled from [thee]101-birdalone ; and [I]0-i have a mind to dwell in [this land]1264-this land : what sayest [thou]101-birdalone ? [The witch]407-the witch neither moved nor spake at [her]407-the witch word ; and [the kine , who had held silence]5841-the kine , who had held silence when [she]407-the witch first came up , and had turned from [her]407-the witch , fell to [their]5841-the kine , who had held silence peevish lowing again .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone drew a step nigher , and said : Dost [thou]101-birdalone hear [me]0-i , [dame]5842-dame , or art [thou]101-birdalone exceeding wroth with [me]0-i , and art pondering what vengeance [thou]101-birdalone wilt take on [me]0-i ? Still no answer came from [the carline]1452-the carline , and [the kine]5844-the kine kept on lowing now and again . Once more [Birdalone]101-birdalone drew nigher , and spake loudly and said : Tell [me]0-i at least , is it peace between [us]5845-us or unpeace ?

But now when [she]101-birdalone looked [she]101-birdalone saw that the eyes of [the witch]407-the witch were open and staring , and [her]407-the witch lips white , and [her]407-the witch hands hard writhen ; and [she]101-birdalone cried out and said : Is [she]407-the witch dead ? or will [she]407-the witch waken presently and beat [me]0-i ? surely [she]407-the witch is dead . And [she]101-birdalone put forth [her]101-birdalone hand and touched [her]101-birdalone face , and it was stone - cold ; and [she]101-birdalone found that [she]101-birdalone was dead beyond any question .

Then was a great weight lifted off [her]101-birdalone heart , and [she]101-birdalone turned about and looked on [the meadows]2079-the meadows and up to the trees of the wood and down to the rippling stream before [her]101-birdalone , and fair and sweet and joyous were [they]5848-they gotten unto [her]101-birdalone ; and [she]101-birdalone looked at [the kine who were drawing up]5849-the kine who were drawing up towards [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone laughed merrily , and went to [the out - house]5850-the out - house hard by and took forth a milking - pail and a stool and fell to milking [them]5848-they one after the other , and the beasts went off down [the meadow]510-the meadow lowing in a changed voice , for joy to wit , this time . But [Birdalone]101-birdalone knelt down and drank a long draught of the sweet warm milk , and then arose and went swiftly into [the house]325-the house , and saw nought changed or worsened so far as [she]101-birdalone could see . There was [her]101-birdalone own bed in the corner , and [the mistress]709-the mistress 's , greater and much fairer , over against it ; and the hutch by the door wherein the victual was kept : [she]101-birdalone opened it now , and found three loaves there on the shelf , and a meal - tub down below , and [she]101-birdalone took a loaf and broke it and fell to eating it as [she]101-birdalone walked about [the chamber]306-the chamber . There was [her]101-birdalone bow standing in a nook beside the hutch , and the quiver of arrows hanging on the wall above it . There was the settle lying athwart from the hearth ; and [she]101-birdalone smiled , and fitted [her]101-birdalone wrists to the back of the carven bear which made its elbow , whereto [the witch]407-the witch was wo nt to tie them when [she]407-the witch chastised [her]101-birdalone .

Then [she]101-birdalone went to the coffers that stood against the wall behind [it]5856-it , and threw up the lid of one of them , and found therein a smock or two of [her]101-birdalone own , yellowed by the lapse of time , and [her]101-birdalone old grey coat , ragged as it was when last [she]101-birdalone wore it , and now somewhat moth - eaten withal ; and [she]101-birdalone drew forth both smocks and coat and laid them on the settle . Then [she]101-birdalone opened another coffer , and therein were gay and gaudy gowns and gear of [the witch]407-the witch 's wear ; but lying amongst them , as if [the witch]407-the witch had worn them also , [her]407-the witch green gown and shoon which [her]407-the witch own hands had broidered . But [she]101-birdalone said : Nay , [ye]5859-ye have been in ill company , [I]0-i will wear [you]5859-ye not , though [ye]5859-ye be goodly , at least not till [ye]5859-ye have been fumigated and hallowed for [me]0-i .

Therewith [she]101-birdalone turned back to [the settle]5860-the settle and did on [her]101-birdalone [her]101-birdalone old smock and [her]101-birdalone ragged grey coat , and said : To - day at least will these be good enough for to - day 's work . And [she]101-birdalone knit [her]101-birdalone brow withal , and walked with a firm step out - a - doors and stood a while gazing on the dead corpse of [[her]101-birdalone enemy]5861-her enemy ; and [she]101-birdalone thought how that here was that which once was so great a thing unto [her]101-birdalone for the shaping of [her]101-birdalone life- days , and which so oft came to [her]101-birdalone waking thoughts after [she]101-birdalone had escaped from [her]101-birdalone hands , though , as aforesaid , [she]101-birdalone seldom dreamed of [her]101-birdalone a - night - time , and moreover an hour ago [she]101-birdalone yet feared it so sore that [she]101-birdalone scarce might stand for the fear of it ; and now it was nought but a carven log unto [her]101-birdalone .

But [she]101-birdalone told [herself]101-birdalone that the work was to be done ; so [she]101-birdalone dragged the body away thence , and across [the brook]711-the brook , and a little way into [the meadow]510-the meadow , and then [she]101-birdalone went back and fetched mattock and spade from [the outhouse]5864-the outhouse , where [she]101-birdalone knew they lay , and so fell to digging a grave for the corpse of [her]101-birdalone dead terror . But howso hard [she]101-birdalone might toil , [she]101-birdalone was not through with the work ere night began to fall on [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone had no mind to go on with [her]101-birdalone digging by night . Wherefore [she]101-birdalone went back into [the house]325-the house , and lighted candles , whereof was no lack , and made [her]101-birdalone supper of the bread and the milk ; and then sat pondering on [her]101-birdalone life that had been till the passion arose in [her]101-birdalone bosom , and the tears burst out , and long [she]101-birdalone wept for desire of [others]2441-others and pity for [herself]101-birdalone . Then [she]101-birdalone went to the bed [she]101-birdalone had been erst wo nt to , and laid [her]101-birdalone down and fell asleep .

And [[her]101-birdalone mistress]419-her mistress walked not , nor meddled with [her]101-birdalone peace ; nor did [Birdalone]101-birdalone so much as dream of [her]101-birdalone , but of [[her]101-birdalone mother]332-her mother and [Master Jacobus]185-jacobus in [the fair city of the Five Crafts]5869-the fair city of the five crafts ; and in [her]101-birdalone sleep [she]101-birdalone wept for thinking of [them]5870-them .

CHAPTER XVII . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone LAYETH TO EARTH THE BODY OF [THE WITCH]407-the witch , AND FINDETH THE SENDING BOAT BROKEN UP

When morning was , [Birdalone]101-birdalone awoke , and felt a weight upon [her]101-birdalone heart , and called to mind the task which lay before [her]101-birdalone . So [she]101-birdalone arose and clad [herself]101-birdalone , and went straight to [the grave begun]5872-the grave begun , and toiled hard till [she]101-birdalone had digged it out deep , and sithence [she]101-birdalone dragged [the witch]407-the witch thereinto and heaped the earth upon [her]101-birdalone . Then [she]101-birdalone bathed [her]101-birdalone in [the nighest pool of the brook]5874-the nighest pool of the brook , and went back into [the house]325-the house and made [her]101-birdalone breakfast on the bread and milk , and it was then about mid - morning . Thereafter [she]101-birdalone went about [the house]325-the house , and saw to the baking of bread , and so out to [the meadow]510-the meadow to see to [the kine]5844-the kine and the goats , and then stored the milk for making butter and cheese , and did in all wise as if [she]101-birdalone were to dwell long in that stead ; but thereafter [she]101-birdalone rested [her]101-birdalone body , whiles [her]101-birdalone thought went wide about . But [she]101-birdalone said to [herself]101-birdalone that [she]101-birdalone would not go up to [the Oak of [Tryst]13-tryst]5879-the oak of tryst to meet [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother that day , but would abide the night , in case aught befell that [she]101-birdalone should tell [her]101-birdalone .

But when the sun was getting low [she]101-birdalone roused [herself]101-birdalone and went out , and walked about [the meadow]510-the meadow , and hearkened to the birds ' song , and watched [the kine]5844-the kine and the goats as [they]5844-the kine fed down [the pasture]7167-the pasture ; and now a soft content came over [her]101-birdalone , that all this was free unto [her]101-birdalone to hold in peace , and to take [her]101-birdalone pleasure in , as much as [one lone child of Adam]7168-one lone child of adam might do .[101-birdalone]

At last [she]101-birdalone wandered down to [the sandy bight of [the lake]369-the lake]5882-the sandy bight of the lake and stood gazing on [Green Eyot]8-green eyot , where the osiers and willows were grown wild and long in all these years , and [she]101-birdalone said that [she]101-birdalone would swim over to [it]8-green eyot on the morrow . But now [her]101-birdalone feet took [her]101-birdalone eastward thence toward [the haven of [the Sending]40-the sending [Boat amongst]5885-boat amongst [the alders]5886-the alders]5884-the haven of the sending boat amongst the alders ; for in [her]101-birdalone heart [she]101-birdalone would fain know if there were any tidings for [her]101-birdalone .

So [she]101-birdalone went softly along the path by [the water]361-the water , where [she]101-birdalone had sped so swiftly that last time , and came at last to [the creek - side]852-the creek - side , and looked down on to [the water]361-the water somewhat timorously . There then [she]101-birdalone saw what [she]101-birdalone deemed was [the very boat itself]5890-the very boat itself lying as [she]101-birdalone had known it ; but when [she]101-birdalone looked again [she]101-birdalone saw that it lay from stem to stern all loose staves with the water betwixt , and the thwarts and ribs all sundered and undone , so that never again might it float upon the waves . Then [she]101-birdalone said in a soft voice : Art [thou]5891-thou dead then , as [[thy]5891-thou mistress]564-thy mistress is dead ? was it not so that [thou]5891-thou wert at the point of death , and [she]564-thy mistress also , when [thou]5891-thou failedst [me]0-i at [the Isle of Increase Unsought]22-the isle of increase unsought ? No voice came to [her]101-birdalone as [she]101-birdalone spake ; and [she]101-birdalone said again : Must [I]0-i then bury [thee]5891-thou as [I]0-i have buried [[thy]5891-thou mistress]564-thy mistress ? Nay , that will [I]0-i not until [thou]5891-thou compellest [me]0-i ; belike in a short while little of the staves of [thee]5891-thou shall be left now that the life is out of [thee]5891-thou . Let [thy]5891-thou ghost and [hers]564-thy mistress foregather if [ye]5891-thou will .

As [she]101-birdalone spake the last word , [she]101-birdalone saw a stir about the stern which lay furthest in up [the creek]687-the creek , and while [she]101-birdalone quaked with failing heart , lo ! a big serpent , mouldy and hairy , grey and brown - flecked , came forth from under the stern and went into [the water]361-the water and up [the bank]1043-the bank and so into the dusk of [the alder - wood]5897-the alder - wood . [Birdalone]101-birdalone stood awhile pale and heartsick for fear , and when [her]101-birdalone feet felt life in them , [she]101-birdalone turned and stole away back again into the merry green mead and the low beams of the sun , pondering whether [this evil creature]5898-this evil creature were the fetch of [the wight who drave the ferry under the blood of the sender]5899-the wight who drave the ferry under the blood of the sender .

So [she]101-birdalone hastened back again to [the house]325-the house , and lit a fire on the hearth , and fell to cooking [her]101-birdalone somewhat of grout to [her]101-birdalone supper ; and [she]101-birdalone watched the fire , thinking withal : Now if [some poor soul]5901-some poor soul be abroad , [they]5901-some poor soul may see the smoke and seek hither , and [I]0-i may comfort [them]5901-some poor soul with food and shelter and converse ; or when night darkens , [they]5901-some poor soul may see the litten windows and come to [me]0-i ; wherefore shall the fire burn yet and the candles be lighted , for as warm as is the evening , even as if it were Yule - tide and the snow deep without , and the wind howling in the woodland trees . And therewith [she]101-birdalone wept for longing of [them]5901-some poor soul that [she]101-birdalone loved .

But in a little [she]101-birdalone dried [her]101-birdalone tears , and reproached [herself]101-birdalone for [her]101-birdalone much softness ; and [she]101-birdalone ate [her]101-birdalone supper when [she]101-birdalone had lighted a candle for it was now dark , and again sat looking at the hearth , till [she]101-birdalone said : Now am [I]0-i getting soft again , and who knows but [my]0-i softness may tempt the ghosts to come in to [me]0-i . [I]0-i will give [my]0-i hands somewhat to do .

Therewith [her]101-birdalone eye caught sight of the rents and rags of [her]101-birdalone old grey gown , and [she]101-birdalone smiled somewhat ruefully as [she]101-birdalone called to mind [[her]101-birdalone gallant knight]5902-her gallant knight 's array , which lay now on [the shore of the evil and ruined isle]5903-the shore of the evil and ruined isle ; and [her]101-birdalone goodly attire of the days of the Five Crafts ; and the rich raiment wherein [[her]101-birdalone friends of [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest]5904-her friends of the castle of the quest had clad [her]101-birdalone . Then [she]101-birdalone arose and sought needle and thread and some remnants of green cloth , and did off the ragged coat and fell to patching and mending it , and so sat at [her]101-birdalone work in smock - sewing till the night was old and [she]101-birdalone was weary and sleep overcame [her]101-birdalone , and [she]101-birdalone lay down in [her]101-birdalone bed and slept dreamlessly till the sun was high next morning .

CHAPTER XVIII . [THE WOOD - MOTHER]200-the wood - mother COMETH TO [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone AND HEARETH [HER]101-birdalone STORY

Now [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose and bathed [her]101-birdalone and broke [her]101-birdalone fast , and then went about [her]101-birdalone work with the beasts and the dairy ; but all that time seemed long to [her]101-birdalone till [she]101-birdalone had bow in hand and quiver on back , and was wending [her]101-birdalone way to [the Oak of [Tryst]13-tryst]5879-the oak of tryst ; and swift were [her]101-birdalone feet and [her]101-birdalone heart beat quick with hope of pleasure .

Forsooth no long tarrying had [she]101-birdalone , for scarce had [she]101-birdalone set [her]101-birdalone down beneath the oak , ere [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother came forth from the thicket even as the first time when [Birdalone]101-birdalone saw [her]101-birdalone , and presently [she]934-the wood - mother had [her]934-the wood - mother arms about [Birdalone]101-birdalone and was kissing and clipping [her]101-birdalone . Then [they]5908-they sat down together in the shade of the great tree , and [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother made much of [[her]934-the wood - mother friend]446-her friend with few words and those but simple , while [Birdalone]101-birdalone wept for joy .

At last spake [Birdalone]101-birdalone : [Wood - mother]1915-wood - mother , [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear , [I]0-i look in [thy]101-birdalone face , and [I]0-i see [thee]101-birdalone that [thou]101-birdalone art nowise changed , so that [thou]101-birdalone callest to [my]0-i mind the Birdalone that met [thee]101-birdalone here when [she]101-birdalone was straying from [the House of Captivity]1021-the house of captivity like to a bird with a string to its leg .

[Habundia]106-habundia smiled on [her]101-birdalone and said : So it is that now [thou]101-birdalone lookest older than [I.]106-habundia Rounder and fuller is [thy]101-birdalone body , and [thy]101-birdalone limbs greater and fairer , and [thy]101-birdalone flesh sleeker ; lovelier art [thou]101-birdalone in all wise , and such as [I]0-i have thought of [thee]101-birdalone during these years , save that [thy]101-birdalone face is grown wiser and sadder than might be looked for . [Mother]200-the wood - mother , [she]101-birdalone said , [I]0-i am grown older than [I]0-i should be by the tale of the years , for [I]0-i have had joy and grief , and grief and joy , and grief again ; and now that the years have worn , the grief abideth and the joy hath departed , save this joy of [thee]101-birdalone and the day of the meeting [I]0-i have so often thought of .

Said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife : Were [I]0-i to hear the story of [thee]101-birdalone , [I]0-i deem it most like that [I]0-i would fain buy [thy]101-birdalone joy with [thy]101-birdalone grief , both that which has been and that which is to come . And now [I]0-i will ask [thee]101-birdalone right out to tell [me]0-i all [thy]101-birdalone tale , as much as [thou]101-birdalone canst ; and all [thou]101-birdalone canst tell to [me]0-i , who am thine other self : and [I]0-i wot moreover that [thou]101-birdalone hast not told of [me]0-i to [any whom [thou]101-birdalone hast met in [the world]430-the world since [we]5917-we were last together]5915-any whom thou hast met in the world since we were last together : is it not so ? In faith and in troth so it is , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . Said [Habundia]106-habundia , after [she]106-habundia had looked hard on [Birdalone]101-birdalone a while : Now there is this [I]0-i find in [thee]101-birdalone , that though [thou]101-birdalone callest [me]0-i [wood - mother]1915-wood - mother still , [thou]101-birdalone art not [[my]0-i daughter]897-my daughter as [thou]101-birdalone wert erewhile , nor [I]0-i [[thy]101-birdalone mother]337-thy mother ; and [I]0-i know not whether to be glad or sorry thereof , since [thou]101-birdalone art even as much [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend as ever [thou]101-birdalone wert . But much do [I]0-i rejoice herein that [thou]101-birdalone hast not told any one soul of [me]0-i .

Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : [I]0-i must tell [thee]101-birdalone that part of the tale [I]0-i shall tell [thee]101-birdalone is how [I]0-i have found [[my]0-i mother]902-my mother in the flesh , and loved [her]902-my mother sorely ; and then [I]0-i lost [her]902-my mother again , for [she]902-my mother is dead .

Quoth [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife , smiling on [her]570-the wood - wife lovingly : Then should [I]0-i be even more [[thy]101-birdalone mother]337-thy mother than erst [I]0-i was : there will be something else in [thy]101-birdalone tale , sweetling .

Then [Birdalone]101-birdalone flushed very red , and [she]101-birdalone smiled piteously in [Habundia]106-habundia 's face ; but then [she]101-birdalone put up [her]101-birdalone hands to hide the change therein which the anguish of longing wrought , and [her]101-birdalone shoulders shook and [her]101-birdalone bosom heaved , and [she]101-birdalone wept bitterly ; but [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife still looked on [her]570-the wood - wife smiling , and said softly at last : Yea , how sweet it were to be grieved with [thy]101-birdalone pain .

But in a while [Birdalone]101-birdalone grew calm again and the very smile blossomed out in [her]101-birdalone face , and [they]5926-they kissed together . Then [Habundia]106-habundia rose up and looked on [her]101-birdalone , and said at last and laughed out withal : One thing [I]0-i must needs say , that [thou]5927-thou hast not fetched [thee]5927-thou raiment of price from [the knighthood]4816-the knighthood and [[the kings]1880-the kings ' houses]7169-the kings ' houses ; or have [I]934-the wood - mother not seen [thy]5927-thou grey coat of old time , while [thou]5927-thou wert living amidst [the witch]407-the witch 's cruelty ? Yea forsooth , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; [thou]5927-thou needest not to ask this . Verily not , said [Habundia]106-habundia , nor why [thou]5927-thou art not clad in the fair green gown which [thou]5927-thou didst broider ; for whiles [I]934-the wood - mother have seen [the witch]407-the witch flaunting it on the wooden ugly body of [her]407-the witch , and [thou]5927-thou wouldst not wear it after [she]407-the witch had cursed it with [her]407-the witch foulness . Is it not so ? Yea , it is even so , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; dost [thou]5927-thou love [me]934-the wood - mother the less therefor ? [Habundia]106-habundia laughed again : Were [I]934-the wood - mother [a man of [Adam]103-adam 's sons]7172-a man of adam 's sons , said [she]106-habundia , [I]934-the wood - mother might make [thee]5927-thou many words on the seemliness of [thy]5927-thou short coat , and the kindness of it , that it will be for ever slipping off one or other of [thy]5927-thou shoulders . But now am [I]934-the wood - mother at least enough [[thy]5927-thou mother]337-thy mother , and [thou]5927-thou art dwelling even so much in [[my]934-the wood - mother house]4770-my house , that the next time [we]7175-we meet and that shall be to - morrow [I]934-the wood - mother shall fetch [thee]5927-thou raiment which shall make [us]7175-we forget that [thou]5927-thou camest back again to [this land]1264-this land as naked as [thou]5927-thou didst depart thence .[934-the wood - mother]

[Birdalone]101-birdalone reddened and hung down [her]101-birdalone head , but [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother sat down beside [her]101-birdalone and kissed [her]101-birdalone and said : But now forget all save [thy]934-the wood - mother tale , and tell all as closely as [thou]934-the wood - mother mayest , for [I]0-i would lose nought thereof . Yea , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; and where shall [I]0-i begin ? Said [Habundia]106-habundia : [I]0-i know nought thereof save the beginning , that [thou]934-the wood - mother fledst away naked and escaped [the witch]407-the witch ; and the ending , to wit , that [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat failed [thee]934-the wood - mother at the last of [the Wonder Isles]37-wonder isles , and that [thou]934-the wood - mother calledst on [me]0-i not wholly in vain , whereas [the witch]407-the witch was dead , and therefore there was nought to stay [me]0-i from sending [thee]934-the wood - mother one of [[my]0-i trees]5934-my trees and the wight thereof whom belike [I]0-i may show to [thee]934-the wood - mother one day to save [thee]934-the wood - mother from [the bottom of [the deep water]5936-the deep water]5935-the bottom of the deep water .

At that word [Birdalone]101-birdalone threw [herself]101-birdalone on [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife and clipped and kissed [her]570-the wood - wife , and thanked [her]570-the wood - wife for the helping with all the dearest words [she]101-birdalone might . But [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother laughed for joy , and stroked [her]101-birdalone cheeks and said : Now [I]0-i deem [thee]101-birdalone [[my]0-i daughter]897-my daughter again , whereas [thou]101-birdalone thankest [me]0-i with such sweet passion for doing to [thee]101-birdalone as [a kind mother]5940-a kind mother needs must without any thought thereof . And [I]0-i bid [thee]101-birdalone , [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear , never again to go so far from [me]0-i as that [I]0-i may not easily help [thee]101-birdalone and comfort [thee]101-birdalone from out of [[my]0-i realm]5942-my realm wherein [I]0-i am mighty . And now tell [me]0-i all in [thy]101-birdalone dear speech .

Therewith [Birdalone]101-birdalone began [her]101-birdalone story without more ado , even as [ye]5943-ye have heard it afore . [Yea]5943-ye and many more things than [we]5944-we can set down did [she]101-birdalone tell , for full filled [she]101-birdalone was with the wisdom of [the wood]348-the wood . And between whiles [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother fed [her]101-birdalone with dainty meat and drink , such as [Birdalone]101-birdalone had never erst tasted the like of . And by then [she]101-birdalone had got so far as [her]101-birdalone flight from [the Isle of [Increase Unsought]32-increase unsought]22-the isle of increase unsought , the sun was set and the twilight begun . And [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife said : Now shalt [thou]101-birdalone go [home]387-home to [thine house]275-thine house ; and have no fear of witch or evil thing , for [I]0-i am not far from [thee]101-birdalone and will watch over [thee]101-birdalone . Sweet is [thy]0-i tale , [[my]0-i daughter]897-my daughter , and dear are [[thy]0-i [she]5952-she - friends]5332-thy she - friends ; and if ever it may be that [I]0-i may do [them]5332-thy she - friends any pleasure , fain were [I]0-i ; and that especially to [[thy]0-i Viridis , who meseemeth is both sweet and wise even as [thou]0-i thyself art]116-viridis . Nay , dost [thou]0-i begrudge [my]0-i loving [her]897-my daughter ? Nay , nay , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , laughing ; but [I]0-i rejoice in it . And hereafter when [I]0-i tell [thee]0-i how sorely [they]5332-thy she - friends paid for helping [me]0-i , [I]0-i will bid [thee]0-i to love [them]5332-thy she - friends yet more than now [thou]0-i dost . Therewith [they]5953-they parted , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone came to [[her]101-birdalone house]5025-her house ; and on the way [she]101-birdalone made as it were a feigned tale in mockery of [her]101-birdalone old trouble , that there would be [the witch - mistress]4389-the witch - mistress awaiting [her]101-birdalone to whip [her]101-birdalone . So that when [she]101-birdalone came to the door [she]101-birdalone was half frighted with [her]101-birdalone own mock , lest [the witch]407-the witch might now at last have taken to walking .

But all was quiet when [she]101-birdalone entered with the last of the twilight , and [she]101-birdalone rested that night in all peace , as in the best of [her]101-birdalone days in [the Five Crafts]4777-the five crafts .

CHAPTER XIX . HABUNDIA HIDETH [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone 'S NAKEDNESS WITH FAERY RAIMENT[101-birdalone]

Next morning [Birdalone]101-birdalone tarried about [the house]325-the house as little a while as [she]101-birdalone might , and then went hastening up to [the wood]348-the wood ; and when [she]101-birdalone came within sight of [the Trysting Tree]5960-the trysting tree , lo ! there was [Habundia]106-habundia before [her]101-birdalone , and the hands of [her]101-birdalone busy turning over goodly raiment , so that it was well - nigh as if the days had gone back to the time of the Captivity , and [the sitter under the oak]5961-the sitter under the oak was [Birdalone]101-birdalone [herself]101-birdalone dealing with [her]101-birdalone half - finished gown .

Joyously [they]5962-they met and embraced [each other]580-each other , and then spake [the wood- wife]5964-the wood- wife : Now , [[thou]5965-thou darling of [the world]430-the world]5966-thou darling of the world , [I]0-i have been no worse than [my]0-i word , and if [thou]5965-thou durst wear web of [the Faery]82-the faery [thou]5965-thou shalt presently be clad as goodly as ever [thou]5965-thou wert down there amongst [the knighthood]4816-the knighthood ; and then [thy]5965-thou tale , [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear , and , if it may be , the wisdom of [the barren wood - wife]5970-the barren wood - wife set thereto .

And therewith [she]5964-the wood- wife laid on [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's outstretched arms the raiment [she]5964-the wood- wife had brought with [her]5964-the wood- wife , and it was as if the sunbeam had thrust through the close leafage of the oak , and made its shadow nought a space about [Birdalone]101-birdalone , so gleamed and glowed in shifty brightness the broidery of the gown ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone let it fall to earth , and passed over [her]101-birdalone hands and arms the fine smock sewed in yellow and white silk , so that the web thereof seemed of mingled cream and curd ; and [she]101-birdalone looked on the shoon that lay beside the gown , that were done so nicely and finely that the work was as the feather - robe of a beauteous bird , whereof one scarce can say whether it be bright or grey , thousand - hued or all simple of colour . [Birdalone]101-birdalone quivered for joy of the fair things , and crowed in [her]101-birdalone speech as [she]101-birdalone knelt before [Habundia]106-habundia to thank [her]106-habundia : then in a twinkling had [she]101-birdalone done off [[her]101-birdalone beggar]5971-her beggar 's raiment , and then the smock clung about [her]101-birdalone darling nakedness , and next the gown was shimmering all over [her]101-birdalone , and the golden girdle embraced [her]101-birdalone loins as though it loved them worthily ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked to the wood round about [her]101-birdalone and laughed , while [Habundia]106-habundia lay in [her]101-birdalone place and smiled upon [her]101-birdalone with gentle loving- kindness .

But in a little while was [Birdalone]101-birdalone sobered ; for the thought of how fair [she]101-birdalone should look to the eyes of [[her]101-birdalone beloved]3932-her beloved when [she]101-birdalone was shown unto [him]3932-her beloved on the day of days , thrust [her]101-birdalone light and eager pleasure aside ; and [she]101-birdalone took up [her]101-birdalone shoes from the ground for [she]101-birdalone had not done them on , and sat down beside [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife and fell a - toying with the marvel of [them]5974-them ; and thus without more ado began [her]101-birdalone tale again , whereas [she]101-birdalone had left it last even , when [she]101-birdalone had told of how [the Sending Boat]832-the sending boat was speeding [her]101-birdalone over [the waters]636-the waters toward [the Isle of [the Young and the Old]201-the young and the old]83-the isle of the young and the old .

CHAPTER XX . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone TELLETH [HABUNDIA]106-habundia OF [HER]101-birdalone LOVE FOR [ARTHUR]125-arthur , AND GETTETH FROM [HER]101-birdalone PROMISE OF HELP THEREIN

Long [they]5977-they sat there that day , and until the sun was down , and by then had [Birdalone]101-birdalone little to tell of [her]101-birdalone story , for [she]101-birdalone was gotten therein to the days of [the Five Crafts]71-the five crafts . Many times had [she]101-birdalone wept and turned to [Habundia]106-habundia for solace as [she]101-birdalone told , not without shame , but without any covering up , all the tale of [her]101-birdalone love for [Arthur the Black Squire]125-arthur , and how [she]101-birdalone was surprised by the love of [him]125-arthur , and of [his]125-arthur wisdom and grace and loveliness . And [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother was ever as sweet and kind unto [her]101-birdalone as could be ; yet might another than [a lover]543-a lover have seen that much of all this was strange unto [her]101-birdalone , and [she]934-the wood - mother looked upon [Birdalone]101-birdalone as [a child who has broken [her]101-birdalone toy , and is hard to comfort for the loss of it , though there be a many more in [the world]430-the world]5980-a child who has broken her toy , and is hard to comfort for the loss of it , though there be a many more in the world . But when it grew dusk as aforesaid , and it was time to part , [she]934-the wood - mother spake to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and said : True it is , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , that [thou]5983-thou hast lived long in these six years time ; neither do [I]0-i wonder at the increase of [thy]5983-thou beauty , and the majesty thereof ; for fair is the life [thou]5983-thou hast lived , although [thou]5983-thou hast been grieved and tormented by it at whiles . And now [I]0-i know what it is for which [thou]5983-thou longest ; and herein again will [I]0-i play [the mother]267-the mother unto [thee]5983-thou , and seek about to fetch [thee]5983-thou that [thou]5983-thou wouldst have ; so be not over - anxious or troubled ; and [thou]5983-thou mayest be good herein , as [[my]0-i fair child]5985-my fair child should be ; for this [I]0-i have noted in [thee]5983-thou , that Love is not so tyrannous [a master]5986-a master but that [[his]5986-a master servants]5987-his servants may whiles think of other matters , and so solace [their]5987-his servants souls , that [they]5987-his servants may live despite of all .

Now was [Birdalone]101-birdalone arisen , and stood before [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend confused and blushing . But [Habundia]106-habundia put [her]106-habundia two hands on [her]446-her friend shoulders and kissed [her]446-her friend , and said : Go [home]387-home now and sleep , and come again to - morrow and let [us]5990-us hear the last of [thy]101-birdalone tale ; and when that is done , maybe [I]0-i shall be able to do something for thine avail .

So [they]5990-us parted , and on the morrow [Birdalone]101-birdalone came again and told the remnant of [her]101-birdalone story , which was not so long now that [the Black Squire]125-arthur was out of it . And when [she]101-birdalone had done , [Habundia]106-habundia kept silence awhile , and then [she]106-habundia said : One thing [I]0-i will tell [thee]5991-thy , that whereas erewhile it was but seldom indeed that [any son of [Adam]103-adam]5992-any son of adam might be seen in [the woodland]669-the woodland here , of late , that is , within the last three years , there be many such amongst [us]5990-us ; and to [our]5990-us deeming [they]5994-they be evil beasts , more pitiless and greedy than any bear ; and but that [we]5990-us have nought to do with [them]5994-they , for [they]5994-they fear [us]5990-us and flee from [us]5990-us , [we]5990-us should have destroyed [them]5994-they one and all . And now that [I]0-i have heard all [thy]5991-thy story , it seemeth unto [me]0-i not so unlike but these may be the remnants of the bands of the Red Hold , and that [they]5994-they have drifted hither fleeing before the might of [[thy]5991-thy friends of [the knighthood]4816-the knighthood]5995-thy friends of the knighthood . Wherefore now , trust [me]0-i that [I]0-i will look into this , but [I]0-i must needs be away from [here]259-here for a little ; so hold [thy]5991-thy soul in patience though hear [thou]5991-thy nought of [me]0-i , and dwell quietly at [home]387-home for seven days ' space , and then come hither and find [me]101-birdalone , farewell now , [[my]101-birdalone child]915-my child ![101-birdalone]

So [they]5999-they kissed and departed ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone went [home]387-home to [the house]325-the house , and wore the days thereafter doing what was needful about the stead , and wandering through [the meadows]2079-the meadows , and swimming the waters about [Green Eyot]8-green eyot ; and the days were not unrestful unto [her]101-birdalone .

CHAPTER XXI . HOW [THE WOOD - WIFE]203-the wood - wife ENTERED [THE COT]84-the cot , AND A WONDER THAT BEFELL THEREON

But when it was the sixth day since [those two]2209-those two had met , [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose in the morning and stood in the door of [the house]325-the house , and [she]101-birdalone looked toward the bent which went up to the wood and saw one coming down it , and knew it for [Habundia]106-habundia clad in [her]106-habundia huntress ' raiment and bearing something over the left arm , for [her]106-habundia bow was in [her]106-habundia right hand . So [Birdalone]101-birdalone ran to meet [her]106-habundia , and embraced and kissed [her]106-habundia , and was merry over [her]106-habundia , and said : [Dear mother]993-dear mother , [thou]106-habundia farest far from [thy]106-habundia fastness to - day . Said [Habundia]106-habundia : There is nought in [the meadows]2079-the meadows now save the neat and the goats and [thou]106-habundia ; of [none of that folk]7180-none of that folk am [I]106-habundia afraid . But mayhappen [thou]106-habundia shalt be afraid to come with [me]106-habundia into the depths of the wildwood , for [thither]7181-thither would [I]106-habundia lead [thee]106-habundia . [I]106-habundia will be afraid of nought with [thee]106-habundia beside [me]106-habundia , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . But come now and look upon [the house that [I]106-habundia have won for [me]106-habundia]7182-the house that i have won for me . And [she]106-habundia took [her]106-habundia hand and led [her]106-habundia along ; and [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife said no more till [they]7184-they were across [the brook]711-the brook and standing by [the porch]664-the porch .[106-habundia]

Then said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : [Thou]6005-thou hast a green gown over thine arm ; is that also for [me]0-i ? Yea , certes , said [Habundia]106-habundia ; the old rag which [thou]6005-thou hast on [thee]6005-thou , and which [thou]6005-thou lovest so sore , is not fine enough for [my]0-i company ; and the glitter - gown [I]0-i gave [thee]6005-thou may be too fine for the thorns and the briars , and moreover [thou]6005-thou mayst be over - easily seen if [thou]6005-thou bear that broidered sunshine mid the boughs . Wherefore go in now and do on this other coat , though [the faery]7087-the faery have made it , and then come out to [me]0-i with [thy]6005-thou bow and [thy]6005-thou quiver , and [I]0-i shall find [thee]6005-thou sandal - shoon and girdle withal .

Nay , [wood - mother]1915-wood - mother , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , hallow [[my]0-i house]4770-my house by entering [it]4770-my house , and eat a morsel with [me]0-i and drink the wine of [the horned folk]6009-the horned folk ere [we]6010-we go [our]6010-we ways .

[Habundia]106-habundia shook [her]106-habundia head and knit [her]106-habundia brows somewhat as [she]106-habundia looked hard on [the house]325-the house ; then [she]106-habundia said : [I]0-i know not , [[Adam]103-adam 's daughter]6012-adam 's daughter ; [I]0-i have little to do with [houses]5389-houses , and doubt if [a house]4766-a house be safe for [me]0-i . And this one that [the witch]407-the witch builded ! and belike [she]407-the witch buried [some human being]6016-some human being at one of [its]325-the house four corners . Tell [me]0-i , [fair child]958-fair child , sawest [thou]6018-thou ever here at night - tide the shape of [a youngling crowned with a garland straying about the house]6019-a youngling crowned with a garland straying about the house ?

Nay , never at all , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . Said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife : Then maybe [thou]6018-thou hast hallowed it with the wisdom and love of [thee]6018-thou , and [I]0-i may venture ; and moreover [I]0-i note that it is all builded of trees and the grass of [the earth]445-the earth ; and [thou]6018-thou art free to use them by [my]0-i leave . But if aught befall of [my]0-i coming under [thy]6018-thou roof , heed it not too much , but think , whatsoever [my]0-i aspect may be , [I]0-i am [thy]6018-thou wood - mother and wisdom - mother that loveth [thee]6018-thou . And [I]0-i bid [thee]6018-thou also wish with all [thy]6018-thou might that [my]0-i aspect may not change to [thee]6018-thou . Also , if [I]0-i eat , [thou]6018-thou wert best not to sign the meat as [[Adam]103-adam 's sons]6022-adam 's sons are wo nt . Lead in then ; for now am [I]0-i grown wilful , and will enter whatever betide .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone marvelled at those words , but [she]101-birdalone fell to wishing strongly that [[her]101-birdalone friend]446-her friend might not lose [her]446-her friend lovely youthful shape either then or ever , and [she]101-birdalone took [her]101-birdalone hand , which trembled somewhat , and led [her]446-her friend over the threshold ; and when [they]6024-they were under the roof herseemed that [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother dwindled in a wondrous way , though [her]934-the wood - mother face was as sweet and [her]934-the wood - mother limbs as shapely as ever ; and [she]934-the wood - mother laughed shrilly yet sweetly , and spake in a thin clear voice : [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear , wish strongly , wish strongly ! though [thou]6018-thou shalt see nothing worse of [me]0-i than this . And [she]934-the wood - mother was scarce three feet high , but as pretty as a picture .

Thereat indeed was [Birdalone]101-birdalone affrighted , but [she]101-birdalone wished all [she]101-birdalone might , and stooped down to kiss [this little creature]6027-this little creature ; and therewith again [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife seemed to wax again as great and tall as ever [she]570-the wood - wife was , and [her]570-the wood - wife voice came full and strong again , as [she]570-the wood - wife laughed and said : Now is it all over for this time , and [I]0-i see how well [thou]6018-thou lovest [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i pray [thee]6018-thou love [me]0-i no less for this wonder [thou]6018-thou hast seen in [me]0-i . But now it were better that [I]0-i never go under a roof again . And [she]570-the wood - wife took [her]570-the wood - wife arms about [Birdalone]101-birdalone and clipped [her]101-birdalone lovingly ; and glad was [Birdalone]101-birdalone to feel [her]570-the wood - wife so strong and solid again .

Then [they]6029-they sat to the board and ate a simple meal of bread and cheese and wood - berries , and drank milk withal ; and [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother was merry , and the smiles danced over [her]934-the wood - mother face as [she]934-the wood - mother looked on [Birdalone]101-birdalone with all loving - kindness , so that [Birdalone]101-birdalone wondered what was toward ; but so light - hearted and happy [she]101-birdalone grew , that [she]101-birdalone deemed it might be nought save good .

But when [they]6029-they had eaten , then [Birdalone]101-birdalone did off [her]101-birdalone old coat , which [she]101-birdalone said was meet enough for [her]101-birdalone daily toil , and did on the fair green hunting - gown and the sandal - shoon , and girt [her]101-birdalone with the fair girdle which [Habundia]106-habundia had fetched [her]101-birdalone , and drew up the laps of [her]101-birdalone gown therethrough till [her]101-birdalone legs were all free of the skirts . And [Habundia]106-habundia looked on [her]101-birdalone , and laughed and said : Now are these white and smooth legs as bad as the gleam - gown for the lying hid ; but it may no better be , and [thou]6031-thou must draw [thy]6031-thou skirts down and stumble , if needs must be , when [we]6029-they come to the ambushment .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone reddened as [she]101-birdalone laughed at the word , and took down [her]101-birdalone bow and hung [her]101-birdalone quiver at [her]101-birdalone back and thrust [her]101-birdalone sharp knife into [her]101-birdalone girdle , and forth [they]6029-they went both of [them]6029-they , and were presently past the bent which went up from [the meadows]2079-the meadows and in amongst [Habundia]106-habundia 's trees .

CHAPTER XXII . [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone WENDETH [THE WILDWOOD]85-the wildwood IN FELLOWSHIP WITH [HABUNDIA]106-habundia

Now as [they]6029-they went [their]6029-they ways lightly through [the wood]348-the wood , spake [Habundia]106-habundia and said : [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , fair is the gold ring with the sapphire stone that the third finger of [thy]915-my child right hand beareth ; seldom have [I]0-i seen so fair a stone as that deep blue one ; hangeth any tale thereby ? Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone : Did [I]0-i not tell [thee]106-habundia thereof , [wood- mother]6035-wood- mother , how that [[my]0-i beloved who is lost]6036-my beloved who is lost gave it unto [me]0-i the very last time [I]0-i saw [him]6036-my beloved who is lost , woe worth the while ? Nay , said [Habundia]106-habundia , [I]0-i mind not the tale . But deemest [thou]106-habundia [he]6036-my beloved who is lost would know it again if [he]6036-my beloved who is lost saw it ? Yea , surely , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , hanging [her]101-birdalone head ; for when first [he]6036-my beloved who is lost gave it , the gift was not to [me]0-i , but to [another woman]6037-another woman . And [she]101-birdalone held [her]101-birdalone peace , and went on with hanging head and all the glee faded out of [her]101-birdalone a while .

At last [she]101-birdalone turned to [Habundia]106-habundia , and said : [I]0-i have now bethought [me]0-i to ask [thee]106-habundia whither [we]6038-we be going and on what errand ; for at first [I]0-i was so glad at heart , [I]0-i know not why , and it was so merry to be wending [the wood]348-the wood with [thee]106-habundia freely , that [I]0-i had no thought in [me]0-i as to whither and wherefore . But now wilt [thou]106-habundia tell [me]0-i ?

Said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife : How if [I]0-i were to tell [thee]106-habundia [we]6038-we were going a- hunting ? [Birdalone]101-birdalone said : Then [I]0-i should ask [thee]106-habundia what like [the quarry were]6041-the quarry were . And suppose it were [men]219-men ? said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife . [Birdalone]101-birdalone turned somewhat pale . [[My]0-i mother]902-my mother , [she]0-i said , if [we]6038-we be going against [some of [those men of the Red Bands]6046-those men of the red bands]6045-some of those men of the red bands , [I]0-i am not happy over it . [I]0-i am [no warrior]5427-no warrior , and fear strokes . Said [Habundia]106-habundia , laughing : Yet art [thou]6048-thou [a fell archer]6049-a fell archer ; and [thou]6048-thou mayest shoot from an ambush of the thick leaves , since June is in to - day . But neither would [I]0-i slay or hurt [any man]2089-any man , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , but it were to save [me]0-i from present death .

[Habundia]106-habundia looked on [her]101-birdalone with a sly smile and said : Well maybe though [we]6038-we take cover and get within wind of [[our]6038-we quarry]6051-our quarry [thou]6048-thou shalt not need to speed an arrow to [him]6051-our quarry . Have patience therefore . For this is a strange beast which [I]0-i have marked down ; [he]6051-our quarry is not ill to look on , and [his]6051-our quarry voice , which [we]6038-we may well hearken , for whiles [he]6051-our quarry singeth , is rather sweet than surly . What meanest [thou]6048-thou , [mother]740-mother ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , growing red and then paler yet ; what man is it ? since [thy]6048-thou calling [him]6051-our quarry [a beast]6053-a beast is a jest , is it not ?

Nay , said [Habundia]106-habundia , [I]0-i neither name [him]6051-our quarry nor know [him]6051-our quarry ; only [I]0-i deem [him]6051-our quarry by no means to be [one of [the Red Band]204-the red band]6054-one of the red band . For the rest , [he]6051-our quarry may be [a man in a beast 's skin]6055-a man in a beast 's skin , or a beast in [a man]234-a man 's skin , for aught [I]0-i know ; whereas [he]6051-our quarry seems , so far as [I]0-i have seen [him]6051-our quarry , to be not wholly man- like or wholly beast - like . But now let [us]6057-they hold [our]6057-they peace of [him]6051-our quarry till [we]6057-they be come nigher to [[his]6051-our quarry haunt]6058-his haunt .

So [they]6057-they went on [their]6057-they way , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone said but little , while [the wood - wife was of many words and gay]6059-the wood - wife was of many words and gay . [They]6057-they made all diligence , for [Birdalone]101-birdalone was not soon wearied , and moreover as now [she]101-birdalone was anxious and eager to see what would befall , which [she]101-birdalone might not but deem would be something great .

[They]6057-they went without stay till past noon , when [they]6057-they were come to [a little shady dale wherethrough ran a clear stream]6060-a little shady dale wherethrough ran a clear stream ; there [they]6057-they rested and bathed [them]6057-they , and thereafter sat under the boughs and ate the dainty meat which [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife provided , howsoever [she]570-the wood - wife came by it ; and when [they]6057-they had rested a while , [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife turned the talk once more unto [Arthur the Black Squire]125-arthur , and would have [Birdalone]101-birdalone tell [her]570-the wood - wife all nicely what manner of [man]548-man [he]125-arthur was ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone was nothing loth thereto ; for had [she]101-birdalone [her]101-birdalone will [she]101-birdalone had talked of [him]125-arthur day - long .

CHAPTER XXIII . [THE WOOD - WIFE]570-the wood - wife BRINGETH [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone TO THE SIGHT OF [ARTHUR]125-arthur IN [THE WILDWOOD]85-the wildwood

Now [they]6057-they go on again , no less speedily than before , and rest but little , until it was hard on an hour before sunset . And now [Habundia]106-habundia began to go warily , as if [they]6057-they were come anigh to [their]6057-they journey 's end and the thing that [they]6057-they sought . [They]6057-they were come by now to a long bent of [the forest]4809-the forest well grown with big - boled oak - trees , not very close together , so that short fine greensward was all underneath [them]6057-they ; and [Habundia]106-habundia went heedfully from bole to bole , as if [she]106-habundia would be ready to cover [herself]106-habundia if need were ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone went after [her]106-habundia , and was now flushed of face , and [her]101-birdalone eyes glittered , and [her]101-birdalone heart beat fast , and [her]101-birdalone legs trembled under [her]101-birdalone , as [she]101-birdalone went running from tree to tree .

So came [they]6057-they nigh to the crown of the bent , and before [them]6057-they were the oak - trees sparser and smaller as [they]6057-they went down the further side , which seemed by their sudden shortening to be steeper than the hither side ; and betwixt [them]6057-they showed the topmost of thorn and whitebeam and logwood , intertwined with eglantine and honeysuckle and the new shoots of [the traveller]6066-the traveller 's joy . There [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife put forth [her]570-the wood - wife hand to bid [Birdalone]101-birdalone stay , who came up to [[her]570-the wood - wife friend]446-her friend and stood before [her]570-the wood - wife eager and quivering : and anon came the sound of [a man]234-a man 's voice singing , though [they]6057-they could hear no words in it as yet amidst the rustle of the trees and the tumult of song which the blackbirds and throstles raised in [the dale below [them]6057-they]6070-the dale below them .

Then spake [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife softly : Hearken , [we]6057-they are right and the time is good , [our]6057-they beast is giving tongue : now below [us]6057-they is [the bent - side steep]6072-the bent - side steep , and goeth down into [a very little dale]6073-a very little dale with a clear stream running amidst ; and therein is [the very lair of the thing that [we]6057-they are hunting]6074-the very lair of the thing that we are hunting . Wherefore now let [us]6057-they slip warily down between the bushes till [we]6057-they get close to the bottom , and then belike [we]6057-they shall see the very creature quite close , and [we]6057-they shall then consider and think what [we]6057-they shall do with [him]6075-him .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone had no voice wherewith to answer [her]570-the wood - wife , but [she]101-birdalone stole quietly along by [her]101-birdalone side till [they]6057-they came to [the bank of [the dale]2735-the dale]6076-the bank of the dale and plunged into the thicket that flourished there , and fell to threading it , making [them]6057-they as small as might be . But ere [they]6057-they had gone but a little way the wordless song of what was below had ceased , and [they]6057-they heard the sweet tingle of the string - play , and [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife stayed [her]570-the wood - wife to hearken , and the smiles went rippling over [her]570-the wood - wife face and [she]570-the wood - wife beat time with [her]570-the wood - wife fingers ; but [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [she]101-birdalone stared wildly before [her]570-the wood - wife , and would have scrambled down [the bank]1043-the bank straightway at all hazards , for that string - play was a melody of [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]59-the castle of the quest , but [Habundia]106-habundia withheld [her]101-birdalone by the arm . And then suddenly the music died , and there came up a voice of wailing and lamenting , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone put [her]101-birdalone hands and held the palms tight against [her]101-birdalone ears , and was at point to cry out aloud [herself]101-birdalone ; but [Habundia]106-habundia drew a hand of [her]101-birdalone down and whispered into [her]101-birdalone ear : [Child]297-child , [child]297-child , make [thyself]6082-thyself strong and forbear , and then perchance joy may come to [thee]297-child ; hold [thy]297-child peace and come softly along with [me]0-i !

So [Birdalone]101-birdalone forbore , and strove with [her]101-birdalone passion , though the sobs rent [her]101-birdalone bosom for a while ; and by then the loud lamenting waned and was done , and the sound of sobbing came up from below , as it had been an echo of [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's grief .

Then [Habundia]106-habundia drew [her]101-birdalone on again till [they]6083-they saw the level of [the dale]2735-the dale and [its]2735-the dale stream piecemeal betwixt the leaves , and [they]6083-they had a glimpse of [a man on the hither side of]6085-a man on the hither side of [the stream]2085-the stream ; and again [they]6083-they went lower , till [they]6083-they were well - nigh on a level with [the greensward of the dale]6087-the greensward of the dale ; and as [Birdalone]101-birdalone knelt with head bent low , and [her]101-birdalone hands covering [her]101-birdalone eyes , [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife put away from before [her]570-the wood - wife the thick leaves of a hazel - bush , and whispering said : [Child]297-child , [child]297-child ! look forth now and see what is before [thee]297-child , and see if [thou]297-child knowest [him]6085-a man on the hither side of , or if [he]6085-a man on the hither side of be strange to [thee]297-child , and [[thy]297-child mother]337-thy mother hath done nought for [thee]297-child when all is said .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone looked up , pale and wild - eyed , and into [the dale]2735-the dale , and saw [a man sitting on the grass by [the stream - side]6094-the stream - side]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side with [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side head bowed down on to [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side knees and [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side face covered with [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side hands ; [he]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side was clad but in two or three deerskins hung about [him]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side , with a strip of skin for a girdle , wherein was thrust a short sword ; [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side brown hair hung down long and shaggy over [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side face . Close by [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side side lay a little harp , and further off a short spear roughly hefted with an ash - staff . [He]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side was beating the earth with [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side feet and writhing [him]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side about over [them]6095-them . And [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked , and [her]101-birdalone breath well - nigh failed [her]101-birdalone . For presently [he]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side sat more quietly , and lifted up [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side head , and [she]101-birdalone saw [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side face that it was [Arthur]125-arthur , [[her]101-birdalone beloved]3932-her beloved ; and now [she]101-birdalone durst not move lest [he]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side should spring up and flee away ; and the mingled pain and longing within [her]101-birdalone was sweet indeed , but well - nigh deadly .

Now [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side hand sought round to [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side harp , and [he]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side took it in [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side arms and fondled it as it were , and [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side fingers went among the strings , and anon the voice of it came forth , and it was nought changed from the last time it spake , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone hearkened breathlessly , till the melody died again and [Arthur]125-arthur looked about [him]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side and raised [his]125-arthur face as a dog when it fares to howl .

Then [Birdalone]101-birdalone gave a great cry , and leapt forth out of the thicket and stood on the greensward with nought betwixt them two , and [she]101-birdalone stretched out [her]101-birdalone arms to [[her]101-birdalone beloved]3932-her beloved and cried out : O ! no , no , no ! do it not , [I]0-i beseech [thee]3932-her beloved , lest [I]0-i deem that [thou]3932-her beloved art all changed , and that [the man]2926-the man and [the dear heart beloved of [thee]3932-her beloved]6099-the dear heart beloved of thee has gone out of [thee]3932-her beloved and left [thee]3932-her beloved but a beast in [a man]234-a man 's shape !

[He]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side leapt up as [she]101-birdalone spake , and thrust forward [his]6093-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side head and looked fierce at [her]101-birdalone , and cried out : What ! art [thou]3932-her beloved come again ? This is the second time [I]0-i have seen [thee]101-birdalone , [thou]101-birdalone image of [her]101-birdalone that hath tormented [me]0-i so long ; of [her]101-birdalone that left [me]0-i in [my]0-i most need and hid [herself]101-birdalone away from [me]0-i . [Hah]6101-hah ! [a man]234-a man , sayest [thou]3932-her beloved ? Did [I]0-i not strive with it , and hold [my]0-i manhood so long as [I]0-i might ; and at last it might no longer be , and [I]0-i became a beast and [a man - slayer]6103-a man - slayer ? But what avails it to talk with [thee]101-birdalone , since [thou]101-birdalone art but the image of [her]101-birdalone that hath wasted [my]0-i life . Yet perchance of the image [I]0-i may make an end since [I]0-i may not lay hand on the very destroyer [herself]101-birdalone ; and , woe 's [me]0-i , how [I]0-i loved [her]101-birdalone ! yea , and do still ; but not [thee]101-birdalone , [O false image]6104-o false image !

And forthwith [he]234-a man drew the blade from [his]234-a man girdle and sprang forward at [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; and [she]101-birdalone cowered and cringed , but moved not else . But therewithal [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife came leaping through the bushes , and [she]570-the wood - wife nocked an arrow on [her]570-the wood - wife bended bow , and threatened [him]234-a man therewith , and cried out : [[Thou]101-birdalone man - beast]6106-thou man - beast , [I]0-i will slay [thee]101-birdalone if [thou]101-birdalone hurt [[my]0-i child]915-my child and [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear ; so forbear ! Nay , [I]0-i tell [thee]101-birdalone more , unless [thou]101-birdalone make [her]101-birdalone as glad at the sight of [thee]101-birdalone as [I]0-i meant [her]101-birdalone to be , [I]0-i will in the long run slay [thee]101-birdalone ; so look to it .

[He]234-a man laughed and said : What ! there is another image of the love that wasted [me]0-i , is there ! Nay , but by [the Hallows]205-the hallows , [this new - comer]6109-this new - comer is [the first one]6110-the first one , and the one who chattered at [me]0-i is the second . Or is it this , that [all women]6111-all women now have the semblance of the evil one that has undone [me]0-i , and there is nought else left ?

And [he]234-a man stood staring at [Birdalone]101-birdalone and moved not a while ; and [she]101-birdalone stood with [her]101-birdalone hands before [her]101-birdalone face cringing before [him]234-a man . Then [he]234-a man raised [his]234-a man arm and cast the weapon far into the bushes of [the bank- side]6112-the bank- side , and then came forward and stood before [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and drew down [her]101-birdalone hands from [her]101-birdalone face and stared in the eyes of [her]101-birdalone , holding [her]101-birdalone by the two arms ; and [he]234-a man said : [Thou]6113-thou hast forgotten now , belike , how fair a life [we]6114-we two might have lived if [thou]6113-thou hadst not fled from [me]0-i and spoiled [me]0-i .

And [thou]6113-thou ! by the looks of [thee]6113-thou , for [thou]6113-thou art sleek and fair , though this moment [thou]6113-thou art pale for fear of [me]0-i , [thou]6113-thou hast lived a happy life through all these years , with many a merry thing to think of : and dost [thou]6113-thou deem that [my]0-i life was happy , or that [I]0-i thought of any merry thing , or of anything save [my]0-i sorrow ? Dost [thou]6113-thou doubt it ? go ask [the good spears of [Greenford]45-greenford]6115-the good spears of greenford , or the Riders of the Red Hold , and [the field of the slaughter]6116-the field of the slaughter ! If there was little joy there , less was there elsewhere .

[He]234-a man left go of [her]6113-thou therewith and stood trembling before [her]6113-thou , and [she]6113-thou bowed down and put palm to palm and held them out to [him]234-a man as [one who prays]6117-one who prays ; and [she]6113-thou knew not what [she]6113-thou did .

Then [he]234-a man cried out with a lamentable cry and said : O woe 's [me]0-i ! for [I]0-i have frighted [her]6113-thou and scared the wit out of [her]6113-thou , so that [she]6113-thou knows not who [I]0-i am nor what [I]0-i would ; and [I]0-i would pray to [her]6113-thou and beseech [her]6113-thou to pity [me]0-i , and not depart from [me]0-i again or mock [me]0-i with images of [herself]6113-thou .

Then [he]234-a man went down on [his]234-a man knees to [her]6113-thou , and [he]234-a man also joined [his]234-a man hands to pray to [her]6113-thou ; but it seemed as if [she]6113-thou was stricken to stone , so wholly [she]6113-thou moved not . But for [him]234-a man , [he]234-a man sank [his]234-a man forehead to earth , and then [he]234-a man rolled over and [his]234-a man limbs stretched out , and [his]234-a man head turned aside and blood gushed out from [his]234-a man mouth . But [Birdalone]101-birdalone shrieked out and cast [herself]101-birdalone on [his]234-a man body , and cried : [I]0-i have found [him]234-a man , and [he]234-a man is dead !
