[he]234-a man is dead , and [I]0-i have slain [him]234-a man , because [I]0-i was [a timorous fool]6118-a timorous fool and feared [him]234-a man ; and [he]234-a man was coming to [his]234-a man right mind and knew [me]0-i for what [I]0-i was !

But [Habundia]106-habundia came and stood over [them]6119-them , and drew up [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and said : Nay , nay , be comforted ! for now [he]234-a man is thus , and the strength is gone out of [him]234-a man for a while , [we]6120-we may deal with [him]234-a man . Abide , and [I]0-i will fetch the blood - staunching herb and the sleepy herb , and then [we]6120-we will heal [him]234-a man , and [he]234-a man will come to [his]234-a man right mind and be [a man]234-a man again .

Therewith [she]0-i hastened away and was gone but a little ; and meanwhile [Birdalone]101-birdalone knelt down by [[her]101-birdalone love]6122-her love and wiped the blood from [him]234-a man , and caressed [his]234-a man sword - hardened hands and moaned over [him]234-a man . But when [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife came back [she]570-the wood - wife put [Birdalone]101-birdalone aside once more , and knelt down by [the squire]3482-the squire and raised [his]234-a man head , and laid the blood - stauncher to [his]234-a man mouth and [his]234-a man heart , and muttered words over [him]234-a man , while [Birdalone]101-birdalone looked over [her]570-the wood - wife shoulder with [her]570-the wood - wife pale face ; then the [she]570-the wood - wife - leech fetched water from the stream in a cup which [she]570-the wood - wife drew from [her]570-the wood - wife wallet , and [she]570-the wood - wife washed [his]234-a man face , and [he]234-a man came somewhat to [himself]234-a man , so that [she]570-the wood - wife might give [him]234-a man drink of the water ; and yet more [he]234-a man came to [himself]234-a man . So then [she]570-the wood - wife took the sleepy herb and bruised it in [her]570-the wood - wife hands and put in [his]234-a man mouth and again said words over [him]234-a man , and presently [his]234-a man head fell back and [his]234-a man eyes closed and [he]234-a man slept peacefully .

[She]570-the wood - wife stood up then and turned to [Birdalone]101-birdalone and said : Now , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , have [we]6126-we done all that [we]6126-we may do , save that [we]6126-we shall bring [him]234-a man to a place where the dew and the sun shall not torment [him]234-a man and sicken [him]234-a man ; for [he]234-a man shall lie thus till the sun comes up to - morrow , or longer ; and fear nor , for when [he]234-a man awaketh [he]234-a man shall be in [his]234-a man right mind , and shall know [thee]6127-thee and love [thee]6127-thee . This [I]0-i swear to [thee]6127-thee by [the earth]445-the earth and the sun and [the woodland]669-the woodland .

Said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , trembling yet : O [mother]740-mother , but may [I]0-i kiss [him]234-a man and caress [him]234-a man ? Yea , surely , said [the wood - mother]934-the wood - mother , smiling in [her]934-the wood - mother face , but be not too long over it , for lo ! the last of the sun , and it were better that [he]234-a man be under cover ere the twilight falls .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone knelt down by [[her]101-birdalone love]6122-her love quietly at that word , and fell to kissing [him]234-a man softly , and laid [her]101-birdalone cheek to [his]234-a man , and called [him]234-a man gentle names such as none can tell again without shame , till [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife laid [her]570-the wood - wife hand on [her]570-the wood - wife shoulder and said kindly and sweetly : Rise up now , for [thou]6134-thou must make it enough for this present ; [thou]6134-thou shalt have time enough hereafter for more and much more .

So [Birdalone]101-birdalone arose and said : How shall [we]6135-we bear [him]234-a man to [[his]234-a man place]6136-his place ? Shall [I]0-i not take [him]234-a man by the shoulders and [thou]6134-thou by the legs ? For [I]0-i am stronger than [thou]6134-thou after all these years .

Laughed [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife : Nay , [little one]6138-little one , said [she]570-the wood - wife ; [thou]6134-thou knowest [me]0-i not utterly as yet . [Thou]6134-thou shalt not bear [him]234-a man at all , nor any part of [him]234-a man ; [I]0-i am strong enough for more than that ; see [thou]6134-thou ! And [she]570-the wood - wife stooped down and took [him]234-a man up in [her]570-the wood - wife arms as if [he]234-a man were [a little child]4915-a little child , and stepped off lightly with [him]234-a man ; but looked back over [her]570-the wood - wife shoulder and said to [Birdalone]101-birdalone : But [thou]6134-thou mayest walk by [me]0-i and hold a hand of [him]234-a man as [we]6140-they go , though it will hinder [me]0-i somewhat ; but [I]0-i know [thine]6141-thine heart and would pleasure [thee]234-a man , [[my]0-i child]915-my child .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone ran up to [her]570-the wood - wife and thanked [her]570-the wood - wife and kissed [her]570-the wood - wife , and took [Arthur]125-arthur 's left hand , while [Habundia]106-habundia bore [him]234-a man on down [the dale]2735-the dale and out of it , and still along [the stream]2085-the stream till [they]6140-they came to a place where [it]6145-it was narrow on either side thereof , and a sheer rock came down so near to the water that there was but a strip of greensward three yards wide betwixt [water and rock]6146-water and rock ; and in the face of [the rock]1847-the rock was a cave wide enough for [a man to enter by stooping somewhat]6148-a man to enter by stooping somewhat . Therein [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife lightly bore [Arthur]125-arthur , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone followed ; and [they]6140-they found [the cave]4283-the cave dry and roomy within ; there was a bed therein of dry heather and bracken , and thereon [Habundia]106-habundia laid [her]106-habundia burden , and said : Now , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , there is nought to do but abide till [he]125-arthur comes to [himself]125-arthur again , which may be some time to - morrow ; and be of good cheer , for [he]125-arthur will come to [his]125-arthur right self , but [he]125-arthur will be weak and humble ; but [I]0-i shall have meat and drink ready for [him]125-arthur . Now if [thou]6152-thou wilt be ruled by [me]0-i , [thou]6152-thou wilt keep out of the way when [he]125-arthur awakens ; moreover , be [thou]6152-thou not scared if [I]0-i meet [his]125-arthur awakening with another shape than that which [thou]6152-thou hast known of [me]0-i ; for sure it is that it will trouble [his]125-arthur wits over - much if again [he]125-arthur seeth [the two of [us]6154-they]6153-the two of us alike . But fear not ; for [thy]6152-thou sake , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , [I]0-i will take no ugly shape , though it may well be less beauteous than thine .

[I]0-i will do what [thou]6152-thou wilt , [mother]740-mother , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone , for [I]0-i see that [thou]6152-thou art helping [me]0-i all [thou]6152-thou mayest ; yet [I]0-i beseech [thee]740-mother let [me]0-i sit by [him]125-arthur till the time of [his]125-arthur awakening draweth nigh .

[The wood - wife]570-the wood - wife smiled and nodded yeasay on [her]570-the wood - wife , and [they]6154-they sat down , both of [them]6154-they , beside [the sleeping man]6158-the sleeping man , and the day died into the night as [they]6154-they sat hearkening to the ripple of [the brook]711-the brook and the song of the nightingales .

CHAPTER XXIV . [THE WOOD - MOTHER]934-the wood - mother CHANGETH [HER]934-the wood - mother FORM TO THAT OF A WOMAN STRICKEN IN YEARS

When the morrow came , there yet lay [Arthur]125-arthur sleeping peacefully , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone awoke from the slumber which had at last fallen on [her]101-birdalone , and looked about [her]101-birdalone and saw not [Habundia]106-habundia in [the cave]4283-the cave ; so [she]101-birdalone arose and bent over [Arthur]125-arthur and kissed [him]125-arthur , and so went forth and stood in the door and looked about [her]101-birdalone . And [she]101-birdalone was still dim - eyed with [her]101-birdalone just departed slumber and the brightness of the morning sunlight , and [she]101-birdalone scarce knew whether it were a part of a dream , or a sight that was verily before [her]101-birdalone , that [she]101-birdalone seemed to see one coming across [the brook]711-the brook toward [her]101-birdalone , stepping heedfully from stone to [stone thereof]6163-stone thereof : [a woman stricken in years , but slim and trim and upright , clad in a gown of green cloth , with a tippet of some white fur]6164-a woman stricken in years , but slim and trim and upright , clad in a gown of green cloth , with a tippet of some white fur . When [she]101-birdalone was come on to [the greensward]682-the greensward [she]101-birdalone spake to [Birdalone]101-birdalone in a sweet voice , but thin with eld , and gave [her]101-birdalone the sele of the day ; and [Birdalone]101-birdalone was somewhat afraid to see [a newcomer]6166-a newcomer , but [she]101-birdalone greeted [her]6166-a newcomer , drawing back a little from [her]6166-a newcomer shyly . But [the old woman]6167-the old woman said : What maketh [thee]101-birdalone here , [[my]0-i daughter]897-my daughter ? Dost [thou]101-birdalone not know that this is [[my]0-i land]6169-my land and [[my]0-i house]4770-my house , and that [I]0-i am said not to be unmighty in [these woods]6171-these woods ?

[I]0-i pray [thee]101-birdalone pardon [me]0-i if [I]0-i have done amiss , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; but here have [I]0-i [a sick friend]6172-a sick friend , [a young man]5116-a young man , and [I]0-i would pray [thee]101-birdalone suffer [him]6172-a sick friend to abide here in [this cave]6174-this cave a little longer ; for there hath been also [another friend]6175-another friend , [a woman]250-a woman , but [she]250-a woman hath gone out while [I]0-i slept , belike to gather simples , for [she]250-a woman is wise in leechcraft , and is tending [the sick man]6177-the sick man . [I]0-i pray [thee]101-birdalone humbly to suffer [us]6178-us lest [we]6178-us lose [[our]6178-us friend]3426-our friend .

As [she]0-i spake , [she]0-i heard [the carline]1452-the carline chuckle softly , and at last [she]0-i said : Why , [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear , dost [thou]101-birdalone not know [me]0-i after all these years ? Look on [me]0-i again , look ! and [thou]101-birdalone shalt see that [I]0-i am not so much changed from what [thou]101-birdalone sawest [me]0-i last night . [I]0-i am still thine image , [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear , only [I]0-i was the image of what [thou]101-birdalone wert , and now [I]0-i the image of what [thou]101-birdalone shalt be when two score years and ten of happy life have worn for [thee]101-birdalone . Tell [me]0-i , am [I]0-i now aught like to [[thy]101-birdalone mother]337-thy mother in the flesh ?

How hast [thou]101-birdalone frighted [me]0-i , [mother]740-mother , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; [I]0-i thought that [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend had forsaken [me]0-i , and that perchance [the new - comer]518-the new - comer was another witch like unto [the old one]6187-the old one , and that [I]0-i was never to be at rest and happy . But as to [[my]0-i mother]902-my mother in the flesh , nay , [thou]101-birdalone art not now wholly like unto [her]902-my mother ; and sooth to say [I]0-i shall be fainer when [thou]101-birdalone hast thine own shape of [me]0-i young back again , for [I]0-i love [thee]101-birdalone not so much as now [thou]101-birdalone art .

[The wood - wife]570-the wood - wife laughed : Well , [she]570-the wood - wife said , [thou]101-birdalone shalt not see over - much of [me]0-i in this shape ; and that the less because of something [I]0-i shall now tell [thee]101-birdalone , to wit , that [I]0-i have been thinking the matter over , and [I]0-i would have [thee]101-birdalone leave [us]6190-us twain together alone before [the young man]5655-the young man awaketh . [I]0-i would have [thee]101-birdalone get [thee]101-birdalone [home]387-home and abide [him]5655-the young man there ; it shall not be long [I]0-i promise [thee]101-birdalone ; and this also , that [he]5655-the young man shall come home to [thee]101-birdalone sound in body and whole in limb .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone 's countenance fell , and [she]101-birdalone said : Why this second mind , [mother]740-mother ? why , [I]0-i pray [thee]740-mother ? Said [Habundia]106-habundia : [I]0-i fear for [thy]740-mother love lest [he]5655-the young man be not strong enough to open [his]5655-the young man eyes upon [thy]740-mother face ; but after [he]5655-the young man hath been a day in [the woods]463-the woods , and [I]0-i have spoken to [him]5655-the young man diversely and cheered [him]5655-the young man with the hope of meeting [thee]101-birdalone , [he]5655-the young man may well be strong enough to seek [thee]101-birdalone for a mile 's length , and find [thine house]275-thine house first and then [thee]101-birdalone . So now wilt [thou]740-mother obey [me]0-i ? Nay , if [thou]740-mother must needs weep , [I]0-i will be gone into [the thicket]3756-the thicket till [thou]740-mother hast done , [thou]740-mother wilful ! [Birdalone]101-birdalone smiled through [her]101-birdalone tears , and said : [I]0-i pray [thee]101-birdalone pardon [my]0-i wilfulness , [mother]740-mother , and [I]0-i will depart without turning back into [the cave]4283-the cave . Nay , said [Habundia]106-habundia , there is no need for so much haste as that : [I]0-i will in now , and do [my]0-i leechdoms with [the sick man]6177-the sick man . But do [thou]740-mother go across [the stream]2085-the stream , [thou]740-mother barefoot , and [thou]740-mother wilt find on the other side , by the foot of the quicken - tree yonder , honeycombs and white bread and a bicker of wild goats ' milk . Bathe [thee]740-mother then if [thou]740-mother wilt , and bring those matters over hither ; and then shalt [thou]740-mother go in and kiss [[thy]740-mother mate]7187-thy mate 's sick face with [thy]740-mother fresh one , and thereafter shall [we]7188-we sit here by the ripple of the water and break [our]7188-we fast ; and lastly , [thou]740-mother shalt go in and kiss again and then take to [the road]2103-the road . But tell [me]570-the wood - wife , deemest [thou]740-mother surely that [thou]740-mother canst find it again ? [Yea]7190-yea , surely , [mother]740-mother , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; [I]570-the wood - wife am [wood - woman]7192-wood - woman enough for that ; and now [I]570-the wood - wife will do all [thy]7190-yea will . And therewith [she]101-birdalone stepped out lightly on to the greensward and sought up [the stream]2085-the stream till [she]101-birdalone found [a smooth - grounded pool]7194-a smooth - grounded pool meet for [her]101-birdalone bath , and when that was done , [she]101-birdalone fetched the victual and came back to [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife ; then [they]7196-they two sat down together , and ate and drank while the water rippled at [their]7196-they feet . But when [they]7196-they were done , [Birdalone]101-birdalone gat [her]101-birdalone into [the cave]4283-the cave again , and kissed [the sleeping man]6158-the sleeping man fondly , and came forth lightly and stood a moment before [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife , and said : Tell [me]570-the wood - wife this at least , [mother]740-mother , when shall [he]6158-the sleeping man be there ? To - morrow quoth [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife ; and , for [my]570-the wood - wife part , [I]570-the wood - wife would keep [thee]101-birdalone within doors and abide [him]6158-the sleeping man [there]232-there , lest there be trouble ; for [he]6158-the sleeping man may not yet be as strong as the strongest . [Birdalone]101-birdalone hung down [her]101-birdalone head and answered not , but said presently : Farewell , [wood - mother]1915-wood - mother , and be [thou]101-birdalone blessed . Then [she]101-birdalone took up [her]101-birdalone bow and betook [her]101-birdalone lightly to [the woodland]669-the woodland way , and [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife stood looking at [her]101-birdalone till the thicket had hidden [her]101-birdalone , and then turned back and went into [the cave]4283-the cave .[570-the wood - wife]

CHAPTER XXV . [THE WOOD - WIFE]570-the wood - wife HEALETH AND [TENDETH THE BLACK SQUIRE]125-arthur

[She]570-the wood - wife stood over [Arthur]125-arthur for a minute or two , and then stooped down and whispered a word in [his]125-arthur ear , and presently [he]125-arthur stirred on the bed and half opened [his]125-arthur eyes , but straightway turned on [his]125-arthur side , as if to gather sleep to [him]125-arthur , but [she]570-the wood - wife took [him]125-arthur by the shoulder and said in a clear voice : Nay , [knight]2610-knight , nay ; hast [thou]125-arthur not slept enough ? is there nought for [thee]125-arthur to do ? [He]125-arthur sat up in the bed and rubbed [his]125-arthur eyes , and [his]125-arthur face was come to its wholesome colour , and [his]125-arthur eyes looked out quietly and calmly as [he]125-arthur looked about [the cave]4283-the cave and saw [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife standing by [him]125-arthur ; and [he]125-arthur spake in a voice which was somewhat weak , but wherein was no passion of rage or woodness : Where am [I]0-i then ? and who art [thou]125-arthur , [dame]5842-dame ? [She]570-the wood - wife said : [Thou]125-arthur art in [a cave of [the woodland]669-the woodland]6206-a cave of the woodland , and [I]0-i am for one thing [thy]125-arthur leech , and meseemeth [thou]125-arthur desirest to eat and to drink . [He]125-arthur smiled and nodded [his]125-arthur head ; and [she]570-the wood - wife fetched [him]125-arthur the milk , and [he]125-arthur drank a long draught , and sighed thereafter , as one who is pleased ; and [she]570-the wood - wife smiled on [him]125-arthur , and fetched [him]125-arthur the bread and the honey , and [he]125-arthur ate and drank again , and then lay down and fell fast asleep . And [she]570-the wood - wife suffered [his]125-arthur slumber for two hours or so , and then awoke [him]125-arthur again ; and again [he]125-arthur asked where [he]125-arthur was and what was [she]570-the wood - wife , but [she]570-the wood - wife said as before . And said [she]570-the wood - wife : The next thing [thou]125-arthur hast to do is to arise , as [thou]125-arthur well mayest , and take this raiment , which is fair and clean , and go wash [thee]125-arthur in [the brook]711-the brook and come back to [me]0-i ; and then [we]6209-we will talk , and [thou]125-arthur shalt tell [me]0-i of how it was with [thee]125-arthur , and peradventure [I]0-i may tell [thee]125-arthur somewhat of how it shall be with [thee]125-arthur . As [she]570-the wood - wife spoke [she]570-the wood - wife went to a coffer which stood in [a nook of [the cave]4283-the cave]6210-a nook of the cave , and drew forth from it a shirt and hosen and shoon , and a surcoat and hood of fine black cloth , and a gilded girdle and a fair sword , red - sheathed , and said : These may serve [thy]125-arthur turn for the present , so take them and don them , and [thou]125-arthur shalt look like [a squire]6212-a squire at least , if not [a knight]1353-a knight .

So [he]6214-thou arose as one in a dream and went out ; but as [he]6214-thou passed by [her]570-the wood - wife [she]570-the wood - wife saw something gleaming on [his]6214-thou breast , and noted that it was [Birdalone]101-birdalone 's fair sapphire ring which hung about [his]6214-thou neck ; so [she]570-the wood - wife smiled , and said under [her]570-the wood - wife breath : Crafty is [[my]0-i dear daughter]6215-my dear daughter ! But that shall save [me]0-i some words at least . And [she]570-the wood - wife abided [his]6214-thou return .

[Anon]206-anon [he]6214-thou cometh back clad in the fair raiment , with the sword by [his]6214-thou side ; and [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife smote [her]570-the wood - wife palms together and cried out : Now indeed [thou]6214-thou art fair and well - liking , and [a fair lady]6217-a fair lady might well take pleasure in beholding [thee]6214-thou .

But [his]6214-thou brow was knit , and [he]6214-thou looked sullen and angry , and [he]6214-thou said : What is all this play ? and where gattest [thou]6214-thou this ring which [I]0-i found e'en now about [my]0-i neck ? And who art [thou]6214-thou , and why have [I]0-i been brought hither ?

[His]6214-thou eyes looked fiercely on [her]570-the wood - wife as [he]6214-thou spake , holding out [his]6214-thou palm with the ring lying thereon . But [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife answered : Many questions , [fair youth]6219-fair youth ! but [I]0-i will tell [thee]6214-thou : the play is for thine healing and pleasure , whereas both sick hast [thou]6214-thou been and sorry . As to the ring , it is [thou]6214-thou hast got it and not [I.]0-i But [I]0-i will tell [thee]6214-thou this , that [I]0-i have seen it on the finger of [a fair damsel who haunteth [the woodland not far hence]6221-the woodland not far hence]6220-a fair damsel who haunteth the woodland not far hence . As to what [I]0-i am , that were a long tale to tell if [I]0-i told it all ; but believe this meanwhile , that [I]0-i am [the lady]1157-the lady and [mistress of hereabouts]6223-mistress of hereabouts , and am not without power over [[my]0-i folk]6224-my folk and [[my]0-i land]6169-my land . And as to why [thou]6214-thou wert brought hither , [I]0-i brought [thee]6214-thou because [I]0-i had [no better house handy for [a sick man]6227-a sick man to lie in]6226-no better house handy for a sick man to lie in .

Then [Arthur]125-arthur stood a long while considering the ring that lay on [his]125-arthur palm , and at last [he]125-arthur put [his]125-arthur hand on [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife 's shoulder , and looked into [her]570-the wood - wife face beseechingly , and said : O [mother]740-mother , if [thou]6214-thou be mighty be merciful withal , and have pity on [me]0-i ! [Thou]6214-thou callest [me]0-i [a youth]3311-a youth , and so [I]0-i may be in regard to [thee]570-the wood - wife ; but [I]0-i tell [thee]570-the wood - wife it is five long years and there hath been no other thought in [my]0-i heart but what was loathsome to [me]0-i , and it hath worn and wasted [my]0-i youth , so that it waneth and withereth and is nought . O , if [thou]6214-thou be mighty , bring [me]0-i to [her]570-the wood - wife that [I]0-i may see [her]570-the wood - wife at least one time before [I]0-i die . And therewith [he]6231-him fell down on [his]6231-him knees before [her]570-the wood - wife , and kissed the hem of [her]570-the wood - wife gown , and wept . But [she]570-the wood - wife drew [him]6231-him up and looked on [him]6231-him with the merry countenance of [a kind old woman]6232-a kind old woman , and said : Nay , nay , [I]0-i am not so hard to be won to [thy]6214-thou helping that [thou]6214-thou needest pray so sore and weep : here need [we]6233-we tarry no longer , and if [thou]6214-thou wilt come with [me]0-i [we]6233-we shall go seek [the damsel who bore this ring]6234-the damsel who bore this ring , though how it should come to [thee]6214-thou why should [I]0-i know ? Neither do [I]0-i know if [the said ring- bearer]6235-the said ring- bearer be the one woman whom [thou]6214-thou needest . But [I]0-i will tell [thee]6214-thou at once that [she]6234-the damsel who bore this ring is [a dear friend of [mine]0-i]6236-a dear friend of mine .

Then [Arthur]125-arthur threw [his]125-arthur arms about [her]6214-thou , and kissed [her]6214-thou cheeks and blessed [her]6214-thou , while [she]6214-thou laughed on [him]125-arthur and said : Nay , [fair sir]2215-fair sir , if [thou]6214-thou wilt do so much with the withered branch , what wilt [thou]6214-thou with the blossom of the tree ? And [he]125-arthur was abashed before [her]6214-thou , but hope made [his]125-arthur heart to dance .

So [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife took up [her]570-the wood - wife bow , slung [her]570-the wood - wife quiver at [her]570-the wood - wife back , and girt [her]570-the wood - wife short sword to [her]570-the wood - wife , and then led [him]125-arthur forth , and so into [the thicket out of [the dale]2735-the dale]6239-the thicket out of the dale and forth into [the oaken bent]6241-the oaken bent , and lightly [she]6214-thou led [him]125-arthur thereafter through [the woodland]669-the woodland .

CHAPTER XXVI . [THE BLACK SQUIRE]1334-the black squire TELLETH [THE WOOD - WIFE]570-the wood - wife OF [HIS]125-arthur DOINGS SINCE [BIRDALONE]101-birdalone WENT FROM [THE CASTLE OF THE QUEST]1931-the castle of the quest

As [they]6246-we went [Habundia]106-habundia said to [Arthur]125-arthur : Now shalt [thou]125-arthur talk and tell for the shortening of the way , and let [us]6246-we know somewhat of [thy]125-arthur story . But first [I]0-i must tell [thee]125-arthur , for [thou]125-arthur mayest not know it , so witless as then [thou]125-arthur wast , that yesterday [we]6246-we found [thee]125-arthur down in [the dale yonder]6247-the dale yonder , playing the string - play sweetly indeed , but otherwise dight like a half beast more than [a man]234-a man , so that [we]6246-we wondered at [thee]125-arthur and pitied [thee]125-arthur .

[Arthur]125-arthur knit [his]125-arthur brows as if [he]125-arthur strove with some memory and might not master it ; then [he]125-arthur said : [Thou]125-arthur sayest [We]6246-we , who then was the other ? Said [Habundia]106-habundia : [I]0-i had [a dear friend with [me]0-i]6249-a dear friend with me . Quoth [he]125-arthur : And did [she]6249-a dear friend with me pity [me]0-i also ? [Yea]6250-yea , said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife , else scarce had [she]6249-a dear friend with me been [a friend to [me]0-i]6252-a friend to me . O let [us]6246-we on swiftly , said [Arthur]125-arthur , so long as the time may be ! And [they]6246-we quickened [their]6246-we pace and ate up the way speedily .

Presently spake [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife again : Now for the tale of [thee]125-arthur , [fair sir]2215-fair sir ; yet will [I]0-i shorten it somewhat by telling [thee]125-arthur that [I]0-i know [thy]125-arthur name , that [thou]125-arthur art [[Arthur]125-arthur the Black Squire of [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]59-the castle of the quest]6255-arthur the black squire of the castle of the quest . [He]125-arthur stared at that word , and said : How knewest [thou]6256-thou this ? how couldst [thou]6256-thou guess it , who hast never seen [me]0-i erst ? [A friend]520-a friend told [me]0-i , said [she]0-i ; too long it were as now to tell [thee]125-arthur thereof . Rather do [thou]6256-thou tell [me]0-i how [thou]6256-thou didst fare when [ye]6256-thou found [[thy]6256-thou friend]2239-thy friend gone from [the castle]1838-the castle that time [ye]6256-thou came [home]387-home from the winning of the Red Hold .

[Arthur]125-arthur stared astonished , and said : What is it ? Dost [thou]6256-thou verily know [my]0-i love ? or art [thou]6256-thou [a sorceress]5688-a sorceress and knowest somewhat of [me]0-i by spell - work ? [I]0-i am somewhat more than [a sorceress]5688-a sorceress , may - happen , said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife ; but heed it not , since [I]0-i am [[thy]6256-thou friend]2239-thy friend to - day , but tell [me]0-i what [I]0-i ask , that [I]0-i may have all the tale of [thee]6256-thou ; it will serve for the shortening of the way . Said [Arthur]125-arthur : And who but [I]0-i needeth it as short as may be ? so stand [we]6265-we not loitering here , and [I]0-i will talk as [we]6265-we wend on speedily .

On [they]6266-they sped therefore , and said [Arthur]125-arthur : How did [I]0-i fare ? as [one stunned]6267-one stunned , [mother]740-mother , and knew not what had happened ; and when [I]0-i heard [their]6266-they babble of how [she]740-mother had done wrong here and right there , [I]0-i was driven half mad by it , so that [I]0-i hastened back to [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold , and became [the captain of [Greenford]45-greenford]6270-the captain of greenford , to hunt down [[their]6266-they scattered foemen]6271-their scattered foemen ; for [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i that needs must [I]0-i rage and slay , and that were worser amongst [[my]0-i friends]2100-my friends than [mine]0-i unfriends . What then ? that business came to an end ; though [all the ill men]6273-all the ill men were not slain , but all were driven away from [the parts of [Greenford]45-greenford]6274-the parts of greenford ; and sooth to say [they]6266-they durst not come anywhere nigh where [they]6266-they heard of [me]0-i . Then became each day like every other , and the thought of [my]0-i hope and [my]0-i despair ate [mine]0-i heart out , and [I]0-i was of no avail unto any . Now it so happened , amidst [my]0-i many battles and chases , [I]0-i had hunted the bands of the Red Hold into [the northwest marches of [the woodland]669-the woodland]6275-the northwest marches of the woodland ; and [I]0-i noted that even [they]6266-they , howsoever hard bestead , and the worst of [men to boot]6277-men to boot , would scarce at the first be driven into the thickets thereof , though at last , whether or no [they]6266-they have made covenant with the devils , there [I]0-i know not , [they]6266-they have betaken [them]6266-they to the depths of [the wood]348-the wood and have borne off [women]433-women from [the dwellings]6280-the dwellings and got [children]1288-children on [them]6280-the dwellings , and are like to breed [an evil folk]6282-an evil folk . That then [I]0-i noted that [this Evilshaw]6283-this evilshaw was [a dwelling loathed and desert]6284-a dwelling loathed and desert , and little like it was that any would meddle with [me]0-i [there]232-there . Three years had worn since [I]0-i was cast away at [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest by [her]6287-her that loved [me]0-i , who must needs sacrifice both [her]6287-her and [me]0-i to the busy devil of folly ; and [I]0-i also deemed that if [I]0-i sought for [her]6287-her [I]0-i should not find [her]6287-her ; and yet more forsooth , that if [I]0-i found [her]6287-her [she]6287-her would be as hard unto [me]0-i as when [she]6287-her fled from [me]0-i . And as for [me]0-i , [I]0-i was gotten hard and crabbed , and [no man]545-no man , if [his]545-no man heart would let [him]545-no man , would have aught to say to [me]0-i . So [I]0-i gat [me]0-i away from [the Red Hold]3471-the red hold , as [I]0-i had from [the Castle of the Quest]1931-the castle of the quest , and [I]0-i gave out that [I]0-i would enter into religion , and forbade [any man]2089-any man to follow [me]0-i . Neither did any desire it . First of all [I]0-i set [me]0-i down at [the very outskirts of [the woodland]669-the woodland]6292-the very outskirts of the woodland , and raised [me]0-i a bower there , rude and ill - shapen . [Few folk]2884-few folk came anigh [me]0-i , and yet [some few , charcoal - burners]6295-some few , charcoal - burners , and [hunters of the edges of the wood]6296-hunters of the edges of the wood , and suchlike . [These]6297-these deemed [me]0-i [a holy man]6298-a holy man , whereas [I]0-i was but surly . Somewhat also [they]6297-these feared [me]0-i , whereas in some of [their]6297-these huntings or goings and comings after prey [I]0-i had put forth all [my]0-i strength , eked out by the lore of knighthood , which was strange to [them]6297-these . [One man]2375-one man there was of [them]6297-these who was fashioned of the minstrel craft by nature , and who forgathered with [me]0-i specially , till [we]6300-we became [friends]416-friends , and [he]2375-one man was a solace to [me]0-i , with [his]2375-one man tales and [his]2375-one man songs of [a rougher people]6302-a rougher people than [I]0-i had been wo nt to deal with . But when [I]0-i had been in [that place]645-that place for two years [he]2375-one man died of a sickness , and [I]0-i was left lonely , and [my]0-i soreness of heart fell upon [me]0-i till [I]0-i scarce knew what next [I]0-i should do . So [I]0-i fared away yet deeper into [the wildwood]523-the wildwood , taking with [me]0-i the harp which [[my]0-i friend]318-my friend had given [me]0-i before [he]2375-one man died . It was summer , and [I]0-i wandered about ever deeper into [the wood]348-the wood , until belike [I]0-i had scarce been able to win out of it if [I]0-i had tried . At last , when the autumn came , [I]0-i built [myself]0-i again some sort of a bower in [a clearing of the wood wherein was water]6307-a clearing of the wood wherein was water , and [the resort of plenteous venison]6308-the resort of plenteous venison .

What befell next ? [My]0-i mind is not over - clear concerning it all , for [I]0-i was now becoming more of a beast than [a man]234-a man . But this [I]0-i know , that [some men of the bands whom [I]0-i had chased]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased happened on [me]0-i . [They]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased knew [me]0-i not for [[their]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased old foeman]6311-their old foeman , but of [their]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased kind it was to torment and slay [any man whom [they]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased might lightly overcome]6312-any man whom they might lightly overcome . Yet was not the battle so over - light but that [I]0-i slew and hurt divers of [them]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased ere [they]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased got [me]0-i under and stripped [me]0-i and bound [my]0-i hands and tormented [me]0-i , after the manner that [the devils]6313-the devils shall do with [them]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased when [they]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased shall go to [their]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased reward . Yet somehow [I]0-i lived , though [they]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased deemed [me]0-i dead , and [I]0-i crawled away thence when [they]6310-some men of the bands whom i had chased were gone ; and somehow [I]0-i was healed of [my]0-i body , but [I]0-i was confused of [my]0-i wit thereafter , and now can call to mind but little of what befell [me]0-i as [I]0-i strayed from place to place , save that [I]0-i remember [I]0-i was hapless and heart - sore ever : and also [meseemeth]6314-meseemeth that [I]0-i saw visions at whiles , and [those who had been in [my]0-i life before these things]6315-those who had been in my life before these things , [their]6315-those who had been in my life before these things images would come before [me]0-i to mock [me]0-i as [I]0-i sat singing whiles and whiles playing the string- play for [my]0-i harp [I]0-i bore ever with [me]0-i ; and whiles [I]0-i bewailed [me]0-i , and called for help on [them]6315-those who had been in my life before these things that would not or might not help [me]0-i . And now [I]0-i may not even tell the years of [my]0-i abiding in [the desert]1927-the desert , how many [they]6317-they be . But [I]0-i pray [thee]6318-thou let [us]6319-us on more swiftly yet .

Said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife : [Thou]6318-thou hast told [me]0-i but little of [thy]6318-thou life , [Black Squire]125-arthur , but it is enough maybe ; and [I]0-i see that [thou]6318-thou mayst not tell [me]0-i more because [thou]6318-thou hast [thy]6318-thou mind set on what may betide [thee]6318-thou when this day is over . But [thou]6318-thou must know that [thou]6318-thou hast come into [the wood of Evilshaw]6321-the wood of evilshaw , wherein , besides [those savage men who quelled [thee]6318-thou and [their]6322-those savage men who quelled thee and their like , there be uncouth things no few , and wights that be not of the race of adam like , there be uncouth things no few , and wights that be not of the race of [Adam]103-adam]6322-those savage men who quelled thee and their like , there be uncouth things no few , and wights that be not of the race of adam ; wherefore no great marvel is it that [thou]6318-thou sawest visions , and images of them that were not by [thee]6318-thou . [Yea]6323-yea , said [he]125-arthur , but one vision had [I]0-i that confused and overcame [me]0-i more than all others , and meseemeth that came to [me]0-i not long ago . For first [I]0-i saw the shape of [her]6324-her that [my]0-i soul desireth ever , and it wept and lamented for [me]0-i ; and then for a little [I]0-i seemed as if [I]0-i were coming forth from [my]0-i confusion of wit ; when lo ! there issued from the thicket another image of [[my]0-i beloved]6325-my beloved and blamed [me]0-i and threatened [me]0-i . [God]120-god wot good cause there was of the blame . But tell [me]0-i , [mother]740-mother , since [thou]6327-thou callest [thyself]6328-thyself wise , what may this portend ?

[The wood - wife]570-the wood - wife laughed : Since [I]0-i am wise , said [she]0-i , [I]0-i will foretell [thee]6330-thee good days . And now [we]6331-they will talk no more of [thee]6330-thee or [thy]6330-thee love or [thy]6330-thee sorrow , but since [thou]6327-thou wilt so fiercely devour the way , [I]0-i will tell [thee]6330-thee a tale or two of this wood and its wights to save [us]6331-they from over - much weariness .

So did [she]0-i , talking and telling as [they]6331-they went ; and [she]0-i went on a pace before [him]6330-thee , and howsoever long or hardly [he]6330-thee might stride [he]6330-thee might not overgo [her]0-i . And so fast [they]6331-they went , that [they]6331-they were within a little way of [the Oak of Tryst]12-the oak of tryst a good while before the sun had set , though [they]6331-they had set out from the cave three hours after the hour when [Birdalone]101-birdalone and [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife had left the House under [the Wood]6-the wood on the yesterday . [They]6331-they had come to [a steep rock that rose up from [a water 's side]6334-a water 's side]6333-a steep rock that rose up from a water 's side , and [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife bade stay , whether [Arthur]125-arthur would or no , and [she]570-the wood - wife made [him]6330-thee eat and drink , bringing the victual and wine from out of a cleft in [the said rock]6336-the said rock . And [she]570-the wood - wife held [him]6330-thee there till the night was come and there was a glimmer of the rising moon in [the east]4043-the east , and [he]6330-thee was ill at ease and restless ; but still [she]570-the wood - wife held [him]6330-thee there till the moon rose high and shone upon them , and the shadows of the oak - boughs lay black all around .

Then [she]570-the wood - wife bade [him]6330-thee arise , and let [him]6330-thee on to [the Oak of Tryst]5879-the oak of tryst , yea and somewhat beyond it toward [the great water]4807-the great water . Then [she]570-the wood - wife spake to [him]6330-thee : [Black Squire]125-arthur , [I]0-i am now come [home]387-home , and will lead [thee]6330-thee no further ; [I]0-i was deeming that [we]6341-we should have slept in [the wood]348-the wood a good way from this , and then would [I]0-i have brought [thee]6330-thee on [thy]6330-thee way to - morrow morning ; but the eagerness of thine heart hath made [thy]6330-thee feet so speedy , that [we]6341-we be here somewhat rathe , and yet [I]0-i am not ill - pleased therewith . Then [she]570-the wood - wife turned [him]6330-thee about and said : Look down the bent and tell [me]0-i what [thou]6330-thee seest . [He]6330-thee said : [I]0-i see the boles of goodly trees , and betwixt them the gleaming of a great water . [She]570-the wood - wife said : Go thitherward then while the moon is yet at [her]570-the wood - wife brightest , and [thou]6330-thee shalt presently come to wide meads lying along [the water]361-the water , and a stream running through [them]361-the water . Enter then into the meads and look about [thee]6330-thee , and [thou]6330-thee shalt see [a little house]6344-a little house there is none other nigh standing just across [the said stream]377-the said stream ; go up thither boldly and crave guesting from whomsoever [thou]6330-thee shalt find there , and maybe things shall go after [thy]6330-thee mind . More than this [I]0-i may not do for [thee]6330-thee . Farewell then , and if [thou]6330-thee wilt [thou]6330-thee mayst meet [me]0-i again ; that is to say , that which is verily [me]0-i : but it is like that this shape which hath been striding on with [thee]6330-thee daylong [thou]6330-thee shalt not see any more .

[He]6346-his looked on [her]570-the wood - wife wondering , for [she]570-the wood - wife seemed to grow goodly and stately before [his]6346-his eyes . But even as [he]6346-his stretched forth [his]6346-his hand to take [hers]570-the wood - wife , [she]570-the wood - wife turned about suddenly and fared into the wood out of [his]6346-his sight , wending full as swiftly as might have been looked for . Then [he]6346-his drew [his]6346-his sword and turned [his]6346-his face from the wood , and went down toward [the water]361-the water .

CHAPTER XXVII . [SIR ARTHUR]157-arthur COMETH TO [THE HOUSE]325-the house UNDER [THE WOOD]6-the wood

So came [Arthur]157-arthur into [the meadows]2079-the meadows , and went eagerly but warily over the dewy grass . And here and there a cow rose before [him]157-arthur and went bundling down [the mead]384-the mead a little way , and the owls cried out from behind [him]157-arthur , and a fox barked from the thicket 's edge . Then [he]157-arthur found [himself]157-arthur on [the stream - side]6094-the stream - side , and [he]157-arthur stayed and looked from side to side , and lo ! on the other side of [the stream]2085-the stream [a little house that looked familiar to [him]157-arthur as [a yeoman]5283-a yeoman 's dwelling in [the builded lands]6355-the builded lands]6353-a little house that looked familiar to him as a yeoman 's dwelling in the builded lands , and the thatch thereon shone under the moon and [its]6353-a little house that looked familiar to him as a yeoman 's dwelling in the builded lands windows were yellow with candle - light ; and so homely it seemed to [him]157-arthur , that [he]157-arthur thrust [his]157-arthur sword into the sheath and lightly crossed [the brook]711-the brook , and came to the door and laid [his]157-arthur hand upon the latch and lifted it and shoved the door , and all was open before [him]157-arthur .

[His]157-arthur eyes , coming from the night , dazzled with the bright light of the candles , but [he]157-arthur saw [a fair woman rising up in [her]6357-a fair woman rising up in her place place]6357-a fair woman rising up in her place , and [he]157-arthur said : May [a traveller in [the woodland]669-the woodland]6358-a traveller in the woodland be welcome [here]259-here to - night , dealing with all in all honour ?

But [the woman]252-the woman came toward [him]157-arthur holding out [her]252-the woman two hands , and ere [he]157-arthur could cry out that [he]157-arthur knew [her]252-the woman , [she]252-the woman had thrown [herself]252-the woman upon [him]157-arthur , and had cast [her]252-the woman arms about [him]157-arthur and was kissing [his]157-arthur face , and murmuring : O welcome indeed ! welcome , welcome , and welcome ! And so sore did [his]157-arthur past grief and [his]157-arthur desire move [him]157-arthur , that [he]157-arthur was weak before [her]252-the woman , and held down [his]157-arthur hands and let [her]252-the woman do . And both those were breathless with wonder and joy and longing ; and [they]6362-they stood aloof a little in a while and looked on [each other]580-each other , [she]252-the woman with heaving bosom and streaming eyes , and [he]157-arthur with arms stretched forth and lips that strove with [his]157-arthur heart 's words and might not utter them ; but once more [she]252-the woman gave [herself]252-the woman to [him]157-arthur , and [he]157-arthur took [her]252-the woman in [his]157-arthur arms strongly now , so that [she]252-the woman was frail and weak before [him]157-arthur , and [he]157-arthur laid [his]157-arthur cheek to [her]252-the woman cheek and [his]157-arthur lips to [her]252-the woman lips , and kissed [her]252-the woman eyes and [her]252-the woman shoulders and murmured over [her]252-the woman . And then again [they]6364-they stood apart , and [she]252-the woman took [him]157-arthur by the hand and led [him]157-arthur to [the settle]5860-the settle , and set [him]157-arthur down by [her]252-the woman , and [herself]252-the woman by [him]157-arthur ; and a while [they]6364-they said nought . Then [she]252-the woman spake as one who had come to [herself]252-the woman and was calm , though [her]252-the woman heart was aflame for love : Tell [me]0-i , love , when [thine]6366-thy hand was on the latch didst [thou]6366-thy look to find [me]0-i here in [this house]4104-this house ? for thine hand it was that waked [me]0-i ; [I]0-i heard not [thy]6366-thy foot before the threshold , for [I]0-i was weary and slumbering . Alas ! that [I]0-i lost the sound of [thy]6366-thy feet ! [He]157-arthur spake , and [his]157-arthur voice sounded false unto [him]157-arthur , as if it came from another 's mouth : [I]0-i wot not ; [the woman that led [me]0-i nearby]6368-the woman that led me nearby seemed to bid [me]0-i hope . Then [he]157-arthur said : Nay , the sooth is that [I]0-i should have died if [I]0-i had not found [thee]6368-the woman that led me nearby here ; [I]0-i have been sick so long with hoping .

Again were [they]6369-they silent till [she]6368-the woman that led me nearby said : [I]0-i would that [I]0-i had heard [thee]157-arthur crossing [the brook]711-the brook . But [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife bade [me]0-i look for [thee]6368-the woman that led me nearby no earlier than to - morrow ; else had [I]0-i time enough ; and [I]0-i would have made [the house]325-the house trim with the new green boughs , and dighted [our]6373-our bed with rose blooms ; and [I]0-i would have done on [me]0-i [my]0-i shining gown that [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife gave [me]0-i . For indeed [she]6368-the woman that led me nearby was but clad in [her]6368-the woman that led me nearby scanty smock and nought else .

But [he]157-arthur laid [his]157-arthur head on [her]6368-the woman that led me nearby bosom and kissed [her]6368-the woman that led me nearby all about , and said : Nay , [my]0-i own love , it is well , it is better . And [she]6368-the woman that led me nearby murmured over [him]157-arthur : O friend , [[my]0-i dear]2256-my dear , think not that [I]0-i had will to hide [me]0-i from [thee]157-arthur . All that is here of [me]0-i is thine , and thine , and thine .

And [she]6368-the woman that led me nearby took [his]157-arthur hand and [they]6376-they arose together , and [she]6368-the woman that led me nearby said : [O friend]6377-o friend , [I]0-i fled from [thee]157-arthur once and left [thee]157-arthur lonely of [me]0-i because [I]0-i deemed need drave [me]0-i to it ; and [I]0-i feared the strife of [friends]416-friends , and confusion and tangle . Now if [thou]6379-thou wilt avenge [thee]157-arthur on [me]0-i [thou]6379-thou mayest , for [I]0-i am in [thy]6379-thou power . Yet will [I]0-i ask [thee]6368-the woman that led me nearby what need will drive [thee]6368-the woman that led me nearby to leave [me]0-i lonely ?

[He]6377-o friend said : The need of death . But [she]0-i said : Mayhappen [we]6380-we shall lie together then , as here to - night [we]6380-we shall lie .

CHAPTER XXVIII . FAIR DAYS IN [THE HOUSE OF LOVE]6381-the house of love

On the morrow it was sweet times betwixt [those twain]6382-those twain , and what was hard and fierce of [their]6382-those twain love [they]6382-those twain seemed to have put behind [them]6382-those twain . A dear joy it was to [Birdalone]101-birdalone that day to busy [herself]101-birdalone about the housekeeping , and to provide whatsoever seemed now , or had seemed to [her]101-birdalone in [her]101-birdalone early days , to be dainties of [[their]6382-those twain meadow]6383-their meadow and woodland husbandry , as cream and junkets and wood - fruit and honey , and fine bread made for that very occasion .

Withal [she]101-birdalone was careful as [a mother]6384-a mother with [a child]245-a child that [he]6377-o friend should not over - weary [himself]6377-o friend with the sun of the early summer , but rather to follow [the brook]711-the brook up into [the wood]348-the wood and lie adown in the flecked shadow and rest [him]6377-o friend wholly , as if there were nought for [him]6377-o friend to do but to take in rest all that was done for [his]6377-o friend service , both by [the earth]445-the earth and by the hands and nimble feet of [Birdalone]101-birdalone . And as [she]101-birdalone was wilful in other ways of [her]101-birdalone cherishing , so also in this , that for nought in that daylight would [she]101-birdalone go anywise disarrayed , nay not so much as to go barefoot , though [he]6377-o friend prayed [her]101-birdalone thereof sorely , and told [her]101-birdalone that fairer and sweeter [she]101-birdalone was in [her]101-birdalone smock alone than in any other raiment . For in the morning [she]101-birdalone went in [her]101-birdalone woodland green let down to [her]101-birdalone heels , and when the day wore towards evening , and the wind came cool from over [the Great Water]30-the great water , then [she]101-birdalone did on [her]101-birdalone wonder- raiment which [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife had given [her]101-birdalone , and led [Arthur]157-arthur over [the meadows]2079-the meadows here and there , and went gleaming by the side of [the black- clad man]6391-the black- clad man along [the water]361-the water 's lip . And [they]6393-they looked forth on to [Green Eyot]8-green eyot and [Rock Eyot]9-rock eyot , and stood by [the shallow bight]6394-the shallow bight where [she]101-birdalone had bathed those times ; and [they]6393-they went along to [the dismal creek]6395-the dismal creek where the Sending Boat was wo nt to lie , and where yet lay the scattered staves of it ; and then along [the meadow - land]6396-the meadow - land [they]6393-they went from end to end , resting oft on the flowery grass , till the dews began to fall and the moon cast shadows on the greensward . Then [home]387-home [they]6393-they fared to [the house]325-the house ; and again on the way must [Birdalone]101-birdalone feign for [their]6393-they disport that [the witch]407-the witch was come back again , and was awaiting [her]101-birdalone to play [the tyrant]3705-the tyrant with [her]101-birdalone ; and [Arthur]157-arthur fell in with [her]101-birdalone game , and kissed [her]101-birdalone and clipped [her]101-birdalone , and then drew [his]157-arthur sword and said : By All - hallows [I]0-i shall smite off [her]101-birdalone head if [she]101-birdalone but lay a finger on [thee]6401-thee .

So [they]6393-they played like [two happy children]6402-two happy children till [they]6393-they came to the door of [the house]325-the house , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone shoved it open , and [they]6393-they two looked in together and saw nought worse therein save the strange shadows that the moon cast from the settle on to the floor . Then [Birdalone]101-birdalone drew in [her]101-birdalone love , and went about lighting the candles and quickening a little cooking fire on the hearth , till the yellow light chased the moon away from the bed of [their]6393-they desire .

CHAPTER XXIX . THOSE TWAIN WILL SEEK THE WISDOM OF [THE WOOD - WIFE]570-the wood - wife

Again next day was [their]6393-they life such as it had been the day before ; and as [they]6393-they lay in cool shadow of a great oak , [Birdalone]101-birdalone fell to telling [Arthur]157-arthur all the whole story of [her]101-birdalone dealings with [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife , and how that [she]101-birdalone had so loved [her]101-birdalone and holpen [her]101-birdalone , that through [her]101-birdalone love and [her]101-birdalone help [she]101-birdalone had escaped [the witch]407-the witch and [her]407-the witch snares , who would have turned [her]101-birdalone into a half - devil for the undoing of [manfolk]6407-manfolk . And how that [the said wood - wife]6408-the said wood - wife had never appeared to [her]101-birdalone but as an image and double of [herself]101-birdalone , save on the time when [she]101-birdalone played the leech to [him]157-arthur . Then [she]101-birdalone told [him]157-arthur how all had gone when [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife had sought [him]157-arthur out for the fulfilment of [their]6410-they love , and of the dreadful day when [they]6410-they had come upon [him]157-arthur out of [his]157-arthur wit and but [little manlike]6411-little manlike .

Then [she]101-birdalone asked , would [he]157-arthur , within the next day or two , that [they]6410-they should go see [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife together and thank [her]101-birdalone for [her]101-birdalone help , and bring [him]157-arthur within the ring of [her]101-birdalone love and guarding ; and [he]157-arthur yeasaid it with a good will .

After this [she]101-birdalone would have [him]157-arthur tell [her]101-birdalone of how things had gone with [him]157-arthur since that evil day when [he]157-arthur had come [home]387-home from [the Castle of [the Quest]31-the quest]1931-the castle of the quest and found [her]101-birdalone gone . So [he]157-arthur told [her]101-birdalone somewhat , and of [his]157-arthur dole and misery , and [his]157-arthur dealings with [the foemen of [Greenford]45-greenford]6415-the foemen of greenford ; but yet scantly , and as [one compelled]6416-one compelled ; and at last [he]157-arthur said :

Dear love , since [thou]6417-thou art cossetting [me]0-i with all solace of caresses , [I]0-i pray [thee]101-birdalone remember [my]0-i trouble and grief , how sore they were , and do with [me]0-i as with [a sick man]6227-a sick man getting well , as [I]0-i wot surely [thou]6417-thou wouldest do ; and do [thou]6417-thou that which is at this present the softest and merriest to [me]0-i , and that forsooth is , that [thou]6417-thou shouldest talk and tell , and [I]0-i should hearken the sweetness of the music , and only here and there put in a word to rest [thee]101-birdalone and make [thy]6417-thou tale the sweeter .

[She]101-birdalone laughed with love on [him]157-arthur , and without more ado fell to telling everything [she]101-birdalone might think of , concerning [her]101-birdalone days in [the House of Captivity]1021-the house of captivity , both when [she]101-birdalone was but a bairn , and when [she]101-birdalone was grown to be [a young woman]6420-a young woman ; and long was [she]101-birdalone about the tale , nor was it all done in one day ; and a multitude of things [she]101-birdalone told [him]157-arthur which are not set down in this book .

In the evening when [they]6421-we were going again to and fro the meads , it was other talk [they]6421-we fell on , to wit , of [[their]6421-we fellows of [the Quest]31-the quest]6422-their fellows of the quest , both of [Sir Hugh]124-hugh and [the three lovely ladies]6423-the three lovely ladies : and now was [Arthur]157-arthur nought but kind when [he]157-arthur spake of [Atra]117-atra , nor spake [Birdalone]101-birdalone otherwise ; but [she]101-birdalone said : [I]0-i shall now say a hard word , yet must [thou]6424-thou bear it , [[my]0-i loveling]3686-my loveling , since [we]6421-we twain are now become one , and have but one joy together and one sorrow . Deemest [thou]6424-thou that [Atra]117-atra is yet alive ? Sooth it is , said [Arthur]157-arthur , it may well be that [I]0-i have slain [her]117-atra . And what may [we]6421-we do by [her]117-atra if ever [we]6421-we fall in with [her]117-atra alive ? said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . [I]0-i wot not , said [Arthur]157-arthur ; some would say that [we]6421-we have done penance for [our]6421-we fault , both [thou]6424-thou and [I]0-i ; and what other penance may [we]6421-we do , save sundering from [each other]580-each other ? And by [God]120-god above [I]0-i will not . By thine head and thine hands [I]0-i will not , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone .

So said [they]6427-they ; but therewith [their]6427-they eyes told tales of the fair eve and [the lovely meadows]6428-the lovely meadows , and [the house]325-the house , [the shrine of the dear white bed]6430-the shrine of the dear white bed no less sweet to [them]6427-they than erst ; but then presently [Birdalone]101-birdalone stayed [her]101-birdalone love , and took [her]101-birdalone arms about [him]157-arthur , and [each]1584-each felt the sweetness of the other 's body , and joy blossomed anew in [their]6427-they hearts . Then fell [Arthur]157-arthur to telling of the deeds and the kindness of [Baudoin]123-baudoin , whom never again [they]6427-they should see on [the earth]445-the earth ; and [they]6427-they turned back [home]387-home to [the house]325-the house , and on the way spake [Birdalone]101-birdalone : This is what [I]0-i would [we]6427-they should do : whereas [I]0-i have sought [thee]6435-thou and [thou]6435-thou [me]0-i , and [we]6427-they have found [each other]580-each other , whereas [ye]6435-thou sought [me]0-i when [I]0-i went astray in [the Black Valley of the Greywethers]87-the black valley of the greywethers , and before , when [ye]6435-thou three sought [your]6435-thou own loves , now [I]0-i would that [we]6427-they should seek [[our]6427-they fellows]2290-our fellows and have joy in [them]2290-our fellows , and thole sorrow with [them]2290-our fellows as in days gone by .

Spake [Arthur]157-arthur : Dear is the rest with [thee]6435-thou in [this wilderness]6438-this wilderness ; yet were it a deed of fame , and would bring about a day of joy , might [we]6427-they find [[our]6427-they friends]2302-our friends again , and knit up the links of the fellowship once more . But [thou]6435-thou the wise and valiant ! belike [thou]6435-thou hast in thine head some device whereby this might be set about .

[Birdalone]101-birdalone said : Simple is [my]0-i device , to wit , that [we]6427-they ask one who is wiser than [I.]0-i Let [us]6427-they tarry not , but go to - morrow and see [the wood- wife]5964-the wood- wife and talk with [her]5964-the wood- wife concerning it . Then [she]101-birdalone smiled upon [him]157-arthur and said : But when [thou]6435-thou seest [her]5964-the wood- wife , wilt [thou]6435-thou be aghast if [she]5964-the wood- wife come before [us]6427-they in [my]0-i shape of what [I]0-i was five years agone , or six ?

Nay , nay , [he]157-arthur said , [thou]6435-thou art not so terrible as that ; not very far do [I]0-i run from [thee]6435-thou now . And therewith [they]6427-they kissed and embraced , and so entered [the House of Love]6381-the house of love .

CHAPTER XXX . [THEY]6427-they HAVE SPEECH WITH [HABUNDIA]106-habundia CONCERNING [THE GREEN KNIGHT]1331-the green knight AND [[HIS]1331-the green knight FELLOWS]2437-his fellows

When the morrow was [they]6427-they arose and went [their]6427-they ways toward [the wood]348-the wood , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone in [[her]101-birdalone hunter]6445-her hunter 's coat , quiver at back and bow in hand . [They]6427-they came to [the Oak of Tryst]5879-the oak of tryst , and [Birdalone]101-birdalone was at point to call on [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife by the burning of a hair of [hers]101-birdalone , when [she]101-birdalone came lightly from out the thicket , clad as [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and [her]101-birdalone very image . [She]101-birdalone stood before [them]6427-they with a glad countenance , and said : Welcome to [the seekers and finders]6448-the seekers and finders . But [Arthur]157-arthur stepped forth and knelt before [her]101-birdalone , and took [her]101-birdalone right hand and kissed it , and said : Here [I]0-i swear allegiance to [thee]101-birdalone , [O Lady of [the Woods]88-the woods]6449-o lady of the woods , to do [thy]101-birdalone will in all things , and give [thee]101-birdalone thanks from [my]0-i heart more than [my]0-i tongue can say .

Quoth [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife : [I]0-i take thine allegiance , [fair young man]6451-fair young man , and [mine]0-i help shalt [thou]101-birdalone have henceforward . Then [she]101-birdalone smiled and [her]101-birdalone eyes danced for merriment , and [she]101-birdalone said : Yet [thy]101-birdalone thanks [meseemeth]6452-meseemeth for this while are more due to [the wise carline who brought [thee]101-birdalone through [the woods]463-the woods two days ago , and only left [thee]101-birdalone when the way was easy and clear to [thee]101-birdalone]6453-the wise carline who brought thee through the woods two days ago , and only left thee when the way was easy and clear to thee .

[Lady]504-lady , said [Arthur]157-arthur , [I]0-i know now how great is [thy]101-birdalone might , and that [thou]101-birdalone canst take more shapes than this only ; and humbly [I]0-i thank [thee]101-birdalone that for [us]6456-us [thou]101-birdalone hast taken the shape that [I]0-i love the best of all on [the earth]445-the earth .

Said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife : Stand up , [Black Squire]125-arthur , and consider a little what [thou]101-birdalone wouldst have [me]0-i do for [thee]101-birdalone , while [I]0-i have speech with [mine]0-i image yonder . And therewith [she]570-the wood - wife came up to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and drew [her]101-birdalone a little apart , and fell to stroking [her]101-birdalone cheeks and patting [her]101-birdalone hands and diversely caressing [her]101-birdalone , and [she]570-the wood - wife said to [her]101-birdalone : How now , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , have [I]0-i done for [thee]101-birdalone what [I]0-i promised , and art [thou]101-birdalone wholly happy now ? O yea , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; if nought else befell [us]6460-us in this life but to dwell together betwixt [the woodland]669-the woodland and [the water]361-the water , and to see [thee]101-birdalone oft , full happy should [we]6460-us be .

Nevertheless , said [Habundia]106-habundia , art [thou]101-birdalone not come hither to ask somewhat of [me]0-i , that [ye]101-birdalone may be happier ? So it is , [wise mother]6463-wise mother , said [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; grudge not against [me]0-i therefor , for more than one thing drives [me]0-i thereto . [I]0-i will not grudge , said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife ; but now [I]0-i will ask [[thy]0-i mate]7187-thy mate if [he]7187-thy mate has thought what it is that [he]7187-thy mate will have of [me]0-i . And [she]570-the wood - wife turned to [Arthur]125-arthur , who came forth and said : [Lady]504-lady , [I]0-i have heard [thee]570-the wood - wife , and herein would [we]6467-us have [thee]570-the wood - wife help [us]6467-us : There were erst [six fellows of [us]6467-us]6468-six fellows of us , [three caries and three queans , to whom was added this sweetling here]6469-three caries and three queans , to whom was added this sweetling here ; but one of [them]6468-six fellows of us , to wit [the Golden Knight]1329-the golden knight , was slain , and for the rest . . . [Yea]6471-ye , [I]0-i know , said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife ; [[my]0-i child]915-my child here hath told [me]0-i all ; and now [ye]6471-ye wot not where [they]6468-six fellows of us are or if [they]6468-six fellows of us be yet alive , all or any of [them]6468-six fellows of us . Now is it not so that [ye]6471-ye would seek [these friends]6474-these friends , if it were but to greet [them]6474-these friends but once , and that [ye]6471-ye would ask of [the wise wood - wife]6475-the wise wood - wife help to find [them]6474-these friends ? Is there any more of the tale ? Nay , [lady]504-lady , said [Arthur]125-arthur .

Said [she]570-the wood - wife : Well then , that help shall [ye]6471-ye have , were it but for the sake of that little Viridis whereof [[my]0-i child]915-my child hath told [me]0-i . Wherefore abide tidings of [me]0-i for a fourteen days , and seek not to [me]0-i ere then ; and [meantime]6478-meantime fear not , nor doubt [me]0-i , for many messengers [I]0-i have , and ever may [I]0-i do somewhat if the end of the tale is to be told in [these woodlands]6479-these woodlands : and [I]0-i deem [these friends]6474-these friends will not be hard to draw hither , for it is most like that [they]6474-these friends be thinking of [you]6471-ye and longing for [you]6471-ye , as [ye]6471-ye for [them]6474-these friends . And now [I]0-i will depart on [my]0-i business , which is [yours]6471-ye , and do [ye]6471-ye be happy to - day in [the woodland]669-the woodland , and to - morrow in [the meadows]2079-the meadows and by [the water]361-the water ; and let no trouble weigh down [your]6471-ye happy days .

Therewith [she]0-i flitted away from [them]6474-these friends , when [she]0-i had kissed [them]6474-these friends both . But when [she]0-i was gone [they]6474-these friends fared away together deep into [the wood]348-the wood , and were exceeding merry disporting [them]6474-these friends , and on [their]6474-these friends return [they]6474-these friends gat [them]6474-these friends venison for [their]6474-these friends meat , and so came back to [the House of Love]6381-the house of love when the moon was up and shining brightly .

CHAPTER XXXI . HABUNDIA COMETH WITH TIDINGS OF [THOSE DEAR FRIENDS]6486-those dear friends

Wore the days thenceforth merrily ; and one day it was delight in [the wide meads]6487-the wide meads , and another [they]6474-these friends went a long way west along [the water- side]6488-the water- side , and so into [another meadow - plain]6489-another meadow - plain , smaller than [[their]6474-these friends home- plain]6490-their home- plain , which [Birdalone]101-birdalone had never erst come into ; and three eyots lay off [it]6491-it , green and tree - beset , whereto [they]6474-these friends swam out together . Then [they]6474-these friends went into [the wood]348-the wood thereby in the heat of the afternoon , and so wore the day , that [they]6474-these friends deemed [themselves]6474-these friends belated , and lay there under a thorn - bush the night through .

Another day [Birdalone]101-birdalone took [[her]101-birdalone mate]6493-her mate over on to [Green Eyot]8-green eyot and [Rock Eyot]9-rock eyot , and showed [him]6493-her mate [all the places [she]101-birdalone was used to haunt]6494-all the places she was used to haunt . And [they]6474-these friends had [their]6474-these friends fishing - gear with [them]6474-these friends , and angled off [the eyots]6495-the eyots a good part of the day , and had good catch , and swam back therewith merrily . And [Birdalone]101-birdalone laughed , and said that it seemed to [her]101-birdalone as if once again [she]101-birdalone were ransoming [her]101-birdalone skin of [the witch - wife]349-the witch - wife by that noble catch .

Divers times also [they]6474-these friends fared into [the wood]348-the wood , and thrice [they]6474-these friends lay out the night there in [some woodlawn where was water]6498-some woodlawn where was water ; and on one of these times it happed that [Arthur]125-arthur awoke in the grey dawn , and lay open - eyed but not moving for a little ; and therewith [he]125-arthur deemed [he]125-arthur saw the gleam of war - gear in the thicket . So [he]125-arthur kept as still as [he]125-arthur might , but gat [his]125-arthur sword out of its sheath without noise , and then leapt up suddenly , and sprang thitherward whereas [he]125-arthur had seen that token , and again saw armour gleam and heard [some man crashing through the underwood]6499-some man crashing through the underwood , for all was gone in one moment . So [he]125-arthur woke up [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and [they]6474-these friends bended [their]6474-these friends bows both of [them]6474-these friends , and searched the thicket thereabouts heedfully , arrow on string , but found nought fiercer than a great sow and [her]6500-her farrow . So came the full day , and [they]6474-these friends gat [them]6474-these friends back to [[their]6474-these friends meadows]6501-their meadows and [[their]6474-these friends house]2007-their house ; but thereafter were [they]6474-these friends warier in going about [the woodland]669-the woodland .

In all joyance then wore the days till the fifteenth , and in the morning early [they]6474-these friends went [their]6474-these friends ways to [the Oak of [Tryst]13-tryst]12-the oak of tryst , and had no need to call [Habundia]106-habundia to [them]6474-these friends , for presently [she]101-birdalone came forth out of the thicket , with [her]101-birdalone gown gathered up into [her]101-birdalone girdle and bow in hand . But [she]101-birdalone cast it down and ran up to [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and kissed [her]101-birdalone and clipped [her]101-birdalone , and then [she]101-birdalone took a hand of [Arthur]125-arthur and a hand of [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and held [them]6504-them both and said : [[My]0-i child]915-my child , and [[thou]6506-thou [dear knight]6508-dear knight]6507-thou dear knight , have [ye]6508-dear knight still a longing to fall in with [those friends of yours]6509-those friends of yours , and to run all risk of whatsoever contention and strife there may be betwixt [you]6508-dear knight thereafter ? [Yea]6510-yea , certes , said [Arthur]125-arthur ; and even so said [Birdalone]101-birdalone . Well is that then , said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife ; but now and for this time , ere [I]0-i help [you]6508-dear knight , [I]0-i shall put a price upon [my]0-i help , and this is the price , that [ye]6508-dear knight swear to [me]0-i never wholly to sunder from [me]0-i ; that once in the year at least , as long as [ye]6508-dear knight be alive and wayworthy , [ye]6508-dear knight come into [the Forest of Evilshaw]89-the forest of evilshaw , and summon [me]0-i by the burning of a hair of [mine]0-i , that [we]6512-we may meet and be merry for a while , and part with the hope of meeting once more at least . And if [ye]6508-dear knight will not pay the price , go in peace , and [ye]6508-dear knight shall yet have [my]0-i help in all other matters that may seem good unto [you]6508-dear knight , but not in this of joining [your]6508-dear knight fellowship together . How sayest [thou]6513-your , [Birdalone]101-birdalone , [[my]0-i child]915-my child ? How sayest [thou]6513-your , [Black Squire]125-arthur , whom , as [meseemeth]6515-meseemeth , [I]0-i have delivered from a fate worse than death , and have brought out of wretchedness into bliss ?

[Spake Birdalone]101-birdalone : Had [I]0-i dared , [I]0-i would have bidden [thee]6513-your to swear to [me]0-i even such an oath , to wit , that [thou]6513-your wouldst never wholly sunder [thee]6513-your from [me]0-i . How then may [I]0-i not swear this that [thou]6513-your biddest [me]0-i , and that with all joy and trustiness ?

[Spake Arthur]207-spake arthur : [Lady]504-lady , had [I]0-i no will to swear oath for [thy]6513-your sake , yet with a good will would [I]0-i swear it for [my]0-i true - love 's sake who loveth [thee]6513-your . Yet verily of [mine]0-i own will would [I]0-i swear it joyfully , were it for nought else save to pleasure [thee]6513-your , who hast done so kindly by [me]0-i , and hath given [me]0-i back [my]0-i manhood and [my]0-i love , which else [I]0-i had miserably lost .

Spake [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife : It is well again . Join hands then , and swear as [I]0-i have bidden [you]6513-your by the love [ye]6513-your bear each other .

Even so [they]6513-your did , and then [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife kissed [them]6513-your both and said : Now do [I]0-i deem [you]6513-your [earth 's very children]6519-earth 's very children and [mine]0-i , and this desire of [yours]6513-your is good , and it shall be done if [I]0-i may bring it about ; yet therein the valiance and wisdom of [you]6513-your both may well be tried . For this have [I]0-i found out by [[my]0-i messengers]6520-my messengers and [others]2441-others , that [[your]6513-your friends]6522-your friends are alive , [all of [them]6522-your friends]3481-all of them ; and [they]6522-your friends have thought of [you]6513-your in [their]6522-your friends inmost hearts , and have long determined that [they]6522-your friends must needs go seek [you]6513-your if [they]6522-your friends are to live lives happy and worthy . Furthermore , [their]6522-your friends quest hath drawn [them]6522-your friends hither to Evilshaw nor say [I]0-i that [I]0-i have been nothing therein , and [they]6522-your friends are even now in [the wood]348-the wood . But [ye]6513-your shall know that peril encompasses [them]6522-your friends ; for [they]6522-your friends fare but a few , and of those few be there [two traitors who are minded to deliver [them]6522-your friends to [the men of [the Red Company]6527-the red company]6526-the men of the red company , unto whom three women as fair as [[your]6513-your she- friends]6528-your she- friends]6525-two traitors who are minded to deliver them to the men of the red company , unto whom three women as fair as your she- friends were a prize indeed . Wherefore [the Red Folk]6529-the red folk are dogging [them]6522-your friends , and will fall upon [them]6522-your friends when [they]6522-your friends find the occasion . But [I]0-i shall see to it that the occasion shall be in time and place where [they]6522-your friends shall not be unholpen . Now what [ye]6513-your have to do for [your]6513-your parts , is to waylay [the waylayers]6530-the waylayers , and keep watch and ward anigh the road [they]6522-your friends must needs take , and to fall on when need is . But this again [I]0-i shall see to , that [your]6513-your onset fail not .

But now [ye]6513-your may say : Since [thou]6531-thou art mighty , why shouldst not [thou]6531-thou [thyself]6532-thyself take [[our]6533-they friends]2302-our friends out of the hands of these accursed , as [thou]6531-thou couldst well do , and [we]6533-they to take no part therein ? [[My]0-i friends]2100-my friends , this might indeed well be ; but [thou]6531-thou , [Birdalone]101-birdalone , hast told [me]0-i the whole tale , and how that there be wrongs to be forgiven which can not be made right , and past kindness to be quickened again , and coldness to be kindled into love , and estrangement into familiar friendship ; and meseems that the sight of [your]6513-your bodies and [your]6513-your hands made manifest to the eyes of [them]6522-your friends may do somewhat herein . Yet if otherwise [ye]6513-your think , then so let it be , and go [ye]6513-your back to [the House under [the Wood]6-the wood]2453-the house under the wood , and in three days ' time [I]570-the wood - wife will bring [you]6513-your [[your]6513-your friends]6522-your friends all safe and sound .[570-the wood - wife]

Now [they]6533-they both said that [they]6533-they would not for aught that [they]6533-they should have no hand in the deliverance of [them]6533-they ; so [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife said : Come with [me]0-i , and [I]0-i shall lead [you]6513-your to [the place of [your]6513-your ambush]6538-the place of your ambush .

Then all [they]6533-they went on together , and fared a long way west , and toward the place where erst [they]6533-they two had found [Arthur]207-spake arthur ; and at last , two hours before sunset , [they]6533-they came to where was a glade or way between the thickets , which was as it were a little beaten by the goings of [man - folk]6539-man - folk . And [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife did [them]6533-they to wit , that [the evil folk aforesaid]6541-the evil folk aforesaid had so used it and beaten it , that it might just look as if [folk]1529-folk were wo nt to pass that way , whereas it was not very far from [[their]1529-folk chiefest haunt]6543-their chiefest haunt and stronghold . A little on the north side of this half - blind way , and some ten yards through the thicket , the ground fell away into [a little dale]6544-a little dale , the bottom whereof was plain and well grassed , and watered by [a brook]6545-a brook .

[Thither]142-thither [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife brought the twain ; and when [they]6533-they all stood together on [the brook - side]6547-the brook - side , [she]570-the wood - wife said to [them]6533-they : [Dear friends]1325-dear friends , this is [[your]1325-dear friends woodland house]6549-your woodland house for this time , and [I]0-i rede [you]1325-dear friends go not forth of [it]6549-your woodland house , lest [ye]1325-dear friends happen upon [any of [those evil men]6551-those evil men]6550-any of those evil men ; for nought have [ye]1325-dear friends to fear from any save [them]6551-those evil men . Here amidst these big stones , which make , see [ye]1325-dear friends , as [it]6552-it were [a cavern]6553-a cavern , have [I]0-i stowed victual for [you]1325-dear friends ; and armour therewithal , because , though both of [you]1325-dear friends are in a manner armed , yet who knoweth where a shaft drawn at a venture may reach .

And from the said stones [she]570-the wood - wife drew forth two very fair armours , helm and hauberk , and leg and arm wards ; and they were all of green , and shone but little , but were fashioned as [no smith of man - folk]6554-no smith of man - folk could have done the like .

This is thine , [Sir Arthur]157-arthur , said [the wood - wife]570-the wood - wife , and [thou]6556-thou wilt wear it like as it were silk ; and this thine , [[my]0-i child]915-my child , and [thou]6556-thou art strong enough to bear such light gear . And [I]0-i charge [you]1325-dear friends both to do on this gear presently , nor do it off till [ye]1325-dear friends have achieved the adventure . And now this is the last word : here is a horn of oliphant which [thou]6556-thou shalt wear about [thy]6556-thou neck , [Birdalone]101-birdalone ; and if [thou]6556-thou be sore bestead , or [thy]6556-thou heart faileth [thee]6556-thou , blow in it , yet not before the onfall ; and then , whether [thou]6556-thou blow much or little , [thou]6556-thou shalt be well holpen .

Now be not downcast if nought befall to - night or to - morrow , or even the day after ; but if the third day be tidingless , then at sunset burn a hair of [my]0-i head , [Birdalone]101-birdalone , and [I]0-i will come to [you]1325-dear friends . And now farewell ! for [I]0-i have yet to do in this matter .

With that [she]0-i kissed [Birdalone]101-birdalone fondly and embraced [Arthur]157-arthur , and went [her]0-i way ; and those twain abode in [the dale]2735-the dale , and slept and watched by turns , and all was tidingless till the morrow 's dawn ; neither was there aught to tell of on that day and the night that ended it .

CHAPTER XXXII . OF THE FIGHT IN [THE FOREST]90-the forest AND THE RESCUE OF [THOSE FRIENDS]6559-those friends FROM [THE MEN OF THE RED COMPANY
